scope=\"row\"| \"My Way\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Houghton |first1=Cillea |title=Lathan Warlick and Tyler Hubbard have it 'My Way' in new song |url=http://abcnewsradioonline.com/music-news/2021/3/15/lathan-warlick-and-tyler-hubbard-have-it-my-way-in-new-song.html |access-date=June 24, 2022 |work=ABC News Radio |date=March 15, 2021}}</ref><br />{{small|(with Lathan Warlick)}}\n| ''My Way''\n|-\n|rowspan=\"3\"| 2022\n!scope=\"row\"| \"[[Death Row (Thomas Rhett song)|Death Row]]\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Vaughn |first1=Grace Lenehan |title=Thomas Rhett, Tyler Hubbard + Russell Dickerson Recall 'Life-Changing' Experience in 'Death Row' |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/thomas-rhett-tyler-hubbard-russell-dickerson-death-row/ |access-date=June 24, 2022 |work=Taste of Country |date=March 5, 2022}}</ref><br />{{small|([[Thomas Rhett]] featuring Tyler Hubbard and [[Russell Dickerson]])}}\n| ''[[Where We Started]]''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"35's\"<ref>{{cite news |title=Tyler Hubbard Has Another Song for Fans to Hear this Friday |url=https://drgnews.com/2022/06/22/tyler-hubbard-has-another-song-for-fans-to-hear-this-friday/ |access-date=June 24, 2022 |work=DRG News |date=June 22, 2022}}</ref>\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Tyler Hubbard''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Way Home\"<ref>{{cite news |title= Tyler Hubbard Finds His 'Way Home' in Faith-Inspired New Song [Listen]|first=Jeremy|last=Chua|url= https://tasteofcountry.com/tyler-hubbard-way-home/|access-date=July 16, 2022 |work=Taste of Country |date=July 15, 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n| 2024\n!scope=\"row\"| \"Wish You Would\"<ref>{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2024/02/tyler-hubbard-slates-sophomore-project-strong-for-april/ | title=Tyler Hubbard Slates Sophomore Project 'Strong' for April | date=16 February 2024 }}</ref><ref>https://video.goodmorningamerica.com/culture/video/tyler-hubbard-performs-gma-109233243 {{Bare URL inline|date=August 2024}}</ref>\n| ''Strong''\n|}\n\n===Other charted songs===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Song\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:3em; font-size:90%\"| [[Hot Christian Songs|US<br />Christ.]]<br /><ref name=\"hotchristian\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/tyler-hubbard/chart-history/ico/|title=Tyler Hubbard Chart History - Hot Christian Songs|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=June 24, 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n| 2021\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Good to Be Loved by You\"<br />{{small|(with [[Chris Tomlin]])}}\n| 34\n| ''Chris Tomlin & Friends: Summer''\n|}\n\n===Guest appearances===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+ List of non-single guest appearances, with other performing artists, showing year released and album name\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Title\n! scope=\"col\"| Year\n! scope=\"col\"| Other artist(s)\n! scope=\"col\"| Album\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Rubber Meets the Road\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hollabaugh |first1=Lorie |title=Tim McGraw, Miranda Lambert, Jason Isbell, More On New 'Ice Road' Soundtrack |url=https://musicrow.com/2021/05/tim-mcgraw-miranda-lambert-jason-isbell-more-on-new-ice-road-soundtrack/ |access-date=June 24, 2022 |work=Music Row |date=May 19, 2021}}</ref>\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2021\n| [[Brantley Gilbert]]\n| ''[[The Ice Road#Music|The Ice Road]]''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Good to Be Loved By You\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hollabaugh |first1=Lorie |title=Chris Tomlin Teams Up With Tyler Hubbard, Jimmie Allen, Russell Dickerson On Summer EP  |url=https://musicrow.com/2021/06/chris-tomlin-teams-up-with-tyler-hubbard-jimmie-allen-russell-dickerson-on-summer-ep/ |access-date=June 24, 2022 |work=Music Row |date=June 25, 2021}}</ref>\n| [[Chris Tomlin]]\n| ''Chris Tomlin & Friends: Summer''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Country Boy Do\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Burton |first1=Jamie |title=Nelly's 'Heartland': Every Country Music Artist Collab on the New Album |url=https://www.newsweek.com/nelly-heartland-album-country-music-collabs-1622357 |access-date=June 24, 2022 |work=Newsweek |date=August 24, 2021}}</ref>\n| [[Nelly]]\n| ''[[Heartland (Nelly album)|Heartland]]''\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{Commons category-inline}}\n\n{{Tyler Hubbard|state=autocollapse}}\n{{Florida Georgia Line}}\n{{Authority control}}\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Hubbard, Tyler}}\n[[Category:1987 births]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Georgia (U.S. state)]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Florida Georgia Line members]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Georgia (U.S. state)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Trisha_Yearwood","to":"Trisha Yearwood"}],"pages":{"1004059":{"pageid":1004059,"ns":0,"title":"Trisha Yearwood","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country singer (born 1964)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2023}} \n{{Good article}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name =  Trisha Yearwood\n| image = Trisha Yearwood Gershwin 2024.jpg\n| caption = Yearwood in 2024\n| birth_name = Patricia Lynn Yearwood\n| birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|9|19}}\n| birth_place = [[Monticello, Georgia]], U.S.<!--As per WP:LINKDIRECT and Template:infobox person, birth/death place indicates city, state, then country. No need to spell out \"United States; 'U.S.' is fine.-->\n| alma_mater =  [[Young Harris College]]<br>[[Belmont University]]\n| occupation = {{flatlist|\n* Singer\n* actress\n* television personality\n* author\n}}\n| years_active = 1985\u2013present\n| spouse = {{plainlist|\n* {{marriage|Christopher Latham<br />|1987|1991|reason=divorced}}\n* {{marriage|Robert Reynolds<br />|1994|1999|reason=divorced}}\n* {{marriage|[[Garth Brooks]]<br />|2005}}\n}}\n| awards = [[List of awards and nominations received by Trisha Yearwood|List of awards and nominations]]\n| module = {{Infobox musical artist\n| embed = yes\n| background = solo_singer\n| instruments = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals, guitar, keyboards\n<!-- only instruments commonly used -->\n}}\n| genre = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[country pop]]\n* [[adult contemporary]]\n}}\n| label = {{flatlist|\n* [[MCA Records|MCA Nashville]]\n* [[Big Machine Records|Big Machine]]\n* [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]]\n* Gwendolyn\n}}\n| website = {{URL|trishayearwood.com}}\n}}}}\n'''Patricia Lynn Yearwood''' (born September 19, 1964)<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.biography.com/people/trisha-yearwood-9542124 | title = Trisha Yearwood Biography | publisher= [[The Biography Channel]] / [[A+E Networks]] | access-date= December 12, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140105052442/https://www.biography.com/people/trisha-yearwood-9542124|archive-date=January 5, 2014}}</ref> is an American country singer. She rose to fame with her 1991 debut single \"[[She's in Love with the Boy]]\", which became a number one hit on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs|country singles]] chart. Its corresponding [[Trisha Yearwood (album)|self-titled debut album]] would sell over two million copies. Yearwood continued with a series of major country hits during the early to mid-1990s, including \"[[Walkaway Joe]]\" (1992), \"[[The Song Remembers When (song)|The Song Remembers When]]\" (1993), \"[[XXX's and OOO's (An American Girl)]]\" (1994), and \"[[Believe Me Baby (I Lied)]]\" (1996).\n\nYearwood's 1997 single \"[[How Do I Live]]\" reached number two on the U.S. country singles chart and was internationally successful. It appeared on her first compilation ''[[(Songbook) A Collection of Hits]]'' (1997). The album certified quadruple-platinum in the United States and featured the hits \"[[In Another's Eyes]]\" and \"[[Perfect Love]]\". Yearwood had a string of commercial successes over the next several years including the hit singles \"[[There Goes My Baby (Trisha Yearwood song)|There Goes My Baby]]\" and \"[[I Would've Loved You Anyway]]\". She released her tenth studio record ''[[Jasper County (album)|Jasper County]]'' in 2005, which debuted at number one on the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart and the top ten of the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. It would become her fastest-selling album in the United States. Yearwood signed with [[Big Machine Records]] in 2007 and released the critically acclaimed ''[[Heaven, Heartache and the Power of Love]]'' the same year.\n\nYearwood spent several years on hiatus from her own musical career to focus on other projects. She published three successful cookbooks, which appeared on [[The New York Times Best Seller list]]. In 2012, she began a culinary television series on the [[Food Network]] called ''[[Trisha's Southern Kitchen]]'', which  later won a [[Daytime Emmy Award]]. Yearwood has sold over 15 million records worldwide.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2014/08/19/trisha-yearwood-announces-first-album-years/14311195/ |title=Trisha Yearwood announces first album in 7 years |publisher=[[The Tennessean]] |author=Cindy Watts |date=August 19, 2014}}</ref> Her work has earned her several awards and nominations, including three [[Grammy Award]]s, three awards from the [[Academy of Country Music]], and three awards from the [[Country Music Association]]. Yearwood has also been a cast member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] since 1999. Since 2005 she has been married to country singer [[Garth Brooks]], with whom she has collaborated on a number of occasions.\n\n==Early life==\nYearwood was born in [[Monticello, Georgia]], the daughter of schoolteacher Gwendolyn Yearwood and local banker Jack Howard Yearwood.<ref name=\"Women in Country Music\">{{cite book |last1=Oermann |first1=Robert K. |last2=Bufwack |first2=Mary F. |title=Finding Her Voice: Women in Country Music |url=https://archive.org/details/findinghervoicew0000bufw |url-access=registration |date=2003 |publisher=Vanderbilt University Press |isbn=0-8265-1432-4 |pages= [https://archive.org/details/findinghervoicew0000bufw/page/470 470\u201371] |ref=Women in Country Music}}</ref> Trisha Yearwood's ancestors came to [[North America]] from [[England]] during the colonial era.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.progenealogists.com/individual/trisha-yearwood|title=Trisha Yearwood - AncestryProGenealogists|website=Progenealogists.com|access-date=July 27, 2020}}</ref> From an early age, she was passionate about music and participated in various music events held by her school and community. This included talent shows, church events, and musicals. After graduating high school, Yearwood studied for two years at [[Young Harris College]], receiving an [[associate degree]] in business. She then attended the [[University of Georgia]] for one semester before dropping out.<ref name=\"Encyclopedia\">{{cite web |last1=Speace |first1=Geri |title=Trisha Yearwood: Encyclopedia.com |url=https://www.encyclopedia.com/people/literature-and-arts/music-popular-and-jazz-biographies/trisha-yearwood |website=[[Encyclopedia.com]] |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> Yearwood then moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1985, enrolling in [[Belmont University|Belmont College]] and pursued a music business degree.<ref name=\"Women in Country Music\"/>\n\nYearwood gained an internship with [[MTM Records]] and was eventually hired as a full-time employee. With the help of the record label's resources, she recorded a series of demo tapes and also sang [[background vocals]] for new artists.<ref name=\"biography\">{{cite web |url= http://www.biography.com/articles/Trisha-Yearwood-9542124 |title= Trisha Yearwood Biography - Biography.com |work= [[Biography Channel]] |access-date= June 26, 2009 |url-status= dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20091126073945/http://www.biography.com/articles/Trisha-Yearwood-9542124 |archive-date= November 26, 2009 |df= mdy-all }}</ref> One of the artists she recorded with was [[Garth Brooks]]. Developing a friendship, Brooks promised to help Yearwood sign a recording contract if his career succeeded. Brooks brought her to his producer, [[Allen Reynolds]], who then brought her to the attention of producer [[Garth Fundis]]. Fundis and Yearwood began collaborating and eventually crafted a demo recording tape. In 1990, she sang background vocals on Brooks' second album, ''[[No Fences]]'', and performed live at a label showcase. [[MCA Records]] producer [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]] heard her performance and was impressed. Brown helped her sign a recording contract with the label.<ref name=\"allmusicbio\">{{cite web|url= {{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1884|pure_url=yes}} |title=Trisha Yearwood > Biography |last=Huey|first=Steve |publisher=[[allmusic]] |access-date=June 25, 2009}}</ref> After signing with the label, she served as the opening act on Brooks' 1991 nationwide tour.<ref name=\"roughguide\">{{cite book |last=Wolff|first=Kurt |title=''Country Music: The Rough Guide'' |editor=Orla Duane |publisher=Rough Guides Ltd. |location=London, England |chapter=Ch. 13: Hunks, Hat Acts, and Young Country Darlings: Nashville in the 1990s}}</ref>\n\n==Music career==\n===1991: Breakthrough===\nYearwood's [[Trisha Yearwood (album)|self-titled debut album]] was released in 1991. Its lead single \"[[She's in Love with the Boy]]\" peaked at number 1 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart, bringing her major success.<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> Three other singles from the album reached the top ten on the country chart \u2014 \"[[Like We Never Had a Broken Heart]]\", \"[[The Woman Before Me]]\", and \"[[That's What I Like About You]]\". Her debut album eventually sold one million copies and was certified double-platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) for shipments of two million copies. Yearwood also became the first female country artist to sell a million copies of her debut album.<ref name=allmusic>Steve Huey [{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1884|pure_url=yes}} ''Trisha Yearwood biography''] ''Allmusic''; retrieved 4-14-08</ref> [[AllMusic]] reviewed the album and called the effort \"a very classy debut that stands the test of time,\" giving it four and a half out of five stars.<ref>{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r123539|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Trisha Yearwood'' album review |last=Jurek|first=Thom |publisher=allmusic |access-date=June 26, 2009}}</ref> Additionally, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', said that Yearwood's voice \"demonstrates technical and emotional authority at every turn.\"<ref>{{cite magazine |url= https://ew.com/article/1991/08/02/trisha-yearwood/ |title=''Trisha Yearwood'' (1991) music review |last=Nash|first=Alanna |magazine= [[Entertainment Weekly]] |access-date=June 26, 2009 |date=August 2, 1991}}</ref> Yearwood's success garnered her a series of major music awards. In 1991, she was named Top New Female Vocalist by the [[Academy of Country Music]] and was voted Favorite New Country Artist by the [[American Music Awards]] in 1992.<ref name=\"biography\"/>\n\nWith success, Yearwood began engaging in more opportunities. Parting ways with her previous management firm, she began working under the supervision of Ken Kragen, who oversaw [[Kenny Rogers]] and [[Travis Tritt]].<ref name=\"Encyclopedia\"/> She also became the spokesperson for the WildHeart fragrance by [[Revlon]]. In a 2010 interview with ''[[Good Housekeeping]]'', Yearwood explained that while filming the fragrance's commercial, she was asked to embrace with a male model. She declined to do so and would not continue production until her manager arrived to support her decision. The commercial was eventually filmed and shown on major television networks.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Yearwood |first1=Trisha |title=Trisha Yearwood's Life-Changing Moments: How Trisha Yearwood learned to stand her ground and raise a family, and the women who inspired her |url=https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/life/inspirational-stories/interviews/a18821/trisha-yearwood-life-changing-moments/ |website=[[Good Housekeeping]] |date=April 8, 2010 |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref>\n\n===1992\u20131996: Career diversification===\nIn 1992, Yearwood released her second studio album, ''[[Hearts in Armor]]''.<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> With her second album, Yearwood chose songs that came from emotional conflicts following the divorce from first husband, Chris Latham. The album was a departure from her previous material, containing ballads and collaborations with [[Don Henley]], [[Emmylou Harris]], and [[Raul Malo]]. Music critics praised the album. Allmusic called the album \"stunning\" and \"one of the best heartbreak records country music delivered in the '80s and '90s.\"<ref>{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r123573|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Hearts in Armor'' album review |last=Jurek|first=Thom |publisher=allmusic |access-date=June 26, 2009}}</ref> [[About.com]] gave it five stars and called ''Hearts in Armor'' \"possibly Trisha's best album ever.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://countrymusic.about.com/od/cdreviewsmz/gr/heartsinarmor.htm |title=Trisha Yearwood \u2013 ''Hearts in Armor'' |last=Huenke |first=Trisha |work=[[about.com]] |access-date=June 26, 2009 |archive-date=June 16, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616155222/http://countrymusic.about.com/od/cdreviewsmz/gr/heartsinarmor.htm |url-status=dead }}</ref> The album's first two singles reached the top ten of the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart in 1992 \u2014 \"[[Wrong Side of Memphis]]\" and \"[[Walkaway Joe]]\", the latter featuring Henley on backing vocals.<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> The remaining singles (\"[[You Say You Will]]\" and \"[[Down on My Knees]]\") peaked within the top twenty of the country songs chart. ''Hearts in Armor'' would later certify platinum in sales from the RIAA.<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/>\n\n{{quote box\n |quote  = I've had to say to myself, well, if I passed [[Emmylou Harris]] on the street, would I be able to hold my head up? \n |source =&nbsp;\u2014 Yearwood on her musical direction in the 1990s<ref name=\"roughguide\"/>\n |width  = 25%\n |align  = left\n}}\nYearwood released her third album in 1993 entitled ''[[The Song Remembers When]]''. The [[The Song Remembers When (song)|title track]] reached number two on the ''Billboard'' country chart that year.<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> The record was recorded in a similar musical style to ''Hearts in Armor'', differing with more contemporary arrangements. The album also included collaborations with other artists such as [[Rodney Crowell]] and [[Willie Nelson]].<ref>{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r187907|pure_url=yes}} |title=''The Song Remembers When'' album review |last=Jurek|first=Thom |publisher=allmusic |access-date=June 26, 2009}}</ref> The album was later accompanied by a [[cable television]] special in 1993, where the title track's music video derived from.<ref name=\"biography\"/> Yearwood followed the studio album with her first [[Holiday album|Holiday compilation]] in 1994 titled ''[[The Sweetest Gift (Trisha Yearwood album)|The Sweetest Gift]]''. It included cover versions of holiday standards, such as \"[[Away in a Manger]]\", \"[[Let It Snow! Let It Snow! Let It Snow!]]\", and \"[[The Christmas Song]]\".<ref>{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r204280|pure_url=yes}} |title=''The Sweetest Gift'' album review |last=Torreano|first=Bradley |publisher=allmusic |access-date=June 26, 2009}}</ref>\n\nIn February 1995, Yearwood released her fourth studio album, ''[[Thinkin' About You]]'', which geared more towards [[adult contemporary]] styles.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> The album was given a positive review by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' which compared ''Thinkin' About You'' to many of [[Linda Ronstadt]]'s albums in the 1970s. The disc included a version of [[Melissa Etheridge]]'s \"[[You Can Sleep While I Drive]]\" and [[Tammy Wynette]]'s \"[['Til I Get It Right]]\".<ref>{{cite magazine |url= https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/127091/review/6068261/thinkinaboutyou |archive-url= https://archive.today/20120910223258/http://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/127091/review/6068261/thinkinaboutyou |url-status= dead |archive-date= September 10, 2012 |title=''Thinkin' About You'': Trisha Yearwood: Review |last=Galvin|first=Peter |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=June 26, 2009}}</ref> ''Thinkin' About You'''s first two singles reached number 1 on the ''Billboard'' country chart: \"[[XXX's and OOO's (An American Girl)]]\" and the [[Thinkin' About You (Trisha Yearwood song)|title track]]. Its third single, \"[[I Wanna Go Too Far]]\" reached the top ten after its release at the end of 1995.<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> Like its predecessors, ''Thinkin' About You'' eventually sold one million copies in the United States and was certified platinum from the RIAA.<ref name=\"about\">{{cite web |url= http://countrymusic.about.com/od/trishayearwood/p/blprtrisha.htm |title= Trisha Yearwood Profile |last= Fabian |first= Shelly |publisher= about.com |access-date= June 26, 2009 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110801031458/http://countrymusic.about.com/od/trishayearwood/p/blprtrisha.htm |archive-date= August 1, 2011 |url-status= dead }}</ref> At the [[37th Annual Grammy Awards|1995 Grammy Awards]], Yearwood's duet with [[Aaron Neville]] titled \"[[I Fall to Pieces]]\" (a cover of the 1961 song by [[Patsy Cline]]) won in the category of [[Best Country Collaboration with Vocals]]. The award became Yearwood's first accolade from the Grammys.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.who2.com/trishayearwood.html |title=Trisha Yearwood Biography |publisher=Who 2.com |access-date=June 26, 2009}}</ref>\n\nIn August 1996, she released her fifth studio album, ''[[Everybody Knows (Trisha Yearwood album)|Everybody Knows]]'', which had similarities to her previous album. The record mostly contained ballads and the songs featured larger melodies. ''Everybody Knows'' received mixed reviews by critics. AllMusic gave the album three out of five stars, calling the songs \"a little uneven\".<ref>{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r239309|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Everybody Knows'' album review |last=Owens|first=Thom |publisher=allmusic |access-date=June 26, 2009}}</ref> However, ''Entertainment Weekly'' praised the album, calling the title track an \"emotional release of a pounding piano\".<ref>{{cite magazine |url= https://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,309275,00.html |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20081010212952/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,309275,00.html |url-status= dead |archive-date= October 10, 2008 |title=''Everybody Knows'' review |last=Nash|first=Alanna |magazine= Entertainment Weekly |access-date=June 26, 2009 |date=January 24, 1992}}</ref> ''Everybody Knows'' spawned the \"[[Believe Me Baby (I Lied)]]\", which became Yearwood's fourth number-one single on the ''Billboard'' country chart. The [[Everybody Knows (Trisha Yearwood song)|title track]] was released as the second single and peaked within the top five in 1996.<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> During this period, Yearwood performed at the [[1996 Summer Olympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony of the 1996 Summer Olympics]], which were held in [[Atlanta, Georgia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/music/news/article_1177284.php |title=Country singer Trisha Yearwood to perform at Atlanta Olympic Celebration |publisher=Monsters and Critics.com |access-date=June 26, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012040401/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/music/news/article_1177284.php |archive-date=October 12, 2012  }}</ref>\n\n===1997\u20132001: Crossover success===\nYearwood released her first greatest hits compilation in August 1997, ''[[(Songbook) A Collection of Hits]]''. The album comprised her major hits up to that point. ''Songbook'' was praised by most music critics, including AllMusic who called it \"a near-definitive collection\".<ref>{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r312415|pure_url=yes}} |title=''(Songbook) A Collection of Hits'' review |last=Owens|first=Thom |publisher=allmusic |access-date=June 26, 2009}}</ref> The compilation became her first album to peak at number 1 on the ''[[Billboard Magazine|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart. It also reached the Top 10 of the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], peaking at number 4. ''Songbook'' included three new tracks that were eventually released as singles. \"[[How Do I Live]]\" was the first single issued and was included in the 1997 film ''[[Con Air]]''. The song was also nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Original Song|Best Song]] at the [[Academy Awards]].<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> \"How Do I Live\" was originally recorded by [[LeAnn Rimes]] for the film. Rimes's version became a major hit on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], peaking at number two, while Yearwood's version peaked at number two on the ''Billboard'' country chart. The song also reached number 23 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref name=\"nashville\">{{cite book |last=Kosser|first=Michael |title=How Nashville Became Music City, U.S.A. |publisher=Hal Leonard Corp. |location=Milwaukee, WI, USA |page=316 |chapter=Ch. 26 \u2014 The King of Independents}}</ref> The album's remaining singles also became major hits on the ''Billboard'' Country Chart. \"[[In Another's Eyes]]\" (a duet with [[Garth Brooks]]) peaked at number 2 on the country chart and the third single, \"[[Perfect Love]]\" reached number one in early 1998. Additionally, Yearwood won a series of accolades. This included accolades from the Grammy Awards, the [[Country Music Association Awards]], and the [[Academy of Country Music]].<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> ''Songbook'' would become Yearwood's highest selling album, selling four million copies in the United States, eventually being certified 4\u00d7 Multi-Platinum from the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]].<ref name=\"about\"/>\n[[File:Trisha Yearwood 2002.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Yearwood at an event in [[Washington, D.C.]], 2002.]]\n\nYearwood issued first studio album two years later, ''[[Where Your Road Leads]]'' (1998). It was her first album produced by [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]], with her five previous albums being produced by [[Garth Fundis]]. The singles, \"[[There Goes My Baby (Trisha Yearwood song)|There Goes My Baby]]\", \"[[Powerful Thing]]\", and \"[[I'll Still Love You More]]\" became top ten hits on the ''Billboard'' country chart. The [[Where Your Road Leads (song)|title track]], was another collaboration with Garth Brooks and became a top twenty hit single.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> The album gained mostly positive reviews. About.com reviewed the album and gave it four stars, calling it \"one of her best albums\".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://countrymusic.about.com/library/reviews/aaprtywyrl.htm |title= ''Where Your Road Leads'' \u2013 Trisha Yearwood |publisher= about.com |access-date= June 27, 2009 |archive-date= August 6, 2011 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110806072811/http://countrymusic.about.com/library/reviews/aaprtywyrl.htm |url-status= dead }}</ref> It was also reviewed by Allmusic, which also gave the release four out of five stars.<ref>{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r366599|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Where Your Road Leads'' album review |last=Pendragon|first=John |publisher=allmusic |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> During this time, Yearwood engaged in additional ventures. In the summer of 1998, she performed with singer [[Luciano Pavarotti]] to benefit [[Liberia]]n children. In 1999, she was inducted as a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] by [[Porter Wagoner]], performing a cover [[Patsy Cline]]'s \"[[Sweet Dreams (Don Gibson song)|Sweet Dreams (Of You)]]\" the night of her induction. She is still a member to date.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opry.com/MeetTheOpry/Members.aspx?id=115 |title=Grand Ole Opry Members: Trisha Yearwood |publisher=opry.com |access-date=June 27, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090512173017/http://www.opry.com/MeetTheOpry/Members.aspx?id=115 |archive-date=May 12, 2009 }}</ref>\n\nFollowing a second divorce, Yearwood released her seventh studio album in March 2000 titled ''[[Real Live Woman]]''. In similarity to ''Hearts in Armor'', the record reflected emotional conflicts following the separation.<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> The album contained twelve tracks and included covers of [[Bruce Springsteen]]'s \"Sad Eyes\" and [[Linda Ronstadt]]'s \"Try Me Again\". It was given critical acclaim from AllMusic, quoting ''Real Live Woman'' as a \"measured, deliberate record in the best possible sense.\"<ref>{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r467282|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Real Live Woman'' album review |last=Thomas Erlewine|first=Stephen |publisher=allmusic |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> The album sold 500,000 copies in the United States and spawned two singles:<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> the [[Real Live Woman (song)|title track]] and \"Where Are You Now\".\n\nIn 2001, Yearwood released her eighth studio record ''[[Inside Out (Trisha Yearwood album)|Inside Out]]''. It was produced by [[Mark Wright (record producer)|Mark Wright]].<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/><ref name=\"biography\"/> The album included a collaboration from Don Henley on the [[Inside Out (Bryan Adams song)|title track]], as well as [[Rosanne Cash]] and [[Vince Gill]]. AllMusic called the release \"bound to inspire fans and fellow artists alike\", calling Yearwood's voice \"timeless\".<ref>{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r534419|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Inside Out'' album review |last=Konicki Dinoia|first=Maria |publisher=allmusic |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> ''Rolling Stone'' gave the album four out of five stars calling, \"Love Alone\" and \"Melancholy Blue\" the best songs on the record.<ref>{{cite magazine |url= https://www.rollingstone.com/artists/trishayearwood/albums/album/310960/review/5944060/inside_out |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080411043544/http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/trishayearwood/albums/album/310960/review/5944060/inside_out |url-status= dead |archive-date= April 11, 2008 |title=Trisha Yearwood: ''Inside Out'': Review |last=Hunter|first=James |magazine= Rolling Stone |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> The album spawned the single \"[[I Would've Loved You Anyway]]\", which reached number 4 on the ''Billboard'' country chart.<ref name=\"biography\"/>\n\n===2002\u20132016: ''Jasper County'', record label switch and new career directions===\nFollowing her 2001 album, Yearwood spent time with family and eventually established a romantic relationship with [[Garth Brooks]]. In September 2005, she released her first album of new recordings in four years, ''[[Jasper County (album)|Jasper County]]''. The album reunited her with Fundis on production duties, and took its name from [[Jasper County, Georgia]], the [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] county in which she was raised. The album consisted of mostly upbeat [[Soul music|Soul]]-styled songs, including \"Sweet Love\", and \"Who Invented the Wheel\". It received positive reviews by critics, including AllMusic writer [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]], who called it \"an album that stretches further musically than most of her albums while being more cohesive than most of her records as well.\"<ref>{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r797879|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Jasper Country'' album review |last=Thomas Erlewine|first=Stephen |publisher=allmusic |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> It received five stars from [[About.com]], praising the songs \"Georgia Rain\", \"Who Invented the Wheel\", and \"Standing Out in a Crowd\".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://countrymusic.about.com/od/cdreviewsmz/gr/bljaspercounty.htm |title= ''Jasper County'' \u2013 review |last= Downs |first= Jolene |publisher= about.com |access-date= June 27, 2009 |archive-date= September 9, 2011 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110909100953/http://countrymusic.about.com/od/cdreviewsmz/gr/bljaspercounty.htm |url-status= dead }}</ref> The album became her third to reach number one on the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart. It also peaked at number 4 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], selling 117,000 copies within its first week. Its first week sales eclipsed those of [[Paul McCartney]]'s ''[[Chaos and Creation in the Backyard]]'', which was released within the same week.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1510280/trisha-yearwoods-jasper-county-tops-country-albums-chart.jhtml |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110623195133/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1510280/trisha-yearwoods-jasper-county-tops-country-albums-chart.jhtml |url-status= dead |archive-date= June 23, 2011 |title=Trisha Yearwood's ''Jasper County'' Tops Country Albums Chart |last=Gilbert|first=Calvin |work= Country Music Television |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> The first single, \"[[Georgia Rain]]\", peaked at number 15 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart, becoming her first major hit since 2002.<ref name=\"cmt\">{{cite web |url= http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/yearwood_trisha/bio.jhtml |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20031224171611/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/yearwood_trisha/bio.jhtml |url-status= dead |archive-date= December 24, 2003 |title=CMT: Trisha Yearwood biography |work= [[Country Music Television]] |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> The second single, \"Trying to Love You\" was released to radio October 31, reaching number 52. Within a month of the album's release, ''Jasper County'' certified gold from the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]], becoming Yearwood's eleventh Gold certification of her career.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://emol.org/emclub/?q=triciayearwood |title=MCA'S Trisha Yearwood Celebrates Eleventh Gold Certification With ''Jasper County'' |work= Entertainment Magazine |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref>\n[[File:Trisha Yearwood 2007.jpg|thumb|left|Yearwood performing on [[Country Music Television]], 2007]]\n\nIn May 2007, Yearwood announced her departure from MCA Nashville Records and her signing with the independent label [[Big Machine Records]]. Yearwood and the label's CEO, [[Scott Borchetta]] met when she originally worked for MTM Records in the late 1980s. She then worked with Borchetta at MCA during the 1990s.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.bizjournals.com/nashville/stories/2007/05/28/focus2.html |title=Big Machine, giant signature: Yearwood deal with an Idie label a sign of the times |last=Yeldell|first=Cynthia |publisher=Biz Journals.com |access-date=June 27, 2009 |date=May 27, 2007}}</ref> Following her separation, MCA released a ''[[Greatest Hits (Trisha Yearwood album)|Greatest Hits]]'' compilation, which included her major hits between 1991 and 2001.<ref>{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r1185971|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Greatest Hits'' album review |last=Jurek|first=Thom |publisher=allmusic |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref>\n\nAfter signing with the label, Yearwood announced plans for the recording of her tenth studio album.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1559313/20070510/yearwood_trisha.jhtml |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070514051324/http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1559313/20070510/yearwood_trisha.jhtml |url-status= dead |archive-date= May 14, 2007 |title=Trisha Yearwood Signs With Big Machine Records |last=Morris|first=Edward |work= Country Music Television |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> In November 2007, she released ''[[Heaven, Heartache, and the Power of Love]]''. The album peaked at number ten on the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart and reached number thirty on the ''Billboard'' 200.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1574933/garth-brooks-carrie-underwood-top-charts.jhtml |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20081226181202/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1574933/garth-brooks-carrie-underwood-top-charts.jhtml |url-status= dead |archive-date= December 26, 2008 |title=Garth Brooks, Carrie Underwood Top Charts |last=Morris|first=Edward |date=November 24, 2007 |work= Country Music Television |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> The album received critical acclaim. AllMusic gave the project four and a half out of five stars, calling it their \"album pick\". Reviewer, Thom Jurek stated, \"It's better than good, it's beyond expectation \u2013 and it was high after ''Jasper County'' \u2013 it's the best example of what a popular record \u2013 not just a country one \u2013 should aspire to be, period.\"<ref>{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=album|id=r1265198|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Heaven, Heartache, and the Power of Love'' review |last=Jurek|first=Thom |publisher=allmusic |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> [[Slant Magazine]] also reviewed the record, giving it four and a half stars, calling it \"a testament to the vitality, intelligence, and soulfulness of modern country's best music.\"<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.slantmagazine.com/music/music_review.asp?ID=1231 |title=''Heaven, Heartcahe, and the Power of Love'', music review |last=Keefe|first=Jonathan |work= [[Slant Magazine]] |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> The [[Heaven, Heartache, and the Power of Love (song)|title track]] was released as the first single in July 2007,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1564565/trisha-yearwoods-new-single-due-on-monday.jhtml |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100117201030/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1564565/trisha-yearwoods-new-single-due-on-monday.jhtml |url-status= dead |archive-date= January 17, 2010 |title=Trisha Yearwood's New Single Due on Monday|date=July 11, 2007 |work= Country Music Television |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> peaking at number 19 on the Hot Country Songs chart.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1565750/taylor-swift-rides-debut-album-to-the-top.jhtml |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080307115107/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1565750/taylor-swift-rides-debut-album-to-the-top.jhtml |url-status= dead |archive-date= March 7, 2008 |title=Taylor Swift Rides Debut Album to the Top |last=Morris|first=Edward |date=July 28, 2007 |work= Country Music Television |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> The second single, \"[[This Is Me You're Talking To]]\" was released in January 2008. The song received critical acclaim, notably from Engine 145, who called it \"one of the best singles of the year\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.engine145.com/trisha-yearwood-this-is-me-youre-talking-to/ |title=Trisha Yearwood \u2013 \"This is Me You're Talking To\" |first=Matt |last=Clark |work=Engine 145 |access-date=June 27, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218093633/http://www.engine145.com/trisha-yearwood-this-is-me-youre-talking-to/ |archive-date=December 18, 2014  }}</ref>\n\nAfter beginning a successful [[Food Network]] cooking show and several cookbooks, Yearwood went into hiatus from her solo music career.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hermanson |first1=Wendy |title=New Music from Trisha Yearwood: The Wait Is (Almost) Over |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/new-music-trisha-yearwood/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |date=April 27, 2018 |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> Although she did not focus on solo projects, she remained active in the music industry. From 2009 to 2014, Yearwood accompanied husband Garth Brooks in his concert residency called [[Garth at Wynn]]. The residence was located at the [[Encore Las Vegas#Encore Theatre|Encore Theatre]] in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]]. Yearwood performed songs as a guest artist in the show.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Katsilometes |first1=John |title=Garth Brooks' deal at Encore: One-man show, five years, all tickets $125 |url=https://lasvegassun.com/blogs/kats-report/2009/oct/15/garth-brooks-deal-encore-five-years/ |website=[[Las Vegas Sun]] |date=October 15, 2009 |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> The Las Vegas production ran for three years, closing in 2014.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Katsilometes |first1=John |title=After three years, Garth Brooks closing at Wynn Las Vegas on Nov. 17 |url=https://lasvegassun.com/blogs/kats-report/2012/oct/03/after-three-years-garth-brooks-closing-wynn-las-ve/ |website=[[Las Vegas Sun]] |date=October 3, 2012 |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> In 2014, Yearwood joined Brooks on his three-year world tour entitled [[The Garth Brooks World Tour (2014\u201317)|The Garth Brooks World Tour]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Vinson |first1=Christina |title=Garth Brooks Announces 2014 World Tour |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/garth-brooks-2014-tour/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |date=December 9, 2013 |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> During this same time, she briefly embarked on her own brief tour called \"Just Because\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Watts |first1=Cindy |title=Trisha Yearwood kicks off 'Just Because' tour |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/life/music/2014/02/21/trisha-yearwood-kicks-off-just-because-tour/5702003/ |website=[[The Tennessean]] |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> In August 2014, Yearwood briefly signed with [[RCA Records Nashville]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/trisha-yearwood-new-music-prizefighter-album/|title=Trisha Yearwood Reveals New Music, 'PrizeFighter' Album|date=August 19, 2014}}</ref> Her only album for the label was the 2014 studio album ''[[PrizeFighter: Hit After Hit]]''. It contained 16 of her major hits re-recorded for the album and several new songs. The [[PrizeFighter (song)|title track]] was released as the lead single and featured guest vocals from [[Kelly Clarkson]].<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Trisha Yearwood Reveals New Music On The Way|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/trisha-yearwood-greatest-hits-album-prizefighter-20140923|access-date=September 23, 2014|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=September 23, 2014}}</ref> The album debuted at number 7 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums|country albums]] chart and the lead single peaked at number 42 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs|country songs]] chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Jessen |first1=Wade |title=Trisha Yearwood's 'Prizefighter' Punches Way Onto Top Country Albums Chart |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6327843/trisha-yearwood-prizefighter-country-albums-chart |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref>\n\nIn 2016, Yearwood appeared in the live television musical ''[[The Passion (U.S. TV special)|The Passion]]''.<ref name=\"usatoday-review\">{{cite news|title=Review: More 'Passion' than sense|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/columnist/2016/03/20/review-more-passion-than-sense/82059978/|date=March 20, 2016|access-date=March 21, 2016|work=USA Today}}</ref><ref name=\"deadline-ratings\">{{cite web|title='The Passion' Ratings & Tyler Perry Down Sharply From 'Grease Live' For Fox|url=https://deadline.com/2016/03/the-passion-ratings-tyler-perry-fox-trisha-yearwood-seal-daughtry-grease-live-fox-1201723502/|website=Deadline|date=March 21, 2016|access-date=March 21, 2016}}</ref> As a result, she was also featured on the event's soundtrack, performing new versions of several well-known songs including; \"[[Hands (Jewel song)|Hands]]\", \"[[My Love Is Your Love]]\", \"[[You'll Never Walk Alone]]\" and \"[[Broken (Lifehouse song)|Broken]]\". \"Broken\" became Yearwood's first hit on the [[Christian songs|Christian charts]], peaking at number 47 and also reaching number 17 on the [[Adult Contemporary (chart)|Adult Contemporary charts]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7008785/trisha-yearwood-christian-chart-appearance-passion|title=Trisha Yearwood Makes First Christian Chart Appearance With Lifehouse Cover From 'The Passion'|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }}</ref> In late 2016 she joined Garth Brooks on their first collaborative studio album titled ''[[Christmas Together (Garth Brooks and Trisha Yearwood album)|Christmas Together]]''. The album featured covers of classic holiday songs and an original track written by the pair called \"What I'm Thankful for (The Thanksgiving Song)\".<ref>{{cite web|title=Garth Brooks and Trisha Yearwood Record Duet Album Over Holiday Break|url=http://wincountry.com/news/articles/2016/jan/20/garth-brooks-and-trisha-yearwood-record-duet-album-over-holiday-break/|website=Wincountry.com|access-date=January 26, 2016|archive-date=January 25, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160125054203/http://wincountry.com/news/articles/2016/jan/20/garth-brooks-and-trisha-yearwood-record-duet-album-over-holiday-break/|url-status=dead}}</ref> Following this, Yearwood was selected as one of 30 artists to perform on the song \"[[Forever Country]]\". The song was created to celebrate 50 years of the [[CMA Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/scenes-cmas-historic-music-video-featuring-30-country/story?id=42129062|title=30 Country Music Stars Join Forces for Historic CMA Music Video|date=September 22, 2016|work=ABC News}}</ref>\n\n===2018\u2013present: Return to music===\n[[File:Trisha Yearwood (49627464492).jpg|thumb|right|200px|Yearwood at the [[Library of Congress]], March 2020.]]\nIn late 2018 Yearwood announced the release of a new album consisting of songs previously recorded by [[Frank Sinatra]]. Titled ''[[Let's Be Frank]]'', it was recorded live at the [[Capitol Records]] building and was backed by a full piece orchestra. Yearwood used Sinatra's original microphone during the recording process. It was released in December 2018, exclusively at [[Williams Sonoma (brand)|Williams Sonoma]] stores, and worldwide on February 14, 2019.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Tracy |first1=Brianne |title=Trisha Yearwood Announces New Album of Frank Sinatra Covers \u2014 Her First in More Than 10 Years |url=https://people.com/country/trisha-yearwood-new-album-frank-sinatra-covers/ |website=[[People Magazine]] |access-date=November 22, 2018}}</ref> The album peaked at number 2 on the ''Billboard'' [[Jazz Albums]] chart.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nashville Notes |url=http://abcnewsradioonline.com/music-news/2019/3/1/nashville-notes.html |website=[[ABC News (United States)|ABC News]] |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> In his review, Kevin John Coyne of ''Country Universe'' praised the release, giving it four of five possible stars. In discussing the album, Coyne commented, \"Let's Be Frank is a delightful detour, and while it doesn't curb the hunger for more country music from the greatest female artist of the greatest generation of female artists, it is chock full of reminders of how she earned that distinction in the first place.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Coyne |first1=Kevin John |title=Album Review: Trisha Yearwood, Let's Be Frank |url=http://www.countryuniverse.net/2018/12/27/album-review-trisha-yearwood-lets-be-frank/ |website=Country Universe |date=December 27, 2018 |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> Trisha Yearwood performed the Sinatra covers on March 7, 2020, with the Baton Rouge Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Timothy Muffitt. Yearwood was invited to perform with the BRSO as the 2020 selection of the \"Pennington Great Performers\" series.\n\nIn 2019, Yearwood announced plans for her twelfth studio album, ''[[Every Girl (album)|Every Girl]]''. Its lead single \"[[Every Girl in This Town]]\" was issued in June 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://people.com/country/trisha-yearwood-new-single-every-girl-in-this-town/|title=Trisha Yearwood Announces Empowering New Single 'Every Girl in This Town' Off Upcoming Album|work=People|date=May 13, 2019}}</ref> The song debuted at number 21 on the ''Billboard'' [[Country Airplay]] chart, marking the highest chart debut of her career.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8515466/trisha-yearwood-sheryl-crow-stevie-nicks-maren-morris-country-airplay|title=Trisha Yearwood, Sheryl Crow, Stevie Nicks, Maren Morris Bound Onto Country Airplay Chart|author=Jim Asker|date=June 11, 2019|publisher=Billboard|access-date=June 11, 2019}}</ref> ''Every Girl'' was released in August 2019. It featured collaborations with Garth Brooks, [[Kelly Clarkson]], and [[Don Henley]].<ref name=\"Every Girl\">{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/trisha-yearwood-every-girl-track-listing-kelly-clarkson-song/|title=Trisha Yearwood's 'Every Girl' Album Will Feature Kelly Clarkson + More|website=Taste of Country|last=Whitaker|first=Stephen|date=June 28, 2019|access-date=June 28, 2019}}</ref> The album peaked at number 5 on the ''Billboard'' Country Albums chart <ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Every Girl'' chart history -- Trisha Yearwood |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/trisha-yearwood/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=January 12, 2020}}</ref> and number 57 on the ''Billboard 200''.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Every Girl'' Chart History (Billboard 200) -- Trisha Yearwood |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/trisha-yearwood/chart-history/tlp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=January 12, 2020}}</ref> ''Every Girl'' received critical praise upon its release. [[Allmusic]]'s Thom Jurek gave the album 4 of 5 stars, calling it \"more commanding and more emotionally resonant than in years past.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Jurek |first1=Thom |title=''Every Girl'' -- Trisha Yearwood -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/every-girl-mw0003293332 |website=[[Allmusic]] |access-date=January 12, 2020}}</ref> ''Roughstock'''s Matt Bjorke commented, \"Trisha Yearwood has chosen fourteen diverse songs which showcase her pristine voice, an instrument as strong today as it has ever been, if not more powerful.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bjorke |first1=Matt |title=Album review: Trisha Yearwood - ''Every Girl'' |url=http://roughstock.com/news/2019/08/43933-album-review-trisha-yearwood-every-girl |website=Roughstock |date=August 30, 2019 |access-date=January 12, 2020}}</ref> Yearwood embarked on her first solo tour in 6 years to support the album, which launched in October 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theboot.com/trisha-yearwood-every-girl-on-tour-2019/|title=Trisha Yearwood Announces Fall 2019 Every Girl on Tour|author=Angel Stefano|date=June 14, 2019|publisher=The Boot|access-date=June 14, 2019}}</ref> To celebrate the 30th anniversary of her career, Yearwood released a deluxe edition of ''Every Girl'' in August 2021. This contained an acoustic version of her debut single \"[[She's in Love with the Boy]]\", along with new songs \"[[I Dare You (Kelly Clarkson song)|I Dare You to Love]]\" and \"[[Shallow (Lady Gaga and Bradley Cooper song)|Shallow]]\", a duet with [[Garth Brooks]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gauk-Roger |first1=Troy |title=Trisha Yearwood Celebrates 30 Years in the Industry with Every Girl Deluxe Album: 'I've Been Lucky' |url=https://people.com/country/trisha-yearwood-celebrates-30-years-music-industry-every-girl-deluxe-album-exclusive/ |website=[[People (magazine)|People]] |access-date=June 28, 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Other career ventures==\n===Cooking===\nIn April 2008, Yearwood released her first cookbook co-written with her mother Gwen and sister Beth ''Georgia Cooking in an Oklahoma Kitchen''. The cookbook included other recipes passed down from her family and liner notes describing each recipe. In total, 120 recipes were included. The book contained recipes for such foods as fried chicken, ribs, meatloaf, and cheesecake. [[Garth Brooks]] wrote the book's foreword, stating how he was always fond of her cooking style.<ref name=\"Georgia Cooking\">{{cite web |url= http://www.theboot.com/2008/03/12/trisha-yearwood-to-release-cookbook/ |title=Trisha Yearwood to release cookbook |date=March 12, 2008 |publisher=The Boot.com |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> ''Georgia Cooking'' reached number 1 on the [[New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' Best Seller list]].<ref name=\"Southern Kitchen\">{{cite web |last1=Evans-Price |first1=Deborah |title='Trisha's Southern Kitchen' is Cookin' for the Food Network |url=https://theboot.com/trishas-southern-kitchen-food-network-trisha-yearwood/ |website=The Boot |date=March 8, 2012 |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> Yearwood then stated plans to publish a second cookbook.<ref name=\"tv\">{{cite web |url= http://musiccitytv.com/2009/05/05/trisha-yearwood-leads-habitat-effort-toolbelt-is-cute/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090510004421/http://musiccitytv.com/2009/05/05/trisha-yearwood-leads-habitat-effort-toolbelt-is-cute/ |archive-date=May 10, 2009 |title=Trisha Yearwood leads Habitat effort: \"A toolbelt is cute\" |author=Brad |publisher= Music City TV.com |access-date=May 10, 2009}}</ref>\n\nOn April 6, 2010, she collaborated again with her mother and sister to release ''Home Cooking with Trisha Yearwood''. The book contained recipes passed down through her mother, aunts, cousins and longtime friends. Yearwood stated that she dedicated many of the cookbook's recipes to relatives, such as Brooks, who also provided the foreword.<ref name=\"Home Cooking\">{{cite web |url= http://thatnashvillesound.blogspot.com/2010/03/tns-cookbook-week-home-cooking-with.html |title=TNS Cookbook Week: ''Home Cooking with Trisha Yearwood: Stories and Recipes to Share with Family and Friends'' |date=March 24, 2010 |work= That Nashville Sound |access-date=April 9, 2010}}</ref> ''Home Cooking'' would also reach number 1 on the ''New York Times'' Best Seller list.<ref name=\"Southern Kitchen\"/> Yearwood's cookbook was the cover article for the April 2010 issue of ''[[Redbook Magazine]]'', where she explained that many of the recipes featured in the cookbook were \"some of the best memories of her childhood\".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20352627,00.html |title=Trisha Yearwood Shares Garth's Secret Recipe (Just Add Bacon!) |last=Orloff|first=Brian |date=March 18, 2010 |work= [[People (magazine)|People]] |access-date=April 9, 2010}}</ref> Later that year, the [[Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine]] included ''Home Cooking with Trisha Yearwood'' on their list of \"The Five Worst Cookbooks of 2010\", noting its recipes are \"loaded with [[fat]] and [[cholesterol]]\", specifically citing one called \"Garth's Breakfast Bowl\" which \"includes eight large eggs, a pound each of bacon and sausage, cheese tortellini, cheddar cheese, tater tots, and B.O.B (Bowl Of Butter).\"<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.pcrm.org/health/reports/five_worst_cookbooks_2010.html |title= The Five Worst Cookbooks of 2010 |publisher= [[Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine]] |date= December 2010 |work= Press release |access-date= December 28, 2010 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20101224081511/http://www.pcrm.org/health/reports/five_worst_cookbooks_2010.html |archive-date= December 24, 2010 |url-status= dead }}</ref> In 2015, Yearwood released her third cooking writing endeavor called ''Trisha's Table''. Garth Brooks wrote the book's foreword and it was another writing collaboration with her sister.<ref name=\"Trisha's Table\">{{cite web |last1=Thompson |first1=Gayle |title=Trisha Yearwood Announces Release Date of Third Cookbook |url=https://theboot.com/trisha-yearwood-trishas-table-cookbook/ |website=The Boot |date=January 29, 2015 |access-date=May 22, 2020}}</ref>\n[[File:Trisha Yearwood 2010.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Yearwood at the Los Angeles Times Festival cooking, 2010.]]\n\nIn 2012, Yearwood announced plans to film a cooking show. ''[[Trisha's Southern Kitchen]]'' premiered on the [[Food Network]] on April 14, 2012. The original six episodes were filmed in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name=\"Southern Kitchen\"/> The show received a positive response from viewers. According to Food Network's senior vice president, viewers enjoyed seeing \"different sides\" of Yearwood: \"Our viewers loved seeing a different side of Trisha. Her impressive cooking skills and family recipes, coupled with her natural southern charm, really resonated with our audience...We're thrilled Trisha will be returning for a second season with more delicious dishes and family traditions.\"<ref>{{cite web |title=Food Network Picks up Second Season of Hit Daytime Series 'Trisha's Southern Kitchen' |url=https://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/network-press-releases/food-network-picks-up-second-season-of-hit-daytime-series-trishas-southern-kitchen/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190630170038/https://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/network-press-releases/food-network-picks-up-second-season-of-hit-daytime-series-trishas-southern-kitchen/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=June 30, 2019 |website=Tv By the Numbers |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> In 2013, ''Trisha's Southern Kitchen'' won an [[Emmy Awards|Emmy award]] for \"Outstanding Culinary Program\". The show has since been nominated for additional Emmy accolades.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Casey |first1=Jim |title=Trisha Yearwood Cooks Up a Daytime Emmy Nomination |url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2017/03/23/trisha-yearwood-cooks-up-a-daytime-emmy-nomination/ |website=Nash Country Daily |date=March 23, 2017 |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> In a 2017 interview, Yearwood stated that she would like to continue hosting the program for \"as long as she can.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wolgamott |first1=L. Kent |title=Talking cooking on TV with Trisha Yearwood |url=https://journalstar.com/entertainment/tv-radio/talking-cooking-on-tv-with-trisha-yearwood/article_ead270e3-1470-5629-aa0b-0abe07649ca1.html |website=[[Lincoln Journal Star|Journal Star]] |date=November 21, 2017 |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref>\n\n===Film and television===\nIn 1997, Yearwood began playing a recurring role on the [[CBS]] military drama ''[[JAG (TV series)|JAG]]'', where she played Lieutenant Commander [[JAG characters#Lieutenant Commander Teresa Coulter, M.D. USNR (MC)|Teresa Coulter]], a Navy [[coroner]] and forensic specialist, who develops feelings for one of the main characters. She appeared on the show at various times until 2002.<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> In the 1999 film ''[[Stuart Little (film)|Stuart Little]]'', Yearwood performed the song \"[[You're Where I Belong]]\", written by [[Diane Warren]] and produced by [[Keith Thomas (record producer)|Keith Thomas]]. In addition, Yearwood also guest-starred in the television series ''[[Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman]]'' in 1994 as a choir director. Yearwood has also stated she is interested in performing in a [[Broadway theater|Broadway]] musical, but not \"anytime soon\".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://entertainment.oneindia.in/music/international/2009/yearwood-debut-broadway-060309.html |title=Trisha Yearwood keen to debut in Broadway |work= Entertainment |date=March 6, 2009 |access-date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> She appeared in an episode of [[TLC (TV channel)|TLC]]'s ''[[Who Do You Think You Are? (U.S. TV series)|Who Do You Think You Are?]]'' on September 3, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tlc.com/tv-shows/who-do-you-think-you-are/videos/trisha-yearwood.htm |title=Who Do You Think You Are |publisher=TLC |access-date=May 23, 2014}}</ref>\n\nIn March 2016, Yearwood appeared as [[Mary, mother of Jesus|Mary]] in the live television musical  ''[[The Passion (U.S.)|The Passion]]'' based on the [[The Passion television franchise|Dutch franchise of the same name]]. The show is a contemporary [[Passion Play|retelling]] of the [[Passion (Christianity)|Passion]] of [[Jesus Christ]] [[Jukebox musical|set]] to [[popular music]] with a mixture of live and pre-recorded segments. The event was broadcast live on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]. The show received mixed reviews. In one interview by Robert Bianco of ''[[USA Today]]'', \"Yearwood's Mary may have been singing about Jesus, but she never interacted with him. While he was mostly seen in segments shot around the city, she sang to the crowd gathered in front of that big white stage, belting out You'll Never Walk Alone to no one in particular.\" A review by ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' called Yearwood's performance of the songs she performed \"expressive\", but lacking the live elements as it was filmed through pre-recorded scenes.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Jensen |first1=Jeff |title=The Passion: EW review |url=https://ew.com/article/2016/03/20/the-passion-live-fox-ew-review/ |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref><ref name=\"usatoday-review\"/><ref name=\"deadline-ratings\"/> In 2019, Yearwood hosted the tenth annual ''CMA Country Christmas''. The special was taped in September 2019 and featured performances by various artists including [[Tori Kelly]], [[CeCe Winans]] and [[Brett Young (singer)|Brett Young]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Reuter |first1=Annie |title=See Who's Performing On the 10th Annual 'CMA Country Christmas' Special |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8529054/trisha-yearwood-cma-country-christmas |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=January 12, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Artistry==\n[[File:Trisha Yearwood USO 2010 Pic2.jpg|thumb|left|Yearwood performing in 2010]]\nYearwood possesses an alto vocal range.<ref>{{Cite web|date=November 9, 2007|title=Trisha Yearwood's 'Heaven' is worth celebrating|url=https://www.ocregister.com/2007/11/09/trisha-yearwoods-heaven-is-worth-celebrating/|access-date=September 1, 2021|website=[[Orange County Register]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Mead|first=David|date=December 11, 2007|title=Trisha Yearwood: Heaven, Heartache & The Power of Love|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/music/trisha-yearwood/heaven-heartache-the-power-of-love/|access-date=September 1, 2021|website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]}}</ref> Yearwood has stated she particularly enjoys singing harmonies, expounding, \"Because I could read music, I was always the one in the school chorus who got the alto part because I could read. I'm never singing the melody and always singing the harmony in church.\"<ref>{{Cite news|last=Yarborough|first=Chuck|date=October 21, 2019|title=Trisha Yearwood continues to make her own way with 'Every Girl' album, Cleveland tour stop|work=[[The Plain Dealer]]|url=https://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/2019/10/trisha-yearwood-continues-to-make-her-own-way-with-every-girl-album-cleveland-tour-stop.html|access-date=September 1, 2021}}</ref> Her musical tastes originated from classic artists her parents listened to. This included [[Elvis Presley]], [[Patsy Cline]], [[Loretta Lynn]], and [[Tammy Wynette]].<ref name=\"WSJ\">{{cite news |title=Trisha Yearwood on the Songs That Filled Her Georgia Home The country singer and cookbook author enjoyed a small-town life while listening to Patsy Cline and Linda Ronstadt |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/trisha-yearwood-on-the-songs-that-filled-her-georgia-home-1493736267 |newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=May 2, 2017 |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> However, as Yearwood developed into her teenage years, she developed a liking for [[country rock]] artists such as [[Allman Brothers]] and [[James Taylor]].<ref name=\"roughguide\"/> She also cited the [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]] and [[Gordon Lightfoot]] as influences.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hilburn |first1=Robert |title=New Sweetheart of the Rodeo : Trisha Yearwood once worried she was 'too normal' for the music business. Now she's positioned to be the next big star of a maverick country generation |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1992-10-25-ca-1093-story.html |website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=October 25, 1992 |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref>\n\nAccording to Yearwood, her primary musical influence is [[Linda Ronstadt]].<ref name=\"roughguide\"/> She discovered her music after her parents bought her Ronstadt's studio album ''[[Simple Dreams]]''. Yearwood commented to the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' that while Ronstadt's music was considered [[pop music|pop]], her phrasing and emotional style appeared [[country music|country]].<ref name=\"WSJ\"/> Music critics and writers have drawn similarities between Ronstadt and Yearwood's voice. In an interview for Ronstadt's album ''[[Feels Like Home (Linda Ronstadt album)|Feels Like Home]]'', Peter Galvin of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' commented, \"Listening to Yearwood's new album, Thinkin' About You, you would sometimes swear you were hearing Ronstadt circa 1976. Yearwood's voice is thinner and more pliable than Ronstadt's, but both resort to a hearty squawk when passion takes them over, and both possess low honey tones.\"<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Galvin |first1=Peter |title=''Feels Like Home'' -- Rolling Stone |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-album-reviews/feels-like-home-2-252107/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=April 6, 1995 |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> She also reported to be influenced by [[Emmylou Harris]].<ref name=\"roughguide\"/>\n\nYearwood's musical style has been considered \"[[country pop]]\"<ref name=\"roughguide\"/> and \"[[adult contemporary]]\".<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> Additionally, her artistic choices have been considered unique from writers because of song choice and quality. When ranking her \"top 10\" songs, staff from ''The Boot'' magazine explained her musical quality, \"Yearwood has carved out a very successful and unique niche for herself by finding some of the highest-quality songs in the genre, then recording them in arrangements that bring them to life in a way that is sonically different from any other artist in the commercial country marketplace.\"<ref>{{cite web |title=Top 10 Trisha Yearwood Songs |url=https://theboot.com/trisha-yearwood-songs/ |website=The Boot |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref> Laura McClellan of ''[[Taste of Country]]'' explained that it is Yearwood's diverse musical styles that make her music quality and career successful. McClellan also noted, \"Her songs have shaped country music \u2014 particularly for female artists \u2014 for decades.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=McClellan |first1=Laura |title=Listen to the 10 Best Trisha Yearwood Songs |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/trisha-yearwood-songs/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |access-date=June 30, 2019}}</ref>\n\n==Philanthropy==\nYearwood has participated in various philanthropic events. She recorded a version of \"[[My Favorite Things (song)|My Favorite Things]]\" for the [[Sears, Roebuck and Company|Sears]] \"Heroes at Home\" program in 2008. The song was available for download via the Sears website. The project supported the families of service men and women during the Christmas holiday season.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wiloughby |first1=Elizabeth |title=Trisha Yearwood's Favorite Things |url=https://www.looktothestars.org/news/1663-trisha-yearwoods-favorite-things |website=Look to the Stars |date=December 2, 2008 |access-date=July 5, 2019}}</ref> Yearwood has been an active member of the charity home building group [[Habitat for Humanity]]. Yearwood first joined with husband [[Garth Brooks]] in 2006. They assisted in the [[Hurricane Katrina disaster relief]] by building flood walls in [[New Orleans]] and protective structures in [[Mississippi]]. Between May 2 to 10, 2009, Yearwood participated in \"National Women Build Week\" near her home in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]]. The project saw two hundred crews of women learn to build houses in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] and Oklahoma. For the project, Yearwood learned to construct and build simple and affordable houses for Habitat for Humanity construction sites nationwide. On [[Mother's Day]], Yearwood, her sister, mother and niece joined the project as well.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sheknows.com/articles/809348.htm |title= Trisha Yearwood joins Habitat for Humanity |last= Spitzer |first= Nina |publisher= She Knows.com |access-date= June 27, 2009 }}{{Dead link|date=August 2024 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Many of these Habitat for Humanity projects have been collaborations with former president [[Jimmy Carter]] and his wife [[Rosalynn Carter]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dukes |first1=Billy |title=Garth Brooks and Trisha Yearwood Reflect on Emotional Habitat for Humanity Build |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/garth-brooks-trisha-yearwood-habitat-for-humanity-build/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |date=August 31, 2018 |access-date=July 5, 2019}}</ref>\n\nDuring the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], Yearwood and her husband Garth Brooks performed an informal concert broadcast on [[List of Facebook features#Live streaming|Facebook Live]]. The website crashed multiple times as an estimated 5.2&nbsp;million streamed the broadcast. As a result of this, Brooks and Yearwood performed a concert in the same format the following week, broadcast live on [[CBS]], along with a donation of $1&nbsp;million to relief efforts.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Leimkuehler |first1=Matthew |title=Garth Brooks, Trisha Yearwood pull fans together for hope, love and a few covers on request show |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/music/2020/04/01/garth-brooks-trisha-yearwood-cbs-live-request-show-recap-highlights/5110034002/ |publisher=USA Today |access-date=April 3, 2020}}</ref> The CBS special scored an estimated 5.6&nbsp;million viewers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.showbuzzdaily.com/articles/showbuzzdailys-top-150-wednesday-cable-originals-network-finals-4-1-2020.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200402205414/http://www.showbuzzdaily.com/articles/showbuzzdailys-top-150-wednesday-cable-originals-network-finals-4-1-2020.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 2, 2020|title=UPDATED:SHOWBUZZDAILY's Top 150 Wednesday Cable Originals and Network Finals|first=Mitch|last=Metcalf|publisher=Showbuzz Daily|date=April 2, 2020|access-date=April 3, 2020}}</ref>\n\nReminding Georgans that their vote matters, Yearwood encouraged voters in the state to participate in the December 6, 2020 runoff election between GOP nominee Herschel Walker and Senator Raphael Warnock, directing voters to non-partisan voter advocate organization [[VoteRiders]] for information and assistance with voter ID requirements.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Houghton |first=Cillea |date=2022-12-06 |title=Trisha Yearwood Encourages Voting in Georgia Runoff Election: \"Your Vote Matters\" |url=https://americansongwriter.com/trisha-yearwood-encourages-voting-georgia-runoff-election/ |access-date=2023-08-26 |website=American Songwriter |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\n[[File:Garth Brooks 2019 by Glenn Francis.jpg|thumb|right|180px|[[Garth Brooks]] and Yearwood at the [[2019 iHeartRadio Music Awards]].]]\nYearwood married her first husband, Chris Latham, in 1987. The pair divorced in 1991. In 1994, she married Robert Reynolds, founding bassist for [[The Mavericks]]. During their marriage, the couple lived in a log cabin-styled home in [[Hendersonville, Tennessee]].<ref name=\"Encyclopedia\"/> The pair divorced in 1999 after five years of marriage.<ref>{{cite web |title=Trisha Yearwood To Divorce Husband: Archived |url=https://www.apnews.com/6d3521c5ef857cf36cfb78ddafd9770d |website=[[Associated Press]] |access-date=July 5, 2019}}</ref> Yearwood commented that the separation was \"difficult\" in a 1999 interview with ''[[Country Weekly]]'', \"Since I do hang on to the past with my fingernails, divorce was difficult...It's a serious decision involving someone you're tied to emotionally, so it's hard to move on. And it's easy to drag things out so you don't have to face people talking about you.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Holden |first1=Larry |title=Country Weekly 2000-05-16 Trisha Yearwood: Divorce, Tabloid Rumors and Country Music |url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2000/05/16/trisha-yearwood-divorce-tabloid-rumors-and-country-music-2000/ |website=[[Country Weekly]] |date=May 16, 2000 |access-date=July 5, 2019}}</ref>\n\nYearwood and [[Garth Brooks]] had been friends and musical partners before romantically seeing each other. According to Brooks, his first encounter with Yearwood felt like \"that feeling when you just meet your wife\". During this period, Yearwood and Brooks were both married to other people.<ref name=\"Country Living\">{{cite web |last1=Carter |first1=Maria |title=The Story Behind How Garth Brooks and Trisha Yearwood Met and Fell in Love |url=https://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/a40540/garth-brooks-and-trisha-yearwood/ |website=[[Country Living]] |access-date=July 5, 2019}}</ref> For these reasons, they remained friends during the first half of their careers.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Paules-Bronet |first1=Ileana |title=Trisha Yearwood And Garth Brooks Open Up About The Secret To Their Successful 13-Year Marriage |url=https://www.littlethings.com/trisha-yearwood-garth-brooks-13-year-marriage/ |website=Little Things |access-date=July 9, 2019}}</ref> Following Brooks's divorce and Yearwood's second divorce, the two began dating around 2000. They became engaged in 2005 when Brooks proposed to Yearwood onstage amidst a crowd of 7,000 in [[Bakersfield, California]].<ref name=\"Country Living\"/> The pair married on December 10, 2005.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hermanson |first1=Wendy |title=Happy Anniversary Trisha Yearwood and Garth Brooks! Remember How They Met? |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/happy-anniversary-garth-brooks-and-trisha-yearwood/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |access-date=July 5, 2019}}</ref> The wedding took place at the couple's home in [[Owasso, Oklahoma]]. Brooks's three children were also part of the wedding ceremony.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Thompson |first1=Gayle |title=13 Years Ago Garth Brooks and Trisha Yearwood Wed |url=https://theboot.com/garth-brooks-trisha-yearwood-marriage-anniversary/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |access-date=July 5, 2019}}</ref>\n\nAccording to Yearwood, the pair made a commitment not to spend time apart. It is estimated by Yearwood that the couple spends about five days away from each other per year. In an interview with ''[[People Magazine]]'' she explained this further, \"We really have made a conscious effort since getting married to not be apart, so we've toured together. If I'm doing something, he'll be with me, even if you don't see him, he'll be in the hotel or around...And we're not always together, but we've been married before, and we decided we don't want to be apart. So [we said] let's make an effort to make sure that's our priority and we've been able to do it.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wallace |first1=Rachel |title=Trisha Yearwood on Garth Brooks: We Only Spend 5 Days Apart Each Year |url=https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/trisha-yearwood-garth-brooks-only-spend-5-days-a-year-apart/ |website=[[People Magazine]] |date=February 16, 2019 |access-date=July 9, 2019}}</ref> She became a [[stepmother]] to Brooks's three children following their marriage. In a 2017 interview, Yearwood explained her new role, \"I had no idea what I was doing. I have to say that now as these girls have grown\u2014they're adults now on their own\u2014it's been a part of my life that I would have never would have even known to dream about and it's been so rewarding to get to be a part of this family.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Brickey |first1=Kelly |title=Trisha Yearwood Spills on Being a Stepmom and Touring with Husband Garth Brooks |url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/trisha-yearwood-stepmom-touring-garth-brooks/ |website=Sounds Like Nashville |date=May 31, 2017 |access-date=July 9, 2019}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Trisha Yearwood discography}}\n;Studio albums\n*''[[Trisha Yearwood (album)|Trisha Yearwood]]'' (1991)\n*''[[Hearts in Armor]]'' (1992)\n*''[[The Song Remembers When]]'' (1993)\n*''[[The Sweetest Gift (Trisha Yearwood album)|The Sweetest Gift]]'' (1994)\n*''[[Thinkin' About You]]'' (1995)\n*''[[Everybody Knows (Trisha Yearwood album)|Everybody Knows]]'' (1996)\n*''[[Where Your Road Leads]]'' (1998)\n*''[[Real Live Woman]]'' (2000)\n*''[[Inside Out (Trisha Yearwood album)|Inside Out]]'' (2001)\n*''[[Jasper County (album)|Jasper County]]'' (2005)\n*''[[Heaven, Heartache and the Power of Love]]'' (2007)\n*''[[PrizeFighter: Hit After Hit]]'' (2014)\n*''[[Christmas Together (Garth Brooks and Trisha Yearwood album)|Christmas Together]]'' {{Small|(with [[Garth Brooks]])}} (2016)\n*''[[Let's Be Frank]]'' (2018)\n*''[[Every Girl (album)|Every Girl]]'' (2019)\n\n== Filmography ==\n{| class=\"wikitable sortable plainrowheaders\"\n|- align=\"center\"\n!
