Notes\n|-\n| 2014\n| ''[[American Country Countdown Awards]]''\n| Themselves/Host\n|\n|-\n| 2016\n| ''[[Hollywood Game Night]]''\n| Themselves\n| Episode: \"Musical Game Night\" <br> (with [[Ciara]], [[Estelle (musician)|Estelle]], & [[Hunter Hayes]])\n|-\n| 2017, 2021\n| ''[[CMT Crossroads]]''\n| Themselves\n| Alongside with [[Backstreet Boys]] (2017) and [[Nelly]] (2021)\n|-\n| 2017\n| ''[[The Ellen Show]]''\n| Performance\n| Alongside with [[Backstreet Boys]]\n|-\n| 2019\n| ''[[Ridiculousness (TV series)|Ridiculousness]]''\n| Themselves/Guest\n| rowspan=2| Episode: \"Florida Georgia Line\"\n|-\n| 2020\n| ''[[Songland]]''\n| Themselves/Guest\n|-\n|}\n\n==Notes==\n{{Notelist|refs=\n{{efn|name=fn1|Indefinite hiatus}}}}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n{{Commons category}}\n* {{official website|http://www.floridageorgialine.com/}}\n\n{{Florida Georgia Line}}\n{{American Music Award for Favorite Country Band/Duo/Group}}\n{{CMA Duo of the Year}}\n{{Tyler Hubbard}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:2010 establishments in Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Country music groups from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Musical duos from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Country pop duos]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2010]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Republic Records artists]]\n[[Category:American male musical duos]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Sam_Hunt","to":"Sam Hunt"}],"pages":{"41703155":{"pageid":41703155,"ns":0,"title":"Sam Hunt","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer and songwriter}}\n{{About|the American musician|other people of the name|Samuel Hunt (disambiguation){{!}}Samuel Hunt}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2011}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Sam Hunt\n| image        = Sam Hunt at C2C Festival 2014.png\n| caption      = Hunt performing at C2C Festival in London's O2 Arena, 2015\n| birth_name   = Sam Lowry Hunt<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/samhuntmusic/status/452637029877035008 |title=Sam Hunt on Twitter: \"My middle name is Lowry\" |website=Twitter.com |access-date=2016-03-05}}</ref>\n<!-- Please do NOT change his name to \"Samuel\" without a reference. Songwriting credits list his name simply as Sam. -->\n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|1984|12|8}}<ref name=\"uab\"/>\n| birth_place  = [[Cedartown, Georgia]], U.S.\n| origin       = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre        = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/sam-hunt-mn0002674420 | title=Sam Hunt | website=[[AllMusic]] | access-date=September 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name = \"Popmatters\">{{cite web|last=Easton |first=Anthony|date=19 November 2014|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/187959-sam-hunt-montevallo/|title=Sam Hunt: Montevallo|publisher=[[Popmatters]]|access-date=December 31, 2014}}</ref>\n* [[country pop]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n* [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]<ref name = \"Popmatters\"/>\n}}\n<!-- to avoid edit warring, all genres must be sourced, and any changes should be discussed on talk page before being made -->\n| occupation   = {{flatlist|\n* Singer\n* songwriter\n}}\n| instrument   = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar<!--- If you think an instrument should be listed, a discussion to reach consensus is needed first per: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Infobox_musical_artist#instrument--->\n}}\n| years_active = 2008\u2013present\n| label        = [[Universal Music Group Nashville#MCA Nashville|MCA Nashville]]\n| website      = {{URL|samhunt.com}}\n}}\n'''Sam Lowry Hunt''' (born December 8, 1984) is an American singer and songwriter. Born in [[Cedartown, Georgia]], Hunt played [[American football|football]] in his high school and college years and once attempted to pursue a professional sports career before signing with [[Universal Music Group Nashville#MCA Nashville|MCA Nashville]] in 2014.\n\nPrior to his successful solo career, Hunt was credited for writing singles for [[Kenny Chesney]], [[Keith Urban]], [[Billy Currington]], and [[Reba McEntire]]. His debut studio album, ''[[Montevallo (album)|Montevallo]]'', broke several chart records with five singles spawned from the record, including three consecutive [[Hot Country Songs]] chart and four [[Country Airplay]] chart number ones. The lead single from the album, \"[[Leave the Night On]]\", peaked concurrently on the Hot Country Songs and Country Airplay charts, making Hunt the first country artist in 22 years, since [[Billy Ray Cyrus]], to reach the top of three country charts simultaneously in the [[Nielsen SoundScan]]-era.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6312087/sam-hunt-scores-country-charts-feat-last-achieved-22-years-ago |title=Sam Hunt Scores Country Charts Feat Last Achieved 22 Years Ago|author= Wade Jessen |date= November 7, 2014 |magazine=Billboard}}</ref> He is also the first country artist since [[Clint Black]] to occupy both year-end number one album and single with ''Montevallo'' and \"[[Take Your Time (Sam Hunt song)|Take Your Time]]\".<ref>{{cite magazine |id={{ProQuest|1648505508}} |last1=Jessen |first1=Wade |title=Hunt's No. 1 Trifecta |magazine=Billboard |volume=126 |issue=38 |date=15 November 2014 |page=86 }}</ref><ref name=\"billboard1\">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/year-end/2015/hot-country-songs|title=Year End Charts - Year-end Singles - Hot Country Songs |magazine=Billboard |access-date=2015-12-10}}</ref><ref name=\"billboard2\">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/year-end/2015/top-country-albums|title=Year End Charts - Year-end Albums - Top Country Albums |magazine=Billboard |access-date=2015-12-10}}</ref> The fifth single \"[[Make You Miss Me]]\" from the album ''Montevallo'', hit number one on the Country Airplay chart, thus making Hunt the first solo male artist to land four number ones on the Country Airplay chart from a debut studio album.<ref>{{cite magazine|author=Keith Caulfield |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7487760/billboard-200-chart-moves-stranger-things-soundtrack |title=200 Chart Moves: 'Stranger Things' Soundtrack Makes Strong Debut |magazine=Billboard |date=2016-08-26 |access-date=2017-01-26}}</ref><ref name=\"billboard2\" />\n\nSince the launch of his career, Hunt has quickly received recognition from both inside and outside the country music community for his blending of genres,  incorporating use of [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] and [[Pop music|pop]] into the production and songwriting of his songs. He has been honored with [[List of awards and nominations received by Sam Hunt|numerous awards]], including one [[American Music Award]], and one [[CMT Music Awards|CMT Music Award]], as well as nominations for [[Billboard Music Award|''Billboard'' Music Awards]] and [[Grammy Award]]s.\n\n==Life and career==\n===Early life and football career===\n{{Infobox college football player\n| name            = Sam Hunt\n| image           = \n| image_size      = \n| alt             = \n| caption         = \n| school          = \n| currentnumber   = \n| currentposition = \n| pastschools     = \n* [[Middle Tennessee Blue Raiders football|Middle Tennessee]] (2003\u20132004)\n* [[UAB Blazers football|UAB]] (2005\u20132007)\n| highschool      = [[Cedartown High School|Cedartown (GA)]]\n| height_ft       = 6\n| height_in       = 3\n| weight_lb       = 215\n}}\n\nHunt was born on December 8, 1984, in [[Cedartown, Georgia]], the eldest of three children of Allen and Joan Hunt, an insurance agent and a teacher respectively.<ref name=\"uab\">{{cite web|url=http://www.uabsports.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/hunt_sam00.html|title=Sam Hunt|work=UAB Sports.com|access-date=January 21, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202123653/http://www.uabsports.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/hunt_sam00.html|archive-date=February 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/sam-hunt-montevallo-album-interview-20141028 |title=Sam Hunt Defends His Country Cred on New Album 'Montevallo'|author= Marissa R Moss |date= October 28, 2014 |magazine=Rolling Stone }}</ref> His brothers are Ben Hunt (Farmer Hunt) and Van Hunt. He studied at [[Cedartown High School]] where he played football. He was named 2002 Co-Offensive Player of the Year, was selected for the Georgia Sportswriters Association All-State Class AAA first-team as an all-purpose player, and was a [[Wendy's High School Heisman]] nominee.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmacloseup.com/2014/10/28/sam-hunt-debut-spotlight-2/ |title=Sam Hunt: Debut Spotlight |work=CMA Close Up Magazine |date=October 28, 2014 |access-date=January 18, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150118172634/http://www.cmacloseup.com/2014/10/28/sam-hunt-debut-spotlight-2/ |archive-date=January 18, 2015 }}</ref>\n\nHe was a [[quarterback]] at [[Middle Tennessee State University]] from 2003 to 2004. He dressed for every game in 2003 but did not play in any of them.<ref name=\"uab\"/> He had limited action in six games in 2004, attempting one pass and rushing once for one yard.<ref name=\"uab\"/><ref name=\"stats\"/> Hunt transferred to the [[University of Alabama at Birmingham]] (UAB) in 2005 and [[redshirted]] his first season there.<ref name=\"uab\"/> He played in only seven games during the 2006 season due to injuries, completing 48 of 82 passes for 655 yards, two touchdowns and five interceptions.<ref name=\"uab\"/><ref name=\"stats\">{{cite web | url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/sam-hunt-1.html | title=Sam Hunt | publisher=Sports Reference LLC | work=sports-reference.com | access-date=October 16, 2017}}</ref> He also rushed 69 times for 159 yards and one touchdown. Hunt completed 155 of 331 passes for 1,905 yards, 10 touchdowns and 14 interceptions in 2007. He also rushed 68 times for 287 yards and two touchdowns.<ref name=\"stats\"/> At UAB, he majored in philosophy before graduating with a business degree in economics.<ref name=\"uab\"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2014/11/14/musicians-sports-sam-hunt-on-his-college-quarterback-years/ |title=Musicians + Sports: Sam Hunt On His College Quarterback Years |author=Scott T. Sterling |date=November 14, 2014 |work=CBS New York }}</ref><ref name=\"billboard\">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/sam-hunt-scores-a-touchdown-as-nashvilles-newest-hot-singer-songwriter-20140813 |title=Sam Hunt Scores a Touchdown as Nashville's Newest Hot Singer-Songwriter|author=Wendy Geller |date= August 13, 2014|magazine=Rolling Stone }}</ref> After practice every day, he would teach himself how to play acoustic guitar. With respect to the root of his interest in music, Hunt recalled between stops in tour, \"I never saw myself as a musician or having any musical talent... I was just killing time that summer, and a buddy had recently bought a guitar. I picked it up one day and on a whim thought, 'You know, I think I want to buy a guitar.'\" Hunt's college roommates, having listened to a few songs he wrote, encouraged him to book shows at bars, marking the start of his pursuit of a career in music.<ref name=RS>{{cite web|last1=Murray|first1=Nick|title=Sam Hunt: How a Former College Football Star Is Making Over Country Music |date=February 26, 2015 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/sam-hunt-how-a-former-college-football-star-is-making-over-country-music-20150226|publisher=Rolling Stone|access-date=27 August 2015}}</ref>\n\nAfter graduating from UAB in 2007, he had a tryout with the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] of the [[National Football League]] in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.samhunt.com/bio|title=Bio: Sam Hunt|access-date=January 30, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209003153/http://www.samhunt.com/bio|archive-date=February 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2012/06/former_uab_quarterback_sam_hun.html | title=Former UAB quarterback Sam Hunt finding success in country music | website=Al.com | date=June 23, 2012 | access-date=October 16, 2017 | author=Irvine, Steve | url-status=bot: unknown | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171016220333/http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2012/06/former_uab_quarterback_sam_hun.html | archive-date=October 16, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/6670447/sam-hunt-breaking-down-stereotypes-taylor-swift-fashion-mens-style | title=Billboard Cover: Sam Hunt on Breaking Down Stereotypes, Teaming With Taylor Swift and Recruiting a 'Team of Misfits' on His Rise to Country Fame | magazine=Billboard | date=August 20, 2015 | access-date=October 16, 2017 | author=Tannenbaum, Rob | url-status=bot: unknown | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171016220545/http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/6670447/sam-hunt-breaking-down-stereotypes-taylor-swift-fashion-mens-style | archive-date=October 16, 2017 }}</ref> \"I knew this was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, and I needed to find out if I could take it all the way,\" Hunt said. In 2008, two months after the unsuccessful attempt to impress the football team, to the surprise of his family and friends, he left to pursue a music career, and moved to Nashville along with a friend with only \"some food and two mattresses and his mom's minivan\".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/naomizeichner/sam-hunt-montevallo-tracklist |title=Sam Hunt Is A Country Star for the Instagram Age |author=Naomi Zeichner |date= September 9, 2014 |work=BuzzFeed }}</ref><ref name=Billb1 />\n\nHunt co-wrote [[Kenny Chesney]]'s 2012 hit \"[[Come Over (Kenny Chesney song)|Come Over]]\", for which he received an [[American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers|ASCAP]] award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1692351/ascap-honors-writers-of-kenny-chesneys-come-over-hit.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120824022806/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1692351/ascap-honors-writers-of-kenny-chesneys-come-over-hit.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=August 24, 2012|title=ASCAP Honors Writers of Kenny Chesney's \"Come Over\" Hit|last=Morris|first=Edward|date=August 22, 2012|work=[[Country Music Television]]|access-date=January 21, 2014}}</ref> He also co-wrote two singles released in 2014: [[Keith Urban]]'s \"[[Cop Car (Keith Urban song)|Cop Car]]\", and [[Billy Currington]]'s \"[[We Are Tonight (song)|We Are Tonight]]\". Hunt independently released the single \"[[Raised on It]]\" in September 2013 and in October 2013, he released via his website a free 15-song mixtape titled ''[[Between the Pines]]''.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/another-country-sam-hunt-maps-out-nashvilles-bold-new-future/2014/11/04/bd37cf86-643d-11e4-bb14-4cfea1e742d5_story.html |title=Another country: Sam Hunt maps out Nashville's bold new future |author=Chris Richards |date=November 4, 2014 |newspaper=Washington Post }}</ref> Hunt also co-wrote \"[[Love Somebody (album)|Love Somebody]]\", the title track from [[Reba McEntire]]'s 27th studio album ''[[Love Somebody (album)|Love Somebody]]''.<ref>Love Somebody (CD booklet and backing card). Reba McEntire. Nash Icon. 2015. NICR0300A.</ref>\n\n=== 2014\u20132016: ''X2C'' and ''Montevallo'' ===\n[[File:Sam Hunt concert 2014.jpg|thumb|Sam Hunt in concert in 2014]]\nIn January 2014, it was confirmed that he had signed a recording contract with [[Universal Music Group Nashville#MCA Nashville|MCA Nashville]]. On August 12, 2014, he released ''[[X2C]]'', a four-song [[Extended play|EP]], intended as a preview of his debut studio album.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2014/08/17/sam-hunt-releases-x2c-album-preview/ |title=Sam Hunt Releases X2C Album Preview |author=Sarah Wyland |date=August 17, 2014 |work=Great American Country }}</ref> The [[Extended play|EP]] debuted at number 36 on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and number five on the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart, selling 8,000 copies in its first week.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6228933/sam-hunt-top-country-albums-x2c |title=Sam Hunt Scores Highest Debut on Top Country Albums With 'X2C'|author= Wade Jessen |date= August 21, 2014 |magazine=Billboard }}</ref>\n\nHunt's first single for [[Universal Music Group Nashville|MCA Nashville]] was \"[[Leave the Night On]]\", which went to number one on the [[Country Airplay]] chart in October 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/135126/sam-hunt-is-1-with-leave-the-night-on?ref=rss |title=Sam Hunt is No. 1 With 'Leave The Night On' |publisher=AllAccess.com |date=2014-11-03 |access-date=2015-07-01}}</ref> and has since been [[Certified platinum|certified Platinum]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.musicrow.com/2014/09/industry-ink-sam-hunt-goes-gold-jason-isbell-sae-nashville/ | title=Industry Ink: Sam Hunt Goes Gold, Jason Isbell, SAE Nashville, Taryn Pray | publisher=Music Row | date=September 18, 2014 | access-date=October 28, 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141028043059/http://www.musicrow.com/2014/09/industry-ink-sam-hunt-goes-gold-jason-isbell-sae-nashville/ | url-status=live | archive-date=October 28, 2014}}</ref> The music video for the song earned Hunt two [[CMT Music Awards]] nominations, winning the CMT Breakthrough Video of the Year award, and nominated for the CMT Video of the Year award. His debut studio album ''[[Montevallo (album)|Montevallo]]'', was released on October 27, 2014.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunt-montevallo-album-details/ | title=Sam Hunt Reveals 'Montevallo' Album Details | publisher=Taste of Country | date=September 16, 2014 | access-date=October 28, 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141005195256/http://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunt-montevallo-album-details/ | url-status=live | archive-date=October 5, 2014}}</ref> On the same day, Sam Hunt released ''Between the Pines: Acoustic Mixtape''. The album is made up of acoustic versions of his hit songs, including his versions of ones that he wrote for other artists. [[Universal Music Group Nashville]] president, Cindy Mabe explained the date of the release: \"The idea was to release it on the same date that ''[[Montevallo (album)|Montevallo]]'' was released [in 2014] as a one-year anniversary gift to fans and Sam's way to offer more music and a thanks for the support.\"<ref>{{cite magazine |id={{ProQuest|1760206906}} |last1=Asker |first1=Jim |title=Rhett, Old Dominion Dominate |magazine=Billboard |volume=127 |issue=34 |date=14 November 2015 |page=65 }}</ref> On November 5, 2014, ''Montevallo'' debuted at number one on the Top Country Albums chart and number three on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.samhunt.com/news/11-05-14/montevallo-country-musics-best-selling-debut-album-2011|title=MONTEVALLO is Country Music's Best-Selling Debut Album Since 2011 |access-date=February 4, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214113900/http://www.samhunt.com/news/11-05-14/montevallo-country-musics-best-selling-debut-album-2011 |archive-date=December 14, 2014 }}</ref> It opened with 70,000 units sold. The album included his own version of \"[[Cop Car (Keith Urban song)#Sam Hunt version|Cop Car]]\". The second single from the album \"[[Take Your Time (Sam Hunt song)|Take Your Time]]\", peaked at number 20 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. The track spent 11 weeks at number one of Hunt's 17 weeks in 2015 on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart, making him the 16th artist in the chart's 57-year history \u2013 and the fifth in the past 50 years \u2013 to rule for 10 weeks or more.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hodak|first1=Brittany|title=How Sam Hunt Won Country Music In 2015|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/brittanyhodak/2015/12/28/how-sam-hunt-won-country-music-in-2015/|work=Forbes|access-date=31 December 2015}}</ref> With ''[[Montevallo (album)|Montevallo]]'' and \"[[Take Your Time (Sam Hunt song)|Take Your Time]]\", Hunt became the first country artist since [[Clint Black]] to have his debut studio album and single to peak atop the year-end charts in the same year.<ref name=\"billboard1\"/><ref name=\"billboard2\"/> Five days after the release of ''[[Montevallo (album)|Montevallo]]'', Hunt announced his first tour Lipstick Graffiti. Tickets went on sale on November 14, 2014. Within a short time of going on sale, the tour sold out at 15 of the venues.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.samhunt.com/news/11-15-14/lipstick-graffiti-tour-sells-out-15-shows-within-minutes-going-sale |title=LIPSTICK GRAFFITI Tour Sells Out 15 Shows Within Minutes of Going On Sale|access-date=November 17, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141123133019/http://www.samhunt.com/news/11-15-14/lipstick-graffiti-tour-sells-out-15-shows-within-minutes-going-sale |archive-date=November 23, 2014 }}</ref> In 2015, he served as an opening act (alongside [[Hunter Hayes]]) for [[Lady Antebellum]]'s [[Wheels Up Tour]].\n\nHunt was featured on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' for the issue of August 29, 2015, where he opened about breaking down country music stereotypes.<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Tannanbaum|first1=Rob|title=Billboard Cover: Sam Hunt on Breaking Down Stereotypes, Teaming With Taylor Swift and Recruiting a 'Team of Misfits' on His Rise to Country Fame|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/6670447/sam-hunt-breaking-down-stereotypes-taylor-swift-fashion-mens-style|access-date=2 December 2015}}</ref> He served as a background vocalist on [[Carrie Underwood]]'s song \"[[Heartbeat (Carrie Underwood song)|Heartbeat]]\", which was released in October 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://therowdy.com/article/sam-hunt-confirmed-as-background-vocalist-on-carrie-underwood-s-heartbeat |title=Sam Hunt confirmed as background vocalist on Carrie Underwood's 'Heartbeat' |website=Therowdy.com |date=2015-10-13 |access-date=2016-03-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208120405/http://therowdy.com/article/sam-hunt-confirmed-as-background-vocalist-on-carrie-underwood-s-heartbeat |archive-date=December 8, 2015 }}</ref> To commemorate the one-year anniversary of Hunt's debut studio album ''Montevallo'', ''Between the Pines'' was re-released on October 27, 2015, peaking at number 31 on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunt-reissues-between-the-pines/ |title=Sam Hunt Reissues Acoustic Record Montevallo's Birthday |author= Laura McClellan |date= October 28, 2015 |work=Taste of Country }}</ref> Hunt won his first [[American Music Award]] for New Artist of the Year on November 22, 2015, in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]].\n\nFor the week of September 10, 2016, Hunt's fifth single \"[[Make You Miss Me]]\" from ''[[Montevallo (album)|Montevallo]]'', hit number one on the Country Airplay chart, thus making him the first solo male artist to land four number ones on the Country Airplay chart from a debut studio album.<ref name=\"billboard2\" />\n\n=== 2017\u2013present: ''Southside'' ===\nOn February 1, 2017, Hunt released \"[[Body Like a Back Road]]\", which went on to become his biggest hit.<ref>References confirming release of \"Body Like a Back Road\":\n* {{cite news|last1=Dukes|first1=Billy|title=Sam Hunt's New Song 'Body Like a Back Road' Written After Engagement [Listen]|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunts-body-like-a-back-road-new-single/|access-date=January 25, 2017|work=[[Taste of Country]]|date=January 25, 2017}}\n* {{cite news|last1=Casey|first1=Jim|title=Sam Hunt Announces New \"Body Like a Back Road\" Single [Listen], New \"15 in a 30 Tour\" & Talks \"Spiritual\" Engagement Details|url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2017/01/25/sam-hunt-announces-new-body-like-a-backroad-single-new-15-in-a-30-tour-talks-spiritual-engagement-details-2/|access-date=January 25, 2017|work=[[Nash Country Weekly]]|date=January 25, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|last=Asker|first=Jim|title=Florida Georgia Line Now Has 3 of the 5 Longest-Leading Hot Country Songs No. 1s, Thanks to 'Meant to Be'|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8280778/florida-georgia-line-bebe-rexha-meant-to-be-number-one-hot-country-songs-18-weeks|access-date=April 5, 2018|magazine=Billboard|date=April 3, 2018}}</ref> In March 2017, while playing a string of live shows with [[Tucker Beathard]], Hunt debuted another song titled \"[[Drinkin' Too Much]]\", a song he wrote and recorded about his on-and-off relationship with his then girlfriend, Hannah Lee Fowler.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mixcloud.com/DJCutt/locash-sam-hunt-scotty-mccreery-blake-shelton-tucker-beathard-dj-cutt-mix/ |title=Locash Sam Hunt Scotty Mccreery Blake Shelton Tucker Beathard DJ Cutt Mix by DJCutt |website=Mixcloud.com |date=2020-03-20 |access-date=2020-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/inside-sam-hunts-apologetic-drinkin-too-much-the-ram-report-109357/ |title=Inside Sam Hunt's Apologetic 'Drinkin' Too Much': Ram Report |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=2017-01-05 |access-date=2020-04-04}}</ref>\n\nIn May 2018, Hunt released the single \"[[Downtown's Dead]]\". He then announced another song titled \"[[Nothing Lasts Forever (Sam Hunt song)|Nothing Lasts Forever]]\", that had yet to be released from his second studio album while performing it at several live shows.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunt-song-nothing-lasts-forever/|title=Next New Sam Hunt Song Better Shows His Musical Direction|work=Taste of Country|last=Dukes|first=Billy|date=May 18, 2018|access-date=May 19, 2018}}</ref>\n\nHunt took a prolonged hiatus from social media and releasing music after the end of the [[What Makes You Country Tour]] with [[Luke Bryan]].<ref>{{cite news|url= https://torontosun.com/entertainment/music/country-star-sam-hunt-debuts-new-song-in-calgary |title= Country star Sam Hunt debuts new song in Calgary |newspaper=[[Toronto Sun]]|last=Volmers|first=Eric|date=September 20, 2019|access-date=October 12, 2019}}</ref> While performing at the Bud Light House Party event in [[Calgary]], Hunt performed \"[[Sinning with You]]\" for the first time which he announced would be on his upcoming album.<ref>{{cite magazine|url= https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8530568/sam-hunt-sinning-with-you |title=Sam Hunt Plays New Song 'Sinning With You' at Canadian Club Show: Watch |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|last=Reuter|first=Annie|date=September 20, 2019|access-date=October 12, 2019}}</ref> Hunt also announced that another single from the new album would be out shortly and the entire album would be released in early 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://etcanada.com/news/510056/sam-hunt-premieres-new-song-sinning-with-you-reveals-details-on-next-album-after-his-reboot/ |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190920235803/https://etcanada.com/news/510056/sam-hunt-premieres-new-song-sinning-with-you-reveals-details-on-next-album-after-his-reboot/ |url-status= dead |archive-date= September 20, 2019 |title= Sam Hunt Premieres New Song 'Sinning With You', Reveals Details On Next Album After His 'Reboot' |work=[[Entertainment Tonight Canada|ET Canada]]|publisher=[[Corus Entertainment]]|last=Colley|first=Katie|date=September 20, 2019|access-date=October 12, 2019}}</ref> In October 2019, Hunt released \"[[Kinfolks]]\", his first radio single in over a year.<ref>{{cite magazine|url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/sam-hunt-new-song-kinfolks-897498/ |title=Hear Sam Hunt's New Song 'Kinfolks' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|last=Freeman|first=Jon|date=October 10, 2019|access-date=October 12, 2019}}</ref> \"[[Sinning with You]]\" was released in January 2020.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sinning With You \u2013 Single by Sam Hunt on Spotify|url=https://open.spotify.com/album/4U6IucCgnIhPWuvWpQ6npi?si=fcAip9MUSteO3-cKw6RbVQ |access-date=December 23, 2019|work=[[Spotify]]}}</ref>\n\nIn February 2020, Hunt announced the title of his second album would be ''[[Southside (Sam Hunt album)|Southside]]'' and that it would be released on April 3, 2020.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunt-sophomore-album-southside/|title=Sam Hunt Announces Long-Awaited Sophomore Album, 'Southside'|date=February 5, 2020|work=Taste of Country}}</ref><ref name=\"theboot1\">{{cite news|url=https://theboot.com/sam-hunt-southside-album-details/|title=Everything We Know About Sam Hunt's Sophomore Album 'Southside'|date=February 5, 2020|work=The Boot|publisher=Townsquare Media, Inc.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2020/music/news/country-star-sam-hunt-announces-sophomore-album-southside-tour-1203493483/|title=Country Hitmaker Sam Hunt Schedules First Album Since 2014 Debut|date=February 5, 2020|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}}</ref> He accompanied the album announcement with the announcement of his headlining ''[[Southside Summer Tour 2020|Southside Summer Tour]]'' with [[Kip Moore]], [[Travis Denning]], and ''Ernest'' as supporting acts,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunt-southside-2020-tour-dates/|title=Sam Hunt Announces 'Southside' Summer 2020 Tour With Kip Moore|date=February 5, 2020|work=Taste of Country}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/sam-hunt-announces-southside-album-headline-tour/|title=Sam Hunt Announces 'Southside' Album and Summer Headline Tour|date=February 5, 2020|work=Sounds Like Nashville}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/touring/8550185/sam-hunt-tour-dates|title=Sam Hunt Announces Sophomore Album 'Southside' After Six-Year Wait, Preps 2020 Tour|date=February 5, 2020|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}}</ref> while releasing his next single \"[[Hard to Forget]]\" the next day.<ref name=\"WYRK\">{{cite news|url=https://wyrk.com/check-out-sam-hunts-next-single-hard-to-forget-listen/|title=Check Out Sam Hunt's Next Single, \"Hard To Forget\" [LISTEN]|work=Country 106.5 WYRK|publisher=Townsquare Media, Inc.|access-date=February 20, 2020 }}</ref> Hunt later cancelled the \"[[Southside Summer Tour 2020|''Southside Summer Tour'']]\" amidst the [[COVID-19 pandemic|coronavirus pandemic]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunt-cancels-2020-southside-tour/|title=Sam Hunt Cancels 2020 Southside Tour|date=May 19, 2020|first=Billy|last=Dukes|work=Taste of Country}}</ref> On April 25, 2020, Hunt was featured on the remix of rapper [[Breland (musician)|Breland]]'s single \"[[My Truck]]\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/de/album/my-truck-feat-sam-hunt-remix-single/1508214109|title=My Truck (feat. Sam Hunt) [Remix] - Single by BRELAND on Apple Music|via=[[Apple Music]]|date=April 25, 2020|access-date=August 2, 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn October 2020, Hunt released \"[[Breaking Up Was Easy in the 90s]]\" as the fifth single to country radio off ''[[Southside (Sam Hunt album)|Southside]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1825692/sam-hunt-seems-to-think-breaking-up-was-easier-in-the-90s/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201007001212/http://www.cmt.com/news/1825692/sam-hunt-seems-to-think-breaking-up-was-easier-in-the-90s/|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 7, 2020|title=Sam Hunt Seems to Think Breaking Up Was Easier in the 90's|publisher=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT News]]|last=Bonaguro|first=Alison|date=October 6, 2020|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref> In April 2021, he joined [[indie pop]] singer [[Sasha Sloan]] on her single \"When Was It Over?\" which they co-wrote together with several other writers including [[Shane McAnally]].<ref>{{Cite web|first=Jeremy|last=Chua|date=2021-04-23|title=Sam Hunt, Sasha Sloan Team Up For Haunting Breakup Song, 'when was it over?'|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/music/sam-hunt-sasha-sloan-breakup-song-when-was-it-over/|access-date=2021-04-26|website=Sounds Like Nashville}}</ref> In August 2021, he dueted with [[Ingrid Andress]] on \"[[Wishful Drinking (song)|Wishful Drinking]]\",<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/ingrid-andress-sam-hunt-wishful-drinking-1206140/|title=Ingrid Andress Teams With Sam Hunt for New Song 'Wishful Drinking'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|last=Freeman|first=Joe|date=August 2, 2021|access-date=December 9, 2021}}</ref> and followed that up with the release of his single \"[[23 (Sam Hunt song)|23]]\" in September 2021.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.umgnashville.com/news/sam-hunt-releases-new-song-23-today/|title=Sam Hunt Releases New Song \"23\" Today|work=Universal Music Group Nashville|date=September 9, 2021|access-date=October 22, 2021}}</ref> In 2022, he released the single \"Water Under the Bridge\", and the promotional single \"Start Nowhere\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunt-water-under-the-bridge-video/|title=Sam Hunt Enjoys Simple Pleasures in 'Water Under the Bridge' Video [Watch]|date=July 19, 2022|work=Taste of Country|access-date=January 17, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunt-start-nowhere/|title=Sam Hunt Gets Back to His Roots on Reflective New Track, 'Start Nowhere' [Listen]|first=Jeremy|last=Chua|date=November 23, 2022|work=Taste of Country|access-date=January 17, 2023}}</ref> In 2023, he released a new single, \"[[Outskirts (song)|Outskirts]]\", and announced that he will be going on tour with the \"Summer on the Outskirts\" tour.<ref>{{cite magazine |author=Jon Freeman |date=March 6, 2023 |title=Sam Hunt Announces Summer on the Outskirts Tour |magazine=Rolling Stone |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/sam-hunt-summer-tour-dates-2023-1234691366/ |url-access=subscription}}</ref>\n\n== Artistry ==\n\n=== Vocals ===\nWriting for ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', Elias Leight observed on Hunt's vocal performance, describing his vocal performance in studio sessions as a \"rough, heartthrob voice that shines clearly,\" but noted that his live vocals \"weren't always easy to hear.\" Leight further praised Hunt's delivery to be \"a mix of speaking and rapid-fire singing that sets him apart from other country singers,\" but commented its impact was \"diminished because of his live singing.\" Finally, Hunt's live performance of \"[[Make You Miss Me]]\" rendered the music writer \"the clearest glimpse of his husky mid-range, smooth but rugged voice in a setting where there were no beats crowding him or guitars to compete with.\"<ref name=Billb2>{{cite magazine|last1=Leight|first1=Elias|title=Sam Hunt Erases Boundaries Between Country & Other Genres at NYC Show|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6472469/sam-hunt-new-york-show-live-review|magazine=Billboard|access-date=27 August 2015}}</ref>\n\n=== Influences ===\nHunt's music contains elements of [[Country music|country]], [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] and [[Pop music|pop]]. [[Dwight Yoakam]], while speaking to ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'', commented on Hunt's music, saying \"It reminds me a little bit of, with the infusion of soul and southern R&B, with the things that happened surrounding the album that Ray Charles put out \u2013 the very historic album The Modern Sounds of Country Music back in the early '60s. It was a reinterpretation that not only intrigued country audiences at the time, but it brought a brand new audience to the country music world.\"<ref name=ET1>{{cite web|last1=Schillaci|first1=Sophie|title=Dwight Yoakam Compares Sam Hunt to Ray Charles: He's Bringing 'A Brand New Audience' to Country|date=May 13, 2015 |url=http://www.etonline.com/music/164437_dwight_yoakam_compares_sam_hunt_to_ray_charles_he_bringing_a_brand_new_audience_to_country/|publisher=Entertainment Tonight|access-date=15 December 2015}}</ref> His songwriting was heavily influenced by [[Brad Paisley]], whose early hit \"[[He Didn't Have to Be]]\" had a big impact on him as a kid growing up in Georgia:<ref name=\"pro.krmd-fm.tritonflex.com\">{{cite web |url=http://pro.krmd-fm.tritonflex.com/common/more.php?m=58&ts=1414058454&article=1A5F068C5A9C11E4B51EFEFDADE6840A&mode=2 |title=Sam Hunt Opens Up About His Unlikely Classic Country Influences |date=October 28, 2014 |work=Nash FM 101.1 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20150210125812/http://pro.krmd-fm.tritonflex.com/common/more.php?m=58&ts=1414058454&article=1A5F068C5A9C11E4B51EFEFDADE6840A&mode=2 |archive-date=February 10, 2015 }}</ref> \"I remember being at church on Wednesday night at Wednesday night supper, and getting the keys from my mom well before it was over to just go sit in the car and to turn the radio on and hopefully wait and catch that song.\"<ref name=\"pro.krmd-fm.tritonflex.com\"/> He also cites [[Billy Currington]], [[Usher (singer)|Usher]], [[K-Ci & JoJo]], [[R. Kelly]], [[Ginuwine]]<ref name=\"tasteofcountry.com\"/> and [[Alice Cooper]]<ref name=\"pro.krmd-fm.tritonflex.com\"/> as musical influences.\n\n=== Lyrical and musical style ===\nHunt told ''[[Taste of Country]]'' that he does not write his songs with a specific genre in mind, but rather follows his instinct.<ref name=\"tasteofcountry.com\">{{cite web |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunt-interview-leave-the-night-on-r-and-b-influences/ |title=Sam Hunt Interview: 'Leave the Night On' Singer Shares His R&B Influences |author= Billy Dukes |date= August 14, 2014 |work=Taste of Country }}</ref> \"I want to sound different than everybody else,\" said Hunt talking about his musical style. \"To use a football phrase, I try to zig when other people zag.\"<ref name=Billb1 /> Commenting on his interpretation of country music, he told ''[[Rolling Stone Country]]'', \"I think country songs are truthful songs about life written by country people, but the beats and sounds will continue to evolve.\"<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moss|first1=Marissa R.|title=Watch Sam Hunt Throw a 'House Party' on 'Fallon' |date=August 19, 2015 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/watch-sam-hunt-throw-a-house-party-on-fallon-20150819#ixzz3k2LjqSc4|publisher=Rolling Stone|access-date=27 August 2015}}</ref> Billy Dukes of ''[[Townsquare Media|Taste of Country]]'', on observing \"[[Break Up in a Small Town]]\", referred the song as \"likely the wordiest song of 2015\" and Hunt's \"most genre-bending release to country radio\", adding \"Any talk of which genre Hunt belongs in misses the point. His story hits hard. It's deep and emotional and sincere and all the things we expect from a great country song.\"<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dukes|first1=Billy|title=Sam Hunt, 'Break Up in a Small Town' [Listen] |date=September 22, 2015 |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunt-break-up-in-a-small-town/|access-date=23 September 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn a 2015 interview with ''Billboard'', Hunt remarked on the position of women in his music, \"Respect for women was a very important part of my upbringing,\" and added, \"The women in my life demanded that from me.\" Hunt even named his album ''[[Montevallo (album)|Montevallo]]'', after the hometown of his wife, Hannah Lee Fowler, and consulted her in the lyrical production: \"I spent a lot of time talking to her about the songs and asking, 'What do you think about this?' Her perspective was a powerful part of me being able to connect with a female audience, not just a male audience.\"<ref name=Billb1>{{cite magazine|last1=Payne|first1=Chris|title=Billboard Cover Sneak Peek: 5 Ways Sam Hunt Is Breaking Down Country Stereotypes|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/6670464/sam-hunt-billboard-cover-sneak-peek|magazine=Billboard|access-date=27 August 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn a June 2018 interview with ''[[Townsquare Media|Taste of Country]]'', Hunt said that his upcoming second album will be much like ''[[Montevallo (album)|Montevallo]]'', but after the release of the second album he plans to \"get back to the foundation of the musical genre that he identifies with\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/sam-hunt-new-country-music-interview-2018/|title=Sam Hunt, Country Traditionalist? It's Burning Within Him|website=Tasteofcountry.com|date=June 14, 2018 }}</ref> In the same interview, he said \"At some point his music will sound more like traditional country musician [[Tyler Childers]].\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/sam-hunt-tyler-childers-traditional/|title=Sam Hunt is Reaching Back to His Country Roots for New Music|website=Theboot.com|date=June 15, 2018 }}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nIn January 2017, it was announced that Hunt became engaged to Hannah Lee Fowler.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Chiu|first1=Melody|title=Sam Hunt Is Engaged to Hannah Lee Fowler|url=http://people.com/country/sam-hunt-engaged-hannah-lee-fowler/|publisher=People|access-date=2 January 2017}}</ref> Fowler, whom Hunt had been dating on-and-off since 2008, was the main inspiration behind his album ''[[Montevallo (album)|Montevallo]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Caldwell|first1=Lindsey|title=Meet Sam Hunt\u2014Country Music's Hottest New Star Dishes on Montevallo|date=October 27, 2014 |url=http://www.eonline.com/news/592065/meet-sam-hunt-country-music-s-hottest-new-star-dishes-on-montevallo|publisher=E! Online|access-date=2 January 2017}}</ref> Her name and their story are also referenced in his song \"[[Drinkin' Too Much]]\".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hudak|first1=Joseph|title=Hear Sam Hunt's Repentant New Song 'Drinkin' Too Much'|date=January 2017 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/hear-sam-hunts-repentant-new-song-drinkin-too-much-w458591|publisher=Rolling Stone|access-date=2 January 2017}}</ref> They were married on April 15, 2017, in Hunt's hometown of Cedartown, Georgia.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mizoguchi|first1=Karen|title=Sam Hunt Marries Hannah Lee Fowler in Intimate Georgia Wedding|url=http://people.com/country/sam-hunt-marries-hannah-lee-fowler/|publisher=People|access-date=15 April 2017}}</ref> Fowler filed for [[divorce]] in February 2022,<ref>{{Cite web |date=February 21, 2022 |author=Rachel DeSantis |title=Sam Hunt's Pregnant Wife Hannah Lee Fowler Files for Divorce, Alleges He Cheated on Her |url=https://people.com/country/sam-hunt-pregnant-wife-hannah-lee-fowler-files-for-divorce-alleges-infidelity/ |access-date=2022-04-23 |website=People |language=en}}</ref> but later retracted her petition in May of the same year.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-05-09 |title=Country Star Sam Hunt and Wife Hannah Lee Fowler Call Off Divorce |url=https://www.eonline.com/news/1330187/country-star-sam-hunt-and-wife-hannah-lee-fowler-call-off-divorce |access-date=2022-06-14 |website=E! Online}}</ref> In June 2022, Hunt announced the birth of their daughter,<ref>Cardoza, Riley [https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-moms/news/sam-hunt-confirms-hannah-lee-fowler-gave-birth-to-1st-child/ Sam Hunt's Wife Hannah Lee Fowler Gives Birth, Welcomes 1st Baby After Reconciliation], ''Us Magazine'' June 8, 2022</ref> and in December 2023, Hunt announced the birth of their son.<ref>Somers, Caitlyn [https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-moms/news/sam-hunt-wife-hannah-lee-fowler-welcome-baby-no-2-details/ Country Star Sam Hunt and Wife Hannah Lee Fowler Welcome Baby No. 2], ''US Magazine'' December 1, 2023</ref>\n\n===Legal issues===\nOn November 21, 2019, Hunt was arrested in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] after allegedly driving under the influence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.globalnews.ca/news/6199421/sam-hunt-arrested-dui-charges/amp/|title=Country singer Sam Hunt arrested on DUI charges in Nashville|date=November 21, 2019|website=Globalnews.ca|access-date=21 November 2019}}</ref> On August 19, 2021, Hunt was found guilty of his [[Driving under the influence|DUI charge]] that occurred nearly two years before. As a result of the conviction, his drivers license was suspended for one year; and he was sentenced to jail for a period of 11 months and 29 days, which was suspended except for 48 hours.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sam Hunt found guilty of DUI |date=August 18, 2021 |url=https://www.nbcnewyork.com/entertainment/entertainment-news/country-star-sam-hunt-pleads-guilty-to-drinking-and-driving/3228061/ |publisher=NBC New York |access-date=August 19, 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Sam Hunt discography}}\n\n*''[[Montevallo (album)|Montevallo]]'' (2014)\n*''[[Southside (Sam Hunt album)|Southside]]'' (2020)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{{main article|List of awards and nominations received by Sam Hunt}}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{Sam Hunt}}\n{{UAB Blazers quarterback navbox}}\n{{American Music Award for New Artist of the Year}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Hunt, Sam}}\n[[Category:Sam Hunt| ]]\n[[Category:1984 births]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American football quarterbacks]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country pop musicians]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:MCA Records artists]]\n[[Category:Middle Tennessee Blue Raiders football players]]\n[[Category:People from Cedartown, Georgia]]\n[[Category:Players of American football from Polk County, Georgia]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Georgia (U.S. state)]]\n[[Category:UAB Blazers football players]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Georgia (U.S. state)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Brett_Young_(singer)","to":"Brett Young (singer)"}],"pages":{"50439416":{"pageid":50439416,"ns":0,"title":"Brett Young (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{about|the country musician|his 2017 album|Brett Young (album){{!}}''Brett Young'' (album)|the pop musician|Ace Young}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Brett Young\n| image             = Brett Young in concert 2015.jpg\n| alt               = \n| caption           = Young in 2015\n| birth_name        = Brett Charles Young\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1981|03|23}}<ref name=\"baseballcube\">{{cite web |url=http://www.thebaseballcube.com/players/profile.asp?P=Brett-Young-1 |title=Brett Young |work=The Baseball Cube }}</ref>\n| birth_place       = [[Anaheim, California]]\n| origin            = \n| genre             = [[Country pop]]\n| occupation        = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument        = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| years_active      = 2007\u2013present\n| label             = [[BMLG Records|BMLG]]\n| website           = {{url|brettyoungmusic.com}}\n}}\n'''Brett Charles Young''' (born March 23, 1981) is an American [[country pop]] singer, songwriter and guitarist from Anaheim, California.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mastrogiannis|first1=Nicole|title=INTERVIEW: Five Things Brett Young Does When He 'Can't Sleep Without You'|url=http://wdsd.iheart.com/articles/entertainment-news-104651/interview-five-things-brett-young-does-14600267/|access-date=May 5, 2016|work=[[WDSD|94.7 WDSD]]|date=April 13, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160806013658/http://wdsd.iheart.com/articles/entertainment-news-104651/interview-five-things-brett-young-does-14600267/|archive-date=August 6, 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref> He was a college [[baseball]] [[pitcher]] but took up songwriting after an elbow injury.<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Littman|first1=Margaret|title=10 New Country Artists You Need to Know: March 2016|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-march-2016-20160301|access-date=May 5, 2016|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=March 1, 2016}}</ref> His [[Brett Young (EP)|self-titled debut EP]], produced by [[Dann Huff]], was released by [[Republic Nashville]] on February 12, 2016.<ref name=\"sounds\">{{cite news|last1=Laffer|first1=Lauren|title=Newcomer Brett Young Debuts Self-Titled EP|url=http://www.soundslikenashville.com/music/newcomer-brett-young-debuts-self-titled-ep/|access-date=May 5, 2016|work=Sounds Like Nashville|date=February 12, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Dukes|first1=Billy|title=Brett Young Is Nothing But Honest on New 'Brett Young' EP|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/brett-young-interview-ep/|access-date=May 5, 2016|work=Taste of Country|date=March 23, 2016}}</ref> The lead single, \"[[Sleep Without You]]\", was released on April 11th that year and he had a major success with a follow-up single, \"[[In Case You Didn't Know (Brett Young song)|In Case You Didn't Know]]\". He released his second major label album ''[[Ticket to L.A.]]'' in 2018, and the third, ''[[Weekends Look a Little Different These Days]]'', in 2021.\n\n==Early life==\nYoung was born in [[Anaheim, California|Anaheim]], Orange County.<ref name=\"baseballcube\"/> He attended Calvary Chapel High School in [[Costa Mesa, California]] and then went to the [[University of Mississippi]] (Ole Miss), [[Irvine Valley College]], and [[California State University, Fresno]] (Fresno State).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ivclasers.com/sports/bsb/alumni |title=Alumni |work=Irvine Valley College}}</ref><ref name=\"OC register\"/> He began singing in the late 1990s when he stepped in to replace a leader of a band who did not show up during a [[Christians|Christian]] worship meeting at high school.<ref name=\"OC register\">{{cite news |url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/young-79310-one-songs.html|title=Orange Pop: Former pitcher Brett Young is an ace as a singer |date=August 13, 2008|first=Robert |last=Kinsler |work=Orange County Register }}</ref>\n\nYoung was a pitcher on his high school baseball team and led the squad to a [[California Interscholastic Federation|CIF]] championship. He went to Ole Miss on a baseball scholarship in 1999 after turning down pre-draft selection by both [[Tampa Bay Rays|Tampa Bay Devil Rays]] and [[Minnesota Twins]].<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1999-jun-04-sp-44241-story.html |title=Calvary Chapel Has Rebels With a Cause - Baseball: Mossberg, Sterbens and Young, all headed to Mississippi, hope to lead Eagles to Division V title tonight |date=June 4, 1999|first=Mike |last=Terry |work=The Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/introducing-brett-young-part-1/|title=Introducing\u2026 Brett Young: Part 1 |first= Lauren|last= Laffer |date=April 6, 2016|work=Sounds Like Nashville }}</ref> In his one-season on the Rebel baseball team in 2000, he earned a varsity letter posting two wins and two saves. He then [[Letterman (sports)|lettered]] for one season at Irvine Valley before moving to Fresno State.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/fres/sports/m-basebl/auto_pdf/Stanford.pdf |title= Baseball Bulldog |date= February 10, 2003 |work= Fresno State University |access-date= December 1, 2016 |archive-date= December 2, 2016 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20161202165551/http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/fres/sports/m-basebl/auto_pdf/Stanford.pdf |url-status= dead }}</ref> However, his pursuit of a professional baseball career was cut short by an elbow injury while at college in Fresno in 2003.<ref name=kfrog /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2016/05/12/whos-new-brett-young/ |title=Who's New: Brett Young |first=Chris |last=Parton |date=May 12, 2016 |work=Nash Country Daily |access-date=December 1, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170810011605/http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2016/05/12/whos-new-brett-young/ |archive-date=August 10, 2017 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n==Music career==\nAccording to Young, he was inspired by [[Gavin DeGraw]] after he heard DeGraw's album ''[[Chariot (album)|Chariot]]'' as well as by singer-songwriter Jeremy Steele. Young decided to return to music.<ref name=\"OC register\"/> He independently released a self-titled four-song EP in 2007,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://myspace.com/brettyoungsmusic/music/album/-b-ep-2007-b-6525511 |title=Brett Young Music |work=Myspace |date=January 2007 }}</ref> ''Make Believe'' in 2011,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://play.spotify.com/album/25NSP90jHNeT0hotJY8NcN |title=Make Believe |work=Spotify}}</ref> followed by the albums ''Brett Young'',<ref>{{cite web |url=https://myspace.com/brettyoungsmusic/music/album/brett-young-19177818 |title=Brett Young |work=Myspace |date=23 December 2012 }}</ref> ''On Fire'',<ref>{{cite web |url=https://myspace.com/brettyoungsmusic/music/album/on-fire-18957794 |title=On Fire |work=Myspace |date=14 February 2013 }}</ref> and ''Broken Down'' in 2012\u201313.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://soundcloud.com/brettyoungmusic/sets/broken-down-acoustic-album |title=Broken Down |work=SoundCloud }}</ref>\n\nAfter being based for eight years in [[Los Angeles]], Young moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/brett-young-ep-2016/ |title=Country Stardom Wasn't Brett Young's First Career Choice |first= Gayle |last=Thompson |date=July 3, 2016 |work=The Boot}}</ref> He was soon signed by the [[Big Machine Label Group]] in August 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bigmachinelabelgroup.com/big-machine-label-group-signs-brett-young/ |title=Big Machine Label Group Signs Brett Young |work=Big Machine Label Group |date=August 21, 2015 |access-date=November 30, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603192710/http://www.bigmachinelabelgroup.com/big-machine-label-group-signs-brett-young/ |archive-date=June 3, 2016 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n===2016\u2013present: ''Brett Young'' EP and album===\n[[File:Brett Young in concert in July 2017.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Brett Young performing in 2017]]\nIn February 2016, Young released a six-song [[Brett Young (EP)|self-titled EP]].<ref name=kfrog>{{cite web |url=http://kfrog.cbslocal.com/2016/04/29/stagecoach-behind-the-artist-brett-young/ |title=Stagecoach Behind the Artist Brett Young |date=April 29, 2016 |first=Monique |last=Parra |work=K-FROG |access-date=November 30, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161201020106/http://kfrog.cbslocal.com/2016/04/29/stagecoach-behind-the-artist-brett-young/ |archive-date=December 1, 2016 |url-status=dead }}</ref> \"[[Sleep Without You]]\" was released as the first single from the EP in April 2016. He wrote the song with Justin Ebach and Kelly Archer.<ref>{{cite news|last=Thompson|first=Gayle|title=Story Behind the Song: Brett Young, 'Sleep Without You'|url=http://theboot.com/brett-young-sleep-without-you-lyrics/|access-date=May 5, 2016|work=The Boot|date=April 15, 2016}}</ref> The second single to be released from the album \"[[In Case You Didn't Know (Brett Young song)|In Case You Didn't Know]]\", was released on January 9, 2017 becoming Young's signature song. The song was his first to reach number one on the [[Country Airplay]] chart<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7816571/brett-young-first-country-airplay-no-1-chris-stapleton |title='Case' Closed: Brett Young Earns First Country Airplay No. 1 |date=May 31, 2017 |first= Jim |last=Asker |magazine=Billboard }}</ref> and it was certified Diamond by RIAA.<ref name=\"RIAA\">{{cite certification|region=United States|artist=Brett Young|access-date=March 1, 2021}}</ref> The album's third single, \"Like I Loved You\" released to country radio on July 17, 2017.\n\nOn February 10, 2017, Young released his self-titled debut studio album ''[[Brett Young (album)|Brett Young]]''. The album was produced by Dann Huff, and released through Big Machine Label Group. It debuted at number two on the [[Top Country Albums]] chart. Young tours with his band which includes lead guitarist Keaton Simons, drummer Billy Hawn, keys/guitarist Matt Ferranti, and bass guitarist Noah Needleman.\n\n===2018\u20132020: ''Ticket to L.A.''===\nIn December 2018, Young released his sophomore album ''[[Ticket to L.A.]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/brett-young-interview-new-album-ticket-to-la-gavin-degraw-766084/ |title=Brett Young Talks New Album 'Ticket to L.A.,' Gavin DeGraw Influence|first= Jon |last= Freeman |magazine=Rolling Stone |date= December 7, 2018}}</ref> The lead single for the album, \"Here Tonight\", which he co-wrote with Ben Caver, Justin Ebach, and [[Charles Kelley]] from [[Lady A]]  was released in September 2018.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/brett-young-here-tonight-today-show-768106/ |title=See Brett Young's Driving 'Here Tonight' on 'Today' |first=Jon |last=Freeman |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=December 12, 2018 }}</ref> It was number one on the Country Airplay in April 2019. The album's second single, \"[[Catch (Brett Young song)|Catch]]\" released to country radio on June 3, 2019.\n\n===2020\u2013present: ''Weekends Look a Little Different These Days''===\nIn April 2020, Young released the single \"[[Lady (Brett Young song)|Lady]]\", which he wrote about his wife and daughter.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/brett-young-lady/|title=Brett Young's 'Lady' Is a Song for His Daughter, and Her Mother|last=Stefano|first=Angela|date=May 1, 2020|accessdate=June 8, 2021|work=[[Taste of Country]]}}</ref> It is the lead-off single to his third studio album ''[[Weekends Look a Little Different These Days]]'', which was released on June 4, 2021.<ref name=\"SLN\">{{cite web|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/brett-young-announces-weekends-look-a-little-different-these-days/|title=Brett Young Announces 'Weekends Look a Little Different These Days'|last=Parton|first=Chris|date=April 27, 2021|accessdate=June 4, 2021|work=Sounds Like Nashville}}</ref> \"Lady\" reached number one on the Country Airplay chart in April 2021. The album's second single \"Not Yet\" was released in the same month. However, it was less successful, only peaking at number 37 on the Country Airplay chart. It was Young's first single to miss the Top 10, as well as his lowest-charting single to date and the first to miss number one since his 2016 debut single \u201c[[Sleep Without You]]\u201d. A third single \"[[You Didn't]]\" was released in November 2021. In October 2021, he released a Christmas album ''Brett Young & Friends Sing the Christmas Classics''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://entertainment-focus.com/2021/10/27/brett-young-brett-young-friends-sing-the-christmas-classics-review/ |title=Brett Young \u2013 'Brett Young & Friends Sing The Christmas Classics' Review |first=Pip|last= Ellwood-Hughes|date=October 27, 2021 |work=Entertainment Focus}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nIn February 2018, Young and his girlfriend Taylor Mills were engaged.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://people.com/music/brett-young-engaged-taylor-mills-proposal-details/ |title=Brett Young Is Engaged to Taylor Mills: All the Details on His Romantic Proposal |first=Sarah|last=Michaud|work=People|date=February 26, 2018|access-date=November 12, 2018}}</ref> They wed in [[Palm Desert, California]] on November 3, 2018. On April 6, 2019, they announced that they were expecting their first child in the fall 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://people.com/parents/brett-young-expecting-first-child-wife-taylor-pregnant/|title = Brett Young is Going to be a Dad! Country Star Expecting First Child with Wife Taylor}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://people.com/country/brett-young-marries-taylor-mills-first-photo/ |title=Brett Young Marries Longtime Love Taylor Mills in Stunning California Wedding \u2014 All the Details |first1=Melody|last1=Chiu|first2=Sarah|last2=Michaud|work=People|date=November 3, 2018|access-date=November 12, 2018}}</ref> Their daughter Presley was born on October 21, 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://people.com/parents/brett-young-welcomes-daughter-presley-elizabeth-first-photo/|title=Brett Young and Wife Taylor Welcome Daughter Presley Elizabeth: See Her First Photo|last1=Akoulitchev|first1=Octavia|last2=Michaud|first2=Sarah|date=October 24, 2019|access-date=October 24, 2019|work=People}}</ref> On January 27, 2021, they announced that they were expecting their second child in summer 2021.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://people.com/parents/brett-young-wife-pregnant-expecting-second-child-exclusive/|title=Brett Young and Wife Taylor Expecting Second Child: 'We Feel Very Blessed'|last1=VanHoose|first1=Benjamin|last2=Michaud|first2=Sarah|date=January 27, 2021|access-date=January 27, 2021|work=People}}</ref> Their second daughter Rowan was born on July 21, 2021.\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Brett Young discography}}\n* ''[[Brett Young (album)|Brett Young]]'' (2017)\n* ''[[Ticket to L.A.]]'' (2018)\n* ''[[Weekends Look a Little Different These Days]]'' (2021)\n* ''[[Across the Sheets]]'' (2023)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! News|date=12 July 2017 |access-date=12 July 2017|language=en-CA}}</ref>\n|-\n| [[Country Music Association Awards]] || New Artist of the Year || Himself || {{nom}} || <ref>{{cite web|title=CMA Awards 2017: Miranda Lambert Tops List of Nominees|url=http://people.com/country/cma-awards-2017-nominations-revealed/|website=PEOPLE.com|access-date=6 September 2017|date=4 September 2017}}</ref>\n|-\n| rowspan=\"5\" | 2018\n|Academy of Country Music Awards\n|New Male Vocalist of the Year\n|Himself|| {{won}} \n|<ref>{{cite of Country|date=26 March 2018 }}</ref>\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\" |[[2018 Billboard Music Awards|Billboard Music Awards]]||[[Billboard Music Award for Top Country Song|Top Country Song]]|| \"[[In Case You 2019}}</ref>\n|}\n<!--<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ajc.com/blog/radiotvtalk/chrisley-knows-best-season-finale-recap-still-chrisley-after-all-these-years/l6WRWIQqiPwJx07VYrq96L/|title='Chrisley (American season 23)|23rd season]] (Colton Underwood)\n|}\n\n==Notes==\n{{notelist-ua}}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{official singers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Mitchell_Tenpenny","to":"Mitchell Tenpenny"}],"pages":{"54684870":{"pageid":54684870,"ns":0,"title":"Mitchell Tenpenny","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Mitchell Tenpenny\n| image            = MitchellTenpenny.jpg\n| birth_name       = James Mitchell Tenpenny III\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1989|8|17}}\n| birth_place      = [[Nashville, Tennessee]]\n| genre            = [[Country pop]]\n| occupation       = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}}\n| years_active     = 2014\u2013present\n| label            = Riser House Records, [[Columbia Nashville]]\n| website          = {{URL|mitchell10penny.com}}\n| spouse          = {{marriage|[[Meghan Patrick]]|2022}}\n}}\n'''James Mitchell Tenpenny III''' (born August 17, 1989) is an American [[country pop]] singer and songwriter from [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. He has released three studio albums and five [[extended play]]s through Riser House Records, with the first being ''[[Telling All My Secrets]]'' released in December 2018. He charted in 2018 with the single \"[[Drunk Me]]\", released on [[Columbia Records]] Nashville. He also co wrote \"[[If the Boot Fits]]\" with [[Granger Smith]] and the song made it to the top 10 on country airplay.\n\n==Early life==\nTenpenny was born and raised in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cmt.com/news/1784017/mitchell-tenpenny-takes-his-turn-center-stage/ |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170718032217/http://www.cmt.com/news/1784017/mitchell-tenpenny-takes-his-turn-center-stage/ |url-status= dead |archive-date= July 18, 2017 |title=Mitchell Tenpenny Takes His Turn Center Stage | first=Samantha |last=Stephens |date=July 17, 2017 |work=CMT}}</ref>  His grandmother was music publishing executive [[Donna Hilley]].  According to Tenpenny, when he was 11, his grandmother introduced to him songwriters [[Bobby Braddock]] and [[Curly Putman]] and he became interested in songwriting.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2017/05/12/mothers-day-remembering-my-incredible-country-music-grandmother-donna-hilley.html |title=Mother's Day: Remembering my incredible country music grandmother Donna Hilley |first=Mitchell |last=Tenpenny|date= May 12, 2017 |work=Fox News }}</ref>  He grew up listening to country, rock, and R&B, and cited [[Vince Gill]], [[John Mayer]], and [[Michael Jackson]] among his musical influences.<ref name=\"rollingstone\"/>  He attended [[Lipscomb Academy]] in Nashville where he played football. He then enrolled at [[Middle Tennessee State University]] where he originally intended to play college football, but became more interested being in a band.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mitchell10penny.com/nashvilleborn-and-raised/ |title=Nashville Born and Raised |work=Mitchell10penny.com |date=5 January 2018 }}</ref> He graduated with a music business degree.<ref name=\"musicrow\">{{cite web |url=https://musicrow.com/2014/12/musicrowpics-mitchell-tenpenny/ |title=MusicRowPics: Mitchell Tenpenny |work=Music Row |date= December 18, 2014}}</ref>\n\n==Music career==\n\nTenpenny released his debut album, titled ''Black Crow'', in 2015. A track, \"Canes Creek\", featured the bluegrass band [[The SteelDrivers]].<ref name=\"rollingstone\">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/premieres/hear-mitchell-tenpenny-jam-with-the-steeldrivers-on-canes-creek-20150428 |title=Hear Mitchell Tenpenny Jam With the SteelDrivers on 'Cane's Creek' |first=Joseph |last=Hudak |date=April 28, 2015 |magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref>  His debut single was the title track of the album, \"Black Crow\".<ref name=\"nashcountry\">{{cite web |url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2015/05/04/whos-new-mitchell-tenpenny/ |title=Who's New: Mitchel Tenpenny |first= Tammy |last=Ragusa |date = May 4, 2015|work=Nash Country Daily }}</ref> In his early songwriting career, he wrote a number of songs with artists such as [[Nick Fradiani]];<ref>{{cite magazine |url= http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7461788/nick-fradiani-hurricane-american-idol-interview |title=Nick Fradiani Talks New Album 'Hurricane' & Writing His Own Music |date=August 5, 2016 |first= Fred|last= Bronson |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }}</ref> an early success is the Top 10 song he co-wrote \"[[If the Boot Fits]]\", recorded by [[Granger Smith]].<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7318592/makin-tracks-granger-smith-if-the-boot-fits-cinderella-country-update |title=Makin' Tracks: Granger Smith's 'If The Boot Fits' Embraces The Cinderella Story |date=March 31, 2016 |first= Tom |last=Roland |magazine=Billboard}}</ref>  He signed a publishing deal with Sony ATV Music Publishing Nashville,<ref name=\"musicrow\"/> and was involved in the documentary film ''The Voyage'' in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wakeboardingmag.com/blog/features/2014/05/14/the-voyage#page-5 |title=The Voyage |first= Brandon |last=Judd |date=May 14, 2014|work=WakeBoarding }}</ref> He was signed to a newly formed Riser Records in 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/money/real-estate/2016/09/09/music-rows-killen-building-sold-15m-cash/89987450/ |title=Music Row's Killen Building sold for $1.5M cash |first=Getahn |last=Ward|work=Tennessean.com |date= September 9, 2016 }}</ref>\n\nIn July 2017, Tenpenny released an EP, ''Linden Ave'', named after the street where his grandmother Donna Hilley used to live.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thecountrynote.com/in-the-news/mitchell-tenpenny-set-to-release-linden-ave-july-14/ |title=Mitchell Tenpenny's \"Truck I Drove In High School\" Takes Us Down Memory Lane |date=July 23, 2017 |first=Christina|last= Foster |work=The Country Note}}</ref> The EP charted at No. 10 on Billboard's [[Independent Albums]] chart, No. 6 in [[Heatseekers Albums]], and No. 12 in Country Album Sales, with 2,100 copies sold in its first week.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/search/charts?f[0]=ts_chart_artistname%3Atenpenny&f[1]=ss_bb_type%3Achart_item&type=2&artist=tenpenny |title=Mitchell Tenpenny |magazine=Billboard }}</ref><ref name=\"roughstock july 2017\">{{cite news |url=http://roughstock.com/news/2017/07/42078-top-10-country-albums-chart-july-24-2017 |title=Top 10 Country Albums Chart: July 24, 2017 |first= Matt |last= Bjorke  |date= July 24, 2017 |work=Roughstock }}</ref>\n\nIn January 2018, Tenpenny entered into a joint venture with Riser House/Columbia Nashville and released a self-titled EP on February 23, featuring a new single \"[[Drunk Me]]\".<ref name=\"hoffman\"/>\n\nHe released his second album and full-length major label debut album titled ''[[Telling All My Secrets]]'' on December 14, 2018.<ref name=\"carr\">{{cite web |url=http://theboot.com/mitchell-tenpenny-telling-all-my-secrets/ |title=Hear the Title Track of Mitchell Tenpenny's Debut Album, 'Telling All My Secret'|first=Courtney |last=Carr |date=October 10, 2018 |work=The Boot }}</ref>  It debuted at No. 5 on ''Billboard''{{'}}s Top Country Albums chart, and No. 53 on [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]],<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/country-albums/2018-12-29 |title=Top Country Albums |magazine=Billboard |date=December 29, 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/billboard-200/2018-12-29 |title=Billboard 200 |magazine=Billboard |date=December 29, 2018 }}</ref> after accruing 20,000 album equivalent units in its first week.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://sonymusicnashville.com/mitchell-tenpenny-achieves-countrys-biggest-new-artist-debut-of-2018/ |title=Mitchell Tenpenny achieves country's biggest new artist debut of 2018 |date=December 24, 2018 |work=Sony Music}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nTenpenny has been in a long-term relationship with fellow country singer [[Meghan Patrick]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/music/mitchell-tenpenny-meghan-patrick-neon-christmas-video/|first=Chris|last=Parton|title=Mitchell Tenpenny and Girlfriend Meghan Patrick Have a 'Neon Christmas' |work=Sounds Like Nashville|date=December 8, 2020}}</ref> On November 24, 2021, the two got engaged in the bar where they first met.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://tasteofcountry.com/mitchell-tenpenny-meghan-patrick-engaged/|title= Mitchell Tenpenny and Meghan Patrick Are Engaged|first=Courtney|last=Carr|date=November 26, 2021|work=Taste of Country}}</ref> Tenpenny and Patrick married on October 23, 2022.<ref name=\"marriage-1\">{{cite news |title=Country Stars Mitchell Tenpenny and Meghan Patrick Marry in Rustic Farm Wedding: See the Photos |url=https://people.com/country/mitchell-tenpenny-marries-meghan-patrick-wedding-photos/ |access-date=24 October 2022 |publisher=People |date=24 October 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" \n|+List of albums, with selected details, peak chart positions, sales and scope=\"row\"| \"Not Today\"<ref>{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/single-track-releases/ | title=Single/Track Releases }}</ref>\n| \u2014 || \u2014 || \u2014 || \u2015 || \u2015\n|\n|\n| ''The 3rd''\n|-\n| colspan=\"10\" style=\"font-size:85%\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n====As featured artist====\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+List of singles as featured artist, with selected peak chart positions and certifications shown\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Can't Go to Church\"\n| \u2014{{efn|group=upper-alpha|\"Can't Go to Church\" did not enter the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart, but peaked at number 24 on the [[Country Digital Song Sales]] chart.<ref name=\"CountryDigital\">{{cite magazine|url= https://www.billboard.com/artist/mitchell-tenpenny/chart-history/cdt/|title=Mitchell Tenpenny Chart History: Country Digital Song Sales|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=December 7, 2021}}</ref>}} || \u2014\n|\n| rowspan=\"2\" {{Non-album singles}}\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Here\"\n| \u2014{{efn|group=upper-alpha|\"Here\" did not enter the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart, but peaked at number 12 on the [[Country Digital Song Sales]] chart.<ref name=\"CountryDigital\"/>}} || \u2014\n|\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2021\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Bucket List\"\n| 45 || 15\n|\n* RIAA: Gold<ref name=\"RIAA\"/>\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Midtown Diaries''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"To Us It Did\"<ref>{{cite news|title=To Us It Did - Single by Mitchell Tenpenny|url=https://open.spotify.com/album/3DMERTbdgd3MG3lLTonBrZ?si=_Ty7zuqcT8aX6gw5Qff0RQ|work=[[Spotify]]|accessdate=May 8, 2021}}</ref> \n| \u2014 || \u2014\n|\n|-\n| colspan=\"11\" style=\"font-size:85%\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n==== Other certified songs ====\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n! scope=\"row\" | \"Bitches\"\n|\n* RIAA: Gold<ref name=\"RIAA\" />\n| ''Telling All My Secrets''\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|+List of music videos, with year of release and director name shown\n!
