artists]]\n[[Category:MNRK Music Group artists]]\n[[Category:1984 establishments in Tennessee]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Lady_A","to":"Lady A"}],"pages":{"14093399":{"pageid":14093399,"ns":0,"title":"Lady A","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music group}}\n{{for|the Seattle-based singer known as Lady A|Anita White}}\n{{redirect|Lady Antebellum|the group's debut album|Lady Antebellum (album){{!}}''Lady Antebellum'' (album)}}\n{{pp-move}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2015}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Lady A\n| image            = Lady A - Charlotte 12-27-12-39.jpg\n| landscape        = yes\n| caption          = Lady A performing in December 2012\n| background       = group_or_band\n| alias            = Lady Antebellum\n| origin           = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country pop]]}}\n| years_active     = 2006\u2013present\n| label            = {{hlist|[[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]]|[[Big Machine Records|Big Machine]]}}\n| website          = {{URL|ladyamusic.com}}\n| current_members  = * [[Hillary Scott]]\n* [[Dave Haywood]]\n* [[Charles Kelley]]\n}}\n\n'''Lady A''', known until 2020 as '''Lady Antebellum''',<ref name=\"namechange\">{{cite web |last1=Willman |first1=Chris |title=Country Group Lady Antebellum Drops 'Antebellum' from Name |url=https://variety.com/2020/music/news/lady-antebellum-drops-antebellum-from-name-lady-a-1234631601/ |website=Variety |date=11 June 2020}}</ref> is an American [[country music]] group formed in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 2006. The group is composed of [[Hillary Scott]] (lead and background vocals, piano, bass), [[Charles Kelley]] (lead and background vocals, guitar), and [[Dave Haywood]] (lead and background vocals, guitar, piano, mandolin). Scott is the daughter of country music singer [[Linda Davis]], and Kelley is the brother of pop singer [[Josh Kelley]]. The band abbreviated the name to \"Lady A\" in June 2020 during the [[George Floyd protests]] in an attempt to blunt the name's associations with [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]] and the [[Antebellum South]], inadvertently causing a dispute with Black blues and gospel singer [[Anita White]], who had been using the name Lady A for more than 20 years.\n\nThe group made its debut in 2007 as guest vocalists on [[Jim Brickman]]'s single \"[[Never Alone (Jim Brickman song)|Never Alone]]\", before signing to [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]]. Lady A has released six albums for Capitol: ''[[Lady Antebellum (album)|Lady Antebellum]]'', ''[[Need You Now (Lady Antebellum album)|Need You Now]]'', ''[[Own the Night]]'', ''[[Golden (Lady Antebellum album)|Golden]]'', ''[[747 (album)|747]]'', ''[[Heart Break (Lady Antebellum album)|Heart Break]]'', plus one Christmas album (''[[On This Winter's Night]]''), and one for [[Nashville Harbor Records & Entertainment]]: ''[[Ocean (Lady Antebellum album)|Ocean]]''. The first three albums are [[RIAA certification|certified platinum]] or higher by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). The albums have produced sixteen singles on the [[Hot Country Songs]] and [[Country Airplay]] charts, of which nine have reached number one. The longest-lasting number one single is \"[[Need You Now (Lady Antebellum song)|Need You Now]]\", which spent five weeks at that position in 2009; both that song and 2011's \"[[Just a Kiss (song)|Just a Kiss]]\" reached number one on the [[Adult Contemporary (chart)|Adult Contemporary charts]].\n\nLady A was awarded Top New Duo or Group by the [[Academy of Country Music]] and New Artist of the Year by the [[Country Music Association]] in 2008. The band was nominated for two Grammy Awards at the [[51st Annual Grammy Awards]] and two more at the [[52nd Annual Grammy Awards]], winning Best Country Performance by Duo or Group with Vocals for \"I Run to You\". It was awarded Top Vocal Group, Song of the Year (\"Need You Now\"), and Single of the Year (\"Need You Now\") at the 44th [[ACM Awards]] on April 18, 2010. It won five awards at the [[53rd Annual Grammy Awards]], including Song of the Year and Record of the Year for \"Need You Now\".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/13/AR2011021303447.html?hpid=top |title=Esperanza Spalding, Arcade Fire top a night of upsets at 2011 Grammys |first=Chris |last=Richards |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=February 14, 2011 |access-date=February 14, 2011}}</ref> At the [[54th Annual Grammy Awards]], Lady A won the award for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] for ''Own the Night''. By August 2013, the group had sold more than 12.5 million digital singles and 10 million albums in the United States.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/08/lady-antebellum-golden_n_3238728.html | work=Huffington Post | title=Lady Antebellum's 'Golden' New Album | date=May 8, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://riaa.com/goldandplatinum.php?content_selector=top-artists-digital-singles|title=RIAA \u2013 Recording Industry Association of America \u2013 September 30, 2014|website=Riaa.com|access-date=September 30, 2014}}</ref>\n\n==History==\n\n===2006\u20132007: Formation and early career===\nLady A was formed in 2006<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p997587/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Lady Antebellum biography |access-date=January 7, 2008 |last=Monger |first=James Christopher |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> by [[Charles Kelley]], [[Dave Haywood]], and [[Hillary Scott]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. Scott, a Nashville native, is the daughter of country music singer [[Linda Davis]], best known for collaborating with [[Reba McEntire]] on her 1993 single \"[[Does He Love You]]\",<ref name=\"cst1\"/> and Charles Kelley is the brother of pop and country artist [[Josh Kelley]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcaugusta.com/news/entertainment/18338164.html|title=EXCLUSIVE: Augusta's Josh Kelley And Lady Antebellum|date=April 28, 2008|work=NBC Augusta|access-date=September 17, 2009|archive-date=August 21, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821101629/http://www.nbcaugusta.com/news/entertainment/18338164.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> Scott attended [[Donelson Christian Academy]] in [[Donelson, Tennessee]]. Kelley and Haywood were [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] natives who went to middle school together. Kelley moved to Nashville in mid-2005 from [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina|Winston-Salem]], North Carolina, where he had been working construction with his brother John. Trying to become a successful solo country artist, Kelley convinced Haywood to relocate to Nashville in 2006 so they could write music together. Shortly thereafter, Scott recognized Kelley from Myspace, and they started to talk at a local music club. Kelley invited Scott to join him and Haywood in the new group, which assumed the name Lady Antebellum.<ref name=\"observe\">{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Price |title=Nashville dreaming gives singer a chance at country stardom |work=[[The Charlotte Observer]] |page=1E |date=April 22, 2008 }}</ref>\n\nOn the ''[[BBC Radio 2]] Drivetime Show'' August 9, 2010, the band explained that the name comes from when the group did a [[photo shoot]] in historical costumes at [[Antebellum architecture|antebellum houses]]. In American history, the [[Antebellum era]] was the period in the [[Southern United States]] before the [[American Civil War|Civil War]]. The trio then began performing at local venues before [[Capitol Records]] Nashville signed them in July 2007. In an interview with [[Sirius Satellite Radio]], Scott said she was rejected from participating in ''[[American Idol]]'' twice, not even making it past the first round.<ref name=\"cst1\">{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=744&t=Capitol_signs_Lady_Antebellum |title=Capitol signs Lady Antebellum |access-date=November 6, 2007 |date=July 5, 2007 |work=Country Standard Time.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120729110707/http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=744&t=Capitol_signs_Lady_Antebellum |archive-date=July 29, 2012 |url-status=dead |df=mdy-all }}</ref>\n\n===2007\u20132009: ''Lady Antebellum''===\n[[File:Lady Antebellum 2008.jpg|thumb|right|The band in concert in 2008, showing Charles Kelley and Hillary Scott]]\nShortly after the trio signed to the label, it was chosen by recording artist [[Jim Brickman]] to sing on his 2007 single \"[[Never Alone (Jim Brickman song)|Never Alone]],\" which reached No. 14 on the ''Billboard'' [[adult contemporary]] charts. In mid-2007, the group also wrote a song for the MTV reality television series ''[[The Hills (TV series)|The Hills]].''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=1034 |title=Lady Antebellum heads for \"The Hills\" |access-date=November 6, 2007 |date=July 5, 2007 |work=Country Standard Time.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120729110738/http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=1034 |archive-date=July 29, 2012 |url-status=dead |df=mdy-all }}</ref>\n\nThe solo debut single \"[[Love Don't Live Here (Lady Antebellum song)|Love Don't Live Here]]\" was released in September 2007, with a music video for the song following in December.<ref name=\"tv\">{{cite web|url=http://www.news2wkrn.com/mctv/?p=1370 |title=Lady Antebellum gets major label deal |access-date=November 6, 2007 |date=June 25, 2007 |work=Music City TV |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714181903/http://www.news2wkrn.com/mctv/?p=1370 |archive-date=July 14, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Neal |first=Chris |date=January 14, 2008 |title=Portrait of a Lady: The members of hot new trio Lady Antebellum kiss heartache goodbye in their new video |journal=[[Country Weekly]] |volume=15 |issue=1 |page=22 }}</ref> This song was the lead-off single to the band's [[Lady Antebellum (album)|debut album]]. Released on April 15, 2008, ''Lady Antebellum'' was produced by [[Paul Worley]] along with [[Victoria Shaw (singer)|Victoria Shaw]], a Nashville songwriter and former solo artist.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> \"Love Don't Live Here\" reached No. 3 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. The album itself was the first album by a new duo or group to debut at Number One on the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] charts.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.businesswire.com/portal/site/google/?ndmViewId=news_view&newsId=20080425005192&newsLang=en |title=Lady Antebellum Debuts with Record-Breaking Digital Sales |website=Businesswire.com |date=April 25, 2008 |access-date=February 15, 2011}}</ref>\n\nA second single, \"[[Lookin' for a Good Time]]\", was released in June 2008 and peaked at No. 11 in December. In addition, Lady A was signed as an opening act on [[Martina McBride]]'s Waking Up Laughing Tour in 2008.<ref>[http://ladyantebellum.musiccitynetworks.com/index.htm?inc=5&news_id=11318]{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>\n\nThe group also contributed the song \"I Was Here\" to the ''[[AT&T Team USA Soundtrack]]'', a song which peaked at No. 24 on the [[Bubbling Under Hot 100]] based on downloads. In December 2008, the rendition of \"[[Baby, It's Cold Outside]]\" peaked at No. 3 on the same chart. The band's third official single, \"[[I Run to You]]\", was released in January 2009. It eventually became the trio's first Number One in July 2009. On October 7, 2009, their debut album was certified platinum by the [[RIAA]] for shipments of one million copies in the United States.<!--stubby para-->\n\nHaywood and Kelley co-wrote labelmate [[Luke Bryan]]'s 2009 single \"[[Do I]]\", on which the group also sings backing vocals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ladyantebellum.com/?inc=5&news_id=15806|title=Charles & Dave Co-Writers On Luke Bryan's New Single, Hillary Sings Background Vocals|date=April 22, 2009|work=Lady Antebellum official website|access-date=April 28, 2009}}</ref> This song is the first single from Bryan's second studio album \"Doin' My Thing\", which was released on October 6, 2009.\n\n===2009\u20132011: ''Need You Now''===\nIn August 2009, the group released its fourth single, \"[[Need You Now (Lady Antebellum song)|Need You Now]]\", the lead-off single and title track to the [[Need You Now (Lady Antebellum album)|second studio album]], which was also produced by Worley. It debuted at No. 50 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart and became its second number 1 hit on the charts for the week of November 28, 2009, spending five weeks at number 1 on that chart. The song also reached No. 2 on the ''Billboard'' [[Billboard Hot 100|Hot 100]] and topped the [[Hot Adult Contemporary]] chart, making it a crossover hit. A second single, \"[[American Honey]]\", was released to radio on January 11, 2010, and would become its third No. 1 hit. The third single from the album, \"[[Our Kind of Love]]\", was released on May 31, 2010, and went No. 1 in September 2010. The song was notable for being written in collaboration with a non-Nashville songwriter [[busbee (songwriter)|busbee]], who at that point had previously written for [[Katy Perry]], [[Timbaland]] and [[Katharine McPhee]].<ref name=\"hitquarters\">{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_busbee.html |title=Interview with busbee |publisher=[[HitQuarters]]|date=April 4, 2011 |access-date=September 23, 2011}}</ref> The fourth single from this album, \"[[Hello World (Lady Antebellum song)|Hello World]]\", was officially released on October 4, 2010.\n\nThe album was released on January 26, 2010, and debuted at No. 1 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and [[Top Country Albums]] charts for the week of February 2, 2010, selling 480,922 copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/lady-antebellum-storms-the-charts-with-need-you-now- |title=Lady Antebellum storms the charts with ''Need You Now'' |website=Roughstock.com |last=Bjorke |first=Matt |access-date=February 8, 2010 |date=February 3, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100207005314/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/lady-antebellum-storms-the-charts-with-need-you-now- |archive-date=February 7, 2010 }}</ref> Four weeks after the album's release, it was certified platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]].<ref name=\"RIAA albums\">{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=Lady%20Antebellum&format=ALBUM&go=Search&perPage=50|title=Lady Antebellum certified albums|work=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|date=February 3, 2009|access-date=July 1, 2009}}</ref>\nOn April 28, 2010, the band performed on the results show of ''[[American Idol (season 9)|American Idol]]'', performing \"Need You Now\". On September 20, 2010, the band launched their first headlining tour, \"Need You Now 2010\" in [[Orlando, Florida]]. On October 28, 2010, they performed the National Anthem before Game 2 at the [[2010 World Series]]. They also appeared on the 44th Annual Country Music Awards on November 10, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/44th-annual-cma-awards/307881\n|title= Country Music Awards|date=November 4, 2010|magazine=TV Guide }}</ref>\n\nChris Tyrrel from [[Love and Theft (band)|Love and Theft]] was in college with Scott and they recconected when both were opening acts for [[Tim McGraw]]'s tour of early 2010. He filled in as drummer for a month in August 2010, they got engaged in July 2011, he became full-time drummer in October 2011, they wed in January 2012 and had a baby in July 2013 and twins in January 2018.\n\n===2011\u20132012: ''Own the Night'' and ''On This Winter's Night''===\nThe week of January 9, 2011, the group began recording the third studio album. In an interview with ''Entertainment Weekly'', Charles Kelley said, \"We actually just went ahead and decided we're gonna take two, two and a half months straight in the studio to create this thing and not have all this distraction. Hopefully that will be a good thing\".<ref>{{cite web|last=Stransky |first=Tanner |url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2011/01/13/lady-antebellum-third-album-recording-studio/ |title=Lady Antebellum hits studio to record third album: Charles Kelley on trying to follow up 'Need You Now' |website=Music-mix.ew.com |access-date=November 13, 2011}}</ref>\n\nOn May 2, 2011, the group released the first single from its upcoming album, titled \"[[Just a Kiss (song)|Just a Kiss]]\". The group performed the single on stage on ''[[American Idol]]''{{'}}s result show on May 5, 2011. It was a commercial and critical success, debuting and peaking at number 7 on the Billboard Hot 100, making it the band's highest debut on the chart. It also topped the Billboard Hot Country Songs, making it the band's fifth number-one single on the chart. On June 7, 2011, the title of third album was announced, ''[[Own the Night]]'', and was released on September 13, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ladyantebellum.com/news/lady-release-3rd-studio-album-own-night-sept-13 |title=Lady A to Release 3rd Studio Album, Own The Night, Sept 13 |publisher=Lady Antebellum |access-date=November 13, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007152112/http://ladyantebellum.com/news/lady-release-3rd-studio-album-own-night-sept-13 |archive-date=October 7, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref> The album cover and track listing was released on July 18, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ladyantebellum.com/news/lady-reveals-track-listing-cover-art-own-night |title=Lady A Reveals Track Listing, Cover Art for OWN THE NIGHT |publisher=Lady Antebellum |access-date=November 13, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110822124327/http://ladyantebellum.com/news/lady-reveals-track-listing-cover-art-own-night |archive-date=August 22, 2011 }}</ref> All together, four singles were released from Own the Night. Follow-up singles were \"We Owned the Night\", \"Dancin' Away with My Heart\", and \"Wanted You More\", which charted moderately in the Hot Country Songs.\n\nLady A released a \"Lady Hazed\" version of [[Jason Aldean]]'s song \"[[Dirt Road Anthem]]\" titled \"Country Club Anthem\" on its installment of Webisode Wednesdays on August 10, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bonaguro|first=Alison|title=OFFSTAGE: Lady Antebellum Take \"Dirt Road Anthem\" Detour|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/cmt-offstage/1668869/offstage-lady-antebellum-take-dirt-road-anthem-detour.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005061436/http://www.cmt.com/news/cmt-offstage/1668869/offstage-lady-antebellum-take-dirt-road-anthem-detour.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 5, 2013|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|access-date=December 6, 2011|date=August 11, 2011}}</ref>\nOn October 1, 2011, the group performed as the musical guests on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Mapes|first=Jillian|title=Lady Antebellum 'Own' Saturday Night Live: Watch|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/viral-videos/466998/lady-antebellum-own-saturday-night-live-watch|magazine=Billboard|access-date=December 6, 2011|date=October 3, 2011}}</ref>\n\nThe group released its first Christmas album ''[[On This Winter's Night]]'' on October 22, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ladyantebellum.com/news/lady-spreads-holiday-spirit-release-christmas-album-winters-night-out-oct-22nd |title=Lady A Spreads the Holiday Spirit with Release of Christmas Album On This Winter's Night, Out Oct. 22nd |publisher=Lady Antebellum |access-date=October 22, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002235930/http://ladyantebellum.com/news/lady-spreads-holiday-spirit-release-christmas-album-winters-night-out-oct-22nd |archive-date=October 2, 2012 }}</ref>\n\n===2013\u20132016: ''Golden'', ''747'', and hiatus===\nOn January 22, 2013, \"[[Downtown (Lady Antebellum song)|Downtown]]\", the first single from a new album, was released to country radio. It was made available on iTunes starting February 5, 2013, and reached number one on the [[Country Airplay]] chart in April 2013. The new album, ''[[Golden (Lady Antebellum album)|Golden]]'', was released on May 7, 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bialas|first=Michael|title=''Golden'' Touch: Lady Antebellum Reveals Details of New Album|url= https://www.huffpost.com/entry/igoldeni-touch-lady-anteb_b_2714241|access-date=June 11, 2020|newspaper=[[HuffPost]]|date=February 19, 2013}}</ref> The album's second single, \"[[Goodbye Town]]\", was released to country radio on May 13, 2013, and peaked at number 11 on the Country Airplay chart. The third single from the ''Golden'' era, \"[[Compass (Lady Antebellum song)|Compass]]\", was released to the [[iTunes Store]] on October 1, 2013, and reached number one on the Country Airplay chart in March 2014. It is one of the new recordings featured on the deluxe edition [[re-issue]] of ''Golden'', which was released on November 12, 2013. Unlike all of the band's previous releases, it was produced by [[Nathan Chapman (record producer)|Nathan Chapman]].<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Dauphin|first=Chuck|title=Lady Antebellum Point to 'Compass' as New Single|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/5740666/lady-antebellum-point-to-compass-as-new-single|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=October 2, 2013}}</ref>\nThey also sang backing vocals on [[Darius Rucker]]'s 2013 single \"[[Wagon Wheel (song)|Wagon Wheel]]\".<ref name=Conaway>{{cite news|last=Conaway|first=Alanna|title=Darius Rucker's New Album Will Feature 'Wagon Wheel' Duet With Lady Antebellum|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/darius-rucker-wagon-wheel-lady-antebellum/|access-date=September 29, 2012|newspaper=Taste of Country|date=July 11, 2012}}</ref>\n\n\"[[Bartender (Lady Antebellum song)|Bartender]]\" was released to country radio on May 12, 2014, as the lead single for the group's sixth studio album, and was made available to digital retailers on May 19.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lady A Releases \"Bartender\" for 1st Single From Upcoming Album!|url=http://ladyantebellum.com/news/210633|publisher=Lady Antebellum|access-date=May 13, 2014|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140513024739/http://ladyantebellum.com/news/210633|archive-date=May 13, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In July 2014, the album's title was confirmed as ''[[747 (album)|747]]'', and the track listing was confirmed. Chapman produced this album as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://roughstock.com/news/lady-antebellum-747-tracklist-cover-art/ |title=Lady Antebellum \"747\" Tracklist & Cover Art |last=Bjorke |first=Matt |date=July 18, 2014 |work=Roughstock |access-date=July 21, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728014450/http://roughstock.com/news/lady-antebellum-747-tracklist-cover-art/ |archive-date=July 28, 2014 |df=mdy }}</ref> \"Bartender\" became the group's ninth number 1 hit on the [[Country Airplay]] charts in 2014, with \"[[Freestyle (Lady Antebellum song)|Freestyle]]\" as the second single. The third single \"[[Long Stretch of Love]]\" was released on February 7, 2015, in the UK and on March 23, to country radio in the US.{{citation needed|date=May 2023}}\n\nThe band recorded two songs, \"I Did With You\" and \"Falling For You\", for the soundtrack of the 2014 romantic drama film ''[[The Best of Me (2014 film)|The Best of Me]]''.{{citation needed|date=May 2023}}\n\nIn October 2015, while appearing on ''[[Good Morning America]]'', the group announced some downtime after the Wheels Up Tour. During the break, Kelley will be working on his solo career. Kelley stated that the group is his priority but he wanted to try working alone. On September 28, 2015, he released his debut solo single, titled \"The Driver\".  It features [[Dierks Bentley]] and [[Eric Paslay]].<ref name=\"Solo Project\">{{cite web|author=<!--Not stated-->|title=Lady Antebellum to Take 'Family Time' After Tour; Charles Kelley Working on Solo Project|url=https://gma.yahoo.com/lady-antebellum-family-time-tour-charles-kelly-working-124300069--abc-news-music.html|website=Gma.yahoo.com|date=October 5, 2015|access-date=November 4, 2015|archive-date=October 16, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016233405/https://gma.yahoo.com/lady-antebellum-family-time-tour-charles-kelly-working-124300069--abc-news-music.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> On October 12, 2015, Charles Kelley announced his tour dates for his solo tour. He played some Lady A songs, but his tour focused on his solo material.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://tasteofcountry.com/lady-antebellum-charles-kelley-solo-tour-dates/|title = Lady Antebellum's Charles Kelley Announces Solo Tour|last = Reuter|first = Annie|date = 12 October 2015|access-date = 14 October 2015}}</ref>  Also during the break, Hillary Scott announced that she and her family (her [[Linda Davis|mother]], father, and sister) would work on a gospel album titled ''Love Remains''. The album was released on 29 July.\n\nIn 2016, Lady A was selected as one of 30 artists to perform on \"[[Forever Country]]\", a mash-up track of \"[[Take Me Home, Country Roads]]\", \"[[On the Road Again (Willie Nelson song)|On the Road Again]]\", and \"[[I Will Always Love You]]\" which celebrates 50 years of the [[CMA Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/scenes-cmas-historic-music-video-featuring-30-country/story?id=42129062|title=30 Country Music Stars Join Forces for Historic CMA Music Video|date=September 22, 2016|website=ABC News}}</ref>\n\n===2017\u20132018: ''Heart Break'' and label change===\nOn January 19, 2017, \"[[You Look Good]]\" was released as the lead single on the upcoming seventh studio album ''[[Heart Break (Lady Antebellum album)|Heart Break]]''. It released on June 9, 2017, and is further promoted with the \"[[You Look Good World Tour]]\", which began on May 26 and ended on October 15, 2017.<ref name=\"Lady Antebellum Back\">{{cite magazine|last1=Kaufman|first1=Gil|title=Lady Antebellum Back With New Single, 'You Look Good,' Prepping Album, Tour|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/7662267/lady-antebellum-back-with-you-look-good-single-prepping-album-tour|magazine=Billboard|date=January 19, 2017}}</ref> The [[Heart Break (Lady Antebellum song)|titular track]] was released as the second single on September 25, 2017. ''Heart Break'' was nominated for Best Country Album, and \"You Look Good\" was nominated for Best Country Duo/Group Performance at the [[60th Annual Grammy Awards]]. The band co-headlined the Summer Plays On Tour with Darius Rucker starting in mid-2018.\n\nIn August 2018, the group ended its recording contract with Capitol Nashville and signed with [[Big Machine Records]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/music/news/lady-antebellum-signs-with-big-machine-1202926700/|title=Lady Antebellum Signs With Big Machine|website=Variety|date=September 4, 2018}}</ref>\n\n===2019\u20132022: Las Vegas residency, ''Ocean'', and ''What a Song Can Do''===\nOn October 24, 2018, the band announced that it would be headlining a residency at the [[Palms Casino Resort]]'s Pearl Concert Theater in [[Las Vegas]] in 2019. The fifteen date Our Kind of Vegas residency began in February 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2018/10/24/lady-antebellum-las-vegas-residency-palms-2019/1756181002/|title=Lady Antebellum reveals 2019 Las Vegas residency|work=The Tennessean|last=Watts|first=Cindy|date=October 24, 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn March 2019, the band headlined the [[C2C: Country to Country]] festival in London and Dublin for the second time (having headlined in 2015) and for the first time in Glasgow. At the London show on March 9, the band announced new music and performed two new songs, \"What If I Never Get Over You\" and \"Be Patient With My Love\".\n\nThe first single on Big Machine, \"[[What If I Never Get Over You]]\", was released on May 17, 2019, along with the music video.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://celebmix.com/lady-antebellum-confirm-release-date-for-new-single-what-if-i-never-get-over-you-2/|title=Lady Antebellum Confirm Release Date for New Single 'What If I Never Get Over You'|date=May 10, 2019|website=CelebMix.com}}</ref>\nThe second single, \"Pictures\", was released on August 9, 2019. The eighth studio album ''Ocean'' was released on November 15, 2019. On September 20, 2019, the title track was released. \"Boots\" was released on October 11, 2019. The song \"What I'm Leaving For\" was also released ahead of the album on October 25, 2019. The album features a collaboration with [[Little Big Town]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/lady-antebellum-ocean-new-album/|title=Lady Antebellum's New Album Includes Little Big Town Collaboration|work=Taste of Country|last=Whitaker|first=Sterling|date=September 20, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/ladyantebellum/|title=Lady Antebellum (@ladyantebellum) \u2022 Instagram photos and videos|website=Instagram.com}}</ref>\n\nThe trio appeared on [[NBC]]'s ''[[Songland]]'' and released the song \"[[Champagne Night]]\" on April 13, 2020.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/9357821/lady-antebellum-champagne-night|title=Lady Antebellum Release 'Champagne Night' Following 'Songland' Appearance: Listen|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|last=Reuter|first=Annie|date=April 14, 2020|access-date=April 16, 2020}}</ref>\n\nOn January 21, 2021, the group became members of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] after being invited by [[Darius Rucker]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/lady-a-grand-ole-opry-members-1117861/amp|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|title=Lady A, the Country Trio, Are the Newest Members of the Grand Ole Opry|last=Hudak|first=Joseph|date=January 22, 2021|access-date=August 18, 2022}}</ref> On March 12, the band released the single \"[[Like a Lady (Lady A song)|Like a Lady]]\"; on October 22 of the same year, their ninth studio album (entitled ''[[What a Song Can Do]]'') was released.\n\nOn August 4, 2022, the group announced that it would postpone their Request a Line Tour until 2023 to support Kelley's sobriety.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.cmt.com/news/1ylsa3/lady-a-postpones-tour-to-support-bandmate-charles-kelley-on-sobriety-journey-were-family|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20220817195128/https://www.cmt.com/news/1ylsa3/lady-a-postpones-tour-to-support-bandmate-charles-kelley-on-sobriety-journey-were-family|url-status= dead|archive-date= August 17, 2022|title=Lady A Postpones Tours To Support Bandmate Charles Kelley on Sobriety Journey: \"We're Family\"|work=CMT|last=Goldstein|first=Tiffany|date=August 4, 2022|access-date=August 18, 2022}}</ref>\n\n===2023\u2013present: New music===\nOn July 17, 2023, Lady A teased a new song on their Instagram called \"Love You Back\".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Kelly|title=Lady A Post Snippet Of Unreleased Track That 'We're Pretty Amped Up About'|url=https://k102.iheart.com/content/2023-07-17-lady-a-post-snippet-of-unreleased-track-that-were-pretty-amped-up-about/ |website=K102|publisher=iHeartMedia, Inc.|date=July 17, 2023|access-date=July 19, 2023}}</ref>\n\n===Name controversy===\nThe band members have always said that the band's name was chosen arbitrarily, complaining about the difficulty of choosing a name. Inspired by the \"country\" style nostalgia of a photo shoot at a [[Antebellum architecture|mansion]] from the [[Antebellum South]], they said, \"one of us said the word and we all kind of stopped and said, man, that could be a name\"<ref name=\"Kings and Queen\">{{cite interview | title=Lady Antebellum: The Kings (And Queen) Of Country Pop | publisher=[[NPR]] | date=September 9, 2011 | interviewer=Scott Simon | first1=Hillary | last1=Scott | first2=Dave | last2=Haywood | first3=Charles | last3=Kelley | url=https://www.npr.org/transcripts/140312877 | access-date=June 16, 2020}}</ref> and \"Man that's a beautiful Antebellum house, and that's cool, maybe there's a haunted ghost or something in there like Lady Antebellum.\"<ref name=\"NYT name\"/> Haywood concluded, \"[We] had a lady in the group, obviously, and threw Lady in the front of it for no reason. I wish we had a great resounding story to remember for the name, but it stuck ever since.\"<ref name=\"Kings and Queen\"/> The name was always controversial, with a critic in ''Ms. Magazine'' writing in 2011 that the band's name \"seems to me an example of the way we still \u2014 nearly 150 years after the end of the Civil War, nearly 50 years after the Civil Rights Act; and in a supposedly post-racial country led by a [[Barack Obama|biracial president]] \u2014 glorify a culture that was based on the violent oppression of people of color\".<ref name=\"NYT name\">{{cite news | title=Lady Antebellum, Hit Country Trio, Changes Its Name in Wake of Protests | date=June 11, 2020 | first=Joe | last=Coscarelli | work=The New York Times | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/11/arts/music/lady-antebellum-name-change-lady-a.html | access-date=June 16, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"MsMag Harris\">{{cite news | title=Lady Antebellum and the Glorification of the Pre-Civil War South | date=February 17, 2011 | first=Tami | last=Winfrey Harris | url=https://msmagazine.com/2011/02/17/lady-antebellum-and-the-glorification-of-the-precivil-war-south/ | access-date=October 15, 2020}}</ref>\n\nOn June 11, 2020, joining widespread commercial response to the [[George Floyd protests]],<ref name=\"NYT name\"/> the band announced it would abbreviate its name to its existing nickname \"Lady A\" to remove the term 'Antebellum'.<ref name=\"Drop RS\">{{cite magazine | title=Lady A Drop 'Antebellum' From Their Name | first=Jon | last=Freeman | date=June 11, 2020 | magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/lady-antebellum-change-name-1013602/ | access-date=June 14, 2020 | quote=move forward as Lady A, the nickname our fans gave us almost from the start}}</ref><ref name=\"namechange\"/> The band members stated on social media that, never having previously sought the dictionary definition of the word \"{{linktext|antebellum}}\", they now consulted their \"closest black friends and colleagues\" so that their \"eyes opened wide to the injustices, inequality and biases black women and men have always faced and continue to face every day. Now, blind spots we didn't even know existed have been revealed.\"<ref>{{Cite news|title=Lady Antebellum Changes Its Name To Lady A|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/live-updates-protests-for-racial-justice/2020/06/11/875062248/lady-antebellum-changes-its-name-to-lady-a|access-date=2020-06-11|newspaper=NPR|date=June 11, 2020|language=en|last1=Tsioulcas|first1=Anastasia}}</ref> Fan response was mixed, with many decrying [[virtue signaling]] or even disparaging the protests.<ref name=\"NYT name\"/> ''[[American Songwriter]]'' said, \"Given that the world knows what that A stands for, to many this change does little more than add extra insult to this ongoing injury.\"<ref name=\"The Original\">{{cite web | title=The Original Lady A Responds to Lady Antebellum's Name Change | date=June 13, 2020 | first=Paul | last=Zollo | work=[[American Songwriter]] | url=https://americansongwriter.com/the-original-lady-a/ | access-date=June 13, 2020}}</ref>\n\nThe next day, it was widely reported that the name \"Lady A\" had already been in use for more than 20 years by Seattle-based African American activist and blues, soul, funk, and gospel singer [[Anita White]]. The band again admitted ignorance of any prior use, which White called \"[[social privilege|pure privilege]]\". Interviewed by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', White described the band's token acknowledgement of racism while blithely appropriating an African American artist's name: \"They're using the name because of a [[Black Lives Matter]] incident that, for them, is just a moment in time. If it mattered, it would have mattered to them before. It shouldn't have taken [[Murder of George Floyd|George Floyd to die]] for them to realize that their name had a slave reference to it. It's an opportunity for them to pretend they're not racist\". A veteran music industry lawyer observed that such name clashes are uncommon due to the existence of the Internet.<ref name=\"rollingstone-1013919\">{{Cite magazine|last1=Wang|first1=Amy X.|last2=Millman|first2=Ethan|date=June 12, 2020|title=Lady Antebellum Is Now 'Lady A.' But So Is a Blues Singer Who's Used the Name for 20 Years|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/pro/news/lady-antebellum-lady-a-country-blues-1013919/|access-date=June 13, 2020|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|first=Sandra | last=Gonzalez|title=Lady Antebellum is changing its name to Lady A|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/11/entertainment/lady-antebellum-name-change/index.html|access-date=2020-07-09|website=CNN| date=June 11, 2020}}</ref> The band members contacted White the next week to apologize for having inadvertently co-opted and dominated her name,<ref name=\"Apologizing\">{{cite web | work=[[USA Today]] | date=June 16, 2020 | first=Hannah | last=Yasharoff | title=Former Lady Antebellum will continue going by Lady A after apologizing to singer with the same name | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/music/2020/06/16/lady-antebellum-name-change-blues-singer-band-connect-lady-dispute/3197200001/ | access-date=June 16, 2020}}</ref> saying that the Black Lives Matter movement had inspired them to a collaborative attitude. They nonetheless required retaining the same name, though she believed dual-naming is inherently impossible.<ref name=\"Bury\">{{cite web | title=Seattle's Lady A to Lady Antebellum, 'We can't both be Lady A, you'll bury me' | author=| date=July 11, 2020 | url=https://komonews.com/news/local/seattles-lady-a-to-lady-antebellum-we-cant-both-be-lady-a-youll-bury-me | work=[[KOMO-TV|KOMO]]News | access-date=2022-02-05}}</ref> She said \"We talked about attempting to co-exist but didn't discuss what that would look like\"<ref name=\"Apologizing\"/> because the band members would not directly respond to that explicit question three times during the conversation or in two contract drafts. She soon submitted a counteroffer that either the band would be renamed, or that her act would be renamed for a $5 million fee plus a $5 million donation to be split between Seattle charities, a nationwide legal defense fund for independent artists, and Black Lives Matter.<ref name=\"Bury\"/>\n\nOn July 8, 2020, the band filed a lawsuit against White, asking a Nashville court to affirm its longstanding trademark of the name. The press release read: \"Today we are sad to share that our sincere hope to join together with Anita White in unity and common purpose has ended. She and her team have demanded a $10 million payment, so reluctantly we have come to the conclusion that we need to ask a court to affirm our right to continue to use the name Lady A, a trademark we have held for many years.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/lady-a-formerly-lady-antebellum-sue-seattle-blues-singer-lady-a/|title=Lady A, Formerly Lady Antebellum, Sue Seattle Blues Singer Lady A|work=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|last=Torres|first=Eric|date=July 8, 2020|access-date=July 9, 2020}}</ref>\n\nOn September 15, 2020, White filed a counter-suit asserting her claim to the Lady A trademark and rejecting the notion that both artists could operate in the same industry under the same brand identity. She is seeking damages for lost sales and a weakened brand, along with royalties from any income the band receives under the Lady A moniker.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/blues-singer-lady-a-sues-the-former-lady-antebellum/|title=Blues Singer Lady A Sues the Former Lady Antebellum|first=Allison|last=Hussey|website=Pitchfork|date=September 16, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-09-15| author=Rietmulder, Michael|author-link=Michael Rietmulder| title=Seattle's Anita 'Lady A' White files lawsuit to block country stars' use of name|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/music/seattles-anita-lady-a-white-files-lawsuit-to-block-country-stars-use-of-name/|access-date=2020-09-16|website=The [[Seattle Times]]|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nIn October 2021, musician [[Lilli Lewis]]'s album ''Americana'' was temporarily blocked and held for review by the streaming-service [[Spotify]] because one of the songs on the album, \"A Healing Inside\", credited White as \"Lady A\". The album was returned to the streaming within a week of Lewis becoming aware of the situation.<ref>{{Cite web| author=Spera, Keith|author-link=Keith Spera| title=Lady A controversy got New Orleans songwriter Lilli Lewis' 'Americana' deleted from Spotify|url=https://www.nola.com/entertainment_life/keith_spera/article_fa41d56a-471c-11ec-9f06-cf06a3b0b67d.html|access-date=2022-02-05|website=[[NOLA.com]]|date=November 16, 2021 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| publisher=Fox 8| last=Brooks|first=Jesse|title=Why was NOLA songwriter Lilli Lewis's album pulled off of Spotify for 3 days?|url=https://www.fox8live.com/2021/11/17/why-was-nola-songwriter-lilli-lewiss-album-pulled-off-spotify-3-days/|access-date=2021-11-21|website=www.fox8live.com| date=November 17, 2021|language=en}}</ref>\n\nIn February 2022, ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'' reported that White and the band had settled their lawsuit: \"the parties filed a joint request for dismissal to a judge in a federal Tennessee court\" and the \"terms of the settlement have not been disclosed\".<ref>{{Cite web|date=2022-02-01|title=Seattle singer Lady A and former Lady Antebellum band end lawsuits| author=Rietmulder, Michael|author-link=Michael Rietmulder| url=https://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/music/seattle-singer-lady-a-and-former-lady-antebellum-band-end-lawsuits/|access-date=2022-02-05|website=The [[Seattle Times]]|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Hussey|first=Allison|date=2022-02-01|title=Lady A Band and Singer Settle Lawsuit Over Shared Name|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/lady-a-band-and-singer-settle-lawsuit-over-shared-name/|access-date=2022-02-02|website=Pitchfork|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Charity==\nSince January 2012, Lady A has been partnered with the charity myLIFEspeaks, to raise awareness of and provide facilities for disabled orphans in [[Haiti]]. At the start of the year 2013, the members of the group also created the fund called LadyAID, which was created in hopes of bringing awareness to children who suffer and cannot help themselves locally, nationally and around the world. The main focus of LadyAID is the children in hospitals, mainly in the United States and Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ladyantebellum.com/charity |title=Lady Antebellum/Charity |website=Ladyantebellum.com |access-date=September 27, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120929081100/http://ladyantebellum.com/charity |archive-date=September 29, 2012 }}</ref><ref>Dauphin, Chuck. \"GOODWORKS.\" Ebsco Host. Ebsco Industries, 2014. Web. October 2, 2014.</ref>\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n[[File:LadyAntebellumAwardsApr10.jpg|thumb|right|Lady A in April 2010]]\n{{Main|List of awards and nominations received by Lady A}}\nSince Lady A won the Country Music Association Awards New Artist of the Year award in 2008, it has accumulated seven more awards, including its first [[Grammy Awards|Grammy]] in 2010 for Best Country Performance by Duo or Group with Vocals. At the 2009 CMAs, the group ended [[Rascal Flatts]]' six-year reign as Vocal Group of the Year. At the 2010 CMAs, the group became the first artist in CMA Award history to receive the Single of the Year honor for two consecutive years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pitchengine.com/miranda-lambert-causes-a-revolution-by-winning-three-at-the-44th-annual-cma-awards/100868/ |title=Miranda Lambert Causes a Revolution by Winning Three at \"The 44th Annual CMA Awards\" |publisher=Country Music Association |access-date=November 11, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715085231/http://www.pitchengine.com/miranda-lambert-causes-a-revolution-by-winning-three-at-the-44th-annual-cma-awards/100868/ |archive-date=July 15, 2011 }}</ref>\n\nAt the 53rd Annual Grammy Awards, the trio won the Song of the Year.<ref>Allen, Floyd. \"''[http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/112158/20110214/lady-of-antebellum-bags-song-of-the-year-trophy-at-2011-grammys.htm Lady Antebellum bags Song of the Year trophy at 2011 Grammys]  {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110218142628/http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/112158/20110214/lady-of-antebellum-bags-song-of-the-year-trophy-at-2011-grammys.htm |date=February 18, 2011 }}''\".  Published by the [http://au.ibtimes.com/entertainment International Business Times AU] {{Webarchive|url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20150402212515/http://au.ibtimes.com/entertainment |date=April 2, 2015 }}. Retrieved February 15, 2011.</ref> It won Top Vocal Group at the 2012 [[ACM Awards]] April 1, 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodlife.com/2012/04/01/acm-awards-winners-2012-list-academy-country-music-results/ |title=Academy Of Country Music Awards 2012 Winners List |website=Hollywoodlife.com |access-date=October 22, 2012 |archive-date=November 11, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111220805/http://hollywoodlife.com/2012/04/01/acm-awards-winners-2012-list-academy-country-music-results/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nIn addition to being honored, Lady A has made efforts to recognize veterans who have returned from service and contributed to their communities. In 2013, Lady A recognized eight deserving military families for their service by inviting them to up close and personal concerts, and acknowledging them from the stage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.easterseals.com/meet-eight-military-families-treated-to-private-lady-a-concerts/|title=Meet eight military families treated to private Lady A concerts|website=Blog.easterseals.com}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Lady A discography}}\n*''[[Lady Antebellum (album)|Lady Antebellum]]'' (2008)\n*''[[Need You Now (Lady Antebellum album)|Need You Now]]'' (2010)\n*''[[Own the Night]]'' (2011)\n*''[[On This Winter's Night]]'' (2012)\n*''[[Golden (Lady Antebellum album)|Golden]]'' (2013)\n*''[[747 (album)|747]]'' (2014)\n*''[[Heart Break (Lady Antebellum album)|Heart Break]]'' (2017)\n*''[[Ocean (Lady Antebellum album)|Ocean]]'' (2019)\n*''[[What a Song Can Do]]'' (2021)\n\n==Tours and residencies==\n{{Main|List of Lady A concert (2019)\n{{col-end}}\n\n==Filmography==\n\n===Television===\n{| class=\"wikitable sortable\"\n|-\n!
