|archive-date=July 10, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230710000031/https://northtexan.unt.edu/issues/2016-winter/hero-her-own-story |url-status=live }}</ref>\n| occupation         = {{flatlist|\n* Singer\n* songwriter\n}}\n| years_active       = 2002\u2013present\n| spouse             = {{marriage|[[Ryan Hurd]]|2018|2024|end={{abbr|div.|divorced}}}}\n| children           = 1\n| website            = {{URL|marenmorris.com}}\n| module             = {{Infobox musical artist\n| embed              = yes\n| genre              = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[country pop]]\n* [[pop music|pop]]<!-- releasing one crossover single with an EDM producer does not make her an EDM artist -->\n* [[contemporary R&B|R&B]]\n* [[Hip hop music|hip hop]]\n}}\n| instrument         = Vocals\n| current_member_of =  [[The Highwomen]]\n| label              = {{flatlist|\n* Mozzi Bozzi\n* Smith\n* [[Sony Music Nashville|Columbia Nashville]]\n* [[Columbia Records|Columbia]]\n}}\n}}\n}}\n'''Maren Larae Morris'''<ref name=huffpost>{{cite web |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/michael-bialas/hero-worship-maren-morris_b_10273058.html |title=Hero Worship: Maren Morris Can Begin Telling Her Musical Glory Story |work=[[Huffington Post]] |date=June 3, 2016 |author=Michael Bialas |access-date=September 5, 2022 |archive-date=January 13, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113040800/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michael-bialas/hero-worship-maren-morris_b_10273058.html |url-status=live }}</ref> (born April 10, 1990<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>) is an American singer and songwriter. Rooted in the [[Country music|country]] genre, her music blends in elements of [[Pop music|pop]], [[contemporary R&B|R&B]], and [[Hip hop music|hip hop]]. Morris has won multiple accolades including a [[Grammy Award]], an [[American Music Award]], five [[Country Music Association Awards]], and five [[Academy of Country Music Awards]].\n\nBorn and raised in [[Arlington, Texas]], Morris enjoyed singing as a child. She started publicly performing in her preteen years and toured throughout Texas. In her late teens and early twenties, she released three studio albums on independent record labels. She relocated to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], to pursue a career in country music during this same time period. Morris signed a publishing contract and later a recording contract following the streaming success of her 2015 self-titled EP.\n\nMorris's major-label debut studio album ''[[Hero (Maren Morris album)|Hero]]'' (2016) was released on [[Sony Music Nashville|Columbia Nashville]] and blended country with R&B. Its lead single \"[[My Church]]\" became her breakout [[Single (music)|single]] at country radio and was followed by the commercially successful songs \"[[80s Mercedes]]\", \"[[I Could Use a Love Song]]\" and \"[[Rich (Maren Morris song)|Rich]]\". In 2018, Morris collaborated with [[Grey (duo)|Grey]] and [[Zedd]] on the song \"[[The Middle (Zedd, Maren Morris and Grey song)|The Middle]]\". Released as a single, the track became a top ten pop success in various countries. She followed it in 2019 with her fifth album titled ''[[Girl (Maren Morris album)|Girl]]''. The album mixed country with various music styles and featured collaborations with different artists. It spawned the number one singles \"[[Girl (Maren Morris song)|Girl]]\" and \"[[The Bones (song)|The Bones]]\". Morris released her sixth studio album on March 25, 2022, titled ''[[Humble Quest]]''. The album earned Morris a [[Guinness World Records]] for most first-day and first-week streams for a country album by a female artist on [[Amazon Music]].\n\nIn addition to her solo work, she has recorded as a member of [[The Highwomen]] and in collaboration with her former husband, Ryan Hurd. Morris has had two albums certified for sales certifications in North America. She has scored three number one songs on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Country Airplay]] chart and eight top ten songs on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart.\n\n==Early years==\nMorris was born in [[Arlington, Texas]], to Greg and Kellie Morris.<ref name=\"EO\">{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/804979/meet-my-church-singer-maren-morris-from-american-idol-reject-to-5-time-cma-award-nominee|title=Meet ''My Church'' Singer Maren Morris: From American Idol Reject to 5-Time CMA Award Nominee|author=Dill, Jennifer|date=November 1, 2016|publisher=[[E!|E! News]]|access-date=April 9, 2018|archive-date=April 9, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180409172128/http://www.eonline.com/news/804979/meet-my-church-singer-maren-morris-from-american-idol-reject-to-5-time-cma-award-nominee|url-status=live}}</ref> She was named after actress [[Maren Jensen]], whose name Morris' mother came across while watching ''[[Battlestar Galactica (1978 TV series)|Battlestar Galactica]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d-e2jHXqT-4|title=Maren Morris on Touring With Her Son & the Origin of Her Name|work=The Bobby Bones Show|date=August 5, 2022|access-date=July 13, 2024}}</ref> She has a younger sister named Karsen.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Denton |first=Korey |title=The Stunning Transformation Of Maren Morris |url=https://www.thelist.com/245823/the-stunning-transformation-of-maren-morris/ |access-date=July 9, 2023 |website=[[The List (magazine)|The List]] |date=September 11, 2020 |archive-date=July 10, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230710002648/https://www.thelist.com/245823/the-stunning-transformation-of-maren-morris/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Her parents owned the Maren Karsen Aveda Hair Salon, which is still in operation today in Arlington. Morris spent much of her childhood at the salon. She later worked there as a front desk clerk and guest coordinator.<ref name=\"Arlington\">{{cite web |title=Billboard Magazine sings praises of Maren Morris, namesake of Downtown Arlington salon |url=https://downtownarlington.org/post/billboard-magazine-sings-praises-of-maren-morris-namesake-of-downtown-arlington-salon |website=Downtown Arlington |access-date=February 12, 2022 |archive-date=February 12, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220212233136/https://downtownarlington.org/post/billboard-magazine-sings-praises-of-maren-morris-namesake-of-downtown-arlington-salon |url-status=live }}</ref> In her elementary years, she participated in the school choir, performed theater and played soccer.<ref name=\"Rolling Stone\">{{cite magazine |last1=Levy |first1=Joe |title=Meet Maren Morris: How a Nineties Pop Fan Became Country's Breakout Star |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=June 2, 2016 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/meet-maren-morris-how-a-nineties-pop-fan-became-countrys-breakout-star-38174/ |access-date=February 12, 2022 |archive-date=February 12, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220212233135/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/meet-maren-morris-how-a-nineties-pop-fan-became-countrys-breakout-star-38174/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Morris discovered she could sing one day at a party at her parents' salon. At the event, she performed [[karaoke]] versions of songs by [[Patsy Cline]] and [[LeAnn Rimes]]. Impressed by her natural singing ability, Greg Morris started encouraging his daughter to perform regularly.<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\">{{cite news |last1=Gage |first1=Jeff |title='This Is Not Just Country': Maren Morris On Her Jump From DFW Bar Singer to Headlining Star |url=https://www.dallasobserver.com/music/the-true-story-of-country-music-star-maren-morris-rise-from-dfw-bars-to-nashville-royalty-9348705 |access-date=February 12, 2022 |work=[[Dallas Observer]] |date=April 11, 2017 |archive-date=February 12, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220212233135/https://www.dallasobserver.com/music/the-true-story-of-country-music-star-maren-morris-rise-from-dfw-bars-to-nashville-royalty-9348705 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nAmong her first performances was at Johnnie High's, a country music revue similar in style to the ''[[Grand Ole Opry]]''. From that moment, Morris realized that \"this [singing] is my calling\".<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\"/> When she was 12, her father bought her a guitar which inspired her to start writing songs.<ref name=\"SLN\">{{cite web |last1=Lenehan Vaughn |first1=Grace |title=10 Things You May Not Know About Maren Morris |url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/10-things-you-may-not-know-about-maren-morris/ |website=Sounds Like Nashville |date=October 27, 2020 |access-date=February 12, 2022 |archive-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220213000141/https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/10-things-you-may-not-know-about-maren-morris/ |url-status=live }}</ref> At the same time, Morris continued going through public school. She attended [[Bowie High School (Arlington, Texas)|James Bowie High School]] in Arlington where she continued playing soccer. Her favorite classes were creative writing and art.<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\"/>\n\n==Career==\n===2002\u20132015: Career beginnings in Texas, move to Nashville and songwriting===\nMorris started touring her home state of Texas when she was 11 years old. Her father acted as her manager and booking agent.<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\"/> Morris often played the cities of [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]] and [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth]], where she played bars and clubs.<ref name=\"SLN\"/><ref name=\"Dallas Observer 2\">{{cite news |last1=McCarthy |first1=Amy |title=Maren Morris Forged Her Own Path From Texas to Nashville and Country Stardom |url=https://www.dallasobserver.com/music/maren-morris-forged-her-own-path-from-texas-to-nashville-and-country-stardom-7834607 |access-date=February 13, 2022 |work=[[Dallas Observer]] |date=December 7, 2015 |archive-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220213222025/https://www.dallasobserver.com/music/maren-morris-forged-her-own-path-from-texas-to-nashville-and-country-stardom-7834607 |url-status=live }}</ref> \"Music was always this weekend job that I had while the rest of my friends were going to slumber parties,\" she recounted.<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\"/>\n\nIn 2005, she took her first plane trip alone to attend a [[Grammy Awards|Grammy]] camp.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Rodman |first1=Sarah |title=Maren Morris on her five Grammy nominations and her new song (and album!) 'Girl' |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=February 8, 2019 |url=https://ew.com/grammys/2019/02/08/maren-morris-five-grammy-nominations-new-song-album-girl/ |access-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220213222024/https://ew.com/grammys/2019/02/08/maren-morris-five-grammy-nominations-new-song-album-girl/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Morris was one of several high school students from across the country selected to attend the camp sponsored by the [[The Recording Academy|Grammy Foundation]]. She got to meet music industry insiders at music workshops.<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\"/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Savage |first1=Mark |title=Maren Morris: From Grammy Camp to Grammy winner |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-39229071 |access-date=19 September 2022 |work=[[BBC]] |date=March 12, 2017 |archive-date=September 20, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220920231343/https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-39229071 |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2005, at the age of 15, Morris released her debut [[studio album]] titled ''Walk On''.<ref name=\"Allmusic\">{{cite web |last1=Erlewine |first1=Stephen Thomas |title=Maren Morris Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/maren-morris-mn0000328633/biography |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220213/https://www.allmusic.com/artist/maren-morris-mn0000328633/biography |url-status=live }}</ref> The disc was released on the independent Mozzi Bozzi label and contained ten tracks of mostly self written material.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Morris |first1=Maren |title=''Walk On'' (CD Booklet) |journal=Mozzi Blozzi Music |date=June 14, 2005 |id=5254}}</ref> The record was financed by her parents who \"literally sold the furniture out of the house\" to pay for its recording and release, according to her mother Kellie Morris.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Thompson |first1=Gayle |title=Maren Morris' Mother Reveals What She Is Most Proud of in Her Famous Daughter |url=https://popculture.com/country-music/news/maren-morris-mother-reveals-most-proud-of-in-famous-daughter/ |website=popculture. |access-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220213222028/https://popculture.com/country-music/news/maren-morris-mother-reveals-most-proud-of-in-famous-daughter/ |url-status=live }}</ref>  Smith Music released Morris's second studio album in 2007, titled ''All That It Takes''.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> The project was similar to her first record because it contained mostly self-composed tracks.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Morris |first1=Maren |title=''All That It Takes'' (CD Booklet) |journal=Mozzi Bozzi Music/Smith Music |date=October 22, 2007 |id=7073}}</ref>\n\nIn her late teens, Morris auditioned for a series of television music competition programs including ''[[American Idol]]'', ''[[America's Got Talent]]'', ''[[The Voice (American TV series)|The Voice]]'', and ''[[Nashville Star]]''.<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\"/> She was rejected after auditioning for all of the television shows. Years later, Morris's songs would be used by contestants performing in the show.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Donovan |first1=Blair |title=Maren Morris Was Actually Rejected From 'The Voice' and 'American Idol' |journal=[[Country Living]] |date=March 23, 2019 |url=https://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/a26908000/maren-morris-the-voice-american-idol-rejection/ |access-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220213222034/https://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/a26908000/maren-morris-the-voice-american-idol-rejection/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Morris also joined a teen band in her teenage years called They Were Stars, with whom she played [[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]] and provided harmony vocals.<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\"/> After graduating high school, Morris briefly enrolled at the [[University of North Texas]]<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> but left after one semester.<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\"/> In 2011, the Mozzi Bozzi label released her third studio disc titled ''Live Wire''.<ref name=\"Live Wire\">{{cite journal |last1=Morris |first1=Maren |title=''Live Wire'' (CD Booklet) |journal=Mozzi Bozzi Music |date=2011 |id=MBR-040102}}</ref>\n\nDuring this time, she paid a visit to a friend, [[Kacey Musgraves]], whom she had first met on the Texas music scene. Musgraves, who was living in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], encouraged Morris to also make the move. After saving enough money, Morris packed a [[U-Haul]] trailer and moved to Nashville.<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\"/> Morris spent her first year in Nashville networking and meeting other writers. She was later introduced to Carla Wallace of Big Yellow Dog Music. Impressed by her songwriting, Wallace signed her to a four-year songwriting contract with the company. She began co-writing material with other songwriters,<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\"/> and her material was soon recorded by several country artists. This began with [[Tim McGraw]], who recorded \"Last Turn Home\" for his 2014 album ''[[Sundown Heaven Town]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/sundown-heaven-town-mw0002703821|title=Sundown Heaven Town - Tim McGraw - Songs, Reviews, Credits - AllMusic|website=AllMusic|access-date=April 17, 2020|archive-date=November 2, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201102110645/https://www.allmusic.com/album/sundown-heaven-town-mw0002703821|url-status=live}}</ref> Another track, \"Second Wind\" was recorded by [[Kelly Clarkson]] for her 2015 album ''[[Piece by Piece (Kelly Clarkson album)|Piece by Piece]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.bigyellowdogmusic.com/news/maren-morris-lands-a-cut-on-kelly-clarkson-s-new-album-piece-by-piece/72/show |title={title} |access-date=December 7, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161013191220/http://bigyellowdogmusic.com/news/maren-morris-lands-a-cut-on-kelly-clarkson-s-new-album-piece-by-piece/72/show |archive-date=October 13, 2016 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nSome of her material was more personal, and Morris was encouraged by Wallace to start recording music herself. Among her personal compositions was the track \"[[My Church]]\", which she wrote in March 2015. After listening to the [[demo (music)|demo recording]], Morris realized she wanted to shelve the song for herself.<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\"/> It was also around this time that she met record producer [[Busbee]]. He was impressed by Morris's writing and vocal delivery, later commenting, \"She was singing her own music, and it was world class. I was super freaked out \u2014 in a good way.\"<ref name=\"Busbee\">{{cite magazine |last1=Hudak |first1=Joseph |title=Busbee, Producer for Maren Morris and Lady Antebellum, Dead at 43 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=September 29, 2019 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/busbee-producer-dead-obit-maren-morris-890062/ |access-date=19 September 2022 |archive-date=September 20, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220920171620/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/busbee-producer-dead-obit-maren-morris-890062/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n===2016\u20132017: Breakthrough with ''Hero''===\nMorris initially self-released five songs on eponymous [[extended play]], ''Maren Morris''. It was released on [[Spotify]] in August 2015.<ref name=\"Us Weekly\">{{cite magazine |last1=Nardino |first1=Meredith |title=Maren Morris' Most Critical Quotes About the Country Music Industry: There's Always 'Room to Grow' |magazine=[[Us Weekly]] |date=April 10, 2021 |url=https://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/pictures/maren-morris-most-critical-quotes-about-the-country-music-industry/ |access-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-date=February 12, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220212182221/https://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/pictures/maren-morris-most-critical-quotes-about-the-country-music-industry/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The songs gained 2.5 million streams on Spotify in a month, with three songs appearing on Spotify's US and Global \"Viral 50\" chart. The success of Morris' EP attracted the interest of major labels, and she was signed to [[Sony Music Nashville|Columbia Nashville]] in September 2015.<ref name=\"Music Row\">{{cite web |url=http://www.musicrow.com/2015/09/sony-music-nashville-signs-singer-songwriter-maren-morris/ |title=Sony Music Nashville Signs Singer-Songwriter Maren Morris |work=Music Row |author=Jessica Nicholson |date=September 10, 2015 |access-date=August 11, 2016 |archive-date=September 13, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160913230645/http://www.musicrow.com/2015/09/sony-music-nashville-signs-singer-songwriter-maren-morris/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=\"leahey\" /> The label re-released the five-song EP in November 2015. \"[[My Church]]\" was issued as the project's the lead single.<ref name=\"The Oswegonian\">{{cite journal |first=Riley |last=Ackley |title=Weekly EP: country newbie sparkles |url=http://www.oswegonian.com/2015/11/12/weekly-ep-country-newbie-sparkles/ |journal=[[The Oswegonian]] |access-date=November 18, 2015 |date=November 12, 2015 |archive-date=February 21, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160221113241/http://www.oswegonian.com/2015/11/12/weekly-ep-country-newbie-sparkles/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The EP charted at number 22 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums|Country Albums]] chart<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Maren Morris chart history (Country Albums) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-date=February 14, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220214235045/https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and number one on the [[Top Heatseekers]] chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Maren Morris chart history (Heatseekers) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=February 13, 2022 |archive-date=February 14, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220214235045/https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nIn 2016, \"My Church\" became Morris's first major hit single. It peaked at number five on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs|country songs]] chart,<ref name=\"Country Songs\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/chart-history/csi/|title=Maren Morris Chart History (Hot Country Songs)|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=October 10, 2017|archive-date=November 18, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211118035418/https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/chart-history/csi/|url-status=live}}</ref> number nine on the same publication's [[Country Airplay]] chart.<ref name=\"Country Airplay\">{{cite magazine |title=Maren Morris chart history (Country Airplay) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/chart-history/csa/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=March 4, 2022 |archive-date=March 4, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220304231122/https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/chart-history/csa/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and number three on the [[Canada Country]] chart.<ref name=\"Canada Country\">{{cite magazine |title=Maren Morris chart history (Canada Country) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/chart-history/csa/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=March 4, 2022 |archive-date=March 4, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220304231122/https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/chart-history/csa/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Morris later won [[Grammy Award for Best Country Solo Performance|Best Country Solo Performance]] for the song at the [[60th Annual Grammy Awards]].<ref name=\"Grammys\">{{cite web |title=Maren Morris: Artist |url=https://www.grammy.com/artists/maren-morris/19894 |website=[[Grammy Awards]] |access-date=March 4, 2022 |archive-date=March 4, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220304231115/https://www.grammy.com/artists/maren-morris/19894 |url-status=live }}</ref> Her first Columbia Nashville album was released in June 2016 titled ''[[Hero (Maren Morris album)|Hero]]''.<ref name=\"Dallas Observer\"/> It reached number five on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], and number one on the [[Top Country Albums|country albums]] chart.<ref name=\"2016 Billboard\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7401269/drake-views-billboard-200-paul-simon-stranger-to-stranger|first=Keith|last=Caulfield|title=Drake's 'Views' Album No. 1 for Sixth Week on Billboard 200, Paul Simon Debuts at No. 3|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=June 2, 2016|access-date=April 17, 2020|archive-date=June 14, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160614120246/http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7401269/drake-views-billboard-200-paul-simon-stranger-to-stranger|url-status=live}}</ref> Joe Caramanica of ''[[The New York Times]]'' called ''Hero'' \"both utterly of its moment and also savvy enough to indicate how the future might sound.\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Caramanica |first1=Joe |title=Review: Why 'Hero' Is an Outstanding Country Music Debut |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/02/arts/music/maren-morris-hero-review.html |access-date=March 4, 2022 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 1, 2016 |archive-date=February 22, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180222104833/https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/02/arts/music/maren-morris-hero-review.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Three more singles were spawned from ''Hero'': \"[[80's Mercedes]]\", \"[[I Could Use a Love Song]]\" and \"[[Rich (Maren Morris song)|Rich]]\". With the exception of \"80's Mercedes\", the singles reached the top ten of the ''Billboard'' country charts between 2016 and 2018.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>\n\nWith newfound commercial success, Morris embarked on a tour with [[Keith Urban]] in 2016.<ref name=\"leahey\">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/maren-morris-plots-hero-album-release-20160314 |title=Maren Morris Plots 'Hero' Album Release |first=Andrew |last=Leahey |date=March 14, 2016 |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=September 4, 2017 |archive-date=September 19, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160919100748/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/maren-morris-plots-hero-album-release-20160314 |url-status=dead }}</ref> This was followed by 2017's headlining \"Hero\" tour to support her album.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/maren-morris-announces-headlining-hero-tour-w445627|title=Maren Morris Announces Headlining Hero Tour|newspaper=Rolling Stone|access-date=February 9, 2017|archive-date=February 11, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211075418/http://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/maren-morris-announces-headlining-hero-tour-w445627|url-status=dead}}</ref> A deluxe edition of ''Hero'' was released in March 2017, featuring three new recordings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/maren-morris-to-release-expanded-version-of-hero-album/|title=Maren Morris To Release Expanded Version of 'HERO' Album|date=March 13, 2017|work=Sounds Like Nashville|access-date=March 13, 2017|language=en-US|archive-date=March 14, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314153437/http://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/maren-morris-to-release-expanded-version-of-hero-album/|url-status=live}}</ref> She also provided vocals to [[Thomas Rhett]]'s \"[[Craving You]]\" in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Whitaker|first1=Sterling|title=Thomas Rhett and Maren Morris Are 'Craving You' on New Single|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/thomas-rhett-craving-you-new-single-maren-morris/|website=Taste of Country|date=March 24, 2017|access-date=February 6, 2018|archive-date=August 19, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170819232922/http://tasteofcountry.com/thomas-rhett-craving-you-new-single-maren-morris/|url-status=live}}</ref> Morris was also featured on [[Niall Horan]]'s pop song \"[[Seeing Blind]]\" in 2017<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Kaufman|first1=Gil|title=Niall Horan Landed Maren Morris For a Duet By Sending an Email|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7897914/niall-horan-maren-morris-duet-seeing-blind-details|magazine=Billboard|date=August 10, 2017|access-date=February 5, 2018|archive-date=November 24, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171124023442/https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7897914/niall-horan-maren-morris-duet-seeing-blind-details|url-status=live}}</ref> and later opened for Horan on his [[Flicker World Tour]].<ref name=\"NiallTour\">{{Cite web |url=http://theboot.com/maren-morris-niall-horan-2018-tour/ |title=Maren Morris Opening for Niall Horan on 2018 Flicker World Tour |last=Carr |first=Courtney |website=The Boot |date=September 22, 2017 |access-date=February 5, 2018 |archive-date=September 7, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180907110416/http://theboot.com/maren-morris-niall-horan-2018-tour/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In response to the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting]], Morris released \"[[Dear Hate]]\", a song she had written and recorded with [[Vince Gill]], with all proceeds from the track going to the Music City Cares Fund.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McKenna|first1=Brittney|title=Maren Morris' 'Dear Hate' Offers Heartfelt Response To Las Vegas Shooting|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/10/04/555616338/songs-we-love-maren-morris-dear-hate-feat-vince-gill|website=NPR.org|date=October 4, 2017|access-date=February 5, 2018|language=en|archive-date=February 5, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180205121007/https://www.npr.org/2017/10/04/555616338/songs-we-love-maren-morris-dear-hate-feat-vince-gill|url-status=live}}</ref> Morris continued earning awards for her success including the \"Best New Artist\" accolade from the [[Country Music Association]] and several more Grammy nominations.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>\n\n===2018\u2013present: Pop crossover, new collaborations and continued country success===\n[[File:Zedd 2014 Divergent Premiere (cropped).jpg|150px|thumb|left|Maren Morris was a featured vocalist on [[Zedd]]'s 2018 single \"[[The Middle (Zedd, Maren Morris and Grey song)|The Middle]]\".]]\nIn 2018, Morris was chosen by [[Zedd]] and [[Grey (musical duo)|Grey]] to appear as the lead vocalist on their pop single \"[[The Middle (Zedd, Maren Morris and Grey song)|The Middle]]\". Zedd traveled to Nashville to record Morris's part and the song was released following that.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Hughes |first1=Hilary |title=Zedd, Maren Morris & Their Collaborators Deconstruct 'The Middle' in New Video: Watch |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/zedd-maren-morris-the-middle-diary-of-a-song-8366470/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=March 4, 2022 |archive-date=March 4, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220304232346/https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/zedd-maren-morris-the-middle-diary-of-a-song-8366470/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The track became her breakout pop crossover single and expanded her audience.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> \"The Middle\" reached the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] top ten, peaking at number five.<ref name=\"middle-billboard\">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-100/2018-04-28 |title=The Hot 100 |date=April 28, 2018 |magazine=Billboard |access-date=May 10, 2018 |archive-date=June 13, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180613070613/https://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-100/2018-04-28 |url-status=live }}</ref> Taylor Weatherby of ''Billboard'' commented that the song \"may have drawn the roadmap for a reliable new path to crossover success.\"<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Weatherby |first1=Taylor |title=How 'Meant to Be,' 'The Middle' & More 2018 Country-Pop Hits May Have Kick-Started the Next Wave of Top 40 |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/meant-to-be-the-middle-country-pop-hits-top-40-new-wave-8491229/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=March 4, 2022 |archive-date=March 4, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220304232346/https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/meant-to-be-the-middle-country-pop-hits-top-40-new-wave-8491229/ |url-status=live }}</ref> On October 5, 2018, Morris appeared as a special guest during [[Taylor Swift's Reputation Stadium Tour]] in [[Arlington, Texas]], performing \"The Middle\" with Swift.<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Kaplan|first1=Ilana|title=See Maren Morris, Taylor Swift Team for Soulful Rendition of 'The Middle'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/maren-morris-taylor-swift-the-middle-733871/|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=October 6, 2018|access-date=February 21, 2019|archive-date=January 20, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190120040802/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/maren-morris-taylor-swift-the-middle-733871/|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nMorris's next studio album ''[[Girl (Maren Morris album)|Girl]]'' was released in March 2019. According to Morris, the project reflected her own experiences as a young woman while also highlighting the experiences of other women her age.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Weatherby |first1=Taylor |title=Maren Morris Announces Sophomore Album 'Girl' |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/maren-morris-new-album-girl-release-date-cover-8497142/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=March 12, 2022 |archive-date=March 12, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220312200308/https://www.billboard.com/music/country/maren-morris-new-album-girl-release-date-cover-8497142/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' rated the album three and a half stars, calling it the project \"where Morris makes her pop move\".<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Sheffield |first1=Rob |title=Review: Maren Morris Makes Her Bid for Top 40 Glory With 'Girl' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=March 5, 2019 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-album-reviews/maren-morris-girl-album-review-803005/ |access-date=March 12, 2022 |archive-date=December 2, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191202072331/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-album-reviews/maren-morris-girl-album-review-803005/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The disc topped the ''Billboard'' country albums chart and the reached the top five of the ''Billboard'' 200.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> She later embarked on ''Girl: The World Tour'', to support the album.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Freeman |first=Jon |title=Maren Morris Sets Dates for Headlining Girl: The World Tour |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/maren-morris-2019-tour-new-song-girl-780360/ |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=January 17, 2019 |access-date=January 28, 2019 |archive-date=February 3, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190203121435/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/maren-morris-2019-tour-new-song-girl-780360/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Its [[Girl (Maren Morris song)|lead single of the same name]] reached the number one spot on the ''Billboard'' country airplay chart and number eight on the ''Billboard'' country songs chart. It was followed by the second single \"[[The Bones (song)|The Bones]]\", which topped both the Country Airplay and Country Songs charts in 2020.<ref name=\"Country Airplay\"/><ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> A duet version with [[Hozier (musician)|Hozier]] became her second crossover pop hit, peaking at number 12 on the Hot 100<ref name=\"Hot 100\">{{cite magazine |title=Maren Morris chart history (Hot 100) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=March 12, 2022 |archive-date=April 1, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220401072636/https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and number one on the [[Adult contemporary (chart)|adult contemporary]] chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Maren Morris chart history (Adult Contemporary) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=March 12, 2022 |archive-date=April 1, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220401072636/https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Girl'' would win Album of the Year at the 2019 [[Country Music Association Awards]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Maren Morris's ''Girl'' Wins Album of the Year at the 2019 CMA's |url=https://theboot.com/2019-cma-awards-album-of-the-year-winner/ |website=The Boot |date=November 14, 2019 |access-date=March 12, 2022 |archive-date=May 26, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220526105157/https://theboot.com/2019-cma-awards-album-of-the-year-winner/ |url-status=live }}</ref> while Morris herself later won Female Vocalist of the Year from the association,<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Bernstein |first1=Jonathan |title=See Maren Morris Praise Black Women Country Singers in Powerful CMA Awards Speech |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=November 12, 2020 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/maren-morris-cma-awards-speech-1089399/ |access-date=March 12, 2022 |archive-date=March 12, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220312200309/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/maren-morris-cma-awards-speech-1089399/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and later two wins for Female Artist of the Year at the [[Academy of Country Music Awards]] (2020 and 2021).<ref name=\"2020acmresults\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.acmcountry.com/noms|title=Nominees|website=Academy of Country Music|language=en|access-date=February 29, 2020|archive-date=March 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200308191634/https://www.acmcountry.com/noms|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nIn March 2019, it was announced that Morris would be forming a group with [[Brandi Carlile]], [[Amanda Shires]] and [[Natalie Hemby]] called [[The Highwomen]] (in reference to [[The Highwaymen (country supergroup)|The Highwaymen]]). A social media post by Shires' husband [[Jason Isbell]] hinted that the group had already begun recording with producer [[Dave Cobb]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2019/music/news/brandi-carline-maren-morris-amanda-shires-highwomen-supergroup-1203156171/|title=Brandi Carlile, Amanda Shires Add Maren Morris to 'Highwomen' Supergroup|first1=Chris|last1=Willman|date=March 6, 2019|website=Variety.com|access-date=March 9, 2019|archive-date=June 8, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190608235415/https://variety.com/2019/music/news/brandi-carline-maren-morris-amanda-shires-highwomen-supergroup-1203156171/|url-status=live}}</ref> The Highwomen made their live debut in April 2019 at [[Loretta Lynn]]'s 87th birthday concert performing \"[[It Wasn't God Who Made Honky Tonk Angels]]\".<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/highwomen-brandi-carlile-loretta-lynn-birthday-concert-816499/|title=See the Highwomen's Live Debut at Loretta Lynn Birthday Show|first1=Marissa R.|last1=Moss|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=April 2, 2019|access-date=July 19, 2019|archive-date=April 5, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190405162535/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/highwomen-brandi-carlile-loretta-lynn-birthday-concert-816499/|url-status=live}}</ref> \"Redesigning Women\" was released on July 19, 2019, as the first single from the group's self-titled debut album. Their [[The Highwomen (album)|self-titled debut album]] was released in September 2019. The album had a top-ten debut on [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and number one on the Country Chart.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/the-highwomen-redesigning-women-video/|title=The Highwomen Light the Ultimate Bonfire in 'Redesigning Women' Video [Watch]|website=Taste of Country|date=July 19, 2019|access-date=July 19, 2019|archive-date=September 7, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200907223124/https://tasteofcountry.com/the-highwomen-redesigning-women-video/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/chart-beat/8530004/post-malone-hollywoods-bleeding-No1-debut-billboard-200-chart|title=Post Malone Scores Second No. 1 Album on Billboard 200 With 'Hollywood's Bleeding'|magazine=Billboard|date=September 15, 2019|access-date=September 18, 2019|archive-date=December 14, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191214192922/https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/chart-beat/8530004/post-malone-hollywoods-bleeding-No1-debut-billboard-200-chart|url-status=live}}</ref> Busbee died in September 2019. \"This just doesn't seem fair. I will always love you and the songs and albums I was lucky to make with you, Busbee,\" she later wrote on [[Twitter]].<ref name=\"Busbee\"/>\n\nIn 2021, Morris collaborated with husband [[Ryan Hurd]] on the single \"[[Chasing After You]]\",<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dowling |first1=Marcus K. |title=Ryan Hurd, Maren Morris Go No. 1 With \"Chasing After You\" |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1839320/ryan-hurd-maren-morris-go-no-1-with-chasing-after-you/ |website=[[Country Music Television]] |access-date=March 12, 2022 |archive-date=March 12, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220312201946/http://www.cmt.com/news/1839320/ryan-hurd-maren-morris-go-no-1-with-chasing-after-you/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> which reached the top five on the ''Billboard'' country charts.<ref name=\"Country Airplay\"/><ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> She was the featured guest vocalist on John Mayer's single \"[[Last Train Home (John Mayer song)|Last Train Home]]\", released on June 4, 2021, as well as appearing on \"Why You No Love Me\" and \"Shot In The Dark\" on his album ''[[Sob Rock]]''. In January 2022, Morris' next single was released titled \"[[Circles Around This Town]]\".<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Freeman|first=Jon|date=January 13, 2022|title=Maren Morris Embarks on a 'Humble Quest' With New Album|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/maren-morris-new-album-humble-quest-1283988/|access-date=January 31, 2022|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|archive-date=January 24, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220124015823/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/maren-morris-new-album-humble-quest-1283988/|url-status=live}}</ref> It was followed by the release of her next studio album ''[[Humble Quest]]'' in March 2022. For this album, [[Greg Kurstin]] served as producer.<ref>{{cite web|last=Willman|first=Chris|date=January 13, 2022|title=Maren Morris to Double Down on Country in Third Album, 'Humble Quest'|url=https://variety.com/2022/music/news/maren-morris-new-album-humble-quest-1235153542/|access-date=January 14, 2022|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|archive-date=January 13, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220113175724/https://variety.com/2022/music/news/maren-morris-new-album-humble-quest-1235153542/|url-status=live}}</ref> ''[[GQ]]'' magazine described its sound as a \"return from glittery pop to her stripped-down country origins\".<ref name=\"GQ\">{{cite magazine |last1=Hymam |first1=Dan |title=How Maren Morris Reconnected With Her Country Roots On Her New Album |magazine=[[GQ]] |date=March 2022 |url=https://www.gq.com/story/maren-morris-humble-quest-interview |access-date=April 16, 2022 |archive-date=April 17, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220417021147/https://www.gq.com/story/maren-morris-humble-quest-interview |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Humble Quest'' debuted at number two on the ''Billboard'' country albums chart<ref name=\"Country Albums\">{{cite magazine |title=Maren Morris chart history (Country 6,Albums) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=April 16, 2022 |archive-date=April 17, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220417185151/https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and number 21 on the ''Billboard'' 200.<ref name=\"Billboard 200\">{{cite magazine |title=Maren Morris chart history (Billboard 200) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=April 16, 2022 |archive-date=April 17, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220417185151/https://www.billboard.com/artist/maren-morris/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'' gave it an 8.0 rating, calling it \"matter-of-factly masterful\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hermes |first1=Will |title=''Humble Quest'': Maren Morris |url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/maren-morris-humble-quest/ |website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]] |access-date=April 16, 2022 |archive-date=April 16, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220416073836/https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/maren-morris-humble-quest/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' gave it 3.5 stars, calling it \"fascinating, and proudly unresolved\".<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Bernstein |first1=Jonathan |title=Maren Morris Finds A Path Away From the Middle on 'Humble Quest' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=March 22, 2022 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-album-reviews/maren-morris-humble-quest-1323573/ |access-date=April 16, 2022 |archive-date=April 17, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220417171708/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-album-reviews/maren-morris-humble-quest-1323573/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nIn late 2023, Morris announced her departure from the country music genre. She told the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' that the reason for her decision is because she has \"said everything\" she has wanted to say. In late 2023, Columbia released an extended play titled ''The Bridge''. The EP contains the tracks \"The Tree\" and \"Get the Hell Out of Here\". Greg Kurstin and [[Jack Antonoff]] alternated as producers on these songs. She also announced plans to work on a new album with Antonoff.<ref name=\"the bridge\">{{cite web | url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/music/story/2023-09-15/maren-morris-the-bridge-nashville-country-music-leaving | title=Maren Morris is getting the hell out of country music: 'I've said everything I can say' | work=The Los Angeles Times | date=September 15, 2023 | accessdate=September 15, 2023 | author=Mikael Wood | archive-date=September 15, 2023 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230915163147/https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/music/story/2023-09-15/maren-morris-the-bridge-nashville-country-music-leaving | url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nIn 2024 Morris performed her song \"Better than We Found It\" at the [[2024 Democratic National Convention]] in Chicago.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2024/08/21/maren-morris-performing-at-2024-dnc-part-of-singers-recent-activism/74888152007/ | title=Maren Morris to appear at DNC convention: How Grammy-winner's performance highlights recent activism | website=[[The Tennessean]] }}</ref>\n\n==Artistry==\nThe musical style of Maren Morris blends country music<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> with [[country pop]],<ref name=\"countrypop\">{{cite magazine |last1=Hight |first1=Jewly |title=The New Pioneers: Maren Morris Songwriter Busbee on Creating Country/Pop Hits |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/features/new-pioneers-maren-morris-songwriter-busbee-pop-country-hits-7468540/ |access-date=17 April 2022 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=August 11, 2016 |archive-date=April 17, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220417230902/https://www.billboard.com/music/features/new-pioneers-maren-morris-songwriter-busbee-pop-country-hits-7468540/ |url-status=live }}</ref> [[contemporary R&B|R&B]]<ref name=\"Distractify\">{{cite news |last1=Garrison |first1=Anna |title=Who Is Maren Morris' Husband? And Do They Have Any Kids? What We Know |url=https://www.distractify.com/p/maren-morris-husband |access-date=17 April 2022 |work=[[Distractify]] |date=March 20, 2022 |archive-date=April 17, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220417230902/https://www.distractify.com/p/maren-morris-husband |url-status=live }}</ref> and [[Hip hop music|hip hop]].<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Writers and critics commented that Morris's first two Columbia albums combined country with R&B and hip hop musical styles. [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of AllMusic found that 2016's ''Hero'' included \"R&B influences\" that \"twists the rhymes\" and \"[rides] the beat\" while \"undercutting her boasts with sly wit\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Erlewine |first1=Stephen Thomas |title=''Hero'': Maren Morris: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/hero-mw0002938929 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=April 17, 2022 |archive-date=April 17, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220417230902/https://www.allmusic.com/album/hero-mw0002938929 |url-status=live }}</ref> Jewly Hight of ''Billboard'' described ''Hero'' as \"a signifier of country-pop's fluidity and a creative process that resembles the track-building of pop, R&B and hip-hop.\"<ref name=\"countrypop\"/> ''[[The Hartford Courant]]'' praised 2019's ''Girl'' for incorporating similar styles: \"If a lot of male country singers dabble with hip-hop in ways that sometimes feel stilted, Morris brings straight-up elements of '90s R&B to the album on songs like the bedroom-centric 'RSVP'.\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Adamian |first1=John |title=Maren Morris, mixing pop and soul with her country, performing at the Oakdale |url=https://www.courant.com/ctnow/music/hc-ctnow-music-maren-morris-oakdale-0905-20190830-mhrzqneni5fqflclnd5wzxv47m-story.html |access-date=17 April 2022 |work=[[Hartford Courant]] |date=August 30, 2019 |archive-date=December 7, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211207033331/https://www.courant.com/ctnow/music/hc-ctnow-music-maren-morris-oakdale-0905-20190830-mhrzqneni5fqflclnd5wzxv47m-story.html |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nMorris's vocal style been noticed by writers and critics. When reviewing her 2019 album, Jon Caramanica described her voice as \"versatile\" in the way it can move between both the country and pop genres.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Caramanica |first1=Jon |title=Maren Morris Is Good for Pop, but Pop Isn't Good for Her |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/12/arts/music/maren-morris-girl-review.html |access-date=19 September 2022 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 12, 2019 |archive-date=September 20, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220920172828/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/12/arts/music/maren-morris-girl-review.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Chris Richards of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' described Morris as having \"the best voice of any country singer working today\". Richards further explained, \"Listen to her jump in and out of her lyrics and you'll hear a sophistication that feels like something metaphysical.\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Richards |first1=Chris |title=Maren Morris has the best voice in country music. She's still learning how to use it. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/maren-morris-has-the-best-voice-in-country-music-shes-still-learning-how-to-use-it/2019/03/08/be77d5be-41c7-11e9-922c-64d6b7840b82_story.html |access-date=19 September 2022 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=March 8, 2019 |archive-date=January 1, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200101065340/https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/maren-morris-has-the-best-voice-in-country-music-shes-still-learning-how-to-use-it/2019/03/08/be77d5be-41c7-11e9-922c-64d6b7840b82_story.html |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nOverall, Morris characterizes herself as a country artist. In an interview with ''[[NPR]]'', Morris was asked about whether she still identified with the genre: \"even though I live in Nashville and I'm from Texas and I feel like my songwriting at its core is country, I think you can hear a lot of different influences when you've heard any of my records.\"<ref name=\"NPR 2\">{{cite news |last1=Martinez |first1=A |last2=Harrell |first2=Phil |title=With 'Humble Quest,' Maren Morris is closely following her compass |url=https://www.npr.org/2022/03/25/1088538247/with-humble-quest-maren-morris-is-closely-following-her-compass |access-date=April 17, 2022 |work=[[NPR]] |date=March 25, 2022 |archive-date=April 16, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220416080715/https://www.npr.org/2022/03/25/1088538247/with-humble-quest-maren-morris-is-closely-following-her-compass |url-status=live }}</ref> Other writers have agreed, including [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]]: \"Morris' music was grounded in country -- prior to striking gold as a performer, she was a professional songwriter in Nashville -- but she also incorporated elements of pop, R&B, hip-hop, and rock, creating a distinctive, stylish hybrid that had wide appeal outside her chosen genre.\"<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>\n\nMorris has cited various artists of different genres as influences on her career, including [[Katy Perry]], [[Coldplay]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Maren Morris Breaks Down Our Favorite Tracks from Her New Album, 'GIRL'|url=https://toofab.com/2019/03/08/maren-morris-breaks-down-favorite-tracks-new-album-girl/|agency=TooFab|date=March 8, 2019|access-date=March 3, 2022|archive-date=January 17, 2022|archive-url=https://archive.today/20220117014119/https://toofab.com/2019/03/08/maren-morris-breaks-down-favorite-tracks-new-album-girl/|url-status=live}}</ref> [[Linda Ronstadt]],<ref name=\"NPR 2\"/> [[Dolly Parton]],<ref name=\"Leo\">{{cite web |last1=Topham |first1=Michelle |title=Who Are Maren Morris' Heroes, Which Singers Have Influenced Her Life? |url=https://leosigh.com/who-are-maren-morris-heroes-which-singers-have-influenced-her-life/ |website=LeoSigh |date=June 4, 2016 |access-date=17 April 2022 |archive-date=June 26, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220626085050/https://leosigh.com/who-are-maren-morris-heroes-which-singers-have-influenced-her-life/ |url-status=live }}</ref> [[Chaka Khan]],<ref name=\"Leo\"/> and [[Hank Williams]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Maren Morris |url=https://www.opry.com/artists/maren-morris/ |website=[[Grand Ole Opry]] |access-date=17 April 2022 |archive-date=April 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230406210853/https://www.opry.com/artists/maren-morris/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n==Advocacy==\nIn 2017, Morris started the Heroes Fund, which raises money for music education in public schools.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Liptak |first1=Carena |title=Maren Morris' Heroes Fund makes donation to local Tennessee high school band program |url=http://abcnewsradioonline.com/music-news/2020/8/6/maren-morris-heroes-fund-makes-donation-to-local-tennessee-h.html |access-date=19 April 2022 |work=[[ABC News Radio]] |date=2020 |archive-date=December 20, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221220164648/http://abcnewsradioonline.com/music-news/2020/8/6/maren-morris-heroes-fund-makes-donation-to-local-tennessee-h.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Through the program, Morris donated $70,000 to [[East Nashville Magnet High School]] that went towards their music and drama departments.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Trapp |first1=Phillip |title=Maren Morris Gives $70K to High School Band Program |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/maren-moris-charity-donations-nashville/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |date=August 10, 2020 |access-date=19 April 2022 |archive-date=April 19, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220419002743/https://tasteofcountry.com/maren-moris-charity-donations-nashville/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In April 2021, Morris donated $300,000 to the [[NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund]], Together We Rise and Ecologi.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Talarico |first1=Brittany |title=Maren Morris to Perform at Fashion Brand Shein's Charity-Driven Virtual Festival: 'It's a Morale Booster' |magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=April 29, 2021 |url=https://people.com/style/maren-morris-to-perform-at-shein-virtual-festival/ |access-date=19 April 2022 |archive-date=April 19, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220419002743/https://people.com/style/maren-morris-to-perform-at-shein-virtual-festival/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In August 2021, Morris joined several country artists to raise money for the program Together: Feeding Nashville. The concert raised money to address [[food security|food insecurity]] in the Nashville area. A total of $450,000 was raised from the show.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nicholson |first1=Jessica |title=Florida Georgia Line, Maren Morris, Thomas Rhett Help Raise $450K During Charity Concert |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1836876/florida-georgia-line-maren-morris-thomas-rhett-help-raise-450k-during-charity-concert/ |access-date=19 April 2022 |work=[[Country Music Television]] |date=August 6, 2021 |archive-date=May 25, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220525164119/http://www.cmt.com/news/1836876/florida-georgia-line-maren-morris-thomas-rhett-help-raise-450k-during-charity-concert/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nMorris has been an advocate for making the country genre more equitable for fellow artists. She has commented on the inequalities particularly for white and black artists in the genre. \"I'm a white woman in country music. I already have this sort of leg-up. There's a huge disparity between men and women in our genre, there's even more of a disparity between white women and black women trying to be in country music,\" she told ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'' in 2021.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Barnes |first1=Hannah |title=Maren Morris Reveals Why She Isn't Afraid to 'Speak out' in Country Music |url=https://popculture.com/country-music/news/maren-morris-why-she-isnt-afraid-to-speak-out-in-country-music/ |access-date=19 April 2022 |work=popculture |date=March 11, 2021 |archive-date=May 26, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220526021312/https://popculture.com/country-music/news/maren-morris-why-she-isnt-afraid-to-speak-out-in-country-music/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In her 2020 CMA Awards acceptance speech, Morris named several black artists who helped make the award possible including [[Mickey Guyton]], [[Linda Martell]] and [[Brittney Spencer]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Oliver |first1=David |title=Maren Morris, Rissi Palmer discuss racism in country music: 'We all should be uncomfortable' |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/music/2021/02/15/maren-morris-rissi-palmer-talk-racism-country-music/6750461002/ |access-date=19 April 2022 |work=[[USA Today]] |date=February 15, 2021 |archive-date=April 19, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220419001647/https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/music/2021/02/15/maren-morris-rissi-palmer-talk-racism-country-music/6750461002/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In early 2021, Morris spoke out against country artist [[Morgan Wallen]] when a video of him using a racial slur surfaced. \"You can't control a human being, but you absolutely can let them know where you stand,\" she told ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Willman |first1=Chris |title=Maren Morris and Luke Combs Take On Racism in Country Music at Radio Seminar |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=February 17, 2021 |url=https://variety.com/2021/music/news/maren-morris-luke-combs-country-music-panel-seminar-1234910013/ |access-date=April 19, 2022 |archive-date=April 19, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220419002155/https://variety.com/2021/music/news/maren-morris-luke-combs-country-music-panel-seminar-1234910013/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nIn August 2022, Morris replied to an [[Instagram]] post made by [[Jason Aldean]]'s wife, Brittany. Both Morris and other country music singers including [[Cassadee Pope]] perceived Aldean's comments as [[transphobia|transphobic]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/maren-morris-brittany-aldean-clash-004831398.html | title=Maren Morris and Brittany Aldean clash again amid backlash to Aldean's recent transphobic remarks | publisher=Yahoo! Entertainment | date=September 2, 2022 | access-date=September 5, 2022 | author=Emlyn Travis | archive-date=September 4, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220904131348/https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/maren-morris-brittany-aldean-clash-004831398.html | url-status=live }}</ref> While interviewing Brittany Aldean, [[Fox News Channel]] host [[Tucker Carlson]] referred to Morris as a \"lunatic country music person.\"<ref name=\"ew clash\">{{cite web | url=https://ew.com/music/maren-morris-brittany-aldean-clash-again-transphobic-remarks/ | title=Maren Morris and Brittany Aldean clash again amid backlash to Aldean's recent transphobic remarks | publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]] | date=September 2, 2022 | access-date=September 5, 2022 | author=Emlyn Travis | archive-date=September 5, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220905032923/https://ew.com/music/maren-morris-brittany-aldean-clash-again-transphobic-remarks/ | url-status=live }}</ref> In response to this comment, Morris sold T-shirts through her website featuring the phrase \"lunatic country music person\" and the telephone number of the [[Trans Lifeline]]. She also stated that proceeds from the shirts would be donated to [[GLAAD]].<ref name=\"ew clash\"/> In September 2022, Morris partnered with GLAAD to design a new T-shirt in honor of [[Spirit Day]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Rowley|first=Glenn|title=Maren Morris Just Designed Another Shirt for LGBTQ+ Spirit Day: 'You Have a Seat at This Table'|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/maren-morris-designs-shirt-lgbtq-spirit-day-1235147083/|date=September 29, 2022|access-date=September 30, 2022|magazine=Billboard|archive-date=September 29, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220929185505/https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/maren-morris-designs-shirt-lgbtq-spirit-day-1235147083/|url-status=live}}</ref>  Morris told ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' in September 2023 that she planned to leave the genre of country music. She cited the country music industry's unwillingness to reckon with issues of [[misogyny]] and [[racism]], as well as its reluctance to support artists from [[Minority group|marginalized demographics]], as her reasons for doing so.<ref name=\"the bridge\"/>\n\n==Personal life==\n[[File:RyanHurd WikipediaImage.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Morris married [[Ryan Hurd]] in 2018.|alt=A picture of singer Ryan Hurd strumming a guitar and singing while on a stage.]]\nMorris met fellow country singer-songwriter [[Ryan Hurd]] while co-writing \"Last Turn Home\" for Tim McGraw.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Fox |first1=Courtney |title=Maren Morris and Husband Ryan Hurd Met While Writing a Tim McGraw Song |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/ryan-hurd-maren-morris-love-story/ |website=Wide Open Country |date=March 2, 2022 |access-date=18 April 2022 |archive-date=April 22, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220422215434/https://www.wideopencountry.com/ryan-hurd-maren-morris-love-story/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In December 2015, the pair began dating. They announced their engagement in July 2017.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Petit|first1=Stephanie|title=Maren Morris Is Engaged to Ryan Hurd \u2014 See Her Ring!|url=http://people.com/country/maren-morris-ryan-hurd-engaged/|website=People|access-date=March 24, 2018|language=en|archive-date=June 16, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200616041705/https://people.com/country/maren-morris-ryan-hurd-engaged/|url-status=live}}</ref> They were married on March 24, 2018, in Nashville, Tennessee.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pasquini|first1=Maria|title=They're Married! Maren Morris Weds Ryan Hurd in Nashville|url=http://people.com/music/maren-morris-marries-ryan-hurd/|website=People.com|access-date=March 24, 2018|language=en|archive-date=August 26, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180826095859/https://people.com/music/maren-morris-marries-ryan-hurd/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Stein |first1=Megan |title=Inside Newlyweds Maren Morris and Ryan Hurd's 'Southern But Not Over-the-Top' Backyard |magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=April 16, 2018 |url=https://people.com/home/maren-morris-and-ryan-hurd-backyard-makeover-house-photos/?slide=6259315#6259315 |access-date=18 April 2022 |archive-date=April 19, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220419000541/https://people.com/home/maren-morris-and-ryan-hurd-backyard-makeover-house-photos/?slide=6259315#6259315 |url-status=live }}</ref> Their son was born in March 2020.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dirken|first=Deirdre|title=Maren Morris and Husband Ryan Hurd Expecting Their First Child: 'See You in March, Baby!|url=https://people.com/parents/maren-morris-ryan-hurd-expecting-first-child-baby-boy/|website=People.com|access-date=October 22, 2019|language=en|archive-date=August 19, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200819203313/https://people.com/parents/maren-morris-ryan-hurd-expecting-first-child-baby-boy/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://people.com/parents/maren-morris-ryan-hurd-welcome-son-hayes-andrew-first-photos/|title=It's a Boy! Maren Morris and Husband Ryan Hurd Welcome Son Hayes Andrew: 'Love of Our Lives'|website=PEOPLE.com|language=en|access-date=March 23, 2020|archive-date=August 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200818164227/https://people.com/parents/maren-morris-ryan-hurd-welcome-son-hayes-andrew-first-photos/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Hermanson |first1=Wendy |title=Maren Morris Gets Real About Difficult C-Section Experience |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/maren-morris-c-section-discussion/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |date=August 18, 2020 |access-date=19 April 2022 |archive-date=June 29, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220629055816/https://tasteofcountry.com/maren-morris-c-section-discussion/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Morris filed for divorce in October 2023;<ref>{{cite news |last=Dominic |first=Anthony |title=Maren Morris and Husband Ryan Hurd Divorcing After 5 Years of Marriage |url=https://www.etonline.com/maren-morris-and-husband-ryan-hurd-divorcing-after-5-years-of-marriage-213162 |access-date=October 17, 2023 |work=[[Entertainment Tonight]] |date=October 17, 2023 |location=United States |archive-date=October 17, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231017160333/https://www.etonline.com/maren-morris-and-husband-ryan-hurd-divorcing-after-5-years-of-marriage-213162 |url-status=live }}</ref> a divorce settlement was reached in January 2024.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.etonline.com/ryan-hurd-covers-taylor-swifts-now-that-we-dont-talk-following-maren-morris-divorce-settlement|title=Ryan Hurd Covers Taylor Swift's 'Now That We Don't Talk' Following Maren Morris Divorce Settlement|first=Zach|last=Seemayer|publisher=Entertainment Tonight|date=January 22, 2024|accessdate=January 23, 2024|location=United States|archive-date=January 23, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240123073642/https://www.etonline.com/ryan-hurd-covers-taylor-swifts-now-that-we-dont-talk-following-maren-morris-divorce-settlement|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nMorris came out as [[Bisexuality|bisexual]] on June 9, 2024.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.out.com/gay-music/maren-morris-comes-out-bisexual|title=Maren Morris comes out as bisexual in new post celebrating Pride Month|last=Sim|first=Bernardo|website=[[Out (magazine)|Out]]|date=June 9, 2024|access-date=June 9, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240610005301/https://www.out.com/gay-music/maren-morris-comes-out-bisexual|archive-date=June 10, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Maren Morris ''[[RuPaul's Drag Race: Untucked]]''\n| 2023\n| Herself\n| Episode: \"Untucked - All Queens Go To Heaven\"\n| align=\"center\"| <ref>{{cite web |title=Untucked - All Queens Go to Heaven |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]]''\n| 2024\n| Herself\n| Episode: 9 April 2024, Stephen and Maren sing The National Anthem\n| align=\"center\"| <ref>{{cite web |last1=McRady |first1=Rachel |title=Stephen Colbert Shocks Maren Morris as They Sing National Anthem Together: 'Where Did That Come From?' |url=https://www.wkyc.com/article/entertainment/entertainment-tonight/stephen-colbert-shocks-maren-morris-as-they-sing-national-anthem-together-where-did-that-come-from/603-cbec14ae-10e2-4645-95c4-8b012809a522 |website=wkyc.com |date=April 10, 2024 |access-date=12 June 2024}}</ref>\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{{main|List of awards and nominations received by Maren Morris}}\n\nMaren Morris has won a series of awards for her work as a music artist. This includes five accolades from the [[Academy of Country Music]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Search winners: Maren Morris |url=https://www.acmcountry.com/winners?awardTitle=maren+morris&awardCategory=&awardYear=&actionButton=Submit |website=[[Academy of Country Music Awards]] |access-date=March 12, 2022}}</ref> five from the [[Country Music Association]]<ref name=\"CMA\">{{cite web |title=CMA Past Winners & Nominees: Maren Morris <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Niko_Moon","to":"Niko Moon"}],"pages":{"61764412":{"pageid":61764412,"ns":0,"title":"Niko Moon","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Niko Moon\n| image           =\n| image_upright   =\n| image_size      =\n| landscape       =\n| alt             =\n| caption         =\n| background = solo_singer\n| birth_name      = Nicholas Cowan<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/niko-moon-mn0003359916/biography | title=Niko Moon biography | publisher=Allmusic | accessdate=February 15, 2021}}</ref>\n| alias           = Nic Cowan\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1982|09|20}}\n| birth_place     = [[Tyler, Texas]], U.S.\n| origin          =\n| genre           = [[Country pop]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| occupation      = Singer, songwriter\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| years_active    = 2008\u2013present\n| label           = [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]]\n| past_member_of  = [[Sir Rosevelt]]\n| website         = {{URL|https://www.nikomoon.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Niko Moon''' (born '''Nicholas Cowan'''; September 20, 1982) is an American [[country pop]] singer and songwriter formerly signed to [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-07-19|title=Niko Moon Signs To Sony's RCA Nashville Imprint|url=https://musicrow.com/2019/07/niko-moon-signs-to-sonys-rca-nashville-imprint/|access-date=2021-02-03|website=MusicRow.com|language=en-US}}</ref> He has written songs for [[Dierks Bentley]], [[Zac Brown Band]], [[Rascal Flatts]], and [[Morgan Wallen]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Niko Moon {{!}} Credits|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/niko-moon-mn0003359916/credits|access-date=2021-02-03|website=AllMusic|language=en}}</ref> He was also a member of the group [[Sir Rosevelt]] with [[Zac Brown]] and Ben Simonetti.<ref>{{Cite magazine|title=Zac Brown Reveals Diplo & Skrillex-Influenced Dance-Pop Project Sir Rosevelt: Interview|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7526468/zac-brown-sir-rosevelt-interview-dance-pop-edm-diplo-skrillex|access-date=2021-02-03|magazine=Billboard|language=en}}</ref>\n\n== Background ==\n\nNicholas Cowan is originally from Tyler, Texas but relocated to Douglasville, Georgia, when he was 10. His father, a truck driver and his mother, a waitress, introduced Niko to the works of artists like [[John Prine]] and [[Patty Griffin]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2019/08/on-the-row-niko-moon-talks-good-time-and-making-music-with-a-positive-impact/|title=On The Row: Niko Moon Talks \"Good Time\" And Making Music With A Positive Impact|date=August 26, 2019}}</ref> He started out as a drummer after seeing his father play. His father was also a musician and gave up being a touring drummer when Niko was born.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.iheart.com/content/2019-08-06-is-niko-moon-reimagining-country-music-with-a-new-sound/ |title=Is Niko Moon Reimagining Country Music With A New Sound? |first= Lauryn |last=Snapp|date=August 6, 2019|work=iHeart Radio }}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\nNiko Moon first found success as a co-writer on songs for the Zac Brown Band, including \u201cHeavy Is the Head\u201d, \u201cHomegrown\u201d, \u201cBeautiful Drug\", \"Keep Me in Mind\", and \"Loving You Easy\u201d as well as [[Keep Me in Mind (Zac Brown Band song)|Keep Me in Mind]] and Island Song under the credits as Nic Cowan.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/niko-moon-mn0003359916|title=Niko Moon &#124; Credits|website=AllMusic}}</ref> He also co-produced the Zac Brown Band albums [[Jekyll + Hyde|Jekyll+Hyde]] and [[Welcome Home (Zac Brown Band album)|Welcome Home]], and co-wrote the song \u201cBack To Life\u201d for [[Rascal Flatts]] along with Cary Barlowe, Shay Mooney, and Fred Wilhelm.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/rascal-flatts-back-to-life-good-morning-america/|title=Rascal Flatts Take Over Times Square for 'GMA' Performance|first=Jacklyn|last=Krol|website=Taste of Country}}</ref> He appeared on [[Colt Ford]]\u2019s album ''[[Every Chance I Get (album)|Every Chance I Get]]'' on the track \"Waste Some Time\" with [[Nappy Roots]].\n\nIn 2010, under the name Nic Cowan, Niko Moon self-released his debut EP titled \"Cheap Wine,\" which featured seven tracks. The following year saw the release of his first full-length album, \"Hard Headed,\" also under the Nic Cowan moniker. According to Moon, the album's title track, \"Hard Headed,\" delves into themes of resisting control from a romantic partner. Distributed by Southern Ground Records, the album includes 13 tracks, among them notable songs such as \"Reno,\" \"New Sh*t,\" and \"Cut it Loose (feat. Zac Brown).\"<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://first-avenue.com/performer/nic-cowan/ | title=Nic Cowan | date=2012}}</ref>\n\nIn 2016, Moon formed the group Sir Rosevelt with Zac Brown and Ben Simonetti, another co-writer with the Zac Brown Band. The group's track \u201cThe Bravest\u201d was used during the 2018 FIFA World Cup.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2017/11/17/zac-browns-new-trio-sir-rosevelt-releases-new-song-the-bravest-listen/ |title=Zac Brown's New Trio, Sir Rosevelt, Releases New Song, \"The Bravest\" [Listen] |first= Jim |last=Casey | date= November 17, 2017 |work=Nash Country Daily}}</ref>\nMoon and Simonetti co-wrote a song on [[Michael Franti]]\u2019s album Stay Human Vol. II.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://relix.com/articles/detail/track-by-track-michael-franti-stay-human-vol-ii/|title=Track By Track: Michael Franti 'Stay Human Vol. II'|date=February 19, 2019|website=Relix Media}}</ref>\n\nIn 2019, Niko Moon signed a recording contract with [[Sony Music Nashville]] imprint [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.musicconnection.com/singer-songwriter-niko-moon-signs-rca-nashville/|title=Singer/Songwriter Niko Moon signs to RCA Nashville|date=July 19, 2019|website=[[Music Connection Magazine]]}}</ref>\n\n== Personal life ==\nNiko is married to singer-songwriter Anna Moon. They have a daughter, Lily Ann Moon.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.thelist.com/430702/the-truth-about-niko-moons-marriage/ | title=The Truth About Niko Moon's Marriage | date=7 June 2021 }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n!
