This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Cole_Swindell","to":"Cole Swindell"}],"pages":{"40123804":{"pageid":40123804,"ns":0,"title":"Cole Swindell","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{for|the singer's debut album|Cole Swindell (album){{!}}''Cole Swindell'' (album)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Cole Swindell\n| image        = Cole Swindell (2021) B (cropped).jpg\n| image_size=\n| landscape    = yes\n| alt          = A head shot of country music singer Cole Swindell\n| caption      = Swindell in 2021\n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|1983|6|30}}<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| birth_name   = Colden Rainey Swindell<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| birth_place  = [[Glennville, Georgia]], U.S.\n| origin       = [[Franklin, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre        = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>|[[country pop]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>}}\n| occupation   = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}}\n| instrument   = Vocals\n| years_active = 2013\u2013present\n| spouse       = {{marriage|Courtney Little|June 12, 2024}}\n| label        = [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros. Nashville]]\n| website      = {{URL|coleswindell.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Colden Rainey Swindell''' (born June 30, 1983) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. He has written singles for [[Craig Campbell (singer)|Craig Campbell]], [[Thomas Rhett]], [[Scotty McCreery]], and [[Luke Bryan]], and has released four albums for [[Warner Bros. Records]] Nashville. He has released thirteen singles, eight of which have reached number one on the [[Hot Country Songs]] and/or [[Country Airplay]] charts. Three more singles have reached the Top 10.\n\n==Early life==\nSwindell was born on June 30, 1983, to William Keith Swindell and Betty Carol Rainey. His father died on September 2, 2013, at 65,<ref name=dad>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/savannah/obituary.aspx?pid=166791689|title=William Swindell Obituary|author=Swindell family|date=September 4, 2013|work=[[Savannah Morning News]]|access-date=February 15, 2014}}</ref> while his mother died in September 2021.<ref name=mom>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/cole-swindells-mom-died/|title=Cole Swindell's Mom Has Died|last=Dukes|first=Billy|date=September 13, 2021|access-date=July 25, 2023|work=Taste of Country}}</ref> He grew up in [[Dawson, Georgia]], and has two brothers and a stepbrother.<ref name=dad />\n\nSwindell attended [[Terrell Academy]] in [[Dawson, Georgia]].<ref name=\"walb150506\">{{cite news|title=Swindell talks wild year, Terrell Academy days|url=http://www.walb.com/story/28988229/swindell-talks-wild-year-terrell-academy-days|access-date=14 January 2018|publisher=WALB|date=May 6, 2015}}</ref>  Swindell attended [[Georgia Southern University]], where he majored in marketing.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/06/12/cole-swindell-savors-defining-days/71095880/ |title=Cole Swindell savors his 'defining days' |author= Cindy Watts|date= June 14, 2015 |work=The Tennessean}}</ref> He met [[Luke Bryan]], who attended the same university some years earlier and was also a fellow [[Sigma Chi]] member,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2014/02/16/cole-swindell-on-the-verge-chillin-it/5368883/ |title= On the Verge: Cole Swindell no longer cooling his heels|author=Brian Mansfield |work= USA TODAY |date= February 16, 2014}}</ref> at the fraternity house when Bryan came back to [[Statesboro, Georgia|Statesboro]] to do a show. They kept in touch, and after Swindell left college in 2007 and moved to Nashville, he sold merchandise for Bryan for three years, and wrote songs on the road.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://radio.com/2014/02/13/new-music-to-know-how-cole-swindell/ |title=New Music to Know: How Cole Swindell Went From Luke Bryan's Merch Guy to Opening Act |date=February 13, 2014 |author=Annie Reuter |work=Radio.com }}</ref>\n\n==Music career==\n===Songwriting===\nIn 2010, Swindell signed a publishing deal with [[Sony/ATV Music Publishing]].\n\nSwindell wrote [[Craig Campbell (singer)|Craig Campbell]]'s \"[[Outta My Head (Craig Campbell song)|Outta My Head]]\",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countryweekly.com/music/craig-campbells-outta-my-head-lyric-video|title=Craig Campbell's \"Outta My Head\" Lyric Video|publisher=Country Weekly}}</ref> [[Luke Bryan]]'s \"Just a Sip\", \"Beer in the Headlights\", \"[[Roller Coaster (Luke Bryan song)|Roller Coaster]]\", \"Out Like That\", \"I'm Hungover\", \"In Love with the Girl\", Florida Georgia Line\u2019s \"[[This Is How We Roll]]\" with Bryan, who was featured on the song. [[Chris Young (singer)|Chris Young]] also had a song on his ''[[A.M. (Chris Young album)|A.M.]]'' album co-written by Swindell, \"Nothin' but the Cooler Left\n\n===2013\u20132015: ''Cole Swindell''===\nIn 2013, Swindell's independently released debut single \"[[Chillin' It]]\", buoyed by heavy airplay on [[SiriusXM]] satellite radio channel \"The Highway\", became a hit<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/cole-swindell-mn0002795282/biography|title=Cole Swindell biography|last=Leggett|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=14 February 2014}}</ref> and Swindell signed a record deal with [[Warner Music Group|Warner Music Nashville]]. The demo of \"Chillin' It\" was sent to radio before it had been [[audio mastering|mastered]].<ref name=\"tenn\">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2014/02/12/father-and-son-producers-jeff-stevens-jody-stevens-celebrate-no-1-and-no-2-hits/|title=Father and son producers Jeff Stevens, Jody Stevens celebrate No. 1 and No. 2 hits|last=Watts|first=Cindy|date=12 February 2014|work=The Tennessean|access-date=14 February 2014}}</ref>\n\nSwindell released his [[Cole Swindell (album)|self-titled debut album]] on February 18, 2014.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/4305396/cole-swindell-rides-chillin-it-to-label-deal |title=Cole Swindell Rides 'Chillin' It' to Label Deal |magazine=Billboard |date=2013-07-23 |access-date=2013-07-31}}</ref> Luke Bryan's guitarist, [[Michael Carter (musician)|Michael Carter]], produced the rest of the album. Along with [[Lee Brice]], Swindell opened Bryan's 2014 [[That's My Kind of Night Tour]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1715778/luke-bryan-announces-2014-tour.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131018150352/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1715778/luke-bryan-announces-2014-tour.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=October 18, 2013 | title=Luke Bryan Announces 2014 Tour: Lee Brice, Cole Swindell Will Open Shows | publisher=CMT | date=2013-10-17}}</ref> \"Chillin' It\" became a top-five hit on [[Country Airplay]] and number 1 single on [[Hot Country Songs]]. The album's second single is \"[[Hope You Get Lonely Tonight]]\", which Swindell and Carter co-wrote with both members of [[Florida Georgia Line]], [[Brian Kelley]] and [[Tyler Hubbard]]. The album's third single, \"[[Ain't Worth the Whiskey]]\", was released to country radio on November 3, 2014. It reached number one on the Country Airplay chart in April 2015. The album's fourth single, \"[[Let Me See Ya Girl]]\", was released to country radio on April 20, 2015. It reached number two on the Country Airplay chart in November 2015.\n\nOn November 17, 2014, Swindell released a five-song digital EP, ''[[The Down Home Sessions]]''. The release coincided with his headlining tour of the same name.<ref name=\"down home\">{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6327202/cole-swindell-down-home-sessions-ep |title=Cole Swindell Brings His Fans 'Down Home' With New EP |author= Chuck Dauphin |date= November 20, 2014 |magazine=Billboard }}</ref>\n\nSwindell won the ACM New Artist of the Year Award in April 2015.<ref>[http://www.etonline.com/news/163084_cole_swindell_talks_acms_best_new_artist_of_the_year_win_i_never_want_to_let_it_go/ole Swindell Talks ACMs Best New Artist Award: 'I Never Want to Let It Go']{{Dead link|date=July 2020 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ET Online. 19 April 2015.</ref>\n\n===2015\u20132018: ''You Should Be Here''===\nThe album's first single, \"[[You Should Be Here (Cole Swindell song)|You Should Be Here]]\" was released to country radio on December 14, 2015. It was written with [[Ashley Gorley]]. It reached at number one on the Country Airplay and Hot Country Songs charts in April 2016. The album's second single, \"[[Middle of a Memory]]\" released to country radio on May 2, 2016. It reached at number one on the Country Airplay in November 2016. The album's third single, \"[[Flatliner (song)|Flatliner]]\" (featuring [[Dierks Bentley]]) released to country radio on January 23, 2017. It reached at number two on the Country Airplay in August 2017. The album's fourth single, \"Stay Downtown\" released to country radio on September 5, 2017. \"You Should Be Here\", \"Middle of a Memory\" and \"Flatliner\" all hit No.1 on [[Mediabase]] country radio singles chart.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://headlineplanet.com/home/2017/08/13/cole-swindells-flatliner-reaches-1-country-radio/|title=Cole Swindell's \"Flatliner\" Reaches #1 At Country Radio|date=2017-08-13|work=Headline Planet|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nSwindell also released a music video for the song which featured a video of him telling his father he received a record contract and subsequent montages of Cole and his brothers grieving outside of the family home and at their father's grave. The video also shows images of Swindell's rising popularity while clearly conveying that he wanted to be able to see his father and share this fame experience with him.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/12/14/cole-swindell-tells-dad-you-should-here-song/77067780/|title=Cole Swindell tells dad: 'You should be here' in song |author= Cindy Watts|date= December 14, 2015 |work=The Tennessean}}</ref>\n\n===2018\u2013present: ''All of It'' and ''Stereotype''===\nSwindell released \"[[Break Up in the End]]\", the lead single from his third album, on February 23, 2018.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8286355/cole-swindell-break-up-in-the-end|title=It's Personal: Cole Swindell Finds the Heart Of 'Break Up In The End' |author=Tom Roland|date=April 4, 2018 |magazine=Billboard}}</ref> Swindell's third album, ''[[All of It]]'', was released on August 17, 2018.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://theboot.com/cole-swindell-2018-new-album-details-information/|title=Everything We Know About Cole Swindell's New Album, 'All of It'|author=Carena Liptak|date=June 1, 2018|work=The Boot}}</ref> After the album became available for pre-order in July 2018, Swindell released the number-one track \"[[Love You Too Late]]\" as a promotional single.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/cole-swindell-love-you-too-late/|title=Cole Swindell Teases New Song, 'Love You Too Late'|last=Hermanson|first=Wendy|date=12 July 2018 |access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref> \"Love You Too Late\" was announced as the album's official second single, being released to radio on November 19, 2018.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/cole-swindell-love-you-too-late-music-video/ | title=Cole Swindell Brings the Action in 'Love You Too Late' Video | website=Taste of Country | date=July 31, 2019 | access-date=October 15, 2019 | author=Jacklyn Krol}}</ref>\n\nThe lead single from Swindell's fourth studio album, \"[[Single Saturday Night]]\", was released on May 22, 2020.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/cole-swindell-single-saturday-night/|title=Cole Swindell Finds Love in 'Single Saturday Night' [LISTEN] |author=Cillea Houghton|date=May 22, 2020 |work=Taste of Country}}</ref> It was followed by \"[[Never Say Never (Cole Swindell and Lainey Wilson song)|Never Say Never]]\", a duet with [[Lainey Wilson]], on November 19, 2021.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/cole-swindell-lainey-wilson-never-say-never/|title=Cole Swindell + Lainey Wilson's Smoldering 'Never Say Never' Recalls the Best Bad Decisions [Listen] |author=Billy Dukes|date=November 22, 2021 |work=Taste of Country}}</ref> Swindell released his fourth album ''[[Stereotype (Cole Swindell album)|Stereotype]]'' on April 8, 2022.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://themusicuniverse.com/cole-swindell-announces-sterotype/|title=Cole Swindell announces 'Stereotype' |author=Buddy Iahn|date=February 4, 2022 |work=The Music Universe}}</ref> Swindell followed the album up with its third single, \"[[She Had Me at Heads Carolina]]\", a remake of [[Jo Dee Messina]]'s 1996 single \"[[Heads Carolina, Tails California]]\". This single has gone on to become the biggest single of Swindell's career so far, having spent four weeks at number one on the [[Country Airplay]] chart, as well as becoming his first Top 20 single on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and was certified [[Multi-Platinum|three-times]] Platinum by [[RIAA]].\n\n==Personal life==\nSwindell is married to Courtney Little, a former member of the [[Charlotte Honey Bees]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Singer Cole Swindell and Courtney Little Wed in Sonoma, 1 Year After Engagement |url=https://people.com/singer-cole-swindell-courtney-little-wed-in-sonoma-8663343 |website=Peoplemag |access-date=14 June 2024 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Who Is Cole Swindell's Fianc\u00e9e? All About Courtney Little |url=https://people.com/who-is-courtney-little-cole-swindell-7964972 |website=Peoplemag |access-date=14 June 2024 |language=en}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Cole Swindell discography}}\n'''Studio albums'''\n* ''[[Cole Swindell (album)|Cole Swindell]]'' (2014)\n* ''[[You Should Be Here (Cole Swindell album)|You Should Be Here]]'' (2016)\n* ''[[All of It]]'' (2018)\n* ''[[Stereotype (Cole Swindell album)|Stereotype]]'' (2022)\n\n==Tours==\n'''Headlining'''\n*Reason to Drink Tour (2018)<ref>{{cite web|author=Cillea Houghton |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/cole-swindell-2018-reason-to-drink-tour-dates-dustin-lynch-lauren-alaina/ |title=Cole Swindell Announces Tour With Dustin Lynch, Lauren Alaina |website=Tasteofcountry.com |date=23 July 2018 |access-date=2020-04-29}}</ref>\n*The Down to Earth Tour (2020)<ref>{{cite news|title=Cole Announces The Down Home Tour presented by Monster Energy Outbreak|url=http://www.coleswindell.com/news/cole-announces-down-home-tour-presented-monster-energy-outbreak-36131|access-date=October 14, 2015|work=Cole Swindell|date=August 25, 2015}}</ref>\n\n'''Supporting'''\n*[[Burn It Down Tour]] with [[Jason Aldean]] (2015)\n*[[The Big Revival Tour]] with [[Kenny Chesney]] (2015)\n*[[Dig Your Roots Tour]] with [[Florida Georgia Line]] (2016)\n*What the Hell Tour with [[Dierks Bentley]] (2017)\n*Sunset Repeat Tour with [[Luke Bryan]] (2019)\n*[[Center Point Road Tour]] with [[Thomas Rhett]] (2021)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Hunter_Hayes","to":"Hunter Hayes"}],"pages":{"4202928":{"pageid":4202928,"ns":0,"title":"Hunter Hayes","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter and record producer}}\n{{About|the artist|the album|Hunter Hayes (album)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2015}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Hunter Hayes\n| background        = solo_singer\n| image             = Hayes in Memphis (cropped).jpg\n| caption           = Hayes performing in Memphis, TN in August 2019\n| birth_name        = Hunter Easton Hayes\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1991|09|09}}\n| birth_place       = [[Breaux Bridge, Louisiana]], U.S.\n| genre             = {{hlist|[[Country pop]]|[[R&B]]|[[Blues music|blues]]|[[Pop music|pop]]|[[Country music|country]]|[[Cajun music|cajun]]|[[pop rock]]|[[alternative rock]]}}\n| years_active      = 1993\u2013present\n| occupation        = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|record producer|multi-instrumentalist}}\n| instrument        = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|piano|accordion}}\n| label             = {{hlist|[[Atlantic Records|Atlantic Nashville]]|[[Warner Music Nashville|Warner Nashville]]|LP Entertainment}}\n| associated_acts   = {{hlist|[[Lady A]]|[[Hunter Brothers]]}}\n| website           = {{URL|hunterhayes.com}}\n}}\n'''Hunter Easton Hayes''' (born September 9, 1991)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnewsnashville.com/hunter-hayes-celebrates-his-20th-birthday-at-house-of-blues|title=Hunter Hayes Celebrates His 20th Birthday at House of Blues|author=Dan Harr|work=Music News Nashville|date=September 14, 2011|access-date=September 14, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111110064648/http://www.musicnewsnashville.com/hunter-hayes-celebrates-his-20th-birthday-at-house-of-blues|archive-date=November 10, 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref> is an American multi-genre singer, songwriter, record producer, and multi-instrumentalist. He is proficient at more than 30 instruments.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6077406/hunter-hayes-leads-country-youth-revolution-storyline-video-interview|title=Hunter Hayes Leads Country's Youth Revolution, Without a Pickup Truck or Beer in Sight|author=Deborah Evans Price|magazine=Billboard|date=May 6, 2014|access-date=May 6, 2014}}</ref>\n\nHayes released his [[Hunter Hayes (album)|self-titled debut album]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/hunter-hayes-debut-album/ |title=Hunter Hayes Sets Release Date for Debut Album |work=Taste of Country |date=August 24, 2011 |access-date=November 7, 2011 |first=Amanda |last=Hensel}}</ref> It reached number seven on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and number one on the [[Top Country Albums]], and sold over 1.1 million copies. Its most successful single, \"[[Wanted (Hunter Hayes song)|Wanted]]\", sold over 3.5 million copies and made Hayes the youngest male act to ever top the [[Hot Country Songs|''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs]].\n\nHayes' commercial success and his talent both as a songwriter and instrumentalist prompted ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' to call him the leader of \"Country Music's Youth Revolution\" in 2014.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6077406/hunter-hayes-leads-country-youth-revolution-storyline-video-interview |title=Hunter Hayes Leads Country's Youth Revolution, Without a Pickup Truck or Beer in Sight |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=May 6, 2014}}</ref> He has been nominated for five [[Grammy Award]]s including [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]], and won the 2012 [[CMA Award]] for [[Country Music Association Award for New Artist of the Year|New Artist of the Year]] and three [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI Awards]].\n\n==Life and career==\nHayes was born on September 9, 1991, in [[Breaux Bridge, Louisiana]]; he is an only child.<ref>[http://www.hunterhayes.com/bio Hunter's Story] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209104810/http://www.hunterhayes.com/bio |date=February 9, 2012 }}. HunterHayes.com. Retrieved on February 21, 2012.</ref> His parents both have [[Cajuns|Cajun]] ancestry, along with [[English people|English]], [[Scotch-Irish Americans|Scots-Irish]], and [[Germans|German]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0371048/bio?ref_=nm_ov_bio_sm#trivia|title=Hunter Hayes : Biography|publisher=IMDb.com|access-date=May 10, 2014}}</ref> He grew up [[Catholic Church|Catholic]], singing songs in both English and French.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20123577,00.html |title=Squeeze Play |journal=People |first=Jeremy |last=Helligar |date=October 27, 1997 |volume=48 |issue=17 |page=113 |access-date=May 2, 2013 |archive-date=April 21, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421054547/http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20123577,00.html |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Wilkinson |first=Hannah |title=You Are Good Enough: Hunter Hayes and Jen Ledger Find Their Value In Christ |url=https://www.jesuscalling.com/podcast/good-enough-hunter-hayes-jen-ledger-find-value-christ/ |access-date=2022-08-14 |website=Jesus Calling |date=August 16, 2018 |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nHayes started performing when he was 2. At 4, he began making appearances locally and on national television,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iz0dAAAAIBAJ&pg=5100,573829&dq=hunter-hayes+accordion&hl=en|title=Kids keep Cajun traditions thriving|last=Rose|first=Christopher|date=April 4, 1997|work=The Tuscaloosa News|access-date=June 30, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/hunter-hayes-music-interview-2011/|title=Hunter Hayes Was 'Born' to Make Country Music|last=Conaway|first=Alanna|work=Taste of Country|date=June 13, 2011 |access-date=June 30, 2011}}</ref> including ''[[Maury (TV series)|Maury]]'', ''[[Rosie O'Donnell Show]]'', and the [[Nickelodeon]] game show ''[[Figure It Out]]'', where he performed \"[[Jambalaya (On the Bayou)]]\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mPpjNgdT2dk/ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211219/mPpjNgdT2dk |archive-date=2021-12-19 |url-status=live|title=Hunter Hayes - \"Jambalaya\" on Figure it Out|website=[[YouTube]]|date=October 16, 2011 |access-date=August 1, 2012}}{{cbignore}}</ref> [[American Songwriter]] writes that \"Hayes received his first guitar from actor [[Robert Duvall]] at age 6\"<ref name=\"American Songwriter\">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/05/hunter-hayes-is-martin-guitars-latest-brand-ambassador/ |title=Hunter Hayes Is Martin Guitars' Latest Brand Ambassador |magazine=American Songwriter |author=Evan Schlansky |date=May 21, 2012 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128022554/http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/05/hunter-hayes-is-martin-guitars-latest-brand-ambassador/ |archive-date=January 28, 2013 |access-date=June 6, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> At age 7, he was invited to perform for President [[Bill Clinton]] for a [[White House]] lawn party. At 13, he appeared on [[America's Most Talented Kids]], a show hosted by [[Dave Coulier]]; he performed the hit [[Hank Williams]] song, \"[[Hey Good Lookin' (song)|Hey Good Lookin']]\". At age 9, Hunter released his debut independent studio album ''\"Through My Eyes\"'' on October 8, 2000, under Suagartown Records and Louisiana Red Hot Records.<ref>{{cite web|title=Through My Eyes - Hunter Hayes {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits {{!}} AllMusic|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/through-my-eyes-mw0000053846|website=AllMusic|access-date=29 December 2017}}</ref> He released several more independent albums: ''Make a Wish'' in 2001, ''Holidays with Hunter'' in 2003, ''Honoring our French Heritage'' in 2006, and ''Songs About Nothing'' in 2008.\n\nIn 2008, he moved from Breaux Bridge to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], and signed with [[Universal Music Publishing Group]] as a songwriter. In 2010, Hayes co-wrote \"Play\" for the [[Rascal Flatts]] album ''[[Nothing Like This (album)|Nothing Like This]]''. In September, he was signed to [[Atlantic Records]] Nashville and began working on what would become his major-label debut.\n\nHayes appeared as the opening act of 10 dates of country star [[Taylor Swift]]'s [[Speak Now World Tour]] throughout the summer of 2011 and concluded his leg of the tour in St. Louis, Missouri.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunter-hayes-will-open-taylor-swift-speak-now-north-american-tour-2011 |title=Hunter Hayes will open for Taylor Swift SPEAK NOW North American Tour 2011 |work=HunterHayes.com |date=March 4, 2011 |access-date=May 2, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120506142749/http://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunter-hayes-will-open-taylor-swift-speak-now-north-american-tour-2011 |archive-date=May 6, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In April 2011, he went on his own radio tour where he debuted songs that would appear on his debut album.<ref name=\"radiotour\">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mpNAs08ZcVc  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211219/mpNAs08ZcVc |archive-date=2021-12-19 |url-status=live|title=Hunter Hayes \u2013 Radio Tour (Week 1) |access-date=October 30, 2011 |author=Hunter Hayes |website=[[YouTube]] |date=April 2011}}{{cbignore}}</ref> His debut headlining tour was the Most Wanted Tour; the first leg of the tour began on October 8, 2011, in [[Beaumont, Texas]], and ended on December 4, 2011, in [[San Bernardino, California]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/hunter-hayes-2011-tour-dates/ |title=Hunter Hayes Sets Fall 2011 Tour Dates |work=Taste of Country |date=September 13, 2011 |access-date=November 7, 2011 |first=Alanna |last=Conaway}}</ref>\n\nHayes and singer [[Victoria Justice]] contributed a duet to the soundtrack of 2011's ''[[Footloose (2011 film)|Footloose]]'' remake, recording a cover of [[Mike Reno]]'s and [[Ann Wilson]]'s 1984 hit \"[[Almost Paradise (song)|Almost Paradise]]\" from the original film. From January to February 2012, Hayes was the opening act on the [[Rascal Flatts]] \"Thaw Out\" tour.<ref>[http://www.rascalflatts.com/story/news/rascal-flatts-announce-ithaw-out-2012i-tour Rascal Flatts Announce Thaw Out 2012 Tour]. RascalFlatts.com (October 17, 2011). Retrieved on February 21, 2012.</ref>\n[[File:Hunter Hayes.jpg|thumb|Hayes signing autographs in [[Frederick, Maryland]] in August 2012]]\n\n\"Where We Left Off\" is an original song, written by Hayes, that can be heard on the [[Act of Valor: The Album|soundtrack]] for the 2012 war film ''[[Act of Valor]]''.<ref>[http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/entertainment/53539733-81/act-valor-original-songs.html.csp 'Act of Valor' soundtrack features original songs from Lady Antebellum, more]. Sltrib.com (February 20, 2012). Retrieved on 2012-02-21.</ref>\n\nDuring the 2012 [[O Music Awards]], [[The Flaming Lips]] broke a [[Guinness World Record]] (previously held by [[Jay-Z]]) for most concerts played in multiple cities in a 24-hr. period. Hayes was the opening act for them at the Hattiesburg stop.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1688734/hunter-hayes-performs-on-o-music-awards.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105061428/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1688734/hunter-hayes-performs-on-o-music-awards.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 5, 2012 |title=Hunter Hayes Performs on O Music Awards |work=[[Country Music Television]] |date=June 28, 2012 |access-date=May 2, 2013}}</ref>\n\nIn May 2012, [[Martin Guitars]] named Hayes as C.F. Martin & Co.'s newest brand ambassador. [[American Songwriter]] quoted Hayes on the subject: \"It is an absolute honor to be named an official Martin Ambassador and to be recognized by the Martin family.\"<ref name=\"American Songwriter\"/>\n\nOn September 7, 2012, he was inducted at the [[Mahalia Jackson Theater]] in [[New Orleans|New Orleans, Louisiana]], into the [[Louisiana Music Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/hunter-hayes-inducted-louisiana-music-194054387.html |title=Hunter Hayes Inducted Into Louisiana Music Hall of Fame |work=[[Yahoo! Finance]] |date=September 10, 2012 |access-date=May 2, 2013}}</ref>\n\n===2011\u20132014: ''Hunter Hayes'' and ''Storyline''===\n[[File:Hunter Hayes Gettysburg, PA.png|thumb|Hayes performing in 2013]]\n[[File:Five-time Grammy nominee Hunter Hayes performs his national anthem soundcheck, hours before Game 6 of the World Series. (30415750290).jpg|thumbnail|Hayes doing a soundcheck at [[Progressive Field]] in preparation for his performance of the [[Star Spangled Banner|US national anthem]] at Game 6 of the [[2016 World Series]]]]\n\nHayes's debut single, \"[[Storm Warning (song)|Storm Warning]]\", released to radio on May 16, 2011. His [[Hunter Hayes (album)|self-titled]] major-label debut album was released on October 11, 2011.<ref>[http://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunter-hayes-release-self-titled-debut-album-atlantic-records-october-11 HUNTER HAYES TO RELEASE SELF-TITLED DEBUT ALBUM ON ATLANTIC RECORDS OCTOBER 11] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220175525/http://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunter-hayes-release-self-titled-debut-album-atlantic-records-october-11 |date=February 20, 2012 }}. HunterHayes.com (August 24, 2011). Retrieved on 2012-02-21.</ref> He co-wrote every song, played every instrument, and along with Dann Huff, produced the album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=5319|title=Hunter Hayes becomes Next Big Thing|date=April 22, 2011|work=Country Standard Time|access-date=June 30, 2011}}</ref> \"[[Wanted (Hunter Hayes song)|Wanted]]\", the second single, was released to radio on March 5, 2012.\n\nOn July 24, 2012, he appeared on the CBS's ''The Talk'', where he was then given an RIAA Gold Certification plaque for \"Wanted\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunters-interview-and-performance-talk |title=Hunter's Interview And Performance On The Talk |work=HunterHayes.com |date=July 25, 2012 |access-date=May 2, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015165352/http://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunters-interview-and-performance-talk |archive-date=October 15, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Just shy of two months since \"Wanted\" went gold, the song was certified Platinum by RIAA on August 23, 2012.\n\n\"Wanted\" became his first No. 1 single,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/hunter-hayes-wanted-no-1-single/ |title=Hunter Hayes Gets What He 'Wanted' With First No. 1 Single |work=Taste of Country |date=September 18, 2012 |first=Alanna |last=Conaway |access-date=May 2, 2013}}</ref> making him the youngest solo male act to top Hot Country Songs, breaking the record set in 1973 by [[Johnny Rodriguez]].<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/475001/hunter-hayes-makes-history-little-big-town-shines-on-country-charts |title=Hunter Hayes Makes History, Little Big Town Shines on Country Charts |magazine=Billboard |date=September 20, 2012 |first=Wade |last=Jessen |access-date=May 2, 2013}}</ref> Twenty weeks after first appearing in the top spot and under a new chart format, \"Wanted\" returned to the top spot.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/1539423/ask-billboard-whats-so-unusual-about-hunter-hayes-new-no-1/ |title=Ask Billboard: What's so unusual about Hunter Hayes's New No. 1 |magazine=Billboard |first=Gary |last=Trust |date=February 18, 2013 |access-date=May 2, 2013}}</ref> \"[[Somebody's Heartbreak]]\", the album's third single, went to No. 1 on the [[Country Airplay]] chart.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Hunter Hayes Dupe 1 - Chart History (Country Airplay)|url= https://www.billboard.com/artist/hunter-hayes-dupe-1/chart-history/csa/ |magazine=Billboard|accessdate=February 11, 2023}}</ref>\n\nStarting September 14, 2012, Hayes began appearing as the opening act on 90+ dates for [[Carrie Underwood]]'s [[Blown Away Tour]].\n\nHe was also nominated for three Grammys including [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] at the [[2013 Grammy Awards]]; he is the youngest male country artist to be nominated in all three categories for which he was nominated.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboardhcom/articles/columns/the-615/1538011/hunter-hayes-my-grammy-ritual |title=Hunter Hayes: My Grammy Ritual |magazine=Billboard |date=February 6, 2013 |first=Matt |last=Diehl |access-date=May 2, 2013 }}{{Dead link|date=January 2020 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=About Hunter Hayes|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/hunter-hayes/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121220034549/http://www.cmt.com/artists/hunter-hayes/|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 20, 2012|access-date=March 16, 2013}}</ref> The album's fourth single, \"[[I Want Crazy]]\", which is from the deluxe ''Encore'' edition, was released to country radio on April 7, 2013. It peaked at number two on the Country Airplay chart in August 2013. Following it was \"[[Everybody's Got Somebody but Me]]\", a re-recording of a song from the original press of the album. The re-recorded version features guest vocals from [[Jason Mraz]].\n\nHunter was one of five country singers who won a CMT Artist of the Year award in 2013. This award is awarded every year to a group of country musicians who have had an outstanding year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1718091/hunter-hayes-interview-cmt-artists-of-the-year.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131130075801/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1718091/hunter-hayes-interview-cmt-artists-of-the-year.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 30, 2013 |title=News : Hunter Hayes Interview: CMT Artists of the Year |publisher=CMT |date=November 28, 2013 |access-date=May 9, 2014}}</ref>\n\nHayes performed \"[[Invisible (Hunter Hayes song)|Invisible]]\", the lead single from his second album, at the [[56th Annual Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Craig Shelburne |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1721157/hunter-hayes-debuts-invisible-on-grammys.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140129074928/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1721157/hunter-hayes-debuts-invisible-on-grammys.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 29, 2014 |title=News : Hunter Hayes Debuts \"Invisible\" on Grammys |publisher=CMT |date=January 26, 2014 |access-date=May 9, 2014}}</ref> ''[[Storyline (Hunter Hayes album)|Storyline]]'' was released on May 6, 2014.<ref name=\"news.radio.com\">{{cite web |url=http://news.radio.com/2014/03/11/hunter-hayes-new-album-storyline-to-drop-may-6/ |title=Hunter Hayes' New Album 'Storyline' to Drop May 6 \u00ab Radio.com |publisher=News.radio.com |date=March 11, 2014 |access-date=May 9, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140321031056/http://news.radio.com/2014/03/11/hunter-hayes-new-album-storyline-to-drop-may-6/ |archive-date=March 21, 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In an effort to promote his album and to raise awareness to end child hunger, Hunter broke the Guinness World Record for the most concerts played in multiple cities in 24 hours, previously held by [[The Flaming Lips]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6084729/hunter-hayes-breaks-the-flaming-lips-guinness-world-record-while-raising-awareness-most-concerts-played-in-multiple-cities-in-24-hours-conagra-Foods |title=Hunter Hayes Breaks Guinness World Record For Most Concerts Played in multiple cities in 24 hours |magazine=Billboard |date=May 10, 2014 |access-date=August 9, 2014}}</ref> The album's second single, \"[[Tattoo (Hunter Hayes song)|Tattoo]]\" released to country radio on June 16, 2014.\n\nOn July 20, 2014, Hayes's self-titled debut album was certified double platinum by the RIAA.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&ar=Hunter+Hayes&ti=Hunter+Hayes#search_section|title=Gold & Platinum - RIAA|website=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]}}</ref> Following that was \"[[Light Me Up (Hunter Hayes song)|Light Me Up]]\", another single from the deluxe version of his debut album, in 2015.\n\n===2015\u20132018: ''The 21 Project'' and canceled album===\nOn May 21, 2015, Hayes released \"[[21 (Hunter Hayes song)|21]]\", which was the title track for both his EP and third studio album, [[The 21 Project]]. He also appeared on the track \"I Can Play Guitar\" on [[Brett Kissel]]'s album ''[[Pick Me Up (album)|Pick Me Up]]''.\n\nOn November 2, 2016, Hayes performed with four holograms of himself on Jimmy Kimmel Live's after the CMA show.\n\nIn March 2017, Hayes performed as part of the [[C2C: Country to Country]] festival in the UK where he played alongside [[Dan + Shay]] and [[Darius Rucker]] supporting [[Reba McEntire]] and would return in 2019 with [[Carly Pearce]] and [[Dustin Lynch]] in support of [[Lady A]]. Following \"21,\" Hayes released several songs including \u201c[[Yesterday's Song|Yesterday\u2019s Song]]\u201d which were slated to be part of a studio album set to be released in February 2018. Hayes then canceled the project citing \u201cshifted priorities.\u201d<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8527354/hunter-hayes-wild-blue-interview|title=Hunter Hayes on His New Album, 'Wild Blue': 'What This Record Did for Me Was Something Pretty Profound'|first= Melinda |last=Newman |date= August 14, 2019 |magazine=Billboard }}</ref>\n\nHayes also appeared as a guest star in the Nickelodeon show ''Bella and the Bulldogs''.{{Citation needed|date=July 2019}}\n\n===2018\u2013present: ''Wild Blue'' and ''Red Sky''===\n{{see also|Red Sky (Hunter Hayes album) }}\nIn December 2018, Hayes guest starred on ''[[Darci Lynne]]: My Hometown Christmas''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Delbel|first1=Julia|title=Star-Studded Lineup Revealed for 'Darci Lynne: A Hometown Christmas'|url=https://talentrecap.com/got-talent/agt/2018/10/20/star-studded-lineup-revealed-darci-lynne-hometown-christmas/|work=Talent Recap|date=20 October 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181022232716/https://talentrecap.com/got-talent/agt/2018/10/20/star-studded-lineup-revealed-darci-lynne-hometown-christmas/|archive-date=October 22, 2018|url-status=dead}}</ref> He also recorded a duet with Irish singer [[Catherine McGrath]] for her debut album ''[[Talk of This Town (album)|Talk of This Town]]''.\n\nIn January 2019, Hayes released his first radio single in three years titled \"Heartbreak\" which was the lead single for an upcoming album to be released by [[Warner Music Nashville]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Future Releases for Country Radio Stations\n|url=https://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases |website=All Access Media |access-date=February 16, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190216014058/https://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases |archive-date=February 16, 2019}}</ref> Hayes headlined the [[Closer to You Tour]] in 2019 with [[Levi Hummon]] and [[Tegan Marie]] as supporting acts.<ref>{{cite web|last=Krol|first=Jacklyn|title= Hunter Hayes Sets Spring 2019 Closer to You Tour|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/hunter-hayes-21-tour-fall-2015/ |publisher=Taste of Country|date=August 14, 2015|access-date=24 June 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Casey|first=Jim|title= Hunter Hayes Drops New Single & Will Hit the Road for \"Closer to You\" Tour |url= https://www.thecountrydaily.com/2019/03/25/hunter-hayes-drops-new-single-will-hit-the-road-for-closer-to-you-tour/|website=The Country Daily|publisher=Cumulus Media|date=March 25, 2019|access-date=24 June 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hollabaugh|first=Lorie|url= https://musicrow.com/2019/02/hunter-hayes-to-launch-closer-to-you-tour-in-april/|title= Hunter Hayes to Launch Closer to You Tour in April|work=MusicRow Magazine|date=February 7, 2019|access-date=24 June 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn August 2019, Hayes made a surprise announcement on [[NBC|NBC's]] [[Today (American TV program)|Today Show]] revealing his album ''[[Wild Blue (Part I)]]'' would be released on August 16, 2019.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunter-hayes-soars-new-album-wild-blue-part-i-6956|title=HUNTER HAYES SOARS ON NEW ALBUM \"WILD BLUE (PART I)\"|date= August 14, 2019 |work=Warner Music Nashville}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2019/08/14/hunter-hayes-shares-heartbreak-growth-new-album-wild-blue/1948649001/|title=Hunter Hayes to drop 'Wild Blue,' surprise album of heartbreak, turbulence|first=Cindy |last=Watts |date= August 14, 2019 |work=The Tennessean}}</ref> The album is the first part of a three-part \u2018trilogy\u2019 of albums.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/hunter-hayes-wild-blue/|title=HUNTER HAYES ANNOUNCES 'WILD BLUE' ALBUM, RELEASES TITLE TRACK [LISTEN]|first= Jacklyn |last=Krol |date= August 14, 2019 |work=Taste of Country }}</ref>\n\nIn April 2020, Hayes competed in the [[The Masked Singer (American TV series) season 3|third season]] of ''[[The Masked Singer (American TV series)|The Masked Singer]]'' as \"Astronaut\".<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://variety.com/2020/tv/news/the-masked-singer-season-3-episode-14-recap-astronaut-1234593561/ |title = 'The Masked Singer' Reveals the Identity of the Astronaut: Here's the Star Under the Mask|date = April 30, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.eonline.com/news/1146480/the-masked-singer-unmasks-the-astronaut |title = The Masked Singer Unmasks the Astronaut|date = April 30, 2020}}</ref> In June 2020, the [[Saskatchewan]]-based [[Hunter Brothers]] released their single \"[[Hard Dirt]]\", co-written and produced by Hayes.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://openroadrecordings.com/news/hunter-brothers-drop-highly-anticipated-new-single-hard-dirt-june-12/ |title=Hunter Brothers drop highly-anticipated new single \"Hard Dirt\" June 12 |date=June 5, 2020 |access-date=June 11, 2020 |work=[[Open Road Recordings]] }}{{Dead link|date=August 2024 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He also co-wrote and produced their 2021 single \"[[Been a Minute]]\".<ref>{{cite news|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2021/03/20/timing-is-everything-and-the-time-couldnt-be-more-perfect-for-the-hunter-brothers-to-release-their-new-single-been-a-minute/|title= Timing is everything and the time couldn't be more perfect for the Hunter Brothers to release their new single \"Been a Minute\"|date=March 20, 2021|access-date=March 22, 2021|work=Canadian Beats Media}}</ref>\n\nIn October 2021, Hayes released the album ''Wild Blue Complete'' an extension of the album ''Wild Blue (Part I)''.<ref>{{Cite web|title=\"Wild Blue Complete\"|url=https://www.hunterhayes.com/news/wild-blue-complete|access-date=2022-01-09|website=Hunter Hayes|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2023, Hayes released the album ''[[Red Sky (Hunter Hayes album)|Red Sky]].''<ref>{{Cite web |last=Fisher |first=Kelly |date=21 April 2023 |title=Hunter Hayes Unleashes Long-Awaited 'Red Sky' After Years In The Making |url=https://country.iheart.com/content/2023-04-21-hunter-hayes-unleashes-long-awaited-red-sky-after-years-in-the-making/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230421180104/https://country.iheart.com/content/2023-04-21-hunter-hayes-unleashes-long-awaited-red-sky-after-years-in-the-making/ |archive-date=21 April 2023 |access-date=2023-07-10 |website=iHeartCountry Radio |language=en}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Hunter Hayes discography}}\n\n* ''Through My Eyes'' (2000)\n* ''Make a Wish'' (2001)<ref>{{cite web|title=Make a Wish - Hunter Hayes {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits {{!}} AllMusic|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/through-my-eyes-mw0000053846|website=Kid's Music|access-date=25 October 2013}}</ref>\n* ''Holidays with Hunter'' (2003)<ref>{{cite web|title=Holidays with Hunter - Hunter Hayes {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits {{!}} Year\n! Title\n! Role\n! Notes\n|-\n| 1997\n| ''[[The Apostle]]''\n| Child Accordionist\n|\n|-\n| 1998\n| ''[[Figure It Out]]''\n| Himself/Guest\n|\n|-\n| 2000\n| ''[[My Dog Skip (film)|My Dog Skip]]'' \n| Accordion Boy\n| \n|-\n| 2003\n| ''[[Charley's War]]'' \n| Montgomery\n|\n|-\n| 2016\n| ''[[Bella and the Bulldogs]]''\n| Himself\n|\n|-\n|2020\n| ''[[The Masked Singer (American season 3)|The Masked Singer]]'' \n| Astronaut\n|\n|-\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{{BLP sources section|date=October 2018}}\n\n===Academy of Country Music Awards===\nThe [[Academy of Country Music Awards]], also known as the ACM Awards, were first held in 1966, honoring the industry's accomplishments during the previous year. It was the first country music awards program held by a major organization. The academy's signature \"hat\" trophy was created in 1968. The awards were first televised in 1972 on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]].\n\n{|class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year !! Category !! Nominated Work !! Result\n|-\n| rowspan=\"4\"|2013\n| New Male Vocalist of the Year<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://knue.com/a-look-at-the-acm-nominees-for-new-male-vocalist/|title=A Look At The ACM Nominees for New Male Vocalist|last=Reynolds|first=Leslie|website=101.5 KNUE|date=January 22, 2013 |access-date=2019-01-15}}</ref>\n| Hunter Hayes\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Single Record of the Year<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/2013-acm-awards-winners/|title=2013 ACM Awards Winners \u2013 Full List|last=Staff|first=Taste of Country|website=Taste of Country|date=April 8, 2013 |access-date=2019-01-15}}</ref>\n| rowspan=\"3\"|\"[[Wanted (Hunter Hayes song)|Wanted]]\"\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Song of the Year<ref name=\":0\" />\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Video of the Year<ref name=\":0\" />\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n|}\n\n===American Country Awards===\nThe [[American Country Awards]] is a country music awards show, entirely voted on by fans. Created by the Fox Network, the awards honor country music artists in music, video, and touring categories. Hayes has won two awards from five nominations.\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n!Year\n!Category\n!Nominee / work\n!Result\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2012\n| New Artist of the Year\n| Hunter Hayes\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Single by a New Artist\n| rowspan=\"2\"|\"[[Wanted (Hunter Hayes song)|Wanted]]\"\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Music Video by a New Artist\n| {{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"| 2013\n| Breakthrough Artist of the Year\n| Hunter Hayes\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Single by a Breakthrough\n| \"Somebody's Heartbreak\"\n| {{nom}}\n|}\n\n===Grammy Awards===\nA [[Grammy Award]] (originally called '''Gramophone Award'''), or '''Grammy''', is an accolade by the [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]] (NARAS) of the United States to recognize outstanding achievement in the [[music industry]]. The annual presentation ceremony features performances by prominent artists, and the presentation of those awards that have a more popular interest.\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n!Year\n!Category\n!Nominee / work\n!Result\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"|[[2013 Grammy Awards|2013]]\n| [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]]\n| Hunter Hayes\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]]\n| ''Hunter Hayes''\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"|[[Grammy Award for Best Country Solo Performance|Best Country Solo Performance]]\n| \"[[Wanted (Hunter Hayes song)|Wanted]]\"\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[2014 Grammy Awards|2014]]\n| \"[[I Want Crazy]]\"\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[2015 Grammy Awards|2015]]\n| \"[[Invisible (Hunter Hayes song)|Invisible]]\"\n| {{nom}}\n|}\n\n===Other awards===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Aleyce_Simmonds","to":"Aleyce Simmonds"}],"pages":{"38863479":{"pageid":38863479,"ns":0,"title":"Aleyce Simmonds","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2020}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=March 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Aleyce Simmonds\n| image           = Aleyce.jpg\n| caption         = Aleyce Simmonds in 2016\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|df=y|1986|12|6}}\n| birth_place     = [[Port Macquarie, New South Wales]], Australia\n| origin          = [[Tamworth, New South Wales]], Australia<ref name=\"travelin1\">{{cite news|title=Aleyce-Simmonds-from-Tamwort|newspaper=Traveling In|url=https://www.travelin.com.au/articles/Aleyce-Simmonds-from-Tamworth-03210|accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref>\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Country pop]], [[Country rock]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 2001\u2013present\n| label           = [[Capitol Records Nashville]], [[Sony BMG]], [[Universal Music Australia]]\n| associated_acts = [[Amber Lawrence]]<br />Christie Lamb<br />[[Dianna Corcoran]]<br />Paul Costa<br />[[The Wildes|Lachlan Bryan & The Wildes]]<br />[[Dean Perrett]]<br />[[Ryan Sampson (singer)|Ryan Sampson]]<br />[[Tommy Emmanuel]]<br />[[Graeme Connors]]\n| website         = {{URL|www.aleyce.com/}}\n}}\n'''Aleyce Simmonds''' (born 6 December 1986 in [[Port Macquarie, New South Wales]]) is an Australian country music recording artist and singer-songwriter. Simmonds' accolades include the [[Telstra]] Road to Tamworth Winner in 2004. As a part of her prize Aleyce visited [[Nashville]] and recorded a successful single, \"Mighty, Mighty Love\". Simmonds also won an [[APRA Award]], in 2017 for Country Work of the Year, with her song \"Greatest Companion\".<ref>{{cite news|title=Young dance and pop songwriters dominate the APRA Music Awards\n|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/young-dance-and-pop-songwriters-dominate-the-apra-music-awards-led-by-flume-and-troye-sivan/news-story/d8a383e134df3841023d338ed0e920fd/|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref>\n\nShe won Australian and National Duet of the year winner with Paul Costa for \"The Way You Make Me Feel\" in 2007.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tamworth's sweetheart \u2013 Aleyce Simmonds|newspaper=Tamworth Country Life|url=http://www.tamworthcountrylife.com.au/tamworths-sweetheart-aleyce-simmonds/|accessdate=22 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330195646/http://tamworthcountrylife.com.au/tamworths-sweetheart-aleyce-simmonds/|archive-date=30 March 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nSimmonds received her 7th [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Golden Guitar]] (Country Music Awards of Australia) nomination in 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=ALEYCE SIMMONDS NOMINATED FOR SIXTH GOLDEN GUITAR\n|url=http://www.nbnnews.com.au/2015/12/08/aleyce-simmonds-nominated-for-sixth-golden-guitar/|accessdate=30 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Toyota Golden Guitar Awards Finalists|url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/2018-Toyota-Golden-Guitar-Awards-Finalists/|accessdate=20 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171124120549/http://www.tcmf.com.au/2018-Toyota-Golden-Guitar-Awards-Finalists|archive-date=24 November 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref> In 2014, Simmonds won Female Artist of the Year at the Australian Independent Country Music Awards for 2014. In October 2015, Simmonds was named Australian Independent Artist of the Year, Female Vocalist of the Year and awarded Best Country Single of the Year.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aleyce Simmonds|newspaper=Tamworth Country Music Festival|url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/Home/Media-Portal/Artists/Aleyce-Simmonds/|accessdate=26 June 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160813021726/http://www.tcmf.com.au/Home/Media-Portal/Artists/Aleyce-Simmonds/|archive-date=13 August 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n==Music career==\nSimmonds released her debut album in 2011 and 4 subsequent radio singles and music videos for \"The Keeper\", \"When I Say Too Much\", \"The Healing Hands of Time\" and \"Bondwood Boat\". All singles except \"Bondwood Boat\" achieved chart positions inside top 20.\n\nSimmonds was nominated for three [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Golden Guitar]] awards at the Country Music awards of Australia, The Healing Hands of Time, written with the album's producer [[Rod McCormack]] ([[Beccy Cole]], [[Adam Harvey]], [[Amber Lawrence]], [[Paul Kelly (Australian musician)|Paul Kelly]]) being nominated for Female Artist of the Year and New Talent of the Year and \"Bondwood Boat\" written with [[Graeme Connors]] being nominated for Heritage Song of the year. She performed the song with Connors at the Golden Guitars.<ref name=\"autogenerated1\"/>\n\nSimmonds was a finalist at the 2016 [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Golden Guitar]] Awards for APRA AMCOS Song of the Year with her song \"Joshua\", about her stillborn baby brother.<ref>{{cite web|title=APRA-AMCOS-Song-of-the-Yea|url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/APRA-AMCOS-Song-of-the-Year-/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160229160347/http://www.tcmf.com.au/APRA-AMCOS-Song-of-the-Year-/|url-status=dead|archive-date=29 February 2016|accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"travelin1\"/> \"Joshua\" was awarded the No. 1 spot on the [[2YOU|88.9FM Tamworth]] Country Music Top 20 charts for 2015. Aleyce also secured No. 12 with \"It Finds Us Anyway\" and No. 14 with \"The Greatest Companion\" on the local station's countdown.<ref>{{cite web|title=Being Awarded #1 on Yearly Countdown| website=[[Facebook]] |url=https://www.facebook.com/509474795861709/photos/a.564366963705825.1073741829.509474795861709/644971785645342/?type=3&theater|accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref>\n\nAt the [[APRA Music Awards of 2017]] Simmonds won the category, Country Work of the Year, with her song, \"Greatest Companion\";<ref name=\"CWotYNom17\">{{cite web | url = http://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2017-awards/apra-music-awards/country/ | title = Country Work of the Year | publisher = [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) &#124; [[Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society]] (AMCOS) | year = 2017 | accessdate = 5 April 2017 | archive-date = 5 April 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170405173405/http://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2017-awards/apra-music-awards/country/ | url-status = dead }}</ref> it was inspired by being in the studio with Luke Bona on [[2UE]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Tamworth's Aleyce Simmonds named 2017 APRA Country Work of the Year recipient|url=http://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/4574397/our-golden-girl-aleyce-simmonds-takes-home-apra-honour/|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Aleyce Simmonds nominated for APRA honour|url=https://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/4532776/our-aleyce-has-eyes-on-apra-nod/|date=17 March 2017|newspaper=The Northern Daily Leader|first=Haley|last=Craig|accessdate=20 March 2019}}</ref> \nIt's about how important overnight radio is to so many people. Aleyce was blown away by the amazing callers Bona receives throughout the night and how important the radio is to them.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aleyce Simmonds Inspiration for Greatest Companion|url=http://www.2ue.com.au/news/aleyce-simmonds-new-song-inspired-by-luke-bonas-overnight-show-20150827-gj9ka7.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160812064316/http://www.2ue.com.au/news/aleyce-simmonds-new-song-inspired-by-luke-bonas-overnight-show-20150827-gj9ka7.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=12 August 2016|accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nAleyce Simmonds was born on 6 December 1986 in [[Port Macquarie, New South Wales]] and moved when she was age 12 to [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]]. At age 13, Aleyce entered her first talent quest but did not win. Then at the age of 16 she entered the Country Capital Music Association's (CCMA) Talent Quest. She was voted the best overall artist under the age of 16 and won $1,000, with which she brought her first guitar.<ref>{{cite video|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=H59SqoRER78&feature=youtu.be|title=\nLee Kernaghan: The Stories, Aleyce Simmonds Part 1|publisher=YouTube|date=31 May 2011|accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"autogenerated1\">{{cite news|title=The Journey: Aleyce Simmonds|newspaper=ABC New England North West|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/audio/2012/10/29/3620717.htm|accessdate=22 March 2013}}</ref> She started writing songs and found she had a natural country sound, and by age 15 she was playing gigs in pubs around Tamworth. While Simmonds still tours regularly, she is currently living on her parents' hundred-acre property outside of Tamworth, where she spends weekdays writing songs before hitting the road to tour on the weekends.<ref name=\"travelin1\"/>\n\nSimmonds is the host for [[BalconyTV]] Tamworth.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tamworth shines on the world|url=http://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/4058121/tamworth-shines-on-the-world-stage/|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref> An online music show that features bands, musicians and other variety acts on balconies around the world.<ref>{{cite news|title=BalconyTV Tamworth|url=https://www.balconytv.com/tamworth|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160718104934/http://www.balconytv.com/tamworth|url-status=usurped|archive-date=18 July 2016|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref> Tamworth is the only city in Australia that is not a Capital City that has BalconyTV. It is in association with the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Tamworth to join global TV network|url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/News/Tamworth-to-join-global-TV-network/|accessdate=30 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130185203/http://www.tcmf.com.au/News/Tamworth-to-join-global-TV-network/|archive-date=30 November 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" border=\"1\"\n|+ List of studio albums, with Australian positions \n! scope=\"row\" | ''More Than Meets the Eye''\n|\n* Released: January 2017<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/more-than-meets-the-eye/1183852216|title=More Than Meets the Eye|website=Apple Music|accessdate=4 November 2020}}</ref>\n* Label: Aleyce Simmonds\n* Formats: CD, DD, streaming\n| align=\"center\" | 25\n|-\n! scope=\"row\" | ''Here & Now''\n|\n* Released: 17 January 2020<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/here-now/1491216755|title=Here & Now|website=Apple Music|accessdate=4 November 2020}}</ref>\n* Label: Aleyce Simmonds\n* Formats: CD, DD, streaming\n| align=\"center\" | 64\n|}\n\n==Awards==\n===APRA Awards===\nThe [[APRA Awards (Australia)|APRA Awards]] are held in Australia and New Zealand by the [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] to recognise songwriting skills, sales and airplay performance by its members annually.\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 2017|2017]]<ref name=\"APRA Mus Wins\">{{cite news | url = http://apraamcos.com.au/news/2017/april/2017-apra-music-award-winners-announced/ | title = 2017 APRA Music Award Winners Announced | publisher = Australasian Performing Right Association (APRA) &#124; Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society (AMCOS) | date = 3 April 2017 | accessdate = 5 April 2017 | archive-date = 5 April 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170405174348/http://apraamcos.com.au/news/2017/april/2017-apra-music-award-winners-announced/ | url-status = dead }}</ref>\n| \"Greatest Companion\"\n| Country Work of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Awards of Australia===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) (also known as the Golden Guitar Awards) is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. They have been held annually since 1973.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|accessdate=2 November 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2021\">{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-01-23/golden-guitars-awards-fanny-lumsden-sweeps-awards-in-tamworth/13081696|title=Fanny Lumsden wins five Golden Guitar Awards despite cancelled Tamworth Country Music Festival|website=ABC|date=23 January 2021|access-date=24 January 2021}}</ref>\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 2018\n| ''More Than Meets the Eye''\n| Female Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2021\n| \"True Blue\" (with [[Amber Lawrence]], [[Kirsty Lee Akers]] and [[Dianna Corcoran]])\n| Vocal Collaboration of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n* Note: wins only\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Simmonds, Aleyce}}\n[[Category:1986 births]]\n[[Category:APRA Award winners]]\n[[Category:Australian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Musicians from New South Wales]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian women singers]]\n[[Category:Australian women singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:People from Port Macquarie]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Caitlyn_Smith","to":"Caitlyn Smith"}],"pages":{"54192584":{"pageid":54192584,"ns":0,"title":"Caitlyn Smith","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2022}}\n{{Short description|American singer-songwriter and musician (born 1986)}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name = Caitlyn Smith\n| image =\n| caption = Smith performing at the [[C2C: Country to Country]] festival in 2022\n| birth_name = Caitlyn Elizabeth Smith\n| birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|06|13}}\n| birth_place = [[Cannon Falls, Minnesota]], U.S.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/caitlyn-smith-mn0000438452/biography | title=Caitlyn Smith biography | publisher=AllMusic | accessdate=March 9, 2021}}</ref>\n| origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre = [[Country Pop]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| occupation = {{hlist|Singer|Songwriter}}\n| label = [[Monument Records|Monument]]\n| website = {{url|caitlynsmith.com}}\n}}\n'''Caitlyn Elizabeth Smith'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/es/repertory#/ace/search/workID/883477058?page=1 |title=THE HEART OF DIXIE |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=September 19, 2023}}</ref> (born June 13, 1986) is an American singer-songwriter and musician. She was raised in [[Cannon Falls, Minnesota]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elle.com/culture/music/a44994/caitlyn-smith-profile/|title=How Caitlyn Smith Defied Sex Symbol Clich\u00e9s to Break Out in Nashville|date=May 2, 2017|work=ELLE|access-date=July 11, 2017|language=en}}</ref> Smith's debut album ''[[Starfire (Caitlyn Smith album)|Starfire]]'' was released on Monument Records on January 19, 2018.<ref name=\"auto\">{{Cite magazine|title= Caitlyn Smith Steps Into the Spotlight With 'Starfire' After Penning Songs for Meghan Trainor and Garth Brooks|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8070989/caitlyn-smith-starfire-premiere|access-date=December 19, 2017}}</ref> Her second studio album, ''Supernova'', was released on March 13, 2020.<ref name=\"supernova\"/> Her third album ''[[High & Low (Caitlyn Smith album)|High & Low]]'' was released on April 14, 2023.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Toth|first1=Emma|title=Caitlyn Smith To Release Self-Produced Third Album, 'High & Low'|url=https://countrynow.com/caitlyn-smith-to-release-self-produced-third-album-high-low/|website=Country Now|access-date=April 13, 2023|date=January 25, 2023}}</ref>\n\nShe has written songs recorded by [[Meghan Trainor]] (\"[[Like I'm Gonna Lose You]]\", duet with [[John Legend]], #1 on [[Adult Top 40|Billboard Adult Top 40]] chart), [[Kenny Rogers]] and [[Dolly Parton]] (\"[[You Can't Make Old Friends]]\"), [[Avicii]]  (\"Chained\") and (\"Love\"), [[Miley Cyrus]] (\"High\") and more.\n\nShe released the EP ''Starfire'' in July 2016. In January 2017, she announced she had signed a label deal with the newly reformed [[Monument Records]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Sony Music's Monument Records Revived By Jason Owen, Shane McAnally|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/7669714/monument-records-sony-music-label|website=Billboard.com|accessdate=July 11, 2017}}</ref> Smith has played at [[Lollapalooza]], Bourbon & Beyond Festival, Americana Fest and ACL Fest.<ref name=\"auto\"/>\n\nCaitlyn was named one of [[Rolling Stone Magazine]]'s \"10 New Artists You Need To Know\".<ref>{{cite web|title=10 New Country Artists You Need To Know: May 2016| date=May 4, 2016 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-may-2016-20160504/caitlyn-smith-20160504|publisher=Rolling Stone Country|accessdate=July 11, 2017}}</ref> She recorded \"The Card You Gamble\", the theme song of the drama series ''[[Monarch (American TV series)|Monarch]]'', which premiered in 2022.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://entertainment-focus.com/2022/01/14/listen-caitlyn-smith-unveils-the-card-you-gamble-the-theme-from-monarch/ | title=Listen: Caitlyn Smith unveils 'The Card You Gamble', the theme from 'Monarch' | date=January 14, 2022 }}</ref>\n\n== Personal life ==\nCaitlyn lives in Nashville with her husband, songwriter Rollie Gaalswyk. They have three sons together, Thomas Miles Gaalswyk (born in 2016), Lewis James Gaalswyk (born in 2018), and Jacob Roland Gaalswyk (born in 2023).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://people.com/parents/caitlyn-smith-welcomes-son-lewis-james/|title=Her New Little 'Starfire' Has Arrived! Caitlyn Smith Introduces Son Lewis James: 'So Grateful'|website=People.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2016/09/12/caitlyn-smith-welcomes-son-thomas-miles/|title=Caitlyn Smith Welcomes Son Thomas Miles|website=People.com|access-date=July 12, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/C0PGvfOsxX6/?img_index=1|title=Welcome to the world, JACOB ROLAND GAALSWYK!|website=Instagram.com}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Studio Miller \n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/awards/8547864/rocketman-joker-music-wins-2020-critics-choice-awards|title='Rocketman,' 'Joker,' 'Wild Rose' Take Home Top Music Prizes at 2020 Critics' Choice Awards|date=January 12, 2020|magazine=Billboard}}</ref>\n|-\n| rowspan=2|2022\n| [[2022 CMT Music Awards|CMT Music Awards]]\n| Breakthrough Video of the Year\n| \"I Can't\" <small>(with [[Old Dominion (band)|Old Dominion]])</small>\n| {{nominated}}\n| <ref>{{Cite web | url=https://deadline.com/2022/03/cmt-music-awards-nominations-2022-cbs-1234979574/ | title=CMT Music Awards Nominations: Kane Brown Leads Field, but First-Timers Abound | date=March 16, 2022 }}</ref>\n|-\n| [[57th Academy of Country Music Awards|Academy of Country Music Awards]]\n| rowspan=2| New Female Artist of the Year\n| rowspan=2| Caitlyn Smith\n| {{nominated}}\n| <ref>{{Cite magazine | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/2022-acm-awards-nominees-1297590/ | title=2022 ACM
