Awards|Academy of Country Music Awards]]\n| {{nominated}}\n|\n|}\n\n== References ==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{allMusic|artist/caitlyn-smith-mn0000438452}}\n*{{discogs artist}}\n\n{{Caitlyn Smith}}\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Smith, Caitlyn}}\n[[Category:1986 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country rock singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:People from Goodhue County, Minnesota]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Minnesota]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Minnesota]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Chase_Rice","to":"Chase Rice"}],"pages":{"38077204":{"pageid":38077204,"ns":0,"title":"Chase Rice","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter and football player}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Chase Rice\n| image           = Chase Rice - cropped.jpg\n| caption         = Rice in 2016\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1985|9|19}}<br>[[Ormond Beach, Florida]]\n| origin          = [[Asheville, North Carolina]], U.S.\n| instrument      = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country pop]]|[[country rock]]}}\n| occupation      = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}}\n| years_active    = 2010\u2013present\n| label           = {{hlist|Dack Janiels|[[Sony Music Nashville|Columbia Nashville]]|[[BBR Music Group|BBR]]}}\n| website         = {{URL|chaserice.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Chase Rice''' (born September 19, 1985<ref>{{cite news|last1=Casey|first1=Jim|title=Chase Rice Might talk New Single, Wikipedia Errors and Showing More \"Depth\" With an Upcoming Album|url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2016/07/01/chase-rice-talks-new-single-wikipedia-errors-and-showing-more-depth-with-upcoming-album/|access-date=July 2, 2016|work=Nash Country Daily|date=July 1, 2016}}</ref>) is an American [[country music]] singer, songwriter and reality television personality. He first came to prominence in 2010 while he was a contestant on ''[[Survivor: Nicaragua]]'', where he was the runner-up to [[Jud Birza|Jud \"Fabio\" Birza]]. In the same year Rice began focusing on a career in country music, and later co-wrote the diamond-certified single \"[[Cruise (song)|Cruise]]\", performed by [[Florida Georgia Line]].\n\nRice has released six studio albums, and his third album, ''[[Ignite the Night]]'', debuted atop the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6236407/chase-rice-country-albums-number-one|title=Chase Rice|date=August 28, 2014|magazine=Billboard|access-date=October 21, 2014}}</ref> He has also scored two number-one singles on the [[Country Airplay]] chart with \"[[Eyes on You (Chase Rice song)|Eyes on You]]\"<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8510439/chase-rice-eyes-on-you-no-1-country-airplay|title=Chase Rice Lands First Country Airplay No. 1 With 'Eyes On You'|magazine=Billboard|access-date=2019-08-28}}</ref> and \"[[Drinkin' Beer. Talkin' God. Amen.]]\" (featuring Florida Georgia Line). Prior to 2010, Rice was a former [[college football]] [[linebacker]] for the [[North Carolina Tar Heels football|North Carolina Tar Heels]] and a former [[NASCAR]] [[pit crew]] member for [[Hendrick Motorsports]].\n\n==Early life, education, and early career==\nBorn in Florida, Rice was raised on a farm in [[Asheville, North Carolina]]. He attended [[AC Reynolds High School]]<ref name=\"Chase Rice Biography\">{{cite web|title=Chase Rice Biography|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_6037395,00.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130124135747/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_6037395,00.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 24, 2013|work=Artists|publisher=Great American Country}}</ref> and the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] where he was a linebacker on the [[North Carolina Tar Heels football|football team]]. He did not pursue an [[National Football League|NFL]] career due to injury.<ref name=\"Debuts Big\">{{cite news|last=Dauphin|first=Chuck|title=Spotlight: Ex-'Survivor' Star Chase Rice Debuts Big With 'Dirt Road Communion'|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/488389/spotlight-ex-survivor-star-chase-rice-debuts-big-with-dirt-road|newspaper=Billboard|date=May 16, 2012}}</ref><ref name=\"ocregister-concert-preview\">{{cite news|last1=Fadorski|first1=Kelli Skye|title=From a NASCAR pit crew member to 'Survivor' star, Chase Rice still prefers country music|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/rice-745140-country-really.html|access-date=February 28, 2017|work=[[Orange County Register]]|date=February 28, 2017}}</ref>\n\nAfter graduating from UNC, Rice was selected to join the [[Hendrick Motorsports]] [[pit crew]] as the rear tire carrier for [[Ryan Newman (racing driver)|Ryan Newman]]'s [[Nationwide Series]] car. He also worked on [[Jimmie Johnson]]'s [[Sprint Cup Series]] car and won two championships with the [[Lowe's]] team.<ref name=\"Chase Rice Biography\"/><ref name=\"Rice Hill Country\">{{cite web|title=Chase Rice|url=http://hillcountry.com/dc/music-calendar/single-event/189543/|publisher=Hill Country BBQ, Washington, D.C.|access-date=March 5, 2016}}{{Dead link|date=July 2020 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>\n\n==''Survivor''==\nRice was selected as a cast member of the [[reality television]] show ''[[Survivor: Nicaragua]]''. He said that he was able to get his application into [[CBS]] through a college friend who had a connection with the network.<ref name=\"runner-up talks\">{{cite news|title=Exclusive: 'Survivor: Nicaragua' runner-up Chase Rice talks|url=http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/exclusive-survivor-nicaragua-runner-up-chase-rice-talks-11830.php|newspaper=Reality TV World|date=December 22, 2012}}</ref>\n\nRice was originally on the La Flor tribe, consisting of younger contestants. During his time on the tribe, he was quickly attracted to fellow contestant Brenda Lowe, who became aware of his attraction and used it to her advantage, recruiting him and several others into an alliance. After La Flor won three of the first four tribal immunity challenges, the tribes were blended and Rice ended up on the new version of the original \"older contestants\" tribe, Espada, while Lowe remained on the new version of the La Flor tribe. Rice and Lowe both ultimately made it to the merged group, Libertad, where their alliance successfully caused the eliminations of Alina Wilson and Marty Piombo, before turning on Lowe and eliminating her as a threat. Following Lowe's elimination, Rice continued with the alliance under new leader Matthew \"Sash\" Lenahan. After two contestants (NaOnka Mixon and \"Purple Kelly\" Shinn) quit, the alliance continued eliminating targets Ben \"Benry\" Henry, Jane Bright, Dan Lembo, and Holly Hoffman, although Bright and Hoffman were members of the alliance. The alliance tried to eliminate [[Jud Birza|Jud \"Fabio\" Birza]] as a threat against the jury, but Birza managed to evade them by winning the last three immunity challenges. Rice performed exceptionally well in the post-merge challenges, being on the winning team in two of the three team-oriented rewards, and winning the last two individual rewards. Eventually, Rice made it to the final three with Lenahan and Birza, where he had a chance to win the $1 million as \"Sole Survivor\". In pleading his case to the jury, Rice claimed that he was being open about how he played the game, but was criticized both for his rash decisions and occasional indecisiveness, as well as being perceived as a follower under both Lowe and Lenahan. Although both Rice and Lenahan tried to accuse Birza of not knowing what was going on in the competition, the jury still ultimately chose Birza who received five of the nine votes; Rice received the votes of Hoffman, Bright, Lowe, and Wilson.\n\nOn the nationally televised reunion show, Rice played his single \"Buzz Back\".<ref name=\"Country Song on Season Finale\">{{cite web|last=Wilkening|first=Matthew|title='Survivor' Finalist Chase Rice Debuts Country Song on Season Finale|date=December 20, 2010 |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/survivor-finalist-chase-rice-country-song-season-finale/|publisher=Taste of Country}}</ref> Although he received national media attention on the show, he says that reality show stardom did not help propel his country music career; instead, he cited it as an important life event that was more valuable than money and that put his life in perspective.\n\nIn the official issue of ''[[CBS Watch]]'' magazine, commemorating the 15th anniversary of ''[[Survivor (TV series)|Survivor]]'' in 2015, Rice was voted by viewers as the 10th \"steamiest\" male contestant in ''Survivor'' history.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/DaltonRoss/status/565168330513080320 |title=Wait, where's @JohnMCochran? |publisher=Twitter |first=Dalton |last=Ross |date=February 10, 2015 |access-date=February 10, 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Country music career==\n[[File:Chase Rice Mojo Club 2020.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Rice in 2020]]\nChase Rice began playing guitar in college. He cites his father as the inspiration for his career, recalling his father saying \"boy anyone can play guitar, but no one is gonna really listen to you until you start singing.\"<ref name=\"Rice Hill Country\"/> He creates his albums based on the live shows he has and is building his career through performing.<ref name=\"Debuts Big\"/> His first studio album, ''Friday Nights & Sunday Mornings'', was released on April 22, 2010. This 13-track album includes the first song he ever wrote/recorded, \"Larger Than Life\", which is about the passing of his father. This is the only full-length album Rice has released that is not available for digital purchase or streaming.\n\nIn March 2011, he released ''Country as Me'', a six-track EP featuring his single \"Buzz Back\". He has received air play as a \"Highway Find\" on satellite radio channel [[The Highway (Sirius XM)|The Highway]]. In April 2012, his second studio album ''[[Dirt Road Communion]]'' debuted at number 48 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard charts|Country Albums]] chart.<ref name=\"Debuts Big\" /> This album included the original recordings of \"Jack Daniels and Jesus\" and \"How She Rolls\", the latter of which has been removed from streaming and digital platforms in its original form. \"Whoa\" has also been removed from all digital and streaming platforms, but was never re-released leaving the current total tracks on the album at 14. \"Happy Hour (Worktape)\" includes a hidden track, \"Kiss My Ass\", which begins at the 4:31 minute mark on the song.\n\nIn July 2012, he signed with [[Creative Artists Agency]].<ref name=\"Signs with CAA\">{{cite news|title=Indie artist Chase Rice Signs with CAA|url=http://nashvillecountryclub.com/News.php?id=4177|newspaper=Nashville Country Club|date=July 19, 2012|access-date=December 31, 2012|archive-date=January 3, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190103005104/http://nashvillecountryclub.com/News.php?id=4177|url-status=dead}}</ref> He was a co-writer of [[Florida Georgia Line]]'s \"[[Cruise (song)|Cruise]]\" which topped ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]].<ref name=\"Platinum Success\">{{cite web|title=Chase Rice 'Cruise's with Florida Georgia Line to Platinum Success and a #1 Single|url=http://www.gotcountryonline.com/chase-rice-cruises-with-florida-georgia-line-to-platinum-success-and-a-1-single/|publisher=Got Country Online|access-date=December 28, 2012}}</ref>\n\nIn October 2013, he released ''[[Ready Set Roll (EP)|Ready Set Roll]]'', a six-song EP including the title track. The physical version of the album was released in November 2013 and included the bonus song \"Jack Daniel's and Jesus\". On January 29, 2014, the official \"[[Ready Set Roll]]\" music video premiered exclusively on CMT.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chaserice.com/103-official-ready-set-roll-music-video-premieres-on-cmt|title=Official Ready Set Roll Music Video Premieres on CMT |access-date=February 4, 2016 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221113825/http://chaserice.com/103-official-ready-set-roll-music-video-premieres-on-cmt |archive-date=February 21, 2014 }}</ref> The next day the video debuted on VEVO. He partnered with [[Columbia Records]] for distribution of \"Ready Set Roll\" in March 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2014/03/columbia-nashville-inks-strategic-partnership-with-chase-rice/|title=Columbia Nashville Inks Strategic Partnership With Chase Rice|work=MusicRow - Nashville's Music Industry Publication - News, Songs From Music City|date=March 27, 2014 |access-date=October 21, 2014}}</ref>\n\nOn June 30, 2014, Rice released the album cover, release date, and album sequence for ''[[Ignite the Night]]''. The full-length album was released on August 19, 2014, and included the platinum-certified single, \"Ready Set Roll\".\n\nIn February 2016, Rice released \"Whisper\", which was intended to be the lead single from an upcoming album. The song was unsuccessful commercially, peaking at number 56 on the week of April 23, 2016, after just 3 weeks of being on the Country Airplay chart.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/299025/chase-rice/chart?f=1226 |title=Chase Rice - Chart history |magazine=Billboard |access-date=July 31, 2016}}</ref> It is currently the single which has peaked the lowest for Rice only behind \"How She Rolls\" which peaked at number 55 in 2013, and never received real label backing. After releasing the single, Rice issued a letter to his fans which said, \"If you have listened to my music for years and want to hear more depth and meaning, I very much appreciate you, too, and your desires will also be fulfilled on this album (and truthfully, that was my goal on previous albums with songs like \"Carolina Can\" and \"Every Song I Sing\").\" He went on to mention that he was influenced by [[Garth Brooks]] and [[Kenny Chesney]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://countrymusicrocks.net/2016/02/chase-rice-pens-honest-and-heartfelt-letter-to-fans.html/|title=Chase Rice Pens Honest and Heartfelt Letter to Fans|date=February 5, 2016|website=Country Music Rocks|language=en-US|access-date=December 1, 2021}}</ref> Rice then released \"Everybody We Know Does\", which was sent to country radio on June 24, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lauren Laffer|url=http://www.soundslikenashville.com/music/chase-rice-releases-new-single-everybody-we-know-does/ |title=Chase Rice Releases New Single, 'Everybody We Know Does' Sounds Like Nashville |publisher=Soundslikenashville.com |date=June 24, 2016 |access-date=July 31, 2016}}</ref>\n\nAfter \"Everybody We Know Does\" failed to crack the top 25, Rice left Columbia in 2017 and signed to [[BBR Music Group|Broken Bow Records]] the same year. The lead single from Rice's first album with BBR, \"Three Chords and the Truth\", was sent to country radio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/chase-rice-bbr-music-group-broken-bow-records/|title=Chase Rice Signs With Broken Bow, Ready to Release New Music|website=The Boot|date=June 21, 2017 |access-date=December 10, 2017}}</ref> This single was highly praised by both country fans and radio, as this was his first single to crack the Top 25 on the [[Country Airplay]] chart in 4 years. ''Lambs & Lions'' is Rice's first album on Broken Bow Records/BMG and is also the first album released by BBR since the BMG takeover. The album was released on November 17, 2017.\n\nRice's single \"[[Eyes on You (Chase Rice song)|Eyes on You]]\" became his first number one on country radio on May 6, 2019, staying at the top for two weeks.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Stevens |first1=Buck |title=Chase Rice Holds Number One for Second Week with \"Eyes On You\" |url=http://www.wbwn.com/2019/05/13/chase-rice-holds-number-one-for-second-week-with-eyes-on-you/ |website=wbwn.com |date=May 13, 2019 |access-date=23 May 2019}}</ref> He then released the follow-up single \"[[Lonely If You Are]]\" on July 1, 2019.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.thecountrydaily.com/2019/06/07/chase-rice-drops-friendly-new-single-lonely-if-you-are-listen/ | title=Chase Rice Drops Friendly New Single, \"Lonely If You Are\" [Listen] | publisher=The Country Daily | date=June 7, 2019 | access-date=September 22, 2020 | author=Jim Casey}}</ref> Rice also wrote and performed the inaugural theme song for ''[[The Pat McAfee Show]]'', which was used from September 10, 2019, to April 30, 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ie1pN5HscGk|title=The Pat McAfee Show - Tuesday September 10th|date=September 10, 2019|via=YouTube}}<br>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxZCaGmkDTI|title=The Pat McAfee Show - Thursday, April 30th|date=April 30, 2020|via=YouTube}}</ref>\n\nRice appeared on the fourth episode of [[The Bachelor (season 24)|season 24 of ''The Bachelor'']], performing at a private concert for bachelor [[Peter Weber (television personality)|Peter Weber]] and his date, Victoria Fuller, at [[Cedar Point]] in [[Sandusky, Ohio]]. Fuller later revealed that she had previously dated Rice.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/tv/2020/01/27/the-bachelor-chase-rice-claims-he-didnt-expect-perform-ex/4594060002/|title=Singer Chase Rice expresses frustration over the 'drama' he was dragged into on 'The Bachelor'|last=Trepany|first=Charles|website=USA TODAY|language=en-US|access-date=2020-01-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/28/entertainment/chase-rice-bachelor-trnd/index.html|title=Chase Rice claims 'Bachelor' producers blindsided him with his ex-girlfriend on latest episode|first=Marianne |last=Garvey|website=CNN|date=January 28, 2020 |access-date=2020-01-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/2020/01/cedar-point-episode-of-the-bachelor-was-a-cold-blustery-lesson-in-reality-and-it-wasnt-pretty.html|title=Cedar Point episode of 'The Bachelor' was a cold, blustery lesson in reality . . . and it wasn't pretty|first=Chuck|last=Yarborough|work=The Plain Dealer|date=2020-01-27|language=en|access-date=2020-01-29}}</ref>\n\nOn June 27, 2020, Rice played a concert at the [[Brushy Mountain State Penitentiary]], in [[Petros, Tennessee]], where many fans chose to ignore recommended safety measures against spreading and contracting [[COVID-19]]. Reaction to the concert drew negative outcry from fans and the music industry.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-06-29|title=As COVID-19 surges, country star Chase Rice plays packed concert for a thousand mask-free fans|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/music/story/2020-06-28/chase-rice-country-concert-covid-19|access-date=2020-06-29|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US}}</ref> In response to the criticism Rice stated: \"If it were up to me I wouldn't cancel one damn show, but it ain't.... I personally, choose not to live scared, especially of something that I can't really control.\"<ref>{{Cite news|date=2020-06-30|title=Country singers criticize Chase Rice as 'selfish' for concert in front of hundreds in Tennessee|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/arts-entertainment/2020/06/29/chase-rice-concert-social-distancing-tennessee/#comments-wrapper|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nIn November 2020, Rice released the single \"[[Drinkin' Beer. Talkin' God. Amen.]]\" featuring his long-time friends Florida Georgia Line.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/pamwindsor/2020/11/30/chase-rice-teams-up-with-florida-georgia-line-for-new-song-drinkin-beer-talkin-god-amen/?sh=60409295c39e| title=Chase Rice Teams Up With Florida Georgia Line For New Song 'Drinkin' Beer Talkin' God Amen'| work=[[Forbes]]| date=November 30, 2020| access-date=December 4, 2020 |first=Pam|last=Windsor}}</ref> It is the second single from Rice's fifth studio album, ''[[The Album (Chase Rice album)|The Album]]'', which was released on May 28, 2021.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases|title=Future Releases for Country Radio Stations|accessdate=May 29, 2021|work=AllAccess}}</ref>\n\nIn November 2022, Rice announced his sixth studio album ''I Hate Cowboys & All Dogs Go to Hell'', which was released in February 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wfms.com/news/chase-rice-announces-new-album-i-hate-cowboys-all-dogs-go-to-hell/|title=Chase Rice Announces New Album 'I Hate Cowboys & All Dogs Go To Hell'|website=[[WFMS]]|date=November 20, 2022|access-date=February 9, 2023|archive-date=November 21, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221121045120/https://www.wfms.com/news/chase-rice-announces-new-album-i-hate-cowboys-all-dogs-go-to-hell/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/chase-rice-album-interview-i-hate-cowboys-1235251656/|title=Chase Rice Finds His True Voice On New Album 'I Hate Cowboys & All Dogs Go to Hell'|work=Forbes|first=Pam|last=Windsor|date=February 20, 2023|access-date=October 24, 2023}}</ref> The sole single from the album, \"Bad Day to Be a Cold Beer\",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbrmusicgroup.com/chase-rice-delivers-summer-anthem-bad-day-cold-beer-country-radio/|title=CHASE RICE DELIVERS SUMMER ANTHEM \"BAD DAY TO BE A COLD BEER\" TO COUNTRY RADIO|website=bbrmusicgroup.com|date=May 8, 2023|access-date=October 24, 2023}}</ref> was released in May and music videos were produced for \"Bench Seat\", \"Way Down Yonder\" and \"I Hate Cowboys\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/chase-rice-album-interview-i-hate-cowboys-1235251656/|title=Chase Rice Refines His Artistic Voice on New Album: 'I'm Not Chasing Anything Anymore'|work=Billboard|first=Jessica|last=Nicholson|date=February 10, 2023|access-date=October 24, 2023}}</ref> During the year, Rice promoted the album on the Way Down Yonder tour,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/chase-rice-2023-way-down-yonder-tour-dates/|title=Chase Rice Will Showcase New Album on 2023 Way Down Yonder Tour|work=Taste of Country|author=Jess|date=December 13, 2022|access-date=October 24, 2023}}</ref> and was a supporting act for [[Jelly Roll (singer)|Jelly Roll]] and [[Old Dominion (band)|Old Dominion]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://countrynow.com/jelly-roll-facetimes-ashley-mcbryde-chase-rice-more-to-make-big-announcement/|title=Jelly Roll FaceTimes Ashley McBryde, Chase Rice & More To Make Big Announcement|work=Country Now|first=Lauren Jo|last=Black|date=February 20, 2023|access-date=October 24, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://countrynow.com/old-dominion-extends-no-bad-vibes-tour-with-new-arena-shows-and-special-guests/|title=Old Dominion Extends No Bad Vibes Tour With New Arena Shows And Special Guests|work=Country Now|first=Madeleine|last=O'Connell|date=May 2, 2023|access-date=October 24, 2023}}</ref> In early 2024, Rice will embark on his headlining \"Get Western Tour\" across Canada and the [[Pacific Northwest]], with [[Owen Riegling]] and Palmer Anthony as supporting acts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2023/11/chase-rice-to-head-up-north-for-get-western-tour/|title=Chase Rice To Head Up North For \u2018Get Western Tour\u2019|date=November 22, 2023|first=Lorie|last=Hollabaugh|work=Music Row|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Chase Rice discography}}\n\n*''Friday Nights and Sunday Mornings'' (2010)\n*''[[Dirt Road Communion]]'' (2012)\n*''[[Ignite the Night]]'' (2014)\n*''[[Lambs & Lions]]'' (2017)\n*''[[The Album (Chase Rice album)|The Album]]'' (2021)\n*''I Hate Cowboys & All Dogs Go to Hell'' (2023)\n*''Go Down Singin'' (2024)<ref>{{Cite web |last=Buondonno |first=Max |date=2024-08-06 |title=Chase Rice Announces New 2016}}</ref>\n*Campus Events Network Presents College Days, Country Nights: Chase Rice Back to College Tour (2016)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chaserice.com/news/268563/ |title=CHASE LAUNCHING BACK Shows (2017)<ref>{{cite web |title=CHASE RICE'S UPCOMING \"PUB SHOWS\" |url=http://ebmediapr.com/news/chase-rice%E2%80%99s-upcoming-%E2%80%9Cpub-shows%E2%80%9D-reminiscent-early-dive-bar-days 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306042718/https://www.onecountry.com/country-artists/chase-rice/chase-rice-announces-headlining-tour-dates/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n*Way Down Yonder Tour (2023)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.cbs.com/shows/survivor/cast/44279/ Chase Rice biography] for ''[[Survivor: Nicaragua]]'' at [[CBS]].com\n* This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Kelsea_Ballerini","to":"Kelsea Ballerini"}],"pages":{"44644307":{"pageid":44644307,"ns":0,"title":"Kelsea Ballerini","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer (born 1993)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2024}}\n{{Use American English|date=September 2022}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Kelsea Ballerini\n| image             = Kelsea Ballerini performing at Red Rocks Amphitheater 2 (cropped) (cropped).jpg\n| caption           = Ballerini in 2021\n| birth_name        = Kelsea Nicole Ballerini<ref>{{cite web|author=Sellers, Morgan |title=Artist Interview: Kelsea Ballerini |url=http://www.thetennesseelife.com/2014/07/meet-kelsea-ballerini.html |website=Thetennesseelife.com |access-date=December 29, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141230004918/http://www.thetennesseelife.com/2014/07/meet-kelsea-ballerini.html |archive-date=December 30, 2014 }}</ref>\n| birth_date        = {{Birth date and age|1993|9|12}}<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| birth_place       = [[Mascot, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| origin            = [[Knoxville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre             = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country pop]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>|[[pop music|pop]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lyricmagazine.co.uk/lyricreviews-the-new-self-titled-album-from-kelsea-ballerini-pop-joy-and-slick-open-honest-songwriting-combine/|title=Kelsea Ballerini New Album Review|website=Lyricmagazine.co.uk|date=March 20, 2020|access-date=December 10, 2021|archive-date=January 14, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210114184048/https://www.lyricmagazine.co.uk/lyricreviews-the-new-self-titled-album-from-kelsea-ballerini-pop-joy-and-slick-open-honest-songwriting-combine/|url-status=dead}}</ref>}}\n| occupation        = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|musician}}\n| instruments       = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| years_active      = 2014\u2013present\n| label             = [[Black River Entertainment|Black River]]\n| website           = {{URL|kelseaballerini.com}}\n| spouse            = {{marriage|[[Morgan Evans (singer)|Morgan Evans]]|2017|2022|reason=divorced}}\n| partner            = \n}}\n\n'''Kelsea Nicole Ballerini''' (born September 12, 1993) is an American [[country pop]] singer and songwriter. A four-time [[Grammy Award]] nominee, she has gained success since the 2010s, being honored with the [[Academy of Country Music Awards#Special awards|Gene Weed Milestone Award]] at the [[Academy of Country Music Awards]] and the Rising Star Award at the [[Billboard Women in Music|''Billboard'' Women in Music]].\n\nShe began songwriting as a child and signed a contract with [[Black River Entertainment]] in 2014,<ref>{{Cite web|title=About {{!}} Black River Entertainment|url=https://www.blackriverent.com/about|access-date=June 9, 2021|website=Blackriverent.com}}</ref> releasing her debut studio album, ''[[The First Time (Kelsea Ballerini album)|The First Time]],'' and her second one ''[[Unapologetically]]'', followed in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Abbey|first=Alison|date=October 13, 2017|title=Kelsea Ballerini Unapologetically Talks New Music, Love and Growing Up|url=https://parade.com/608697/alison-abbey/kelsea-ballerini-unapologetically-talks-new-music-love-and-growing-up/|access-date=June 9, 2021|website=Parade: Entertainment, Recipes, Health, Life, Holidays}}</ref> The two albums account for seven songs on the [[Hot Country Songs]] and [[Country Airplay]] charts. She has five No.&nbsp;1 singles on the latter, starting with her debut single \"[[Love Me Like You Mean It]]\", which made her the first female artist to send a debut single to the top of that chart since [[Carrie Underwood]] in 2006. It was followed by \"[[Dibs (song)|Dibs]]\" and \"[[Peter Pan (Kelsea Ballerini song)|Peter Pan]]\", whose peaks also made her the first female country artist to send her first three singles to the top of that chart since [[Wynonna Judd]]. \n\nHer third studio album, ''[[Kelsea]]'', and a counterpart [[Remix album|acoustic album]], ''[[Ballerini (album)|Ballerini]]'', were both released in 2020. The collaboration \"[[Half of My Hometown]]\" with [[Kenny Chesney]] garnered two [[Country Music Association Awards]]. Her fourth studio album, ''[[Subject to Change (Kelsea Ballerini album)|Subject to Change]]'' was released in 2022.\n\n==Early life==\nBallerini, an [[only child]], grew up in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]]<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/kelsea-ballerini-mn0003312551/biography|title=Kelsea Ballerini biography|last=Leggett|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=December 9, 2014}}</ref> with her father Ed<ref name=\"cmt1\">{{cite web|last1=Shelburne|first1=Craig|title=Next Women of Country: Kelsea Ballerini|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1746335/next-women-of-country-kelsea-ballerini/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141213015155/http://www.cmt.com/news/1746335/next-women-of-country-kelsea-ballerini/|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 13, 2014|website=CMT|access-date=June 23, 2015|date=December 5, 2014}}</ref><ref name=\"995qyk\">{{cite web|title=Would Kelsea Ballerini ever change her name|url=http://995qyk.com/2015/04/18/would-kelsea-ballerini-ever-change-her-name/|website=99.5 QYK|access-date=June 23, 2015 |date=April 18, 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623152240/http://995qyk.com/2015/04/18/would-kelsea-ballerini-ever-change-her-name/ |archive-date=June 23, 2015 }}</ref> and her mother Carla. Ed was a sales manager at a country radio station and is of [[Italian people|Italian]] descent. Carla has worked in marketing for the [[Bible]] publishing division of [[Thomas Nelson (publisher)|Thomas Nelson]] and a sponsorship company.<ref name=\"995qyk\" /> Kelsea started taking dance lessons at Premiere Dance Studio in [[Seymour, Tennessee]] when she was three and quit ten years later.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hudelson|first1=Molly|title=Country singer Kelsea Ballerini talks her debut EP, upcoming NYC show and more|url=http://www.axs.com/news/country-singer-kelsea-ballerini-talks-her-debut-ep-upcoming-nyc-show-a-40000|website=AXS|access-date=June 23, 2015|date=February 9, 2015}}</ref> She also sang in a church choir and the school choir.<ref name=\"cmt1\"/> She wrote her first song at 12 for her mother<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mansfield|first1=Brian|title=On the Verge: Kelsea Ballerini means it|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/ontheverge/2015/04/05/kelsea-ballerini-love-me-like-you-mean-it-on-the-verge/70635632/|website=[[USA Today]]|access-date=June 23, 2015|date=April 5, 2015}}</ref> and moved to [[Nashville]] three years later.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> She attended [[Central High School (Knoxville, Tennessee)|Central High School]] in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]]; [[Centennial High School (Tennessee)|Centennial High School]] in [[Franklin, Tennessee]]; and [[Lipscomb University]] for two years until pursuing a musical career.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kelsea Ballerini experiences several firsts, headlines SGA Spring Concert |url=http://www.luminationnetwork.com/2015/04/09/kelsea-ballerini-experiences-several-firsts-headlines-sga-spring-concert/|website=Lumination Network|access-date=June 23, 2015|date=April 9, 2015|url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623142315/http://www.luminationnetwork.com/2015/04/09/kelsea-ballerini-experiences-several-firsts-headlines-sga-spring-concert/ |archive-date=June 23, 2015 }}</ref>\n\n==Career==\n===2014\u20132016: Self-titled EP and ''The First Time''===\n[[File:Kelsea Ballerini Country Artist 3 (cropped).jpg|left|thumb|Ballerini in 2014]]\nAt 19, Kelsea Ballerini signed a deal with [[Black River Entertainment]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> In late 2014, she released her debut single \"[[Love Me Like You Mean It]]\", which debuted on the [[Country Airplay]] chart in October 2014.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6281325/tomorrows-hits-lillywood-robin-schulz-logic-kelsea-ballerini|title=Tomorrow's Hits: Lillywood & Robin Schulz, Logic, Kelsea Ballerini|date=October 10, 2014|magazine=Billboard|access-date=December 9, 2014}}</ref> She released a [[Kelsea Ballerini (EP)|self-titled extended play]] for the label in November.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/kelsea-ballerini-e.p./id940713706 |title=Kelsea Ballerini EP |work=iTunes Store |access-date=December 9, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109222114/https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/kelsea-ballerini-e.p./id940713706|archive-date=January 9, 2015}}</ref> She was named one of [[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]]'s Next Women of Country in 2014. She performed for the first time at the [[Grand Ole Opry]] on February 14, 2015, and sang \"Love Me Like You Mean It.\"<ref name=\"cmt1\"/> On May 19, 2015, Ballerini's debut album ''[[The First Time (Kelsea Ballerini album)|The First Time]]'' was released through Black River. For the chart dated July 4, 2015, \"Love Me Like You Mean It,\" the album's first single, reached number one on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Country Airplay]] chart, making Ballerini the first solo female country music artist to score a number one hit with her debut single since [[Carrie Underwood]] did so with \"[[Jesus, Take the Wheel]]\" in 2006, and only the eleventh in history to achieve the feat.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Moss|first=Marissa R.|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/kelsea-ballerini-joins-carrie-underwood-in-elite-number-one-club-20150622 |title=Kelsea Ballerini Joins Carrie Underwood in Elite Number One Club|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=June 22, 2015 |access-date=March 2, 2016}}</ref> Ballerini also became only the fifth solo female country music artist to score back-to-back number one hits with her first two singles when \"[[Dibs (song)|Dibs]]\" reached the top of the Country Airplay chart and the first to do it since [[Jamie O'Neal]] in 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6889333/kelsea-ballerini-has-dibs-on-second-country-airplay-no-1|title=Kelsea Ballerini Has 'Dibs' on Second Country Airplay No. 1|author=Jim Asker|date=February 23, 2016|publisher=Billboard.com|access-date=February 23, 2016}}</ref>\nThe album's third single, \"[[Peter Pan (Kelsea Ballerini song)|Peter Pan]],\" was released to country radio on March 21, 2016. \"Peter Pan\" reached number one on both the [[Country Airplay]] and [[Hot Country Songs]] charts in September, making Ballerini the first solo female country music artist to top both country music charts simultaneously.<ref name=\"same time\">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7503747/kelsea-ballerini-tops-two-country-charts-same-time-peter-pan|title=Kelsea Ballerini Is the First Woman to Top Hot Country Songs & Country Airplay Charts at the Same Time|last=Asker|first=Jim|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=September 12, 2016|access-date=September 15, 2016}}</ref> The achievement made her the first solo female to send her first three singles to number one since [[Wynonna Judd]] accomplished the same feat in 1992.<ref name=\"same time\"/> The album's fourth single, \"[[Yeah Boy]],\" was released to country radio on October 10, 2016.\n\n===2017\u20132019: ''Unapologetically'', coaching ''The Voice'', and joining the Grand Ole Opry===\n[[File:Kelsea Ballerini in concert in 2017.jpg|thumb|301x301px|Kelsea Ballerini in concert in 2017]]\nIn early 2017, Ballerini was named to [[Forbes|Forbes']] [[30 Under 30]] \u2013 Music list at number two.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kelsea Ballerini|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/kelsea-ballerini/|website=Forbes|access-date=January 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Bonaguro|first1=Alison|title=Kelsea Ballerini Named No. 2 Forbes' \"30 Under 30\" List|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1775317/kelsea-ballerini-named-no-2-forbes-30-under-30-list/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170105062545/http://www.cmt.com/news/1775317/kelsea-ballerini-named-no-2-forbes-30-under-30-list/|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 5, 2017|website=CMT News|access-date=January 5, 2017}}</ref> In 2017, she received two [[Academy of Country Music Award]] nominations for Female Vocalist of the Year and Video of the Year for \"Peter Pan.\"<ref name=\"ACM 2017 noms\" /> In June 2017, Ballerini released \"[[Legends (Kelsea Ballerini song)|Legends]]\" as the first single from her second studio album.<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Gugala|first1=John|title=Hear Kelsea Ballerini's Wistful New Song 'Legends'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/kelsea-ballerinis-legends-hear-the-new-song-w486223|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=June 7, 2017|access-date=June 26, 2017}}</ref> On November 3, she released her second album, titled ''[[Unapologetically]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Whitaker|first1=Sterling |title=Kelsea Ballerini Announces Title, Date for Second Album|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/kelsea-ballerini-second-album-unapologetically-release-date/ |website=Taste of Country|date=July 25, 2017 |access-date=October 4, 2018}}</ref> The album debuted at number three on the [[Billboard Top Country Hits|Billboard Top Country Album Chart]] and number seven on the [[Billboard 200]] Album Chart, making it her highest-charting album on both charts.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Kelsea Ballerini Chart History |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/kelsea-ballerini/chart-history/tlp/ |magazine=Billboard}}</ref>\n\nThe second single from the album, \"[[I Hate Love Songs]]\", was released in March.<ref name=\"i hate love songs\">{{cite web |title=Single Releases : MusicRow \u2013 Nashville's Music Industry Publication \u2013 News, Songs From Music City |url=https://musicrow.com/calendars-2/single-releases/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180222214933/https://musicrow.com/calendars-2/single-releases/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 22, 2018 |access-date=January 29, 2019 |date=February 22, 2018}}</ref> In September 2018, she announced that she would be releasing a deluxe edition of the album with four new tracks.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Despres|first1=Tricia|title=Kelsea Ballerini Releasing 'Unapologetically' Deluxe Edition|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/kelsea-ballerini-unapologetically-album-deluxe-version/|website=Taste of Country|date=September 25, 2018 |access-date=October 4, 2018}}</ref> On September 18, 2018, [[Electronic dance music|EDM]]-[[Pop music|pop]] duo [[The Chainsmokers]] released a song titled \"[[This Feeling (The Chainsmokers song)|This Feeling]]\" featuring Ballerini, which later performed at the 2018 [[Victoria's Secret Fashion Show]] in November.<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Bein|first1=Kat|title=The Chainsmokers Drop Kelsea Ballerini Collaboration 'This Feeling'|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/8475393/the-chainsmokers-kelsea-ballerini-this-feeling|magazine=Billboard|date=September 17, 2018|access-date=October 4, 2018}}</ref> The third and final single from ''[[Unapologetically]]'', \"[[Miss Me More]],\" was released in October 2018.<ref>{{cite web |title=Kelsea Ballerini's 'Miss Me More' Celebrates Her Independence Day |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/kelsea-ballerini-miss-me-more/ |website=Taste of Country |date=October 10, 2018 |access-date=January 29, 2019}}</ref> In October, she provided vocals on her husband Morgan Evans' song \"Dance With Me.\"<ref name=\"dance with me\">{{cite web |last1=Houghton |first1=Cillea |title=Hear Morgan Evans' 'Dance With Me,' a Duet With Kelsea Ballerini |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/morgan-evans-kelsea-ballerini-duet-dance-with-me/ |website=Taste of Country |date=October 15, 2018 |access-date=January 29, 2019}}</ref> Ballerini joined the [[The Voice (U.S. season 15)|15th season]] of ''[[The Voice (U.S. TV series)|The Voice]]'' as the fifth coach, where she coached six contestants who did not get a chair turn during The Blinds, in a new round called ''The Comeback Stage'', a digital companion series to the show.<ref name=\"The Voice\">{{cite web|url=https://www.eonline.com/news/966817/the-voice-launching-the-comeback-stage-companion-series-with-kelsea-ballerini-as-fifth-coach|title=The Voice Launching The Comeback Stage Companion Series With Kelsea Ballerini as Fifth Coach|author=Chris Harnick|date=September 15, 2018|access-date=October 10, 2018|publisher=[[E!]]}}</ref> In October 2018, Ballerini released the song \"We Were Like.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/we-were-like/1467637315|title=We Were Like \u2013 Single by Kelsea Ballerini|website=[[Apple Music]]|date=October 29, 2018|access-date=June 11, 2019}}</ref> In December 2018, ''Unapologetically'' received a nomination for [[Best Country Album]] at the [[61st Annual Grammy Awards|61st annual Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |title=61st Annual GRAMMY Awards |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/awards/61st-annual-grammy-awards |website=GRAMMY.com |access-date=January 29, 2019 |date=December 6, 2018}}</ref>\n\nOn March 5, 2019, Ballerini was invited by [[Little Big Town]] to become a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]]. On April 16, 2019, she was inducted into the Grand Ole Opry by [[Carrie Underwood]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Laffer |first=Lauren |title=Kelsea Ballerini Invited to Join Grand Ole Opry |url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/kelsea-ballerini-invited-grand-ole-opry/ |website=Sounds Like Nashville |access-date=March 5, 2019}}</ref> Ballerini embarked on the [[Miss Me More|Miss Me More Tour]] in support of ''Unapologetically'' in April 2019.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dukes |first1=Billy |title=Kelsea Ballerini Reveals 2019 Miss Me More Tour With Brett Young |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/kelsea-ballerini-miss-me-more-tour-dates-brett-young/ |website=Taste of Country |date=October 29, 2018 |access-date=January 29, 2019}}</ref> The tour was a success, with Ballerini selling out multiple dates.<ref>{{cite web |title=Kelsea Ballerini Kicked off 'Miss Me More Tour' with Sold Out Arena Shows |url=https://musicmayhemmagazine.com/kelsea-ballerini-kicked-off-miss-me-more-tour-with-sold-out-arena-shows/ |website=Music Mayhem |access-date=June 9, 2019|date=April 15, 2019 }}</ref> In June 2019, Ballerini was a guest on the [[NBC]] competition show ''[[Songland]]'' and released the song \"Better Luck Next Time.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/us/album/better-luck-next-time-single/1466173359|title=Better Luck Next Time \u2013 Single by Kelsea Ballerini|website=Apple Music|date=June 11, 2019|access-date=June 11, 2019}}</ref>\n\n===2019\u20132021: ''Kelsea'' and ''Ballerini''===\n[[File:Kelsea Ballerini performing at Red Rocks Amphitheater 2021 4 (cropped).jpg|thumb|Kelsea Ballerini performing at [[Red Rocks Amphitheatre]] in 2021]]\nIn July 2019, Ballerini confirmed in an [[Instagram]] post that work on her third studio album was complete.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iheart.com/content/2019-07-29-kelsea-ballerinis-third-studio-album-is-officially-complete/|website=Iheart.com|access-date=August 1, 2019|title=Kelsea Ballerini's Third Studio Album Is Officially Complete|date=July 27, 2019 }}</ref> On September 6, 2019, Ballerini released the first single off of her then upcoming third album, titled \"[[Homecoming Queen?]]\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Henderson |first1=Wendy |title=Kelsea Ballerini Cries in Raw \"Homecoming Queen\" Video |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/kelsea-ballerini-homecoming-queen-video/ |website=Taste of Country |date=September 8, 2019 |access-date=September 13, 2019}}</ref> The song debuted at number 22 on the [[Country Airplay]] chart, making it Ballerini's highest debut on the chart to date.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=FiddleSabre |last1=Owen |first1=Chris |number=1171161603829575681 |title= \"homecoming queen?\" by @KelseaBallerini debuts at #22 on Billboard Country Airplay this week.|date=September 9, 2019|access-date=September 13, 2019}}</ref> On November 8, Ballerini released the promotional single \"Club\".<ref name=\"club\">{{cite magazine |last1=Freeman |first1=Jon |title=Kelsea Ballerini Opts to Stay Home in Sleek New Song 'Club' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/kelsea-ballerini-new-song-club-909885/ |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=November 8, 2019 |date=November 8, 2019}}</ref> Ballerini confirmed on January 20, 2020, that the album is self-titled (''[[Kelsea]]'') and was released March 20, 2020.<ref name=\"nash daily\">{{cite news |last1=Casey |first1=Jim |title=Kelsea Ballerini to Release Third Album, \"Kelsea,\" on March 20 |url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2020/01/23/kelsea-ballerini-to-release-third-album-kelsea-on-march-20/ |access-date=January 23, 2020 |work=[[Nash Country Daily]] |date=January 23, 2020}}</ref> The announcement coincided with the release of a second promotional single, \"LA\".<ref name=\"nash daily\"/> On February 28, she released the single \"[[Hole in the Bottle]]\" (stylized in all lowercase) and announced the tracklist for ''Kelsea'', including \"[[Half of My Hometown]]\" featuring [[Kenny Chesney]] and \"[[The Other Girl (song)|The Other Girl]]\" featuring [[Halsey (singer)|Halsey]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dukes |first1=Billy |title=Kelsea Ballerini Unveils Kenny Chesney, Halsey Duets |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/kelsea-ballerini-kenny-chesney-album-track-list/ |website=Taste of Country |date=February 27, 2020 |access-date=February 28, 2020}}</ref>\n\nOn September 2, Ballerini announced she would be releasing a counterpart album to ''Kelsea'', titled ''[[Ballerini (album)|Ballerini]]'', featuring stripped-down versions of the songs. It was released on September 11, 2020. The stripped-down version of \"Club\" was released alongside the album announcement.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=KelseaBallerini|number=1301201859730911232|title=ballerini 9.11.20 // club out in 10 minutes|date=September 2, 2020|access-date=September 11, 2020}}</ref> She described ''Ballerini'' as \"emotional, vulnerable and soft\" while ''Kelsea'' showed her \"bold and effervescent\" side.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/kelsea-ballerini-new-album-ballerini-1054438/|title=Kelsea Ballerini Announces Stripped Album 'Ballerini'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|last=Hudak|first=Joseph|date=September 2, 2020|access-date=September 11, 2020}}</ref> As of October 16, 2020, ''Kelsea'' and ''Ballerini'' can be purchased physically as a [[double album]], exclusively from [[Target Corporation|Target]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Kelsea Ballerini - \"kelsea {{!}} ballerini\" (CD) |url=https://www.target.com/p/kelsea-ballerini-34-kelsea-ballerini-34-cd/-/A-81280324|website=[[Target Corporation|Target]]|access-date=September 29, 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn 2021, Ballerini temporarily filled in for [[Kelly Clarkson]] as a coach during [[The Voice (American season 20)|Season 20]] of ''[[The Voice (American TV series)|The Voice]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Henderson|first=Cydney|title='The Voice': Kelsea Ballerini fills in for sick Kelly Clarkson, who tested negative for COVID-19|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/tv/2021/03/29/the-voice-kelsea-ballerini-sick-kelly-clarkson/7053758002/|access-date=May 27, 2021|website=USA TODAY}}</ref> She co-hosted the [[2021 CMT Music Awards]] with [[Kane Brown]], where she won the award for [[CMT Music Awards|CMT Performance of the Year]]. In May, it was announced she would be an opening act on the [[Jonas Brothers]]' Remember This tour which began in August.<ref>{{Cite magazine|title=Jonas Brothers 'Remember This' Tour Tickets Are On Sale Now|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/9574935/jonas-brothers-2021-summer-tour-dates/|access-date=August 25, 2021|magazine=Billboard|date=May 27, 2021}}</ref> Her debut book of poetry, ''Feel Your Way Through'', was released on November 16, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|date=June 24, 2021|last=Holly GPublished|title=Kelsea Ballerini Is Releasing a Book of Poetry|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/kelsea-ballerini-poetry-book-feel-your-way-through/|access-date=August 25, 2021|website=Taste of Country}}</ref>\n\n===2022\u20132024: ''Subject to Change'', ''Rolling Up the Welcome Mat'', and ''The Voice''===\nIn March 2022 Ballerini announced that \"[[Heartfirst]]\" would be released April 8, 2022. The song serves as the first single from her fourth studio album, ''[[Subject to Change (Kelsea Ballerini album)|Subject to Change]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/kelsea-ballerini-announces-new-album-subject-to-change-1235113804/|title=Kelsea Ballerini Announces New Album 'Subject to Change': Here's When It Arrives|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|last=Nicholson|first=Jessica|date=July 13, 2022|access-date=July 14, 2022}}</ref> While co-hosting during the [[2022 CMT Music Awards]], Ballerini performed the song for the first time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1844034/2022-cmt-music-awards-host-kelsea-ballerini-debuts-new-anthem-heartfirst/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220412065857/http://www.cmt.com/news/1844034/2022-cmt-music-awards-host-kelsea-ballerini-debuts-new-anthem-heartfirst/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=April 12, 2022 |title= 2022 CMT Music Awards: Host Kelsea Ballerini Debuts New Anthem, \"HEARTFIRST\" |work=CMT|last=Goldstein|first=Tiffany|date=April 12, 2022|access-date=April 12, 2022}}</ref> The music video for the song premiered July 7, 2022.<ref name=\"O'Connell\">{{cite web|url=https://musicmayhemmagazine.com/kelsea-ballerini-debuts-new-song-love-is-a-cowboy-announces-new-album-subject-to-change/|title=Kelsea Ballerini Debuts New Song \"Love Is A Cowboy,\" Announces New Album 'Subject To Change'|work=musicmayhemmagazine|last=O'Connell|first=Madeleine|date=July 16, 2022|access-date=July 16, 2022}}</ref> On July 15, 2022, a promotional single, \"Love is a Cowboy\" was released along with the official music video.<ref name=\"O'Connell\"/> The album features a collaboration, \"[[You're Drunk, Go Home]]\", with [[Kelly Clarkson]] and [[Carly Pearce]]. The album was released on September 23, 2022.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Norwin|first1=Alyssa|title=Carly Pearce Teases 'Super Fun' New Song With Kelsea Ballerini & Kelly Clarkson |url=https://hollywoodlife.com/2022/09/12/carly-pearce-kelly-clarkson-kelsea-ballerini-song-acm-honors-interview/|website=Hollywood Life|date=September 12, 2022|access-date=September 12, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Kelsea Ballerini opens up about post-divorce album 'Subject to Change': 'I just acknowledge that life is so messy' |url=https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/kelsea-ballerini-post-divorce-album-subject-to-change-i-just-acknowledge-that-life-is-so-messy-193321511.html |access-date=September 23, 2022 |website=www.yahoo.com |date=September 22, 2022}}</ref> In November 2022, \"Heartfirst\" was nominated for [[Best Country Solo Performance]] at the [[65th Annual Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Liebig |first=Lorie|title=BREAKING: 2023 Grammy Nominees Announced |url=https://theboot.com/2023-grammy-awards-nominees-country-americana/ |access-date=December 7, 2022 |website=The Boot |date=November 15, 2022}}</ref> On December 5, 2022, \"[[If You Go Down (I'm Goin' Down Too)]]\", was released as the album's second single. On February 13, 2023, Ballerini announced that her short film and EP ''[[Rolling Up the Welcome Mat]]'' would be released the next day.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://tasteofcountry.com/kelsea-ballerini-ep-short-film-rolling-up-the-welcome-mat| title=Kelsea Ballerini Announces Surprise EP + Short Film, 'Rolling Up The Welcome Mat'| author= Carena Liptak| publisher=Taste of Country| date=February 13, 2023| access-date=February 13, 2023}}</ref> Promoting the EP, she performed \"Blindsided\" and \"Penthouse\" on the March 5, 2023, episode of [[Saturday Night Live (season 48)|Saturday Night Live]].<ref>{{cite news |url= https://lahoreherald.com/kelsea-ballerini-steals-the-show-with-debut-performance-on-saturday-night-live/ |title= Kelsea Ballerini Steals the Show with Debut Performance on Saturday Night Live|date= March 5, 2023 |website= Lahore Herald}}</ref>\n\nOn June 5, 2024, it was announced that Ballerini would be featured as a coach on the [[The Voice (American TV series) season 27|27th season]] of ''[[The Voice (American TV series)|The Voice]]'' which is set to air spring 2025.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Adam Levine Returns to 'The Voice'! Singer Joins Season 27 Alongside Kelsea Ballerini, Michael Buble and John Legend |url=https://people.com/adam-levine-returning-to-the-voice-for-season-27-alongside-kelsea-ballerini-michael-buble-john-legend-8658141 |access-date=June 5, 2024 |website=Peoplemag |language=en}}</ref>\n\n===2024\u2013present: ''Patterns''===\nOn August 8, 2024, Ballerini announced her fifth studio album ''Patterns'', and that the song \"Sorry Mom\" would be released the following day. The album will be released on October 25, 2024.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/kelsea-ballerini-album-patterns |title=Kelsea Ballerini's New Album, 'Patterns', Is On Its Way |author=Liptak, Carena |publisher=Taste of Country |date=August 8, 2024 |access-date=August 8, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Influences==\nBallerini has been influenced by artists in both the pop music and country music fields. Originally influenced by pop music, Ballerini states \"I grew up on top 40 pop. I didn't know what country music was, which is so funny because I grew up in [[East Tennessee]].\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://radio.com/2015/05/14/kelsea-ballerini-the-first-time-interview-positive-songs-taylor-swift-new-music-to-know/|title=Kelsea Ballerini on Her New Album, Taylor Swift & Staying 'Positive': New Music to Know|access-date=April 30, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817081204/http://radio.com/2015/05/14/kelsea-ballerini-the-first-time-interview-positive-songs-taylor-swift-new-music-to-know/|archive-date=August 17, 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref> Ballerini lists [[Britney Spears]], [[Christina Aguilera]], [[NSYNC]], and [[Hilary Duff]] among these early artists influencing her.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.argusleader.com/story/blogs/scotthudson/2015/08/19/chart-topping-kelsea-ballerini-loves-pizza-songwriting/31991065/|title=Chart-topping Kelsea Ballerini loves pizza, songwriting|website=Argus Leader|access-date=April 30, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/see-kelsea-ballerini-cover-britney-spears-nsync-in-nineties-medley-20150723|title=See Kelsea Ballerini Cover Britney Spears, N'Sync in Nineties Medley|date=July 23, 2015|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=April 30, 2016}}</ref> Ballerini also cites [[Justin Bieber]] as an early pop musical inspiration.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Watch Kelsea Ballerini Sing Justin Bieber, Taylor Swift, and Cher in a Game of Song Association|url=https://www.elle.com/culture/music/a31187981/kelsea-ballerini-song-association/|date=March 3, 2020|website=Elle.com|access-date=May 17, 2020}}</ref> It was not until Ballerini heard \"[[Stupid Boy]]\" by [[Keith Urban]] that she decided to delve deeper into country music by listening to albums by [[Taylor Swift]], [[Sugarland]], and [[Dixie Chicks]]. She credited Swift's [[Taylor Swift (album)|self-titled debut studio album]] for introducing her to country music. Ballerini also cites [[Shania Twain]] as her greatest influence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teenvogue.com/story/kelsea-ballerini-interview|title=Kelsea Ballerini Says She'll Never Stray From Her Country Roots|last=Nesvig|first=Kara|website=Teen Vogue|date=February 23, 2016|access-date=April 30, 2016}}</ref> She has also performed songs originally recorded by [[Alison Krauss]] and sang \"[[Ghost in This House]]\" alongside Krauss at the CMT Artists of the Year Awards in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PU_4E_sF8W8 |title=Kelsea Ballerini - \"Ghost In This House\" &#124; Live at the Grand Ole Opry &#124; Opry |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=August 10, 2016 |access-date=June 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url=https://vimeo.com/296307613 | title=Kelsea Ballerini & Alison Krauss &#124; Ghost in This House &#124; 2018 CMT Artists of the Year Performance|website=Vimeo.com}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\n[[File:Morgan And Kelsea CMC Awards 2016.jpg|upright=1.1|alt=Morgan Evans and Kelsea Ballerini in March 2016|thumb|[[Morgan Evans (singer)|Morgan Evans]] and Kelsea Ballerini during a [[Planet Country with Big Stu & MJ|Planet Country]] interview on the [[Country Music Channel|CMC Awards]] red carpet in March 2016 around the time their relationship started]]\n\nIn March 2016, Ballerini began dating Australian country singer [[Morgan Evans (singer)|Morgan Evans]]. They became engaged on Christmas Day 2016<ref>{{cite web|author=Sarah Michaud |url=http://people.com/country/kelsea-ballerini-engaged-morgan-evans-see-the-ring/ |title=Kelsea Ballerini Engaged to Morgan Evans - See the Ring |website=People.com |date=December 25, 2016 |access-date=June 9, 2017}}</ref> and were married on December 2, 2017, in [[Cabo San Lucas, Mexico]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kelsea Ballerini and Morgan Evans' Wedding Album |url=https://people.com/country/kelsea-ballerini-morgan-evans-wedding-album-photos-2/ |access-date=June 9, 2024 |website=Peoplemag |language=en}}</ref> On August 29, 2022, Ballerini announced that she and Evans were divorcing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://people.com/country/kelsea-ballerini-files-for-divorce-morgan-evans|title=Kelsea Ballerini Files for Divorce from Morgan Evans: 'Deeply Difficult Decision'|author1=Rachel Desantis |author2=Melody Chiu |magazine=People|date=August 29, 2022|access-date=August 30, 2022}}</ref> On November 3, 2022, it was revealed that Ballerini and Evans had reached a settlement agreement, and their divorce was finalized on November 15, 2022.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://people.com/country/kelsea-ballerini-and-morgan-evans-reach-divorce-settlement-agreement|title=Kelsea Ballerini and Morgan Evans Reach Settlement Agreement 2 Months After She Filed for Divorce |author1=Daniela Avila |author2=Rachel DeSantis |magazine=People|date=November 3, 2022|access-date=November 4, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://people.com/country/kelsea-ballerini-says-she-spent-grammy-nom-day-finalizing-divorce|title=Kelsea Ballerini Spent Grammy Nom Day 'Finalizing' Divorce and Picking Up Keys to 'Dream Home'|author=Rachel DeSantis|magazine=People|date=November 16, 2022|access-date=November 16, 2022}}</ref>\n\nIn February 2023, it was confirmed that Ballerini was dating ''[[Outer Banks (TV series)|Outer Banks]]'' actor [[Chase Stokes]]. The couple reportedly began dating in December 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kelsea Ballerini and Chase Stokes' Relationship Timeline |url=https://people.com/country/kelsea-ballerini-and-chase-stokes-relationship-timeline/ |access-date=June 9, 2024 |website=Peoplemag |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Kelsea Ballerini Kisses Chase Stokes on the Cheek in Adorable Photo |url=https://people.com/country/kelsea-ballerini-kisses-chase-stokes-on-cheek-photo/ |access-date=February 28, 2023 |website=People}}</ref>\n\nBallerini was a student at [[Central High School (Knoxville, Tennessee)|Central High School]] during the 2008 shooting, which she witnessed. She has said she suffers from [[post-traumatic stress disorder]] due to the experience.<ref>{{Cite web|date=November 17, 2021|first=Jeff|last=Nelson|title=Kelsea Ballerini Talks About PTSD from Witnessing School Shooting, Says Concerts Can Trigger Her|url=https://people.com/country/kelsea-ballerini-ptsd-triggers-after-witnessing-school-shooting/|access-date=November 26, 2021|website=People.com}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Kelsea Ballerini discography}}\n\n'''Studio albums'''\n* ''[[The First Time (Kelsea Ballerini album)|The First Time]]'' (2015)\n* 2015}}</ref>\n|-\n| rowspan=\"12\" |[[Country Music Association Awards]]\n| rowspan=\"2\" |2015\n| rowspan=\"7\" |Herself\n|Female Vocalist of the Year\n|{{nom}}\n|rowspan=\"2\"|<ref name=two>{{cite
