''Feel Your Way Through: A Book of Poetry''. [[Ballantine Books]].\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n* {{Official website|http://kelseaballerini.com/}}\n* {{Discogs artist|Kelsea Ballerini}}\n\n{{Kelsea Ballerini}}\n{{Grand Ole Opry members}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Ballerini, Kelsea}}\n[[Category:1993 births]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American people of Italian descent]]\n[[Category:Black River Entertainment artists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Country pop musicians]]\n[[Category:Lipscomb University alumni]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Knoxville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:People from Knox County, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Grand Ole Opry members]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Cam_(singer)","to":"Cam (singer)"}],"pages":{"47078839":{"pageid":47078839,"ns":0,"title":"Cam (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music singer and songwriter}}\n{{good article}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name               = Cam\n| image              = Country singer Cam at Bra Country Concert.jpg\n| caption            = Cam performing live in 2015\n| birth_name         = Camaron Marvel Ochs<ref name=\"burning\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-cams-haunting-new-single-burning-house-20150618|title=Hear Cam's Haunting New Hit Single 'Burning House'|last=Shelburne|first=Craig|date=18 June 2015|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=25 June 2015}}</ref>\n| birth_date         = {{birth date and age|1984|11|19}}<ref name=\"Allmusic Bio\"/>\n| birth_place        = [[Huntington Beach, California]], U.S.\n| education          = [[University of California, Davis]]\n| other_names        = <!--Per Template:Infobox person and MOS:MULTINAMES, it is not necessary to list off her names here. Also see WP:BLP.-->\n| occupation         = {{flat list|\n* Singer\n* songwriter\n}}\n| years_active       = 2010\u2013present\n| spouse             = {{marriage|Adam Weaver<br />|2016}}\n| children           = 1\n| awards             = \n| website            = \n| module             = {{Infobox musical artist\n| embed           = yes\n| genre           = [[Country pop]]\n| instrument      = Vocals\n| label           = {{flat list|\n*Rubber Room\n*[[Arista Nashville]]\n*[[RCA Records|RCA]]/[[Thirty Tigers]]\n}}\n| website         = [http://www.camcountry.com/ camcountry.com]\n}}\n}}\n'''Camaron Marvel Ochs''' (born November 19, 1984), known professionally as '''Cam''', is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. She began her career as a songwriter and has composed material for several artists including [[Beyonc\u00e9]], [[Sam Smith (singer)|Sam Smith]] and [[Miley Cyrus]]. In 2010, she released her debut studio album ''Heartforward'' on an independent record label. Signing with [[Sony Music Entertainment]], she released her debut major label [[extended play|EP]] in March 2015, ''[[Welcome to Cam Country]]'', followed by the studio album ''[[Untamed (Cam album)|Untamed]]'' later that same year. Her third album was ''[[The Otherside (album)|The Otherside]]'', released on [[Thirty Tigers|Triple Tigers]] in 2020. Her second single \"[[Burning House]]\" is her most commercially successful, peaking at the number two position on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] and [[Country Airplay]]. Spurred by airplay on ''[[The Bobby Bones Show]]'', the song received widespread acclaim, including a Best Country Solo Performance nomination at the [[58th Annual Grammy Awards]] and a Triple Platinum certification by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA).\n\n==Early life==\nCam was born on November 19, 1984, in [[Huntington Beach, California]],<ref name=\"rocha\">{{cite news|last1=Rocha|first1=Michael James|title=Country singer Cam on her musical journey \u2014 from Oceanside to Nashville to the Grammys|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/entertainment/music/sd-et-music-cam-20171127-story.html|access-date=29 November 2017|newspaper=The San Diego Union-Tribune|date=November 28, 2017}}</ref> and was raised in [[Lafayette, California]], a suburb in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]].<ref name=SAENash>{{cite news|last1=Malone|first1=Dana|title=Pathway to a record deal: Hard work, circumstance and originality take Cam Ochs 'Down The Road'|url=http://sportsandentertainmentnashville.com/pathway-to-a-record-deal-hard-work-circumstance-and-originality-take-camaron-ochs-down-the-road/|access-date=22 April 2015|publisher=Sports and Entertainment Nashville|date=5 September 2014}}</ref> She also spent time in [[Oceanside, California]], where her grandparents operated a [[ranch]]. They helped develop Cam's appreciation for country music, listening to and performing it regularly.<ref name=BilboarWlecomccount>{{cite magazine|last1=Dauphin|first1=Chuck|title=Welcome To Cam Country: Arista Nashville Singer Has a Short Name, Potentially Long Career|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6531920/welcome-to-cam-country-arista-nashville-singer-has-a-short-name|access-date=22 April 2015|magazine=Billboard|date=16 April 2015}}</ref> Pursuing music throughout high school and college, she sang in various choral groups.<ref name=OCOmayinspire>{{cite news|last1=Schadewald|first1=Amber|title=Oakland's Camaron Ochs may inspire folk-pop Barbie|url=http://www.sfbg.com/noise/2010/03/16/oaklands-camaron-ochs-may-inspire-folk-pop-barbie|access-date=22 April 2015|publisher=San Francisco Bay Guardian|date=16 March 2010}}</ref> This included performing in the Contra Costa Children's Chorus, where she learned to sing in 14 languages. She attended the [[University of California, Davis]] as an [[undergraduate education|undergraduate student]], studying psychology.<ref name=\"Smoldering Ballad\">{{cite magazine|last1=Roland|first1=Tom|title=Country Singer Cam Dreams Up a Smoldering Ballad With 'Burning House'|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/6633599/country-singer-cam-dreams-up-a-smoldering-ballad-with-burning-house|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=28 December 2015}}</ref> There, she formed an all-female collegiate [[a cappella]] group called [[The Spokes]] and learned to play the [[guitar]] while studying abroad in the [[Netherlands]]. She developed confidence in playing the instrument on a trip to [[Nepal]]. Taking residency in a rural mountain community, she lived for several weeks with limited electricity and basic needs; in addition, she developed a friendship with various Canadian musicians and started playing the guitar more consistently. In a 2010 interview, Cam stated that she grew more confident in playing once from the trip.<ref name=OCOmayinspire/>\n\nFollowing college, she sporadically performed music but mostly pursued other interests. This included work in research labs, including one at [[Stanford University]]. Yet she remained conflicted about the choices she made.<ref name=\"USA Today\">{{cite news|last1=Ryan|first1=Patrick|title=On the Verge: Cam|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/ontheverge/2015/11/01/on-the-verge-cam-burning-house/74596536/|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|access-date=28 December 2015}}</ref> A meeting with a college professor influenced Cam's choice to embark on a full-fledged music career. The professor said to her, \"Just picture yourself at 80 years old. Looking back at your life, what would you regret not doing: music or psychology?'\"<ref name=\"USA Today\"/><ref name=\"Billboard Interview\">{{cite magazine|last1=Hight|first1=Jewly|title=Why 'Burning House' Singer Cam Gave Up Psychology for Country Music|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/magazine-feature/6708058/cam-burning-house-women-country-music-psychology|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=28 December 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\n===2010\u20132014: Early beginnings===\nIn 2010, Cam released her debut studio album titled ''Heartforward'' via the independent Rubber Room label. Credited to her full name of Camaron Ochs, the album contained contemporary [[pop music|pop]] songs.<ref name=\"Allmusic Bio\">{{cite web|last1=Deming|first1=Mark|title=Cam: Biography and History|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/cam-mn0003380333/biography|website=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=28 December 2015}}</ref> Amber Schadewald of the ''[[San Francisco Bay Guardian]]'' called the album a brand of [[Folk rock|folk pop]] that \"is light and sweet, with genuine lyrics that ask listeners to live with their 'heartforward'\". Songs written for the project were based on experiences from her trip to Nepal. She promoted ''Heartforward'' through performances in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] and [[San Francisco, California]], including shows at the Stork Club and Mama Buzz.<ref name=OCOmayinspire/>\n\nCam soon moved to [[Los Angeles, California]], and began collaborating with songwriter and producer [[Tyler Johnson (music)|Tyler Johnson]]. She recorded some demos with Johnson in an attempt to attract [[Faith Hill]], eventually leading to the recordings being heard by [[Tim McGraw]]'s manager.<ref name=SAENash/> Her song \"Fall Madly in Love with You\" was chosen as a track for ''[[Cut to Impress]]'', the 2013 debut album from [[Maggie Rose]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Yes they Cam|url=http://hitsdailydouble.com/news&id=295480|website=HitsDailyDouble|publisher=Hits Digital Ventures|access-date=October 7, 2015|date=April 10, 2015}}</ref><ref name=GlamourMag>{{cite news|last1=Radloff|first1=Jessica|title=Here's What Really Happened Behind the Scenes at the ACM Awards Last Night|url=http://www.glamour.com/entertainment/blogs/obsessed/2015/04/acm-awards-video-photos-red-carpet|access-date=22 April 2015|publisher=Glamour Magazine|date=20 April 2015}}</ref> [[Miley Cyrus]] also recorded one of Cam's songs, \"Maybe You're Right\", on her 2013 album ''[[Bangerz]]''.<ref name=SwedishHDse>{{cite news|last1=Lindqvist|first1=Stefan|title=Camaron Ochs sjunger med Helsingborgsband|url=http://www.hd.se/noje/2013/11/30/camaron-ochs-sjunger-med-helsingborgsband/|access-date=22 April 2015|publisher=HD.se|date=30 November 2013|language=sv}}</ref> The success of these songs led her to  move to [[Nashville, Tennessee]]; there, began writing music for other artists, turning down a publishing deal in attempt to prove herself on her own.<ref name=SAENash/><ref>{{cite news|title=Cameron Ochs keeps it country with rootsy, organic debut|url=http://forthecountryrecord.com/2014/02/12/cameron-ochs-keeps-it-country-with-rootsy-organic-debut-review/|access-date=22 April 2015|publisher=For The Country Record|date=12 February 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150413063846/http://forthecountryrecord.com/2014/02/12/cameron-ochs-keeps-it-country-with-rootsy-organic-debut-review/|archive-date=13 April 2015|url-status=dead}}</ref> She launched a [[Kickstarter]] campaign in 2013 to produce 10 songs with Johnson.<ref name=StamTodayLocals>{{cite news|last1=Inglis|first1=Nicole|title=Country star on the rise with support from Steamboat locals|url=http://www.steamboattoday.com/news/2012/dec/19/country-star-rise-support-steamboat-locals/|access-date=22 April 2015|publisher=Steamboat Today|date=20 December 2012}}</ref> The campaign was supported by producer [[Jeff Bhasker]], known best for his work with artists that include [[Beyonc\u00e9]], [[Fun (band)|fun.]], [[Bruno Mars]], and [[Pink (singer)|P!nk]].<ref name=SAENash/> The same year Cam toured Denmark and Sweden with [[Helsingborg]] band Karavan, having previously collaborated with Anders Mouridsen of the group while in Los Angeles.<ref name=SwedishHDse/>\n\nCam released a [[single (music)|single]] in 2013 titled \"Down This Road\" with the encouragement of manager Lindsay Marias. Through a photo posted on [[Instagram]], local radio director Michael Bryan discovered the song and played it on the air. According to Cam, radio airplay of the single helped her choose which label she wanted to sign to. Ultimately, she chose to meet with [[Doug Morris]], the director of [[Sony Music Entertainment]]. She flew to the label's headquarters in [[New York City]] to meet with him.<ref name=SwedishHDse/> Using only an [[acoustic guitar]], she sang a song she had already been developing, \"[[Burning House]]\". Morris started humming along to the chorus and stated, \"This is the reason why I got into the music business.\" He would later ask her to perform the song at the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]] ceremony.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rau|first1=Nate|title=Sony Music CEO Doug Morris touts Nashville up-and-comers|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/07/24/sony-music-ceo-doug-morris-touts-nashville-up-and-comers/30641039/|website=[[The Tennessean]]|access-date=28 December 2015}}</ref> She was soon signed to Sony's country division, [[Arista Nashville]] in 2014<ref name=BilboarTomorrowhits>{{cite magazine|title=Tomorrow's Hits: The Avener's 'Fade Out Lines,' Cam and Young Rising Sons|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6472726/tomorrow-hits-avener-cam-young-rising-sons|access-date=22 April 2015|magazine=Billboard|date=13 February 2015}}</ref> and toured nationally with [[Dan + Shay]] that same year on their ''Where It All Began'' tour.<ref name=BilboarTomorrowhits/>\n\n===2015\u20132017: Breakthrough===\nIn early 2015, [[Arista Nashville]] released Cam's first single for them, \"[[My Mistake (Cam song)|My Mistake]]\".<ref name=BilboarTomorrowhits/> In March, the song debuted at No. 58 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Country Airplay]] chart.<ref name=BillboardBlackberry>{{cite magazine|last1=Jessen|first1=Wade|title=Blackberry Smoke's 'Roses' Blooms at No. 1 on Top Country Albums|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6479936/blackberry-smoke-top-country-albums|access-date=22 April 2015|magazine=Billboard|date=19 February 2015}}</ref> The song peaked at number 52 only a few weeks later.<ref>{{cite web|title=New Country Adds|url=http://www.country103.ca/new-music-added/|website=Country 103|access-date=28 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160106231408/http://www.country103.ca/new-music-added/|archive-date=2016-01-06|url-status=dead}}</ref> Still using her full name (Camaron Ochs) during the single's promotion, she ultimately shortened it to \"Cam\" because some people found her last name \"too hard to pronounce\".<ref name=BilboarWlecomccount/> \"My Mistake\" preceded Cam's debut [[extended play|EP]], ''[[Welcome to Cam Country]]'', released in March 2015. It contained four songs, with Bhasker and Johnson serving as producers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Allers|first1=Hannahlee|title=Cam Releases Debut EP|url=http://theboot.com/cam-welcome-to-cam-country-ep/|website=The Boot|date=12 April 2015 |access-date=28 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sonymusicnashville.com/press/cam/97966/arista-nashville-recording-artist-cam-reveals-debut-ep-exclusively-spotify|title=Arista Nashville Recording Artist Cam Reveals Debut EP, Exclusively on Spotify|work=Sony Music Nashville|access-date=25 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626130318/http://www.sonymusicnashville.com/press/cam/97966/arista-nashville-recording-artist-cam-reveals-debut-ep-exclusively-spotify|archive-date=26 June 2015|url-status=dead}}</ref> It peaked at No.  31 on the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart, No. 88 on the [[Billboard 200]], and No. 5 on the [[Top Heatseekers]] survey.<ref>{{cite web|title=''Welcome to Cam Country'' - Cam: Awards|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/welcome-to-cam-country-mw0002836605/awards|website=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=28 December 2015}}</ref>\n\n\"Burning House\" served as her next single. She performed the song live on the radio program ''[[The Bobby Bones Show]]'', which attracted and fueled attention to the song.<ref name=\"burning\"/> [[Sony Music Entertainment]], of which Arista Nashville is a division, then arranged a meeting and decided to release the track as a single on June 16, 2015, after the song had initial success on the [[iTunes]] charts.<ref name=\"Smoldering Ballad\"/> \"Burning House\" became a top-five hit on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs|country songs]] and country airplay charts.<ref name=\"Top Five\">{{cite magazine|last1=Asker|first1=Jim|title=Cam & Emily Ann Roberts' Versions of 'Burning House' Are Both in the Hot Country Songs Top Five|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6820766/cam-emily-ann-roberts-burning-house-charts|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=28 December 2015}}</ref> It also was the highest-selling female country song of 2015, selling more than 500,000 copies in the United States.<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Leahey|first1=Andrew|title=Watch Cam Cap Off Smoldering Year With Live 'Burning House'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/watch-cam-cap-off-smoldering-year-with-live-burning-house-20151216|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=28 December 2015}}</ref> In addition the song received nominations at the 2016 [[Grammy Awards]], [[Academy of Country Music Awards]], and [[Country Music Association Awards]].<ref name=\"Best Country Albums\">{{cite magazine|title=Cam, \"Burning House\" - 25 Best Country Songs of 2015|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/25-best-country-songs-of-2015-20151214/cam-burning-house-20151214|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=28 December 2015}}</ref> In January 2022 \"Burning House\" was certified triple-platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). The success of the song led to the release of her first Arista Nashville album ''[[Untamed (Cam album)|Untamed]]'' on December 11, 2015. Also produced largely by Bhasker and Johnson, it consisted of 11 tracks all co-written by Cam, including all of the songs from the EP.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Reuter|first1=Annie|title=Cam Announces Title, Release Date for Major Label Debut Read More: Cam Announces Title, Release Date for Major Label Debut|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/cam-debut-album-untamed/|website=[[Taste of Country]]|date=2 November 2015 |access-date=28 December 2015}}</ref> It debuted at number two on the Top Country Albums chart and was the highest-selling debut country studio album of 2015.<ref name=\"Top Five\"/> ''Rolling Stone'' ranked the album at number 15 on their list of the \"40 Best Country Albums of 2015\". The magazine commented, \"For an artist at the start of career, Cam already sounds like one of the most secure in the game.\"<ref name=\"Best Country Albums\"/> \"[[Mayday (Cam song)|Mayday]]\" was released as the album's third single in February 2016.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Carr|first1=Courtney|title=Cam Selects 'Mayday' as New Single [LISTEN]|url=http://theboot.com/cam-mayday-song-single/|website=The Boot|date=27 January 2016 |access-date=20 February 2016}}</ref> It was a minor Top 40 hit on the country charts, peaking at number 36 on ''Billboard'' Country Airplay. \n\nIn October 2017, Cam announced a new single titled [[Diane (Cam song)|\"Diane\"]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/hear-cams-jolene-inspired-new-song-diane-w510372|title=Hear Cam's Supercharged, 'Jolene'-Inspired New Song 'Diane'|last=Betts|first=Stephen L.|date=October 27, 2017|work=Rolling Stone Country|access-date=27 October 2017}}</ref> She promoted the song with several live performances including on [[Good Morning America]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/a19681578/cam-diane-song/|title=Watch Dolly Parton Surprise Country Singer Cam On 'Good Morning America'|last=Matthews|first=Lauren|date=4 April 2018|work=Country Living|access-date=2 January 2019}}</ref> ''[[The Late Late Show with James Corden]]'',<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8343549/late-late-show-cam-diane|title=Cam Gives Mesmerizing Performance of 'Diane' on 'The Late Late Show'|last=Cummings-Grady|first=Mackenzie|date=17 April 2018|magazine=Billboard|access-date=2 January 2019}}</ref> and as a duet with a contestant on [[American Idol (season 16)|season 16 of ''American Idol'']].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/cam-american-idol-effie-passero-diane-shannon-ohara-burning-house/|title=Cam Duets with 'American Idol' Contestants on 'Diane,' 'Burning House'|last=Stefano|first=Angela|date=17 April 2018|work=The Boot|access-date=2 January 2019}}</ref> In April 2018, \"Diane\" was added to the [[BBC Radio 2]] A-list and hit No. 1 on iTunes for 5 weeks. Also in 2017, Cam, along with [[Sam Smith (singer)|Sam Smith]] and Tyler Johnson, co-wrote the song \"Palace\" for Smith's 2017 album ''[[The Thrill of It All (Sam Smith album)|The Thrill of It All]]'' and providing background vocals and guitar to the track.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://people.com/country/cam-wrote-sam-smith-song-we-had-same-heartache/|title=Country Star Cam on Writing a Song for Sam Smith's New Album: We Had the 'Same Heartache'|last=Nelson|first=Jeff|date=3 November 2017|work=People|access-date=2 January 2019}}</ref> The song saw international success and was highlighted in the Holiday \"Sway\" commercial for [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] which led to its reaching No. 1 on the Billboard Top TV Commercials Chart.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8093860/sam-smith-palace-apple-ad-top-tv-commercials-chart-number-one|title=Sam Smith's 'Palace' Hits No. 1 on Top TV Commercials Chart for December|last=Zellner|first=Xander|date=11 January 2018|magazine=Billboard|access-date=2 January 2019}}</ref> The widespread embrace of \"Palace\" included much international success, specifically in [[Japan]], where Smith performed the song on multiple TV talk shows. Cam opened for Smith on the Summer US leg of his 2018 The Thrill Of It All Tour.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/cam-joins-sam-smiths-thrill-of-it-all-tour-629146/|title=Cam Joins Sam Smith's Thrill of It All Tour|last=Betts|first=Stephen L.|date=7 June 2018|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=2 January 2019}}</ref> Cam has also shared the stage with [[Tim McGraw]] and [[Faith Hill]] on their [[Soul2Soul: The World Tour|Soul2Soul Tour]]<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/tim-mcgraw-faith-hills-soul2soul-tour-taps-devin-dawson-caitlyn-smith-127866/|title=Tim McGraw, Faith Hill's Soul2Soul Tour Taps Devin Dawson, Caitlyn Smith|last=Parton|first=Chris|date=19 March 2018|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=2 January 2019}}</ref> as well as [[Harry Styles]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://people.com/country/harry-styles-invited-cam-open-nashville-concert-better-than-hype/|title=Harry Styles Invited Country Star Cam to Open His Nashville Show: 'He's Even Better Than All the Hype'|last=Nelson|first=Jeff|date=29 September 2017|work=People|access-date=2 January 2019}}</ref>\n\n===2018\u2013present: Transition to RCA ===\nIn July 2018, Cam released \"Road to Happiness\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/cam-road-to-happiness/|title=Cam Ponders the Real Meaning of Joy in 'Road to Happiness'|last=Whitaker|first=Sterling|date=13 July 2018|work=Taste of Country|access-date=2 January 2019}}</ref> and parted ways with Arista Nashville.<ref name=\"triple tigers signing\">{{cite magazine |title=Cam Signs with Nashville's Triple Tiers Label in Partnership with RCA New York |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/9410902/cam-signs-nashville-triple-tigers-partnership-rca-new-york |access-date=June 29, 2020 |magazine=Billboard}}</ref> In 2019, she provided vocals for [[Diplo]]'s song \"[[So Long (Diplo song)|So Long]]\" for his ''[[Diplo Presents Thomas Wesley, Chapter 1: Snake Oil]]'' album.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/diplo-cam-so-long-thomas-wesley-828677/|title=Song You Need to Know: Diplo and Cam, 'So Long'|last=Freeman|first=Jon|date=2019-05-02|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|access-date=2020-02-13}}</ref>\n\nOn June 29, 2020, it was announced that Cam had signed a new partnership for radio promotion with Nashville-based [[Triple Tigers]] in a joint venture with her label [[RCA Records]]. \"Classic\" was released on July 17, 2020, as her first country radio single since \"Diane\" in 2017. Her critically acclaimed sophomore album, ''[[The Otherside (album)|The Otherside]]'', was released on October 30, 2020.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Otherside by Cam |url=https://music.apple.com/nz/album/the-otherside/1523527625}}</ref> For this release, she once again enlisted producers [[Tyler Johnson (musician)|Tyler Johnson]] ([[Harry Styles]], [[Miley Cyrus]]) and [[Jeff Bhasker]] ([[Kanye West]], [[Alicia Keys]]). The record featured the international Jolene-in-reverse hit \u201c[[Diane (Cam song)|Diane]],\u201d the song \u201cTill There's Nothing Left,\u201d plus songwriting from [[Avicii]], [[Harry Styles]], [[Jack Antonoff]], and [[Sam Smith]]. <ref name=\"triple tigers signing\"/><ref name=\"Rolling Stone\">{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/cam-till-theres-nothing-left-952115/|title=Cam Addresses Sex and Swagger on New Song, 'Till There's Nothing Left'|last=Freeman|first=Jon|date=2020-02-13|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|access-date=2020-02-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Cam preps \"magical\" new song, \"Redwood Tree\" |url=http://www.hotcountry931.com/2020/05/cam-preps-magical-new-song-redwood-tree/ |website=Hot Country 931 |access-date=28 May 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn 2024, she contributed songwriting, production and backing vocals for [[Beyonc\u00e9]]'s ''[[Cowboy Carter]]'' album (\u201cAmerican Requiem,\u201d \u201cAmen,\u201d \u201cProtector,\u201d \u201cTyrant,\u201d \u201cDaughter\u201d).<ref>{{cite web | url=https://variety.com/2024/music/news/cam-beyonce-cowboy-carter-writing-production-1235963667/ | title=Singer-Songwriter Cam Discusses Working on Five Tracks for Beyonc\u00e9's Cowboy Carter: She's Just Such a Creative Genius | date=8 April 2024 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Cam Post on Twitter |url=https://twitter.com/camcountry/status/1773788015346974744 |website=twitter.com |publisher=X Corp. |access-date=2024-04-07}}</ref>\n\n==Artistry==\nCam was exposed to classic country music at an early age from the time spent on her grandparents' ranch. They introduced her to the musical sounds of [[Patsy Cline]], [[Bonnie Raitt]] and [[Willie Nelson]].<ref name=BilboarWlecomccount/> She was largely influenced by the vocal phrasing of Cline and [[Ray Charles]]. She also developed an appreciation for [[the Chicks]] and the [[Indigo Girls]], commenting that she was \"so into those female harmonies\". She additionally cites [[Bob Dylan]], [[Joni Mitchell]], and [[Randy Newman]] as influences on her songwriting style.<ref name=\"Billboard Interview\"/> Although she has a variety of musical influences, Cam stated that country music is where she felt most connected to. In a 2015 interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', she explained her reasoning: \"I grew up singing in a lot of different languages and a lot of world music choirs, so I have a lot of musical influences. But the songwriting structure of country music is the standard in my mind. ... That structure seems to feel the most homey to me.\"<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Cam - 10 New Country Artists You Need to Know: Spring 2015|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-spring-2015-20150505/cam-20150505|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=28 December 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nIn September 2015, Cam became engaged to Adam Weaver, a business broker with First Choice Business Brokers in Nashville.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McClellan|first1=Laura|title=Cam Shows Off New Bling|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/cam-engaged/|website=Taste of Country|date=9 September 2015 |access-date=22 July 2016}}</ref> In October 2016, the couple married in a small ceremony in a California desert.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Anderson|first1=Danielle|title=See Cam's Stunning Wedding Album!|url=http://people.com/country/cam-wedding-album-marries-adam-weaver/|website=People|access-date=11 October 2016}}</ref> In December 2019, she gave birth to her first child, Lucy. Shortly after giving birth, Cam posted on social media that she was a \"breech at 39wks, a next-day c-section (ouch) & here we are... three of us now.\"<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Iasimone |first1=Ashley |title=Cam Gives Birth to Baby Lucy Marvel: See the Photos |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8546960/cam-baby-birth-announcement |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=24 February 2020}}</ref>\n\nCam is a vocal advocate for music education and inclusion. She spoke on the psychology of music in her 2017 [[TEDx talk|TEDx Talk]] at the University of Nevada.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/5-things-we-learned-from-cams-tedx-talk-193313/|title=5 Things We Learned From Cam's TEDx Talk|last=Parton|first=Chris|date=7 March 2017|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=2 January 2019}}</ref> Cam is on the [[Academy of Country Music]] (ACM) Board and was invited to join [[The Recording Academy]]'s Task Force on Diversity and Inclusion in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/news/recording-academy-names-diversity-and-inclusion-task-force-members/|title= Recording Academy Names Diversity And Inclusion Task Force Members|date=9 May 2018|work=Grammy.com|access-date=2 January 2019}}</ref> In 2018, Cam joined the speaker list on [[Hello Sunshine (company)|Hello Sunshine]] x Together Live's touring event<ref>{{cite web|url=http://togetherlive.com/about/|title= Our Stories Travel|access-date=2 January 2019}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Cam discography}}\n'''Studio albums'''\n* ''Heartforward'' (2010)\n* ''[[Untamed (Cam album)|Untamed]]'' (2015)\n* ''[[The Otherside (album)|The Otherside]]'' (2020)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{|class=\"wikitable 2016 | access-date=March 31, 2020}}</ref>\n\n'''Headlining'''\n*The Long Road Festival (2023)\n* The Burning House Tour (2016)<ref>{{cite 2016|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]}}</ref>\n* Best Coast Tour (2017)<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/cam-announces-2017-best-coast-tour-w506118|title=Cam Unveils 2017 title=Cam Announces The Oh, The Places We'll Go! Summer Tour | work=Anti Music | date=June 4, 2019 | access-date=March 31, 2019}}</ref>\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n{{commons category}}\n* {{Official website|www.camcountry.com}}\n\n{{Cam}}\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Cam}}\n[[Category:1984 births]]\n[[Category:Arista Nashville artists]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from California]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Huntington Beach, California]]\n[[Category:RCA Records artists]]\n[[Category:People from Lafayette, California]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from California]]\n[[Category:University of California, Davis alumni]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Thirty Tigers artists]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Kellie_Pickler","to":"Kellie Pickler"}],"pages":{"3859453":{"pageid":3859453,"ns":0,"title":"Kellie Pickler","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country singer (born 1986)}}\n{{About|the singer|her self-titled album|Kellie Pickler (album){{!}}''Kellie Pickler'' (album)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Kellie Pickler\n| image           = KellieP.JPG\n| alt             = Pickler smiling while holding a microphone\n| caption         = Pickler performing in 2013\n| birth_name      = Kellie Dawn Pickler\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1986|06|28}}\n| birth_place     = [[Albemarle, North Carolina]], U.S.\n| spouse          = {{marriage|[[Kyle Jacobs (songwriter)|Kyle Jacobs]]|2011|2023|reason=died}}\n| background      = solo_singer\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country pop]]}}\n| occupation      = {{hlist|Singer|actress|television personality}}\n| years_active    = 2005\u20132019, 2022-present\n| label           = {{hlist|[[BNA Records|BNA]]|[[19 Entertainment|19 Recordings]]|[[Sony Music Nashville|Columbia Nashville]]|[[Black River Entertainment]]}}\n| website         = {{URL|kelliepickler.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Kellie Dawn Pickler''' (born June 28, 1986) is an American [[country music]] singer, actress and television personality. Pickler gained fame as a contestant on the [[American Idol (season 5)|fifth season]] of ''[[American Idol]]'' and finished in sixth place. In 2006, she signed to [[19 Entertainment|19 Recordings]] and [[BNA Records]] as a recording artist. Her debut album, ''[[Small Town Girl (album)|Small Town Girl]]'', was released later that year and has sold over 900,000 copies. The album, which was certified [[Music recording certification|gold]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]], produced three singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts: \"[[Red High Heels]]\" at No. 15, \"[[I Wonder (Kellie Pickler song)|I Wonder]]\" at No. 14, and \"Things That Never Cross a Man's Mind\" at No. 16. \n\nPickler released her [[Kellie Pickler (album)|self-titled]] second album in 2008 that produced four singles: \"[[Don't You Know You're Beautiful]]\" at No. 21, \"[[Best Days of Your Life]]\" at No. 9 (which she co-wrote with [[Taylor Swift]]), \"[[Didn't You Know How Much I Loved You]]\" at No. 14, and \"Makin' Me Fall in Love Again\" at No. 30. Following the closure of BNA Records, she moved to [[Black River Entertainment]].\n\nOn May 21, 2013, Pickler and her partner, [[Derek Hough]], won the [[Dancing with the Stars (American TV series) season 16|16th season]] of ''[[Dancing with the Stars (American TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]].'' In 2016, she was inducted into the [[North Carolina Music Hall of Fame]].\n\nFrom 2017 to 2019, she co-hosted the nationally syndicated daytime TV talk show ''[[Pickler & Ben]]'' with comedian [[Ben Aaron]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2017/09/kellie_picklers_new_talk_show.html|title=Kellie Pickler's new talk show 'Pickler & Ben' offers a little bit of everything|last=Morona|first=Joey|date=September 18, 2017|work=[[The Plain Dealer]]|access-date=September 21, 2017}}</ref> Pickler was married to Nashville songwriter and record producer [[Kyle Jacobs (songwriter)|Kyle Jacobs]] from 2011 until his suicide in 2023.\n\n==Early life==\n[[File:Courthouse Square Park, Albemarle, North Carolina.jpg|thumb|A banner proclaims Albemarle as \"Home of Kellie Pickler\"|alt=A clock in a small public square with a sign proclaiming it the hometown of Kellie Pickler]]\nKellie Pickler was born June 28, 1986, at Stanly Memorial Hospital in [[Albemarle, North Carolina]], to Cynthia Morton and Clyde \"Bo\" Raymond Pickler Jr. Her mother left when Kellie was two years old, then returned and took custody of her for two years. Eventually, the court returned Kellie to her grandparents when she was 12 and they raised her to adulthood because her father was absent in her life.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lansinglowdown.com/index.php/article/450 |title=Country singer's runaway mom comes out of hiding :: Lowdown |publisher=Lansinglowdown.com |access-date=May 1, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100929065917/http://www.lansinglowdown.com/index.php/article/450 |archive-date=September 29, 2010 }}</ref> Pickler says the major influences in her life are her grandfather, Clyde Raymond Pickler Sr., a former [[electrician]], and grandmother, Faye Pickler.{{citation needed|date = February 2012}} Pickler graduated in 2004 from North Stanly High School in [[New London, North Carolina]] where she was a [[cheerleader]]. She sang \"[[On the Side of Angels]]\" by [[LeAnn Rimes]] at her high school graduation.\n\n==''American Idol''==\nThe 19-year-old Pickler auditioned for ''American Idol'' in the fall of 2005 in [[Greensboro, North Carolina]]. She sang both [[Kelly Clarkson]]'s \"[[Since U Been Gone]]\" and [[Martina McBride]]'s \"[[A Broken Wing]]\". The judges sent her to Hollywood. Pickler advanced through the semi-final rounds in February. On March 9, she reached the Top 12.\n\nPickler was among judge [[Simon Cowell]]'s favorites. He once predicted Pickler would be in the final three, and said he preferred her over the previous season's winner, [[Carrie Underwood]].<ref>''American Idol''.[http://www.televisionwithoutpity.com/articles/content/a392/index-9.html Recap] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061026192304/http://www.televisionwithoutpity.com/articles/content/a392/index-9.html |date=October 26, 2006 }} of Season 5 Episode 12]. Retrieved March 7, 2006.</ref> Recognized for her \"quirky\" personality and [[Southern United States|Southern]] charm, Pickler gained attention on the show by saying that she had hardly ever performed before real audiences, and by mispronouncing words.<ref>''American Idol'' Top 24, Top 11 and Top 9</ref> She was compared to [[Jessica Simpson]] in a March 27-story in ''[[US Weekly]]'' magazine titled \"Kellie: The Next Jessica Simpson\", due to her \"sweet Southern style and ditzy demeanor\". Pickler has stated in the past a previous ignorance of common popular culture before her ''Idol'' fame.\n\n===Performances and results (during voting weeks)===\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"float:left;\"\n|+Kellie Pickler performances on ''American Idol''\n|-\n!scope=\"col\"| Week #\n!scope=\"col\"| Theme\n!scope=\"col\"| Song choice\n!scope=\"col\"| Original artist\n!scope=\"col\"| Result\n|-\n| Top 24 (12 Women)\n| N/A\n|scope=\"row\"| \"[[How Far]]\"\n| [[Martina McBride]]\n| Safe\n|-\n| Top 20 (10 Women)\n| N/A\n|scope=\"row\"| \"[[Something to Talk About (Bonnie Raitt song)|Something to Talk About]]\"\n| [[Bonnie Raitt]]\n| Safe\n|-\n| Top 16 (8 Women)\n| N/A\n|scope=\"row\"| \"[[I'm the Only One]]\"\n| [[Melissa Etheridge]]\n| Safe\n|-\n| Top 12\n| [[Stevie Wonder]]\n|scope=\"row\"| \"[[Blame It on the Sun]]\"\n| Stevie Wonder\n| Safe\n|-\n| Top 11\n| The 1950s\n|scope=\"row\"| \"[[Walkin' After Midnight]]\"\n| [[Patsy Cline]]\n| Safe\n|-\n| Top 10\n| Songs from The 21st Century\n|scope=\"row\"| \"[[Suds in the Bucket]]\"\n| [[Sara Evans]]\n| Safe\n|-\n| Top 9\n| [[Country music|Country]]\n|scope=\"row\"| \"[[Fancy (Bobbie Gentry song)|Fancy]]\"\n| [[Bobbie Gentry]]\n| Safe\n|-\n| Top 8\n| [[Queen (band)|Queen]]\n|scope=\"row\"| \"[[Bohemian Rhapsody]]\"\n| Queen\n| Safe\n|-\n| Top 7\n| [[Great American Songbook]]\n|scope=\"row\"| \"[[Bewitched, Bothered and Bewildered]]\"\n| [[Vivienne Segal]]\n| Safe\n|-\n| Top 6\n| [[Love song]]s\n|scope=\"row\"| \"[[Unchained Melody]]\"\n| [[Todd Duncan]]\n| Eliminated\n|}\n{{Clear}}\n\n==Post-''Idol'' career==\n[[File:Kellie Pickler Dec. 16, 2008, Ramstein AFB, Germany, USO Holiday Tour.jpg|thumb|Pickler and members of her band Ryan Ochsner, left, and Joshua Henson perform for U.S. service members during the first stop of the 2008 USO Holiday Tour on [[Ramstein Air Base]], Germany, December 16, 2008|alt=Pickler singing with guitarists on either side of her]]\nAfter her elimination, she appeared in numerous shows promoting the TV show and performed the song \"[[Walkin' After Midnight]]\" in some of her appearances.\n\nOn May 6, 2006, she returned to [[Albemarle, North Carolina]], for a parade and a reunion with her father. She received a key to the city from the mayor of Albemarle. The mayor also proclaimed the day as \"Kellie Pickler Day\". Pickler also received numerous awards from local and statewide government officials praising her accomplishments as a contestant on the ''American Idol'' television show.<ref>Hometown support links: [http://www.co.stanly.nc.us/Commissioners/Minutes/2006/05012006rm.htm Stanly County Board of Commissioners] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061002215512/http://www.co.stanly.nc.us/Commissioners/Minutes/2006/05012006rm.htm |date=October 2, 2006 }}, [http://www.albemarledowntown.com/kellie.htm Downtown Albemarle Development Corporation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060502171805/http://www.albemarledowntown.com/kellie.htm |date=May 2, 2006 }}, [http://www.ci.albemarle.nc.us/kelliepickler.htm Official City of Albemarle Website] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060615105911/http://www.ci.albemarle.nc.us/kelliepickler.htm |date=June 15, 2006 }}</ref>\n\nPickler pursued her recording aspirations in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], shortly thereafter. On July 17, 2006, she signed a record deal with [[19 Entertainment|19 Recordings]]/[[BNA Records]]. She later announced it herself on ''[[The View (talk show)|The View]]''. She was part of the ''[[American Idols Live! Tour 2006|American Idols LIVE! Tour 2006]]'', performing for three months in various cities. During that period, Pickler worked on her album in collaboration with top industry experts in different cities wherever the tour took her.<ref>{{cite web|author = Rick Ellis|title = Q&A With Kellie Pickler|url = http://www.allyourtv.com/0607season/q&akelliepickler.html|publisher = allyourtv.com|date = October 30, 2006|access-date = November 22, 2006|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927182619/http://www.allyourtv.com/0607season/q%26akelliepickler.html|archive-date = September 27, 2007}}</ref>\n\n===2006\u201307: ''Small Town Girl''===\nHer first single, \"[[Red High Heels]]\", debuted on September 13, 2006, and its music video was officially released on October 26, 2006. It received a nomination for the [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] Video Awards for \"Breakthrough Video of the Year\".<ref>{{cite web |title = CMT 2007 music Awards|url = http://www.cmt.com/shows/events/cmt_music_awards/2007/vote/\n|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070307151510/http://www.cmt.com/shows/events/cmt_music_awards/2007/vote/\n|url-status = dead\n|archive-date = March 7, 2007\n|publisher = Country Music Television|date = January 31, 2007|access-date = February 2, 2007}}</ref>\nHer debut album, ''[[Small Town Girl (album)|Small Town Girl]]'', released on October 31, 2006, topped Billboard's [[Top Country Albums]] and landed at number nine on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] selling over 79,000 copies in its first week, making Pickler the highest-selling first-week sales for a new artist in 2006. The album includes five songs that Pickler co-wrote with songwriters [[Chris Lindsey]], [[Aimee Mayo]], and [[Karyn Rochelle]].<ref>{{cite news|title = Kellie Pickler Debuts First Single|url = http://www.americanidol.com/news/2006/09/pickler-debuts-first-single.htm|publisher = Fox American Idol |date = September 12, 2006|access-date = September 13, 2006}}</ref><ref name=\"CMTinterview\">{{cite news|title = CMT Loaded: CMT Top 20 Countdown 10.26.06 Kellie Pickler Interview 1|url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/pickler__kellie/artist.jhtml|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20061102221700/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/pickler__kellie/artist.jhtml|url-status = dead|archive-date = November 2, 2006|publisher = Country Music Television|date = September 23, 2006|access-date = October 26, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web\n|title = Red High Heels \u2013 Kellie Pickler\n|url = http://www.songmusiclyric.com/2006/10/22/red-high-heels-kellie-pickler/|publisher = songmusiclyric.com|date = September 22, 2006|access-date = October 28, 2006 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070301024358/http://www.songmusiclyric.com/2006/10/22/red-high-heels-kellie-pickler/ |archive-date = March 1, 2007}}</ref>\n\nOn January 18, 2007, Pickler co-hosted ''[[The View (talk show)|The View]]'' and was presented with a [[Music recording sales certification|gold record]] by [[Rosie O'Donnell]], certifying that her album has reached the 500,000 sales mark. She also performed her second single, \"[[I Wonder (Kellie Pickler song)|I Wonder]]\", which is a personal song about her absent relationship with her mother, Cynthia Morton. It was the first performance of the song on national television.<ref>{{cite news|title=\"Montana\" soundtrack, Manilow lead U.S. charts |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20061108/media_nm/sales_dc_2 |publisher=[[Yahoo! News]] |date=November 8, 2006 |access-date=November 10, 2006 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title = Top recordings|url = http://www.belleville.com/mld/belleville/entertainment/15977368.htm?source=rss&channel=belleville_entertainment|publisher = [[Belleville News-Democrat]]\n|date = November 10, 2006|access-date = November 10, 2006 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n\nPickler was nominated for \"Top New Female Vocalist\" for the 42nd [[Academy of Country Music]] Awards.<ref>{{cite news|title = Nominations Announced for the 42ND ANNUAL ACADEMY OF COUNTRY MUSIC(R) AWARDS Country Music's Party of the Year (R)|url = http://biz.yahoo.com/prnews/070305/nym087.html\n|publisher = Yahoo!|date = March 5, 2007|access-date = March 5, 2007}} {{cite web|url=http://www.sitiincontri.it |title=siti di incontri}}</ref>\n\nShe was also part of Brad Paisley's \"Bonfires & Amplifiers\" concert tour from April 2007 through October as one of the opening acts. The tour was booked in at least 37 cities across North America including a couple of stops in Canada.<ref>{{cite news|author = Kym Kilgore|title = Brad Paisley rolls with 'Bonfires & Amplifiers'|url = http://www.livedaily.com/news/Brad_Paisley_Taylorswift_rolls_with_Bonfires__Amplifiers-11306.html|publisher = Livedaily.com|date = January 9, 2007|access-date = January 17, 2007|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930202144/http://www.livedaily.com/news/Brad_Paisley_Taylorswift_rolls_with_Bonfires__Amplifiers-11306.html?t=98|archive-date = September 30, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author = Mike Zeppieri|title = Calendar of Canadian concerts for June 29 to July 29'|url = https://news.yahoo.com/s/cpress/20070628/ca_pr_on_en/tab_concert_calendar_2\n|publisher = Yahoo! News|date = June 28, 2007|access-date = January 1, 2007 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070705014619/http://news.yahoo.com/s/cpress/20070628/ca_pr_on_en/tab_concert_calendar_2 |archive-date = July 5, 2007}}</ref>\n\nPickler appeared in [[country music]] artist [[Brad Paisley]]'s music video \"[[Online (Brad Paisley song)|Online]]\" in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7GcVnhNjWV0 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070917102232/http://youtube.com/watch?v=7GcVnhNjWV0| archive-date=2007-09-17 | url-status=dead|title=Broadcast Yourself |via=YouTube |access-date=May 1, 2010}}</ref>\n\nIn September 2007, Pickler released a version of \"[[Santa Baby]]\" for a Christmas country compilation. A month later, at the [[American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers|ASCAP]] Awards in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Pickler received a songwriter award for co-writing \"Red High Heels\". She performed \"I Wonder\", at the 2007 [[CMA Awards]]. During the performance, she was visibly overcome with emotion and struggled to even finish the song before bursting into tears. The performance received a [[standing ovation]]. She was also nominated for the Horizon Award. The performance led her to receive 3 [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] awards the following April.\n\n===2008\u201310: ''Kellie Pickler''===\nWhile \"[[Things That Never Cross a Man's Mind]]\" was climbing the country charts (it eventually reached number sixteen), Pickler returned to the studio to record her second studio album for [[19 Entertainment|19 Recordings]]/[[BNA Records]]. She performed the debut single, \"[[Don't You Know You're Beautiful]]\" at the [[Academy of Country Music|ACM Awards]] on May 18, 2008, and received a good response from the audience. She was nominated for \"Top New Female Vocalist\", but the award went to [[Taylor Swift]].\n\n\"Don't You Know You're Beautiful\" was released to radio in June 2008 and was a Top 25 hit for Pickler, peaking eventually at number twenty-one. Her second album, ''[[Kellie Pickler (album)|Kellie Pickler]]'', was released on September 30, 2008, and debuted at the top of the country chart, as well as number nine on the ''Billboard'' 200, selling over 43,000 copies in its first week. It matched the debuting spots of her first album, ''[[Small Town Girl (album)|Small Town Girl]]''.\n\nOn November 12, 2008, Pickler performed the second single from her album ''[[Best Days of Your Life]]'' at the [[CMA Awards]]. She was also nominated for \"New Artist of the Year\" for the second year in a row, but lost to [[Lady Antebellum]]. \"Best Days of Your Life\" made its radio debut in November 2008, and debuted at number 56. The song climbed very slowly up the chart, but ended up becoming Pickler's first Top 10 hit on the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart. After nearly 40 weeks on the chart, the song peaked at number nine in August 2009. A music video was made by [[Roman White]], featuring [[Taylor Swift]], who co-wrote and sang background harmony vocals on the song.\n\nPickler was nominated for \"Female Video of the Year\" at the 2009 [[CMT Music Awards]] for \"Don't You Know You're Beautiful\". She lost once again to Swift. She also presented the award for \"USA Weekend Breakthrough Video of the Year\" with ''Idol'' judge [[Randy Jackson]].\n\nPickler accompanied Swift on the first leg of her [[Fearless Tour]] 2009. In June, she launched her first ever headline concert tour in promotion of her self-titled album. On October 8, it was announced that Pickler would be part of the second leg of ''Fearless Tour''.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/267140/taylor-swift-announces-second-leg-of-fearless-tour |title=Taylor Swift announces second leg of Fearless Tour |magazine=Billboard |date=September 14, 2009 |access-date=July 29, 2012}}</ref>\n\n\"[[Didn't You Know How Much I Loved You]]\", a re-recording from Pickler's first album ''[[Small Town Girl (album)|Small Town Girl]]'', was released as the album's third single on August 30, 2009. The song debuted at number 55 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart, and became her fifth Top 20 hit, peaking at number fourteen in February 2010.\n\nOn October 26, Pickler won the title of Country Weekly's poll of most beautiful woman in country music for the second year in a row. [[Reba McEntire]] and [[Carrie Underwood]] were the second and third places, respectively.<ref>[http://www.cmt.ca/News/NewsItem.aspx?news_id=8675] {{dead link|date=June 2024}}</ref>\n\n\"Makin' Me Fall in Love Again\" was released as the album's fourth single on April 19, 2010. It debuted at number 53 and peaked at number 30.\n\n===2011\u201312: ''100 Proof''===\nIt was announced that Pickler's third album would be produced by Frank Liddell, known for producing country artist [[Miranda Lambert]]'s [[Miranda Lambert discography|albums]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Hazel Smith |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/hot-dish/1627685/hot-dish-its-been-a-great-year-for-country-music.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100526101431/http://www.cmt.com/news/hot-dish/1627685/hot-dish-its-been-a-great-year-for-country-music.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=May 26, 2010 |title=Cmt News |publisher=Country Music Television |date=December 7, 2009 |access-date=July 29, 2012}}</ref> \"[[Tough (Kellie Pickler song)|Tough]]\" was released on June 13, 2011, as the lead-off single to Pickler's third album, ''[[100 Proof (album)|100 Proof]]'', which was released on January 24, 2012. The album debuted at number seven on the ''Billboard'' 200 and at number two on the Top Country Albums chart. \"Tough\" reached a peak of number 30 on the Hot Country Songs chart, while the album's [[100 Proof (song)|title track]], which was released as the second single in April 2012, peaked at number 50 on the same chart.\n\nOn June 27, 2012, ABC News Radio reported that Pickler parted ways with [[Sony Music Nashville|Sony Nashville]]. Pickler's manager told ABC News Radio, \"Kellie's contract with Sony came to an end and they mutually decided not to renew it\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnewsradioonline.com/music-news/2012/6/27/kellie-picklers-camp-confirms-split-with-sony-music-nashvill.html |title=Kellie Pickler's Camp Confirms Split with Sony Music Nashville \u2013 Music News \u2013 ABC News Radio |publisher=Abcnewsradioonline.com |date=June 27, 2012 |access-date=July 29, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120725130935/http://abcnewsradioonline.com/music-news/2012/6/27/kellie-picklers-camp-confirms-split-with-sony-music-nashvill.html#ixzz1z2A0NESc |archive-date=July 25, 2012 }}</ref>\nOn July 10, 2012, she sang \"[[God Bless America]]\" during the seventh inning stretch at the [[2012 Major League Baseball All-Star Game]].\nOn October 8, 2012, [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] reported Pickler had signed with the independent record label [[Black River Entertainment]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Kellie Pickler Signs to Black River Entertainment|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1695102/kellie-pickler-signs-to-black-river-entertainment.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011012319/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1695102/kellie-pickler-signs-to-black-river-entertainment.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 11, 2012|publisher=CMT|access-date=October 8, 2012}}</ref>\n\n===2013\u2013present: ''The Woman I Am''===\nPickler's first single with Black River Entertainment, \"[[Someone Somewhere Tonight]],\" was released on May 14, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/someone-somewhere-tonight/id643082388?i=643082517 |title=iTunes Music \u2013 Someone Somewhere Tonight \u2013 Single by Kellie Pickler |publisher=iTunes Store |date=May 14, 2013 |access-date=June 1, 2013}}</ref> After eight weeks, it reached a peak of number 49 on the ''Billboard'' Country Airplay chart in July 2013, and served as the lead-off single to Pickler's fourth album, ''[[The Woman I Am (Kellie Pickler album)|The Woman I Am]]'', which was released on November 11, 2013. Pickler wrote the title track with her husband, songwriter Kyle Jacobs.<ref name=\"Pickler Branches Out on New Album\">{{cite magazine|last=Gold|first=Adam|title=Kellie Pickler Branches Out on New Album 'The Woman I Am'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/kellie-pickler-branches-out-on-new-album-the-woman-i-am-20130913|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=September 13, 2013 |access-date=September 13, 2013}}</ref>\n\n\"[[Little Bit Gypsy]]\" and \"Closer to Nowhere\" were released as the album's second and third singles and reached peaks of number 50 and number 59 on the Country Airplay chart, respectively. A promotional single, \"Feeling Tonight,\" was made available as a digital download on June 2, 2015, but never received an official radio release. It was later announced in June 2016, that Pickler had parted ways with Black River.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/kellie-pickler-black-river-entertainment-split/|title=Kellie Pickler Parts Ways With Black River Entertainment|first=Sterling|last=Whitaker|website=Tasteofcountry.com|date=June 18, 2016 }}</ref>\n\nOn May 21, 2013, Pickler and [[Derek Hough]] were announced the winners of the [[Dancing with the Stars (American season 16)|sixteenth season]] of ''[[Dancing with the Stars (American TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]''. She performed a well received super sized freestyle, which scored a perfect 30 and garnered effusive praise from the dance judges.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dorothy Hamill and Andy Dick among 'Dancing' stars|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/tv/dorothy_hamill_and_andy_dick_among_art7dOspaAd3bBHI5z2ekN|work=New York Post|date=February 26, 2013 |access-date=February 26, 2013}}</ref> She performed \"Little Bit Gypsy\" on November 25, 2013, episode in the [[Dancing with the Stars (American season 17)|seventeenth season]].\n\nIn 2013, Pickler starred as Mirabelle in the fiftieth [[VeggieTales]] video, ''Beauty and the Beet'' released on October 14, 2014.{{Citation needed|date=May 2023}} In February 2022, Pickler began work as a DJ on [[SiriusXM]]'s country music station, ''The Highway.''<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.siriusxm.com/hosts/kellie-pickler#:~:text=Kellie%20Pickler%20on%20The%20Highway&text=56)%20Monday%20through%20Friday%20from,on%20the%20SXM%20App%20now | title=Platinum-selling country singer/Songwriter and actress, Kellie Pickler, is now a host on the Highway on SiriusXM! }}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nPickler's parents split up the day after her second birthday; a year later, in July 1989, her mother vanished. During periods when her father, Bo, was incarcerated, she would live with her grandparents outside Albemarle, {{convert|45|mi}} northeast of [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]]. In 1992, Pickler's mother returned to Albemarle, but rarely made contact with her. But in March 1995, with Bo Pickler in prison for armed robbery, her mother was granted custody. Pickler was in the fourth grade. In a February 2006 interview with the ''[[Charlotte Observer]]'', Pickler said: \"She got custody of me for two years... During that time, she was physically and mentally abusive of me.\" In a 1997 court filing, Pickler's grandparents said that her mother had moved to [[Union County, North Carolina|Union County]] with her and treated her harshly. The court restored custody to the grandparents. Her mother vanished again. Her father, whom she describes as an alcoholic and [[drug addict]], served a three-year-nine-month prison sentence at [[Florida State Prison]] for [[aggravated assault]] and [[battery (crime)|battery]] stemming from a 2003 stabbing incident.<ref>[http://www.charlotte.com/mld/charlotte/entertainment/television/13893587.htm 'American Idol's' Pickler: Singer and survivor], [[Charlotte Observer]], February 17, 2006. Retrieved July 5, 2006.</ref> <!-- dead reference :: [http://www.dc.state.fl.us/activeinmates/detail.asp?Bookmark=1&From=list&SessionID=431956515] --> He was released on May 6, 2006, a week after her elimination from ''Idol''. In an April 2006 interview with [[National Broadcasting Company|NBC]] Pickler said, \"One thing that's so important in life is we learn to forgive others. I ask the Lord every day to forgive me for my sins and for things that I've done wrong. And who am I to not forgive someone for what they've done?\" ...\"God tells us to love everyone.\"<ref>[http://www.wcnc.com/news/topstories/stories/wcnc-042806-kellie.7c42b036.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070305230245/http://www.wcnc.com/news/topstories/stories/wcnc-042806-kellie.7c42b036.html|date=March 5, 2007}}</ref>\n\nIn 2007, Pickler was in a relationship with [[Nashville Predators]] player [[Jordin Tootoo]] and visited his family in [[Nunavut]].<ref>{{cite news |title = Kellie Pickler's New Love |url = http://www.usmagazine.com/kellie_pickler_love |work=US Magazine |date=May 23, 2007 |access-date=June 27, 2007 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070525044028/http://usmagazine.com/kellie_pickler_love |archive-date = May 25, 2007}}</ref><ref name=Nunavut>[https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nunavut-hockey-star-introduces-american-idol-girlfriend-to-family-1.688351?ref=rss Nunavut hockey star introduces American Idol girlfriend to family]. CBC News. June 21, 2007.</ref> Later that year, the two broke up.<ref>Aarthun, Sarah. [http://www.wcnc.com/kelliepickler/stories/wcnc-100207-jmn-pickler_hockey-pickler_section.12ea85b87.html Kellie Pickler breaks it off with 'hockey guy'] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.today/20070617001912/http://www.wcnc.com/kelliepickler/stories/wcnc-100207-jmn-pickler_hockey-pickler_section.12ea85b87.html |date=June 17, 2007 }}. ''The Charlotte Observer''. WCNC-TV. October 2, 2007.</ref>\n\n[[File:25 Dec. 2016 CJCS USO Holiday Tour PT. 2 161225-D-PB383-061 (31061990464).jpg|200px|thumb|left|Pickler was married to songwriter [[Kyle Jacobs (songwriter)|Kyle Jacobs]] from 2011 until his suicide in 2023.]]\n\nAfter two and a half years of dating, Pickler became engaged to songwriter [[Kyle Jacobs (songwriter)|Kyle Jacobs]] on June 15, 2010.<ref>{{cite news |last=Derschowitz |first=Jessica |title=Kyle Jacobs and Kellie Picker are Engaged |newspaper= CBS News N.p. |date=June 23, 2010 |access-date= June 23, 2010 |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/kyle-jacobs-and-kellie-picker-are-engaged/}}</ref> For a background piece on ''Dancing with the Stars'', Pickler related that the couple had planned an elaborate ceremony, but as the date approached, \"I looked at him and said, 'Baby, this ain't us.'\"<ref name=\"MostMemorableYear\">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oEDrWWHLplA YouTube video of Kellie Pickler segment] of \"Most Memorable Year\" episode of ''Dancing with the Stars'' Season 16, aired April 8, 2013.</ref> On January 1, 2011, she and Jacobs eloped and married in a \"small, intimate ceremony on a private island in the Caribbean\".<ref>{{cite web |title=Kellie Pickler & Kyle Jacobs Have a Surprise Wedding |work= People |date=January 4, 2011 |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20454272,00.html }}</ref>\n\nIn 2015, it was announced that Pickler and Jacobs would star in a 13-episode reality show for CMT entitled ''I Love Kellie Pickler''. The show premiered on November 5, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kellie Pickler gets personal, but no drama on reality show|url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/entertainment/article42197973.html|website=The Charlotte Observer|access-date=November 3, 2015}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>\n\nOn February 17, 2023, Jacobs died by a self-inflicted gunshot wound in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] at the age of 49.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hume |first=Ashley |date=2023-02-17 |title=Kellie Pickler's husband Kyle Jacobs dead at 49 after apparent suicide: police |url=https://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/kellie-picklers-husband-kyle-jacobs-dead-apparent-suicide-police |access-date=2023-02-18 |website=Foxnews.com |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Shafer |first=Ellise |date=2023-02-18 |title=Kellie Pickler's Husband Kyle Jacobs Identified as Man Found Dead at Singer's House |url=https://variety.com/2023/music/news/kellie-pickler-house-man-dead-suicide-1235527221/ |access-date=2023-02-18 |website=Variety.com |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Kellie Pickler's Husband Kyle Jacobs Identified as Man Found Dead at Singer's House |url=https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/kellie-pickler-husband-kyle-jacobs-002751515.html |access-date=2023-02-18 |website=Yahoo.com |date=February 18, 2023 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Kellie Pickler's husband Kyle Jacobs dead by suicide in Nashville home |url=https://www.nydailynews.com/snyde/ny-kellie-pickler-husband-kyle-jacobs-dead-suicide-20230218-ejwptk475bbkhg5yghkwnx7oxy-story.html |access-date=2023-02-18 |website=New York Daily News|date=February 17, 2023 }}</ref>\n<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://people.com/kellie-pickler-breaks-silence-thanks-fans-after-husband-kyle-jacobs-death-suicide-exclusive-7644767|title=Kellie Pickler Breaks Silence, Thanks Fans After Husband Kyle Jacobs' Death: 'Darkest Time in My Life' (Exclusive)|website=People.com}}</ref>\n\n===Philanthropy===\n[[File:Kellie Pickler 2008-11-06 (2).jpg|thumb|left|upright|Pickler in [[Jacksonville, Florida]], November 6, 2008|alt=Pickler singing while holding a microphone]]\nPickler actively supports [[St. Jude Children's Research Hospital]], where she helps raise funds and gives kids special visits. She also participates in charitable events to help raise funds for various organizations. She has performed to help raise funds for the \"N.C. Children's PROMISE\" to benefit the Children's Hospital on November 12, 2006,<ref>{{cite web|title = RADIOTHON/TELETHON|url = http://ncchildrenspromise.org/radiothon.shtml|publisher = ncchildrenspromise.org|date = November 16, 2006|access-date = March 7, 2007|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070705080952/http://www.ncchildrenspromise.org/radiothon.shtml|archive-date = July 5, 2007}}</ref> to help refurbish the [[Hurricane Katrina]]-damaged NFL Youth Education Towns Boys & Girls Club of [[New Orleans]] on December 16, 2006,<ref>{{cite web|title = CMT, Cox Restock N.O. Kids' Haven|url = http://www.multichannel.com/article/CA6397326.html?display=Breaking+News|publisher = MultiChannel.com|date = December 5, 2006|access-date = March 7, 2007}}</ref> visited St. Jude Children's Research Hospital on January 12, 2007,<ref>{{cite web|title = St. Jude|url = http://kelliepickler.com/site.php?content=links|publisher = kelliepickler.com|date = March 1, 2007 |access-date = March 7, 2007 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070819111710/http://www.kelliepickler.com/site.php?content=links |archive-date = August 19, 2007}}</ref> and visited Pennington Elementary School on February 1, 2007.<ref>{{cite web|title = Kellie Pickler Adjusts to Spotlight|url = http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,,GAC_26063_5324115,00.html|archive-url = https://archive.today/20130123151657/http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,,GAC_26063_5324115,00.html|url-status = dead|archive-date = January 23, 2013|publisher = gactv.com|date = February 2, 2007|access-date = March 7, 2007}}</ref> \"When you're able to give back to your communities and organizations like St. Jude, it's a great thing,\" Pickler said. \"It's been a great experience, and I encourage anyone and everyone to help.\"<ref>{{cite web |title = Country stars visit St. Jude |url = http://www.stjude.org/countrycares/0,2710,618_3348_22427,00.html?rss=fundraising|publisher = stjude.org |date = January 12, 2007|access-date = March 7, 2007}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>\n\nPickler participated with other country artists in an online auction for charity by Mario Magro: Kiss for a Cause Foundation Celebrity Auction held June 15\u201325, 2007, in support of orphaned and abandoned children. The event auctioned off celebrity lip prints and signatures pressed on the inside of Mario Magro Crystal Le Coop handbags at the 42nd Annual Academy of Country Music Awards.<ref>{{cite web|title = Mario magro kiss for a cause foundation to hold online celebrity auction|url = http://www.kissforacause.org/press.html|publisher = Kissforacause.org|date = June 10, 2007|access-date = June 28, 2007|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070809064926/http://www.kissforacause.org/press.html|archive-date = August 9, 2007|url-status = dead}}</ref> In November 2007, Pickler appeared on a celebrity edition of the [[quiz show]] ''[[Are You Smarter than a 5th Grader? (American game show)|Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?]]'', playing for the charities of her choice, [[American Red Cross]] and the [[AARP]]'s Grandparenting Program.<ref>{{cite news|title = Kellie Appears on \"Are You Smarter Than A 5th Grader|url = http://www.kelliepickler.com/site.php?em2277=185249_-1__0_~0_-1_9_2008_0_0|publisher = KelliePickler.com|date = November 12, 2007|access-date = September 11, 2008}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cey35bBWXls| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111024175651/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cey35bBWXls&gl=US&hl=en| archive-date=2011-10-24 | url-status=dead|title=YouTube|via=YouTube}}</ref> During the show, she was asked to name the European country for which Budapest is the capital, to which she responded \"...I thought Europe ''was'' a country ...I know they speak French there. Is France a country?\"  She chose the copy cheat, allowing her to go along with the 3rd grader's correct response of Hungary.<ref>{{cite news|title = Dumbest Blonde Ever\n|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r8pnec4Hxps|via = YouTube|date = December 7, 2007|access-date = August 29, 2014}}</ref>\n\nPickler has participated in three tours on behalf of [[United Service Organizations]]. The first, in late 2007 and early 2008, took her to Iraq;<ref name=\"GACMyUSODiary\">{{cite video| people = Kellie Pickler| title = Kellie Pickler: My USO Diary| url = http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_az_kellie_pickler| medium = TV-Documentary Special| publisher = GACTV| location = Iraq|year = 2008| url-status = dead| archive-url = https://archive.today/20130123143310/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_az_kellie_pickler| archive-date = January 23, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title = Kellie Pickler to Perform on USO Tour|url = http://www.americanidol.com/news/view/?pid=1105|publisher = Dave|date = December 3, 2007|access-date = December 3, 2007}}</ref> the second, in December 2008, included stops in Germany, Afghanistan, Iraq, Kosovo, and England.<ref>[http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20248545,00.html Kellie Pickler's USO Tour] ''People'', December 22, 2008</ref> In January 2010, Pickler made stops in Iraq and Kuwait on a 10-day tour with Randy Houser and Jamey Johnson. The three country stars \"played remote bases on the front lines of the war zone, and the sound of gun fire became their frequent companion at night.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2010/02/04/randy-houser-puts-his-army-boots-on/ |title=Randy Houser puts his army boots on |publisher=Blog.gactv.com |date=February 4, 2010 |access-date=February 14, 2010 |archive-date=February 6, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100206070733/http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2010/02/04/randy-houser-puts-his-army-boots-on/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nIn early August 2009, Pickler participated in ABC's ''[[Extreme Makeover: Home Edition]]'''s rebuilding of James Terpenning's family home in [[Beavercreek, Ohio]]. Pickler performed a free concert at the home, and helped during reconstruction.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://projects.daytondailynews.com/cache/galleries/Entertainment/Music/2009extrememakeover_pickler/ |title=Dayton Daily News &#124; Kellie Pickler performs at 'Makeover' site |publisher=Projects.daytondailynews.com |date=August 5, 2009 |access-date=May 1, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091209172102/http://projects.daytondailynews.com/cache/galleries/Entertainment/Music/2009extrememakeover_pickler/ |archive-date=December 9, 2009 }}</ref>\n\nOn June 26, 2016, on an episode of ''[[Celebrity Family Feud]]'', Pickler and her team won $25,000 for her charity, [[USO]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Brelsford |first1=Erin |title=Kellie Pickler Nearly Took a Tumble on \"Family Feud\" |url=https://www.onecountry.com/country-music/kellie-pickler-family-feud/ |website=Onecountry.com |date=June 27, 2016 |access-date=January 17, 2020 |archive-date=November 29, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201129021218/https://www.onecountry.com/country-music/kellie-pickler-family-feud/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n{{Clear}}\n\n==''Dancing with the Stars'' performances==\n{|class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center\"\n|+Kellie Pickler performances on ''Dancing with the Stars''\n!scope=\"col\" please read [[WP:EL]] first -->\n{{S-start}}\n{{s-ach}}\n{{succession box | title=[[Dancing with the Stars (US TV series)|''Dancing with the Stars'' (US)]] winners | before=[[Melissa Rycroft]] & [[Tony Dovolani]]| years=Season 16<br>(Spring 2013 with [[Derek Hough]])|after= [[Amber Riley]] and [[Derek Hough]]}}\n{{S-end}}\n{{Kellie Pickler}}\n{{American Idol}}\n{{American Idol 5}}\n{{Dancing with the Stars (United States)}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Pickler, Kellie}}\n[[Category:1986 births]]\n[[Category:19 Recordings artists]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:Actresses from North Carolina]]\n[[Category:American beauty pageant winners]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American Idol participants]]\n[[Category:Beauty pageant contestants from North Carolina]]\n[[Category:Black River Entertainment artists]]\n[[Category:BNA Records artists]]\n[[Category:Columbia Records artists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from North Carolina]]\n[[Category:Dancing with the Stars (American TV series) winners]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Albemarle, North Carolina]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from North Carolina]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Dolly_Parton","to":"Dolly Parton"}],"pages":{"8716":{"pageid":8716,"ns":0,"title":"Dolly Parton","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country musician (born 1946)}}\n{{Use American English|date=August 2021}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2023}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name               = Dolly Parton\n| image              = Dolly Parton in 2022.jpg\n| caption            = Parton in 2022\n| birth_name         = Dolly Rebecca Parton\n| birth_date         = {{Birth date and age|1946|1|19}}\n| birth_place        = [[Pittman Center, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| spouse             = {{marriage|Carl Dean|May 30, 1966}}\n| relatives          = {{ubl|[[Bill Owens (songwriter)|Bill Owens]] (uncle)|[[Randy Parton]] (brother)|[[Stella Parton]] (sister)||[[Rachel Dennison|Rachel Parton George]] (sister)}}\n| occupation         = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|musician|actress|philanthropist|businesswoman}}\n| years_active       = 1955\u2013present\n| awards             = [[List of awards and nominations received by Dolly Parton|Full list]]\n| module             = {{Infobox musical artist | embed=yes\n| genre = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country pop]]|[[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]|[[Gospel music|gospel]]|[[Rock music|rock]]}} \n| instruments = {{hlist|Vocals}}\n| discography = {{hlist|[[Dolly Parton albums discography|Albums]]|[[Dolly Parton singles discography|singles]]}}\n| label = {{hlist|[[Goldband Records|Goldband]]|[[Mercury Records|Mercury]]|[[Monument Records|Monument]]|[[RCA Victor]]|[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]|[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]|[[Rising Tide Records|Rising Tide]]|[[Decca Records|Decca]]|[[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]]|Dolly<ref>[http://www.websterpr.com/dollyparton/1423-dolly-parton-to-release-new-album-blue-smoke-in-the-u-s-on-may-13-2014 \"Dolly Parton to release new album, ''Blue Smoke'', in the US on May 13, 2014\"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421064118/http://www.websterpr.com/dollyparton/1423-dolly-parton-to-release-new-album-blue-smoke-in-the-u-s-on-may-13-2014 |date=April 21, 2014 }}, websterpr.com; accessed May 10, 2014.</ref>|Butterfly}}\n}}\n| website            = {{URL|dollyparton.com}}\n| signature          = Dolly Parton Signature.png\n}}\n'''Dolly Rebecca Parton''' (born January 19, 1946) is an American singer-songwriter, actress, and philanthropist, known primarily for her decades-long career in [[country music]]. After achieving success as a songwriter for others, Parton made her album debut in 1967 with ''[[Hello, I'm Dolly]]'', which led to success during the remainder of the 1960s (both as a solo artist and with a series of duet albums with [[Porter Wagoner]]), before her sales and chart peak arrived during the 1970s and continued into the 1980s. Some of Parton's albums in the 1990s did not sell as well, but she achieved commercial success again in the new millennium and has released albums on various independent labels since 2000, including her own label, Dolly Records.\n\nWith a career spanning 60 years, Parton has been described as a \"country legend\" and has sold more than 100 million records worldwide, making her one of the [[List of best-selling music artists|best-selling music artists of all time]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Blistein |first=Jon |date=November 20, 2023 |title=Dolly Parton Updates Her Classic 'Jolene' for Her Rock & Roll Era |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/dolly-parton-bonus-songs-new-album-rockstar-1234886964/ |access-date=January 20, 2024 |magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Yahr |first=Emily |date=October 17, 2023 |title=Dolly Parton was told 'gaudy' clothes would hurt her career. She doubled down. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/style/fashion/2023/10/17/dolly-parton-rockstar-fashion/ |access-date=January 20, 2024 |newspaper=Washington Post |language=en |id=as much a part of her empire's origin story as her legendary singing (more than 100 million records sold; the first female country singer to sell 1 million copies of an album)}}</ref> Parton's music includes [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA)-certified gold, platinum and multi-platinum awards. She has had 25 [[single (music)|singles]] reach No.{{spaces}}1 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country music charts, a record for a female artist (tied with [[Reba McEntire]]). She has 44 career Top{{spaces}}10 country albums, a record for any artist, and she has 110 career-charted singles over the past 40 years. She has composed over 3,000 songs, including \"[[I Will Always Love You]]\" (a two-time U.S. country chart-topper, and an international hit for [[Whitney Houston]]), \"[[Jolene (song)|Jolene]]\", \"[[Coat of Many Colors (song)|Coat of Many Colors]]\", and \"[[9 to 5 (Dolly Parton song)|9{{spaces}}to{{spaces}}5]]\".
