This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Billy_Currington","to":"Billy Currington"}],"pages":{"2503565":{"pageid":2503565,"ns":0,"title":"Billy Currington","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country musician (born 1973)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Billy Currington\n| image           = Billy_Currington_2008.jpg\n| caption         = Currington in August 2008\n| birth_name      = William Matthew Currington\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1973|11|19}}\n| birth_place     = [[Savannah, Georgia]], U.S.\n| origin          = [[Rincon, Georgia]], U.S.\n| instrument      = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar\n}}\n| genre           = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[country pop]]\n* [[country rock]]\n}}\n| occupation      = {{flatlist|\n* Singer\n* songwriter\n}}\n| years_active    = 1996\u2013present\n| label           = [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Nashville]]<!-- PLEASE DO NOT ADD ADDITIONAL LABELS WITHOUT A RELIABLE SOURCE. AND DO NOT REMOVE THE NOTE! -->\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|billycurrington.com}}\n}}\n\n'''William Matthew Currington''' (born November 19, 1973) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. Signed to [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Records Nashville]] in 2003, he has released seven studio albums for the label: his [[Billy Currington (album)|self-titled debut]] (2003), ''[[Doin' Somethin' Right]]'' (2005), ''[[Little Bit of Everything]]'' (2008), ''[[Enjoy Yourself (Billy Currington album)|Enjoy Yourself]]'' (2010), ''[[We Are Tonight]]'' (2013), ''[[Summer Forever]]'' (2015), and ''Intuition'' (2021).\n\nThese six albums have produced 18 singles on the U.S. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] and [[Country Airplay]] charts, including 11 number one hits: \"[[Must Be Doin' Somethin' Right]]\", \"[[Good Directions]]\", \"[[People Are Crazy]]\", \"[[That's How Country Boys Roll]]\", \"[[Pretty Good at Drinkin' Beer]]\", \"[[Let Me Down Easy (Billy Currington song)|Let Me Down Easy]]\", \"[[Hey Girl (Billy Currington song)|Hey Girl]]\", \"[[We Are Tonight (song)|We Are Tonight]]\", \"[[Don't It]]\", \"[[It Don't Hurt Like It Used To]]\", and \"[[Do I Make You Wanna]]\". Currington has also charted as a duet partner on [[Shania Twain]]'s single \"[[Party for Two]]\", and his own non-album single \"Tangled Up\", for a total of 20 top 40 hits.\n\nSetting a new record in August 2017 with his number-one single \"[[Do I Make You Wanna]]\", Currington is the only country music artist in US ''Billboard'' Country Airplay chart history to have a song in the number one spot gain an audience of nearly 9,500,000 over another country music artist's song in the number two spot.<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/files/pdfs/country_update_0807.pdf |title=Archived copy |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2018-03-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180513172844/https://www.billboard.com/files/pdfs/country_update_0807.pdf |archive-date=2018-05-13 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n==Early life and career==\nBilly Currington was born in [[Savannah, Georgia]], raised in [[Rincon, Georgia]],<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1479717/billy-currington-walks-a-little-straighter-with-debut-hit.jhtml|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090527091342/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1479717/billy-currington-walks-a-little-straighter-with-debut-hit.jhtml|url-status= dead|archive-date= May 27, 2009|title= Billy Currington Walks a Little Straighter With Debut Hit|publisher=Country Music Television|access-date=September 4, 2012}}</ref> and currently lives in [[Savannah, Georgia]]. He has four sisters (Lexie, Ann, Kim, and Kellie) and two brothers (Charles and Jason).\n\nWhen he was a junior in [[Effingham County High School]] ([[Springfield, Georgia]]), Currington auditioned for a spot at [[Opryland USA|Opryland]], the renowned country music theme park located in Nashville. Failing the audition, after high school he moved to Nashville to pursue his career in country music.<ref name=\"easy\"/> His first stint did not last too long, and he later sang for a bar named Cavalier Country Club in [[Savannah, Georgia|Georgia]]. In Nashville, Currington also worked for a concrete company, and as a [[personal trainer]].{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}\n\nOne of the clients he worked with as a personal trainer led Currington to recording demo tapes, as well as writing songs. He eventually had cuts by [[George Strait]], [[Tracy Byrd]], and [[Marty Raybon]].<ref name=\"walks\">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1479717/billy-currington-walks-a-little-straighter-with-debut-hit.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090527091342/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1479717/billy-currington-walks-a-little-straighter-with-debut-hit.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 27, 2009|title=Billy Currington Walks a Little Straighter With Debut Hit|last=Morris|first=Edward|date=2003-10-13|work=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]]|access-date=2009-05-21}}</ref> After almost being offered to join [[RCA Records]], he signed to Mercury Records in 2003.\n\nCurrington founded the Global South Relief organization which delivers supplies to those in need in Central American countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.umgnashville.com/billycurrington/about|title=PROFILE: BILLY CURRINGTON|publisher=Universal Music Group|access-date=September 4, 2012}}</ref>\n\n==Musical career==\n[[File:BillyCurringtonApr10.jpg|thumb|left|Currington in April 2010]]\n\n===''Billy Currington'' (2003\u20132004)===\nCurrington's [[Billy Currington (album)|self-titled debut album]] was released in September 2003. The album's first single was \"[[Walk a Little Straighter]]\". This song is about his relationship with his alcoholic stepfather, including a chorus that Currington wrote when he was just 12 years old.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p561063/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Billy Currington biography|last=Leggett|first=Steve|work=[[AllMusic|Allmusic]]|access-date=2009-04-21}}</ref> \"Walk a Little Straighter\" went to No.8 that year on the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart. Also, it allowed Currington to become a major country performer in Nashville. The second single from the album, \"[[I Got a Feelin' (Billy Currington song)|I Got a Feelin,']] became the singer's first Top 5 on the US country charts, with a peak at No.5.\n\nHe scored a third consecutive top 10 hit with [[Shania Twain]] in late 2004 with the song \"[[Party for Two]]\". The song was from Twain's ''[[Greatest Hits (Shania Twain album)|Greatest Hits]]'' album and was released in two formats: a pop version with [[Mark McGrath]] as Twain's duet partner, and the country version, which featured Currington.\n\n===''Doin' Somethin' Right'' (2005\u20132007)===\nIn 2005, Currington released his second studio album ''[[Doin' Somethin' Right]]'',<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> which peaked at No.2 on the Top Country Albums chart and at No.11 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. This album produced his first number one hit with \"[[Must Be Doin' Somethin' Right]]\", followed by \"[[Why, Why, Why]]\" at No.13 and another number one hit with \"[[Good Directions]]\". Co-written by [[Capitol Records]] artist [[Luke Bryan]], \"Good Directions\" was the No.2 country song of 2007 according to the [[Billboard Year-End|''Billboard'' Year-End]] charts. ''Doin' Somethin' Right'' was certified [[Music recording certification|platinum]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]. The album also featured \"[[Lucille (Kenny Rogers song)|Lucille]]\", a song that Currington covered from original artist [[Kenny Rogers]].\n\n===''Little Bit of Everything'' (2007\u20132009)===\nOn July 19, 2007, Currington announced that he would cancel the rest of his tour dates for the year because of [[laryngitis]]. His 2007 single, \"Tangled Up\", peaked at No.30 in late 2007, and the release of his third studio album was delayed.<ref name=\"easy\">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1597135/billy-currington-takes-it-easy-with-new-album.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018181158/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1597135/billy-currington-takes-it-easy-with-new-album.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 18, 2008|title=Billy Currington Takes It Easy With New Album|last=Shelburne|first=Craig|date=2008-10-15|work=CMT|access-date=2009-05-21}}</ref>\n\nHe was absent from the charts for nearly a year before the release of his next single, \"[[Don't (Billy Currington song)|Don't]]\", in mid-2008. That song was the first single from his third studio album, which was entitled ''[[Little Bit of Everything]]''. The album was released on October 14. Currington co-wrote five of the songs on it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1593643/billy-curringtons-new-album-arrives-oct-14.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080831160920/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1593643/billy-curringtons-new-album-arrives-oct-14.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=August 31, 2008|title=Billy Currington's New Album Arrives Oct. 14|date=2008-08-27|work=CMT|access-date=2009-05-21}}</ref> \"Don't\" peaked at No.2 on the country charts in early 2009. \"[[People Are Crazy]]\", co-written by [[Bobby Braddock]] and Troy Jones, was released as the second single from the album in March 2009 and became his third number one hit in July 2009. The third single, \"[[That's How Country Boys Roll]]\", became his fourth number one hit in March 2010. The song was the first that Currington shared writing credit on to reach number one.\n\nOn August 1, 2009, Currington suffered a [[concussion]] at the Big Valley Jamboree in [[Camrose, Alberta]] after the stage on which he was performing collapsed during a massive wind storm that also injured the singer's [[bass guitar]]ist and killed a spectator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1617493/billy-currington-and-band-back-in-nashville-following-tragedy-at-canadian-festival.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806061709/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1617493/billy-currington-and-band-back-in-nashville-following-tragedy-at-canadian-festival.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=August 6, 2009|title=Billy Currington and Band Back in Nashville Following Tragedy at Canadian Festival|date=2009-08-03|work=CMT|access-date=2009-08-03}}</ref>\n\n===''Enjoy Yourself'' (2010\u20132012)===\nIn May 2010, Currington released his tenth single overall, \"[[Pretty Good at Drinkin' Beer]]\". That song hit No.1 in September. Also written by Troy Jones, it was the first single from his fourth studio album ''[[Enjoy Yourself (Billy Currington album)|Enjoy Yourself]]'', which was released on September 21, 2010. The album's second single \"[[Let Me Down Easy (Billy Currington song)|Let Me Down Easy]]\" was released on October 4, 2010, and reached No.1 in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=billy currington|chart=Country Songs}} |title=Top Country Songs & Charts, Country Music Hits & Popular Country Music Charts |publisher=Billboard.com |access-date=2012-03-26}}</ref> The third single \"[[Love Done Gone]]\", released to country radio on April 18, 2011, and reached No.11 later that year. Its fourth single \"[[Like My Dog]]\" released to country radio on October 10, 2011, and peaked at No.24 in 2012.\n\n===''We Are Tonight'' (2013\u20132014)===\nCurrington's fifth studio album, ''[[We Are Tonight]]'', was released on September 17, 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last=Skates|first=Sarah|title=Billy Currington Preps First Album in Three Years|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2013/06/billy-currington-preps-first-album-in-three-years/|access-date=June 11, 2013|newspaper=[[MusicRow]]|date=June 10, 2013}}</ref> The album's first single, \"[[Hey Girl (Billy Currington song)|Hey Girl]]\", was released in March 2013. It peaked at number one on the [[Country Airplay]] chart in October of that year. The album's second single, [[We Are Tonight (song)|the title track]], was released on November 18, 2013. It also peaked at No.1 on the Country Airplay chart, this time in August 2014.\n\n===''Summer Forever'' (2014\u20132017)===\nCurrington released a new single, the first from his sixth studio album, in late October 2014, titled \"[[Don't It]]\".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://tasteofcountry.com/billy-currington-dont-it/ | title=Billy Currington, 'Don't It' [Listen] | publisher=Taste of Country | date=October 28, 2014 | access-date=November 4, 2014}}</ref> The album, ''[[Summer Forever]]'', was released on June 2, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nicholson|first1=Jessica|title=Billy Currington To Release 'Summer Forever' in June|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2015/04/billy-currington-to-release-summer-forever-in-june/|access-date=April 22, 2015|work=[[MusicRow]]|date=April 22, 2015}}</ref> The album's second single, \"[[Drinkin' Town with a Football Problem]]\", was released on June 8, 2015. \"[[It Don't Hurt Like It Used To]]\" was released on February 8, 2016, as the album's third single. It reached number one on Country Airplay in October 2016, remaining in that spot for two consecutive weeks. The album's fourth single, \"[[Do I Make You Wanna]]\", was released on November 21, 2016. The song reached number one on the Country Airplay chart in August 2017 and stayed there for three consecutive weeks, making it Currington's third number-one single from this album. \"Wake Me Up\", the album's fifth and final single, was released in September 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/billy-currington-wake-me-up/|title=Billy Currington Fights with Insomnia-Inducing Heartbreak in 'Wake Me Up'|website=Soundslikenashville.com|date=August 29, 2017}}</ref>\n\n===''Intuition'' (2018\u2013present)===\n\"Bring It On Over\" was released to country radio on September 24, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases|title=Future Releases for Country Radio Stations &#124; New Music Artist Free Song|website=Allaccess.com}}</ref> It debuted and peaked at No.29 on the ''Billboard'' Country Airplay charts. \"Details\" was released in 2019 and was also a minor top 40 hit on the same chart. The Stay Up 'Til the Sun Tour began on October 4, 2019, in Arizona and included nine concerts in total. He ended the tour in Florida.\n\nCurrington's seventh studio album, ''Intuition'', was released on August 6, 2021. Currington co-wrote the album with producer [[Rob Persaud]].<ref name=\"rollingstone-intuition\"/> It was a surprise release, in that it was not announced with advance warning and no new singles were released prior to the album to promote it, nor did it include either of his previous standalone singles.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/billy-currington-surprise-album-intuition/|title=Billy Currington Surprises Fans with a New Album, 'Intuition'|author=Carena Liptak|date=August 10, 2021|publisher=Taste of Country|access-date=August 15, 2021}}</ref> ''Intuition'' serves as a musical departure from his previous work as it was not marketed as a country album and instead drew inspirations from \"synth pop, Eighties R&B, and tropical house\".<ref name=\"rollingstone-intuition\">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/billy-currington-new-album-intuition-1208581/|title=Billy Currington Leans into Dance and Prince Funk on Surprise New Album 'Intuition'|author=Jon Freeman|date=August 6, 2021|publisher=Rolling Stone|access-date=August 15, 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nOn April 24, 2013, the [[Chatham County, Georgia]], Grand Jury indicted Currington on felony criminal charges of \"abuse of an elder person by inflicting mental anguish\" and \"making terroristic threats\". Both criminal charges stemmed from an incident involving boat captain Charles Harvey Ferrelle on April 15, 2013. The indictment alleged that Currington had made terrorist threats to Ferrelle. Currington was later released from a Georgia jail after posting $27,700 bond. Had he been convicted, Currington would have faced a prison term of 1 to 5 years. Also, on April 26, 2013, as a result of negative press surrounding the indictment incident, the [[Charlotte Motor Speedway]] replaced Currington as a performer for its All Star pre-race entertainment.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/sports/2013/04/26/charlotte-motor-speedway-replaces-billy-currington-as-all-star-race-pre-race|work=Fox News|title=Charlotte Motor Speedway replaces Billy Currington as All-Star race pre-race entertainment|date=April 26, 2013}}</ref> He entered a \"not guilty\" plea in August 2013.<ref>[http://tasteofcountry.com/billy-currington-terroristic-threats-trial Testimony from Currington's trial for \"making terroristic threats\"], tasteofcountry.com; accessed September 6, 2015.</ref>\n\nOn September 25, 2013, Currington pleaded [[Nolo contendere|no contest]] to the abuse charge; the terroristic threats charge was dropped. Currington was sentenced to five years probation, a $1,000 fine, and [[anger management]] counseling; he was also required to have no contact with the boat captain.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=foxnews.com|title=Billy Currington pleads no contest in threats case|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2013/09/27/billy-currington-pleads-no-contest-in-threats-case|date=September 27, 2013}}</ref>\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Rider Tour with [[Tim McGraw]] (2015)\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{Official website}}\n*[http://www.umgnashville.com/our-artists/billy-currington/ Official Billy Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Shires_(duo)","to":"The Shires (duo)"}],"pages":{"40880425":{"pageid":40880425,"ns":0,"title":"The Shires (duo)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|British country music duo}}\n{{BLP primary sources|date=May 2020}}\n{{EngvarB|date=January 2018}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = The Shires\n| image           = The Shires, Towersey 2018.jpg\n| caption         = Performing at [[Towersey Festival]], 2018\n| landscape       = true\n| origin          = [[Hertfordshire]] and [[Bedfordshire]], England, UK\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[country pop]]\n| label           = [[Decca Records|Decca]], [[Universal Music Group Nashville]], [[Dot Records|Dot]], [[BMG Rights Management]]\n| years_active    = 2013\u2013present\n| website         = {{url|https://www.theshiresmusic.com/}}\n| current_members = Ben Earle<br />Crissie Rhodes\n}}\n\n'''The Shires''' are a British [[country music]] duo composed of singer-songwriters Ben Earle and Crissie Rhodes. Earle sings harmony vocals, plays piano and guitar, and Rhodes is lead singer. The duo formed in 2013 and released their debut album ''[[Brave (The Shires album)|Brave]]'' in 2015, becoming the first UK country act to chart in the Top 10 of the [[UK Albums Chart]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicweek.com/news/read/the-shires-become-first-uk-country-act-to-reach-albums-chart-top-10/061094|title=The Shires become first UK country act to reach Albums Chart Top 10|last=Stassen|first=Murray|date=9 March 2015|work=[[Music Week]]|accessdate=9 March 2015|archive-date=21 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150421034712/http://www.musicweek.com/news/read/the-shires-become-first-uk-country-act-to-reach-albums-chart-top-10/061094|url-status=live}}</ref> The group's second album, ''[[My Universe (album)|My Universe]]'', became the fastest-selling UK country album in history when it was released in October 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Shires sign US record deal with man who discovered Taylor Swift|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-37797669|website=Bbc.co.uk|date=28 October 2016|access-date=21 June 2018|archive-date=20 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180820193659/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-37797669|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nThey hail from the neighbouring counties of [[Hertfordshire]] and [[Bedfordshire]] in England. \"[[Shire]]\" is the original term for what is usually known as a county in the United Kingdom. The duo took the band name to maintain a British identity and take a small part of Britain to the United States. After playing hardly half a dozen shows together, The Shires caught the attention of [[Decca Records]], who signed them in the United Kingdom, and they secured a contract with American record label [[Universal Music Group Nashville]], thus becoming the first English country act to be signed to a major Nashville label.<ref name=\"The Sunday Times Article\">[http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/culture/music/article1405270.ece The Sunday Times: That British twang, Country is being reborn in Bedford, not Nashville] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140513064640/http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/culture/music/article1405270.ece |date=13 May 2014 }}. ''[[The Sunday Times]]'', Retrieved 12 May 2014, published by Paul Sexton, 4 May 2014</ref><ref name=\"Sounds Like Nashville\">[http://www.soundslikenashville.com/artist/the-shires/ Sounds Like Nashville Artist Profile Page] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140513042522/http://www.soundslikenashville.com/artist/shires/ |date=13 May 2014 }} Retrieved on 12 May 2014</ref><ref name=\"Bob Harris Session\">[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01ydp16/ Bob Harris BBC Radio 2 Live Session] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528152030/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01ydp16 |date=28 May 2014 }}. Bbc.co.uk, Retrieved 12 May 2014</ref> They were also the first UK country act to have a top ten album and the first to receive an award from the American [[Country Music Association Awards|Country Music Association]].\n\nEarle and Rhodes were awarded Honorary Doctorates of the Arts by the University of Bedfordshire for their services and contributions to music on 25 July 2019.\n\n==Career==\n===2012\u20132013: Early beginnings===\nCrissie Rhodes has performed at weddings, [[pubs]] and clubs performing songs by [[Dolly Parton]] amongst others. After joining ''[[The X Factor (UK TV series)|The X Factor]]'' in [[The X Factor (UK series 10)|2013]], she was tipped as a winner but failed to qualify out of the early rounds. Her country music influences include [[Alison Krauss]], [[Martina McBride]] and [[Faith Hill]]. Ben Earle was previously a solo artist and had supported [[KT Tunstall]] on tour. Also a failed ''The X Factor'' contestant, and a struggling songwriter who had been writing for 10 years, he had tried to get cuts for other artists. He discovered country music in 2012 via [[Lady Antebellum]], the American Grammy Award-winning group. He cites the [[Kacey Musgraves]] album ''[[Same Trailer Different Park]]'' as a major career inspiration.<ref name=\"Bob Harris Session\" /> Earle and Rhodes met after Ben, with an aim to become part of a duo, posted a \"There must be a country singer somewhere\" message on the social media website Facebook, seeking a partner, to which Rhodes responded.<ref name=\"The Sunday Times Article\" /><ref name=\"Sounds Like Nashville\" />\n\nAs part of [[BBC Radio 2]]'s coverage of a festival, the Shires were included as a segment in a documentary titled \"''Nashville UK''\", which assessed country music's standing in the UK and, as one of its promising artists, their determination to export their British country roots to their American counterparts.<ref name=\"Nashville UK\">[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03y0ljc/ Nashville UK presented by Paul Sexton; first broadcast: Thursday 20 March 2014] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324024209/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03y0ljc |date=24 March 2014 }}. Bbc.co.uk, Retrieved 12 May 2014</ref> The Shires have composed songs with hit Nashville songwriter Steve Mcewan (Keith Urban, Tim McGraw, Carrie Underwood) and Play Productions an accomplished Swedish writing and production company, who comprise Tim Larsson, Johan Fransson and Tobias Lundgren, who have worked with [[Rascal Flatts]] and [[Celine Dion]].<ref name=\"Sounds Like Nashville\" /><ref name=\"Play Productions\">[http://www.playproduction.se/ Play Productions Homepage] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421115208/http://www.playproduction.se/ |date=21 April 2014 }}. Playproductions.se, Retrieved 12 May 2014</ref>\n\n===2014\u20132015: ''Brave''===\nThey were invited to the [[C2C: Country to Country]] 2014 Festival and performed at The Town Square Pop Stage on 16 March 2014 outside the [[London O2 arena]].<ref name=\"C2C Festival\">[http://www.c2c-countrytocountry.com/line-up/pop-up-stages/the-shires/ C2C: Country to Country 2014 Festival Profile Page] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140513092004/http://www.c2c-countrytocountry.com/line-up/pop-up-stages/the-shires/ |date=13 May 2014 }}. C2c-countrytocountry.com, Retrieved 2014-05-12, published March 2014</ref> Their first single \"Nashville Grey Skies\" was released on 4 April 2014 and received its first airplay on the [[Bob Harris (radio)|Bob Harris]] BBC Radio 2 Country show on 3 April 2014. It was added to the BBC Radio 2 \"B\" Playlist for the week commencing 3 May 2014 and climbed to the \"A\" playlist the following week.<ref name=\"BBC Radio 2 Playlist\">[http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio2/playlist/ BBC Radio 2 Playlist] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140428161716/http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio2/playlist |date=28 April 2014 }}. Bbc.co.uk, Retrieved 2014-05-12, published 9 May 2014</ref><ref name=\"Twitter Status\">[https://twitter.com/theshiresuk/status/461591077255147520/ The Shires Twitter Comment] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140513172656/https://twitter.com/theshiresuk/status/461591077255147520/ |date=13 May 2014 }}. Twitter.com, Retrieved 12 May 2014, published 30 April 2014</ref><ref name=\"BBC Radio 2 Artist Page\">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/artists/7a98818a-28d2-4856-a183-1df6f0984c21/ BBC Radio 2 Artist Profile Page] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201160513/https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/artists/7a98818a-28d2-4856-a183-1df6f0984c21 |date=1 February 2018 }}. Bbc.co.uk, Retrieved 12 May 2014</ref> The song was written by Earle before visiting [[Music City USA|Music City]] which is a song about hope with a pipe dream of building, and the UK having, a country music capital of its very own.<ref name=\"Allmusic\">[http://www.allmusic.com/album/nashville-grey-skies-mw0002644298/credits/ Allmusic Artist Credits] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211002172017/https://www.allmusic.com/search/albums/nashville+grey+skies |date=2 October 2021 }}. [[AllMusic]], Retrieved 12 May 2014</ref> It takes the musicality influences from America whilst maintaining a Britishness with the song writing. It contains [[facetious]] lines such as \"Well they say it's way too cold for cut-off jeans and they won't be drinking [[moonshine]] but [[Gin and tonic|G & T's]]\" and \"We can build our own Nashville under these grey skies\".\n\nOn 21 April 2014 they travelled to Sweden and then headed to Nashville to begin preparations and record their debut album. The duo toured the UK with [[Ward Thomas (band)|Ward Thomas]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chriscountry.co.uk/the-shires-and-ward-thomas-to-co-headline-a-tour-in-november/ |title=The Shires and Ward Thomas-Tour Dates|website=Chris Country-The UK's Country Station|access-date=7 February 2016|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402184657/http://www.chriscountry.co.uk/the-shires-and-ward-thomas-to-co-headline-a-tour-in-november/|archive-date=2 April 2015}}</ref> and [[Little Big Town]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theshiresmusic.com/the-shires-go-on-tour-with-little-big-town/|title=The Shires|website=Theshiresmusic.com|access-date=13 March 2015|archive-date=24 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224213309/http://theshiresmusic.com/the-shires-go-on-tour-with-little-big-town/|url-status=live}}</ref> prior to their own headlining tour in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theshiresmusic.com/announcing-the-2015-uk-tour/|title=The Shires|website=Theshiresmusic.com|access-date=13 March 2015|archive-date=2 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402111622/http://www.theshiresmusic.com/announcing-the-2015-uk-tour/|url-status=live}}</ref> In March 2015 the duo returned to play C2C and also released their debut studio album ''[[Brave (The Shires album)|Brave]]'' on 2 March 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theshiresmusic.com/music/|title=Music \u2013 The Shires|website=Theshiresmusic.com|access-date=21 September 2016|archive-date=15 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315205225/http://www.theshiresmusic.com/music/|url-status=live}}</ref> The album peaked at number 10 on the [[UK Albums Chart]], making The Shires the first UK country act to have an album in the top 10. In March 2016, as the most successful country music act the UK has ever had, they were invited to C2C as \"ambassadors\", introducing the acts on the pop-up stages throughout the weekend in London, playing their own sets and appearing in the arena to introduce acts performing on the Yamaha Music Stage. The Shires opened for [[The Corrs]] on their comeback tour in 2016 including shows at Birmingham's Genting Arena, Cardiff's Motorpoint Arena, Liverpool's Echo Arena, The O2 Arena London, Manchester Arena, Glasgow's SSE Hydro, Dublin's 3Arena and the SSE Arena Belfast between 19 and 29 January.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stereoboard.com/content/view/193879/9|title=The Shires To Open for the Corrs on Comeback Tour|website=Stereoboard.com|first=Huw|last=Baines|access-date=1 February 2016|archive-date=8 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108160908/http://www.stereoboard.com/content/view/193879/9|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\n===2016\u20132017: ''My Universe''===\nIn July 2016, The Shires announced their second studio album ''[[My Universe (album)|My Universe]]'' would be released on 30 September 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theshiresmusic.com/|title=The Shires &#124; Official Website &#124; Good Years Out Now|website=Theshiresmusic.com|access-date=16 May 2020|archive-date=13 May 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200513125559/https://www.theshiresmusic.com/|url-status=live}}</ref> They released \"Beats to Your Rhythm\" on 29 July as the first single from the album. The second single from the album was \"My Universe\" and was released on 16 September 2016; it charted at 89 in Scotland. Online music news site, Get to the Front, reviewed the album and stated that \"musically, lyrically and vocally there is little else you could ask for in a country album.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gettothefront.co.uk/review-shires-brave/|title=Review: The Shires \u2013 'My Universe' \u2013 GetToTheFront|date=26 August 2016|access-date=23 May 2018|archive-date=23 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180523173814/https://www.gettothefront.co.uk/review-shires-brave/|url-status=live}}</ref> ''My Universe'' debuted at number 3 on the [[UK Albums Chart]] and became the fastest selling UK country album of all time.\n\nIn October 2016, The Shires secured a recording contract with American label [[Big Machine Label Group]] and its imprint [[Dot Records]]. The Shires said : \"We are absolutely thrilled to sign with Dot Records in the USA. The UK is our home and we are proud of our success so far, thanks to [[Decca Records]], but it's always been a massive goal for us to build our presence and make a name for ourselves in the USA.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicweek.com/labels/read/the-shires-make-uk-country-history-with-big-machine-record-deal/066376|title=The Shires make UK country history with Big Machine record deal|website=Musicweek.com|access-date=30 October 2016|archive-date=31 October 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161031024912/http://www.musicweek.com/labels/read/the-shires-make-uk-country-history-with-big-machine-record-deal/066376|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nIn 2017 their new single \"Daddy's Little Girl\" was released, joining BBC Radio 2's playlist. It is about Rhodes's late father; the video features footage of her and her dad.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/|title=Official Charts - Home of the Official UK Top 40 Charts|website=Officialcharts.com|access-date=19 March 2015|archive-date=23 March 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323093517/http://www.officialcharts.com/|url-status=live}}</ref> On 9 March 2017, The Shires were presented with their first [[CMA Awards|CMA Award]] by [[Kristian Bush]] during the songwriters event at the [[C2C: Country to Country]] festival.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=CountryMusic|author=CMA Country Music|number=840286404521426944|date=10 March 2017|title=Country Music duo @TheShiresUK were surprised with their first CMA \ud83c\udfc6 at the #CMAsongwriters Series show in London!|website=Twitter.com}}</ref>\n\n===2018\u20132020: ''Accidentally on Purpose''===\nOn 26 January 2018, The Shires announced their third studio album ''Accidentally on Purpose'' would be released on 20 April 2018 alongside a UK tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/theshiresuk/status/956834688462704641|title=The Shires on Twitter|website=Twitter.com|access-date=10 April 2018|archive-date=2 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211002172227/https://twitter.com/theshiresuk/status/956834688462704641|url-status=live}}</ref> On 8 March 2018, the first single from the album \"Guilty\" premiered on [[BBC Radio 2]] before being released that day.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/theshiresuk/status/971660526102155264|title=The Shires on Twitter|website=Twitter.com|access-date=10 April 2018|archive-date=2 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211002172149/https://twitter.com/theshiresuk/status/971660526102155264|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nThe second single \"Accidentally on Purpose\" was released on 9 June 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/theshiresuk/status/982182711216373761|title=The Shires on Twitter|website=Twitter.com|access-date=10 April 2018|archive-date=2 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211002172150/https://twitter.com/theshiresuk/status/982182711216373761|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nThe third single \"Echo\" was released on 13 July 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://yourlifeinasong.com/the-shires-announce-new-single-echo|title=The Shires New Single Echo|website=Yourlifeinasong.com|date=25 June 2018 |access-date=8 December 2018|archive-date=9 December 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181209124308/https://yourlifeinasong.com/the-shires-announce-new-single-echo|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nIn 2019, Earle and Rhodes were awarded Honorary Doctorates of the Arts by the University of Bedfordshire for their services to the Arts.\n\nIn March 2020, The Shires were announced to be playing the main stage at the [[C2C: Country to Country]] festival, replacing [[Old Dominion (band)|Old Dominion]] who withdrew due to concerns over the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], making The Shires the first UK country act to perform a set on the main stage.\n\nMarch 2020 saw the release of a compilation album called Greatest Hits which  saw the end of their record deal with their record label Decca. The album featured highlights from all three studio albums to that point  as well as many of the bands singles. However, chart wise it failed to equal the success of their other albums only reaching NO52.\n\nThe duo also released in March 2020 a new album for their new label BMG entitled Good Years. A single \"This Independence Day\" was included. This album also saw the group return to the top five of both the Country and National charts which they had also achieved with their previous two studio albums.\n\n<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://c2c-countrytocountry.com/news/2020/the-shires-announced-to-replace-old-dominion-at-c2c-2020/|title=THE SHIRES ANNOUNCED TO REPLACE OLD DOMINION\u2026|date=2020-03-12|website=C2c-countrytocountry.com|language=en|access-date=2020-03-16|archive-date=14 August 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210814103208/https://c2c-countrytocountry.com/news/2020/the-shires-announced-to-replace-old-dominion-at-c2c-2020/|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\n===2021\u2013present: ''10 Year Plan''===\n\nIn January 2022, The Shires announced their lead single from their upcoming fifth album, '10 Year Plan' would be titled 'I See Stars'. The band appeared on the Radio 2 breakfast show with Zoe Ball for the single's debut on 26 January, and followed it with the release date for their new album on March 11, 2022.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.instagram.com/p/CZKXg40LINc/ | title=Instagram }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.instagram.com/p/CZMv9vdKPl1/ | title=Instagram }}</ref>'I See Stars' was BBC Radio 2's record of the week in February 2022.<ref>https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=501779127975784&id=100044311035489&refid=17&_ft_=mf_story_key.501779127975784%3Atop_level_post_id.501779127975784%3Atl_objid.501779127975784%3Acontent_owner_id_new.100044311035489%3Athrowback_story_fbid.501779127975784%3Apage_id.580897285277056%3Astory_location.4%3Astory_attachment_style.video_inline%3Aott.AX8Ym71umzot3a_7%3Atds_flgs.3%3Athid.100044311035489%3A306061129499414%3A2%3A0%3A1646121599%3A-3165699792943917578%3A%3A&__tn__=%2AW-R {{User-generated source|certain=yes|date=March 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" \u2014\n| ''Livin' the Dream''\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year\n! Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2017\n| \"Daddy's Little Girl\"\n| [[Shaun Silva]]\n|-\n|}\n\n== Tours ==\n'''Headline Tour'''\n\n* [[UK Tour 2015]] (2015)\n* [[My Universe Tour]] (2016/17)\n* [[Accidentally on Purpose Tour]] (2018)\n\n'''Supporting'''\n\n* [[Pain Killer Tour]] ([[Little Big Town]]) (UK) (2015)\n* White Light Tour ([[The Corrs]]) (UK and Ireland) (2016)\n* Alone in the Universe tour ([[Electric Light Orchestra]]) (UK: Wembley Stadium and KCOM Stadium only) (2017)<ref>{{cite web|title=Tom Chaplin and the Shires To Support Jeff Lynne's ELO on UK Dates|url=https://www.stereoboard.com/content/view/206188/9|website=Stereoboard.com|access-date=17 August 2021|archive-date=17 August 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210817210439/https://www.stereoboard.com/content/view/206188/9|url-status=live}}</ref>\n* [[Now Tour (Shania Twain)|Now Tour]] ([[Shania Twain]]) (UK and Ireland) (2018)\n* [[Cry Pretty Tour 360]] ([[Carrie Underwood]]) (UK) (2019)\n* The Tipping Point World Tour ([[Tears For Fears]]) (2022)\n* Surrounded by Time Tour ([[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]]) (2022)\n\n==Live radio appearances==\nThe Shires made their national radio debut on 1 May 2014 with a recorded live session with [[Bob Harris (radio)|Bob Harris]] OBE on BBC Radio 2. They performed 2 songs \"Brave\" and \"Only Midnight\".<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03zdgq1   Bob Harris Country BBC Radio 2 playlist] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140410230949/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03zdgq1 |date=10 April 2014 }}. Retrieved 2014-05-12, published 3 April 2014</ref>\n\nBen Earle presents a show on the country music radio station [[Absolute Radio Country]] every Sunday from 9&nbsp;am to 12&nbsp;pm.<ref>{{cite web |title=About Ben Earle |url=https://planetradio.co.uk/absolute-radio-country/presenters/ben-earle/ |website=planetradio.co.uk |access-date=12 May 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230512040928/https://planetradio.co.uk/absolute-radio-country/presenters/ben-earle/ |archive-date=12 May 2023 |language=en |url-status=live}}</ref>\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[https://www.theshiresmusic.com/ Official website]\n*{{AllMusic | id= the-shires-mn0003241391| label= The Shires}}\n\n{{The Shires}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Shires (duo), The}}\n[[Category:Country music duos]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2013]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:English musical duos]]\n[[Category:English country music groups]]\n[[Category:Decca Records artists]]\n[[Category:Universal Music Group artists]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:2013 establishments in England]]\n[[Category:Male\u2013female musical duos]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Scooter_Lee","to":"Scooter Lee"}],"pages":{"46317971":{"pageid":46317971,"ns":0,"title":"Scooter Lee","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2015}}{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Scooter Lee\n| image        =\n| caption      =\n| birth_name   = Scooter Lee\n| birth_date   = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1957|3|10}}\n| birth_place  = [[New Orleans, Louisiana]], U.S.\n| genre        = {{flat list|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[country pop]]\n* [[Gospel music|gospel]]\n}}\n| occupation   = {{flat list|\n* Singer-songwriter\n* record producer\n* philanthropist\n}}\n| years_active = 1971\u2013present\n| label        = {{flat list|\n* [[Universal Music Group|Universal]]\n* [[Sony Music Entertainment|Sony Music]]\n* [[Bill Lowery (record producer)|Lowery Music]]\n* Scootway\n* Superline\n}}\n| website      = {{URL|https://www.scooterlee.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Scooter Lee''' (born March 10, 1957) is an American singer-songwriter & line dance entertainer. Raised on St. Charles Avenue in [[New Orleans, Louisiana]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Scooter Lee loves giving line dance instructions to senior citizens|url=https://linedanceinstructions2.wordpress.com/|website=Line Dance Instructions|accessdate=4 April 2015|date=August 22, 2009}}</ref> her career started at age 14 when she was signed to [[Allen Toussaint|Allen Toussaint's]] record label in New Orleans, recording with [[Irma Thomas]], [[Jerry Lee Lewis]] and [[Fats Domino]]. There, she was labeled as 'the little lady with the big voice'; recording country blues for the label. She soon settled in on recording country music with a blues overtone.\n\nDuring the 1970s, Scooter Lee toured alongside major artists, including [[Linda Ronstadt]], [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[Tammy Wynette]] and [[Johnny Cash|Johnny]] & [[June Carter Cash]]. In the 1980s, Scooter Lee gained ground with her 5 piece band sponsored by the [[RJ Reynolds Tobacco Company]], working 10 months a year at every major state fair and other regional festivals. Performing 2-3 shows daily, 300 dates a year, taught her the art of fully commanding a stage. Spotted in Los Angeles in 1985, Scooter Lee was invited to join the [[Bob Hope]] [[United Service Organizations|USO Tours]] and gained experience on stages in war-torn countries.\n\nScooter Lee grabbed the attention of the country music dance community during the early 1990s when she was signed to [[Sony Records]] to follow in the footsteps of [[Billy Ray Cyrus]], [[Brooks & Dunn]], [[Tracy Byrd]] and [[Reba McEntire]] just as the '[[line dance]]' phenomenon emerged. She developed and perfected the formula of writing & recording a perfectly phrased song that was not only 'dancer friendly' but 'radio friendly' as well.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scooter Lee Biography|url=http://stompede.com/scooter_lee.html|website=Sundance Stompede|accessdate=4 April 2015}}</ref> Some of her most successful singles include J'ai du Boogie, Dizzy, Rose Garden, High-Test Love, Ribbon Of Highway, Roll Back The Rug, Honky Tonk Twist, OeeOeeO, Rock & Roll Waltz, Rompin' Stompin', Louisiana Hot Sauce, This Little Light Of Mine, Splish Splash and Break Away.\n\nIn [[Nashville, TN]], Scooter Lee is considered one of the hardest working artist on the road, performing more than 175 days a year worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hanson|first1=Eric|title=Recording Artist Scooter Lee to Perform at San Francisco Gay Rodeo & Festival|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2006/08/prweb427854.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080925045603/http://www.prweb.com/releases/2006/08/prweb427854.htm|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 25, 2008|website=PRWeb|accessdate=4 April 2015|location=San Francisco, CA|date=August 23, 2006}}</ref> She tours 27 countries, including: the USA, England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland, Denmark, France, Belgium, Netherlands, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Malaysia, Sweden, Japan, Canada, Finland, Norway, Germany, Switzerland and Belgium.\n\nCurrently, Scooter Lee resides in [[Atlanta, Georgia]] where she owns and operates her international distribution company for audio and video as well as founding a senior health [[501(c) organization|501(c)(3) charity organization]] that uses line dance as its chosen form of exercise. The nonprofit charity, Dancing For The Dream, Inc., promotes healthy lifestyles for seniors throughout the United States & abroad<ref>{{cite web|last1=Murugap|first1=Revathi|title=Line dance to health|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/story/?file=%2F2008%2F10%2F11%2Fhealth%2F2222347|website=The Star|accessdate=4 April 2015|date=October 11, 2008}}</ref> and encourages \"Dancing For The Health Of It\".<ref>{{cite web|title=Dancing For The Dream Health Seminars for Active Adults|url=https://dancingforthedream.com/|website=Dancing For The Dream|accessdate=5 April 2015}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n* ''Honky Tonk Twist'' (1994)\n* ''Scooter Lee's New Album'' (1995)\n* ''High-Test Love'' (1997)\n* ''In the Name of Love'' (1997)\n* ''Moving On Up'' (1998)\n* ''By Request\u2026 The Disco/Dance Album'' (1999)\n* ''Would You Consider'' (2000)\n* ''The Best of Scooter Lee'' (2000)\n* ''Dancing in the Streets'' (2001)\n* ''Steppin' Out'' (2001)\n* ''Set the Northpole on Fire'' (2002)\n* ''More of the Best'' (2002)\n* ''Puttin' on the Ritz'' (2003)\n* ''Walking on Sunshine'' (2004)\n* ''Test of Time'' (2005)\n* ''Go to the Rock'' (2007)\n* ''Home to Louisiana'' (2008)\n* ''Sing a New Song, Dance a New Dance'' (2011)\n* ''Big Bang Boogie'' (2011)\n* ''Welcome to Scooterville'' (2013)\n* ''I'm Gonna Love You Forever'' (2014)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n* singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Louisiana]]\n[[Category:Singers from New Orleans]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Louisiana]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at
