This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Crystal_Gayle","to":"Crystal Gayle"}],"pages":{"589960":{"pageid":589960,"ns":0,"title":"Crystal Gayle","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music singer (born 1951)}}\n{{Good article}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2022}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name               = Crystal Gayle\n| image              = Crystal Gayle.jpg\n| image_upright      = \n| caption            = Gayle performing in 2007\n| birth_name         = Brenda Gail Webb\n| birth_date         = {{Birth date and age|1951|01|09}}\n| birth_place        = [[Paintsville, Kentucky]], U.S.\n| known_for          = \"[[Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue]]\"\n| awards             = [[List of awards and nominations received by Crystal Gayle|Full list]]\n| occupation         = {{Flatlist|\n* Singer\n* songwriter\n}}\n| years_active       = 1969\u2013present\n| net_worth          = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source -->\n| spouse             = {{marriage|Vassilios \u201cBill\u201d Gatzimos<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Gregory |editor1-first=Andy |title=The International Who's Who in Popular Music \u2013 2002 |date=2002 |publisher=Psychology Press |isbn=978-1857431612 |page=187}}</ref>|1971}}\n| children           = 2\n| relatives          = {{plainlist|\n* [[Loretta Lynn]] (sister)\n* [[Jay Lee Webb]] (brother)\n* [[Peggy Sue (singer)|Peggy Sue]] (sister)\n}}\n| module             = {{Infobox musical artist\n| embed           = yes\n| genre           = {{Flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[country pop]]\n* [[Folk music|folk]]\n* [[gospel music|gospel]]\n* [[Jazz music|jazz]]\n}}\n| instrument      = {{Flatlist|\n* Vocals\n}}\n| label           = {{Flatlist|\n* [[Decca Records|Decca]]\n* [[United Artists Records|United Artists]]\n* [[Columbia Records|Columbia]]\n* [[Elektra Records|Elektra]]\n* [[Warner Records|Warner Bros.]]\n* [[Capitol Records|Capitol]]\n* [[Liberty Records|Liberty]]\n* [[Intersound Records|Intersound]]\n* [[Madacy Lifestyle Marketing|Madacy]]\n* [[The Orchard (company)|The Orchard]]\n* Southpaw\n}}\n| associated_acts = {{Flatlist|\n* [[Bob Hope]]\n* [[Eddie Rabbitt]]\n* [[Gary Morris]]\n* [[Tom Waits]]\n* [[The Statler Brothers]]\n}}\n| website         = {{URL|crystalgayle.com}}\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Brenda Gail Webb''' (born January 9, 1951), known professionally as '''Crystal Gayle''', is an American [[country music]] singer widely known for her 1977 hit \"[[Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue]]\". Initially, Gayle's management and record label were the same as that of her oldest sister, [[Loretta Lynn]].  Not finding success with the arrangement after several years, and with Lynn's encouragement, Gayle decided to try a different approach. She signed a new record contract and began recording with Nashville producer [[Allen Reynolds]]. Gayle's new sound was sometimes referred to as [[Middle of the road (music)|middle-of-the-road]] (MOR) or [[country pop]], and was part of a bigger musical trend by many country artists of the 1970s to appeal to a wider audience. Subsequently, Gayle became one of the most successful [[crossover music|crossover]] artists of the 1970s and 80s.<ref name=\"You Don't Know Me\">{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=Crystal Gayle Sings With Loretta Lynn, Interprets Country Staples on 'You Don't Know Me' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/crystal-gayle-loretta-lynn-you-dont-know-me-album-904127/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=26 October 2019 |access-date=30 December 2019}}</ref><ref name=\"Taste of Country\">{{cite web |title=Country Music's Most Powerful Women |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/crystal-gayle-powerful-female-country-singers/ |website=[[Townsquare Media#Web publications and services|Taste of Country]] |date=10 September 2017 |access-date=30 December 2019}}</ref> She is known for her floor-length hair.<ref name=\"Three Good Reasons\">{{cite web |title=SHORT TAKES: Hair Harasses Crystal Gayle |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1990-09-19-ca-874-story.html |website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=19 September 1990 |access-date=1 January 2020}}</ref>\n\nGayle was said to have begun her career in the 1960s performing as a background singer in Lynn's band (although Gayle says this actually never happened).<ref>{{Cite web |title=Country music icon Crystal Gayle blows through Texas once again for renewed tour |url=https://sanantonio.culturemap.com/news/entertainment/country-music-icon-crystal-gayle-blows-through-texas-once-again-renewed-tour/ |access-date=2022-04-15 |website=CultureMap San Antonio |language=en}}</ref> Lynn helped her sign a recording contract with [[Decca Records]] in 1970. Having minor success, she was encouraged to develop her own musical identity. Under the direction of producer Reynolds at [[United Artists Records]], Gayle shifted towards a [[country pop]] style that was more successful. In 1975, \"[[Wrong Road Again]]\" became Gayle's first major hit. However, it was in 1977 when Gayle achieved her biggest success with \"Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue\". The single topped the ''Billboard'' country chart, crossed over to the top five of the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and became a major international hit.\n\nGayle continued having success from the late 1970s and through late 1980s. Her biggest hits included \"[[Ready for the Times to Get Better]]\" (1977), \"[[Talking in Your Sleep (Crystal Gayle song)|Talking in Your Sleep]]\" (1978), \"[[Half the Way]]\" (1979) and \"[[You and I (Eddie Rabbitt and Crystal Gayle song)|You and I]]\" (1982). In the 1990s, Gayle shifted artistic directions by recording various genres of music. This included an album of [[inspirational music]] titled ''[[Someday (Crystal Gayle album)|Someday]]'' (1995) and an album of standards called ''[[Crystal Gayle Sings the Heart and Soul of Hoagy Carmichael]]'' (1999). During the decade she also owned and operated a fine arts shop called Crystal's Fine Gifts and Jewelry. Her most recent studio release was in 2019 and Gayle has since continued to tour throughout the world.\n\nGayle has won one [[Grammy Award]] and has been nominated for several others since the 1970s. She has also won five [[Academy of Country Music]] awards; those awards include receiving the Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award in 2016. In addition, she has won two [[Country Music Association]] awards and three [[American Music Awards]]. ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' ranked her among the 100 greatest country artists of all time and [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] ranked her within their list of the 40 greatest women of country music. Gayle has her own star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] and was inducted as a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in 2017.\n\n==Early life==\n[[File:Loretta-Lynn-Childhood-Home-Butcher-Holler-Van-Lear-Kentucky-2014.JPG|thumb|right|Webb family home]]\nGayle was born Brenda Gail Webb in [[Paintsville, Kentucky]] on January 9, 1951.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2020/01/09/UPI-Almanac-for-Thursday-Jan-9-2020/6871578415895/|title= UPI Almanac for Thursday, Jan. 9, 2020|publisher= [[United Press International]] | date= January 9, 2020|access-date=January 16, 2020 |archive-date= January 15, 2020|archive-url= https://archive.today/20200115192229/https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2020/01/09/UPI-Almanac-for-Thursday-Jan-9-2020/6871578415895/|url-status=live|quote=... country singer Crystal Gayle in 1951 (age 69)}}</ref> She was the last of eight children born to Clara Marie \"Clary\" ([[maiden and married names|n\u00e9e]] Ramey; May 5, 1912 \u2013 November 24, 1981) and Melvin Theodore \"Ted\" Webb (June 6, 1906 \u2013 February 22, 1959). Unlike her sister [[Loretta Lynn|Loretta]] and her other siblings, Gayle was the only child born at the Paintsville hospital, and not at home. Through her [[matrilineality|matriline]], Gayle is a distant cousin of singer [[Patty Loveless]].{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=344}} Gayle and her siblings claim [[Irish people|Irish]] and [[Cherokee]] descent, although she is not [[Native American recognition in the United States|enrolled]] with any Native tribe.<ref name=\"Associated Press\">{{cite web |last1=Whiteley |first1=Jenni |title=Country music star Crystal Gayle coming to Fort Hall Oct. 13 |url=https://apnews.com/1f39f58f44b34bb0b75946c966a61e03 |website=[[Associated Press]] |date=6 October 2017 |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> Gayle's father was a [[coal mining|coal miner]] who developed [[Coalworker's pneumoconiosis|black lung disease]]. In search of better medical treatment, the family moved to [[Wabash, Indiana]], when Gayle was four years old. They lived in a retired miner's community and Clara Webb worked as a [[Unlicensed assistive personnel|nurse's aide]].<ref name=\"People 1978\">{{cite web |last1=Windeler |first1=Robert |title=Loretta Lynn & Crystal Gayle: Sister Rivalry |url=https://people.com/archive/cover-story-loretta-lynn-crystal-gayle-sister-rivalry-vol-9-no-22/ |website=[[People (magazine)|People]] |access-date=30 December 2019}}</ref><ref name=\"Naples News\">{{cite web |last1=Osborn |first1=Dave |title=Crystal Gayle brings sweet sound to Bonita Springs on Friday |url=https://www.naplesnews.com/story/entertainment/music/2018/03/21/crystal-gayle-brings-sweet-sound-bonita-springs-friday/443551002/ |website=Naples Daily News |access-date=30 December 2019}}</ref> Ted Webb died from a stroke in 1959.{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=345}} From early age, Gayle had an interest in singing. She noted that she could sing before she could walk.<ref name=\"Naples News\" /> The family's new home in Wabash was in an urban setting. She was exposed to diverse cultural groups and norms and in turn to various styles of music.{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=439}} She sang along frequently to songs she heard on the radio and was inspired by the music of her sister [[Loretta Lynn]].<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\">{{cite web |last1=Huey |first1=Steve |title=Crystal Gayle -- Biography & History |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/crystal-gayle-mn0000132449/biography |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=30 December 2019}}</ref>\n\nGayle's musical interests were shaped further in her teenage years. She started singing in church, performed [[folk music|folk]] songs, and recorded demonstration tapes.<ref name=\"Platinum Crossover\">{{cite news |last1=Zibart |first1=Evee |title=The Platinum Crossover |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1978/07/19/the-platinum-crossover/f7dcc2cd-5cae-4412-ad88-00665946be1c/ |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=30 December 2019}}</ref><ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" /> With encouragement from Lynn, she began touring during summers in [[high school]].<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" /> At age 16, Gayle performed on the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in replacement of her sister who had gotten ill. She performed a cover of [[Gordon Lightfoot]]'s \"[[Ribbon of Darkness]]\".<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Crystal Gayle to Be Inducted Into Grand Ole Opry |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/7662590/crystal-gayle-grand-ole-opry-inducted |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=1 January 2020}}</ref> After graduating from high school in 1970, she signed her first recording contract with her sister's label: [[Decca Records]]. Upon signing with Decca, the label insisted that Gayle change her first name from \"Brenda\" to another name. The conflict was due to the fact that [[Brenda Lee]] was already signed to Decca at the time. Shortly thereafter, Lynn drove past a sign for the [[Krystal (restaurant)|Krystal]] fast-food restaurant and said to Gayle, \"That's your name. Crystals are bright and shiny, like you.\"{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1353}} It was then that she changed her name professionally to \"Crystal Gayle\", with \"Gayle\" taken from her middle name (Gail).<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" />\n\n==Career==\n===1969\u20131976: Decca Records and musical shifts===\nGayle was first managed by [[Oliver Lynn]] (Loretta Lynn's husband) after signing with [[Decca Records]]. Among her first professional gigs were routine appearances on [[Jim Ed Brown]]'s television show ''The Country Palace''. On the program, Gayle performed original songs written by Loretta Lynn including \"Sparklin' Look of Love\" and \"Mama, It's Different This Time\".{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1353}} Her debut single was released in 1970 titled \"[[I've Cried (The Blue Right Out of My Eyes)]]\". Also written by Lynn, the song peaked within the top 40 of the [[Hot Country Songs|''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Singles]] chart.<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" /> The song was followed by other singles that reached minor positions on the country songs chart: \"Everybody Oughta Cry\" (1972) and \"I Hope You're Havin' Better Luck Than Me\" (1972).{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1353}} Gayle's career stalled while at the Decca label.<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" />{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1353}} This was due to the fact that the label wanted Gayle to record in the same style as her sister. Steve Huey of [[AllMusic]] criticized her early singles, calling them \"little Loretta records\".<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" /> Writers Mary A. Bufwack and Robert K. Oermann noted that Gayle was \"probably stigmatized\" for being the sibling of Loretta Lynn.{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=345}} In a 2019 interview with ''[[Forbes]]'', Gayle reflected on the experience, \"It didn't take me long to realize I was only there because I was Loretta's sister.\"<ref name=\"Forbes\">{{cite web |last1=Windsor |first1=Pam |title=Crystal Gayle Sings Classic Country On New \"You Don't Know Me\" Album |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/pamwindsor/2019/09/07/crystal-gayle-sings-classic-country-on-new-you-dont-know-me-album/#50cf416e70c6 |website=[[Forbes]] |access-date=1 January 2020}}</ref> During this period, Lynn gave Gayle advice that prompted her to expand her musical styles. Lynn said, \"quit singing my songs...We have one Loretta Lynn and we don't need another.\" The conversation led Gayle to ultimately  leave Decca in 1974.<ref name=\"Naples News\" />\n[[File:Krystal.jpg|thumb|right|Krystal burgers, inspiration for Crystal Gayle's stage name]]\n\nGayle signed a new recording contract with [[United Artists Records]] in 1974. Under the direction of producer [[Allen Reynolds]], her musical style shifted.<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" /> Reynolds (who had recent success producing [[Don Williams]]) encouraged Gayle to record in a softer, mellower format. He also helped market her music towards a [[crossover music|crossover]] audience.{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=439}} Gayle also released her first United Artists single in 1974, \"Restless\". Mary Bufwack and Robert Oermann called the song \"assertive\" and \"sexy\".{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=344}} The song peaked at number 39 on the ''Billboard'' country songs chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Crystal Gayle -- \"Restless\" Chart History |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=1 January 2020}}</ref> The same year, Gayle's [[Crystal Gayle (album)|self-titled debut album]] was issued,<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" /> reaching number 25 on the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] survey.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Crystal Gayle'' Chart History |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=1 January 2020}}</ref> The following year, she had her first top ten hit on the country chart with \"[[Wrong Road Again]]\", also written by Allen Reynolds.<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" /> She had minor hits with the singles \"This Is My Year for Mexico\" (1975) and \"Beyond You\" (1975). The latter song was co-written by Gayle and her husband, Bill Gatzimos. Her second studio album ''[[Somebody Loves You (Crystal Gayle album)|Somebody Loves You]]'' spawned a second top 10 hit: the [[Somebody Loves You (Crystal Gayle song)|title track]].{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1354}}\n\nGayle's shift towards [[country pop]] was received better than her earlier recordings with Decca. Kurt Wolff of ''Country Music: The Rough Guide'' praised the new style, calling it a \"pleasant, easygoing sort of [[country music|country]]-[[folk music|folk]] blend \u2013 a close cousin to music of [[Emmylou Harris]].\"{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=439}} Encyclopedic writer Collin Larkin called her new music approach to have the \"easygoing charm\" of records by Don Williams.{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1354}} Oermann and Bufwack called the new style \"ear-catching\" and praised Allen Reynolds's \"gentle rhythm productions.\"{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=344}}\n\nReynolds had limited time to write material for Gayle. Instead, he arranged for songwriters [[Bob McDill]] and [[Richard Leigh (songwriter)|Richard Leigh]] to help compose music.{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1354}} This arrangement proved successful when in 1976, Gayle had her first number 1 hit on the [[Hot Country Songs|''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles]] chart with \"[[I'll Get Over You]]\", written by Leigh. This was followed by a second number 1 hit, \"[[You Never Miss a Real Good Thing (Till He Says Goodbye)]]\", and the number 2 hit, \"[[I'll Do It All Over Again]]\".<ref name=\"20th Century\">{{cite book |last1=DiMartino |first1=Dave |title=Music in the 20th Century |date=1990 |publisher=M.E. Sharpe |location=New York, NY |isbn=0-7656-8012-2 |pages=[https://archive.org/details/musicin20thcentu0000unse/page/239 239] |url=https://archive.org/details/musicin20thcentu0000unse/page/239 }}</ref> Her third studio album, ''[[Crystal (Crystal Gayle album)|Crystal]]'', was released in 1976, peaking at number 7 on the Top Country Albums chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Crystal Gayle -- ''Crystal'' Chart History |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=1 January 2020}}</ref>\n\n===1977\u20131979: Crossover breakthrough===\nProducer Allen Reynolds believed Gayle was poised to have [[crossover (music)|crossover pop]] success if the right song were found.{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1354}} In 1977, Richard Leigh had composed a tune called \"[[Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue]]\". The song was originally intended for British singer [[Shirley Bassey]].<ref name=\"Brown Eyes\">{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=Flashback: Crystal Gayle's 'Brown Eyes Blue' Goes Global |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/flashback-crystal-gayles-brown-eyes-blue-goes-global-199753/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=23 June 2017 |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> When Reynolds heard the song he said to Leigh, \"You're not sending that song anywhere.\"<ref name=\"Slick Country\">{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=Crystal Gayle Reflects on 'Slick Country' and Coal Miner's Family |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/crystal-gayle-reflects-on-slick-country-and-coal-miners-family-187005/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=22 September 2014 |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> As was common practice at the time, according to the documentary <ref>''Country Girls''</ref> the track was recorded alongside a guide or [[scratch vocal]], which Gayle recorded in one single take. Going back later to re-record the final production vocal, after several tries, she said she couldn't get the same feeling back as in the original, so this was kept as the master.\n\n\"Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue\" was released as a single in 1977, peaking at number 1 on the [[Hot Country Songs|''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles]] chart and crossing over to number 2 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. Internationally, it became a hit in several countries including the [[United Kingdom]], where it reached the number 5 position. Since its release, \"Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue\" has been received positively by music critics and fans. They have also considered it her [[List of signature songs|signature song]].<ref name=\"Brown Eyes\" /> Stephen Thomas Erlewine of [[AllMusic]] praised Gayle's vocals, commenting, \"She never stressed it too heavily, nor were her vocals cloying&nbsp;\u2014 they were pretty and straightforward, making the song quite alluring.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Erlewine |first1=Stephen Thomas |title=\"Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue\" -- Crystal Gayle -- Song info |url=https://www.allmusic.com/song/dont-it-make-my-brown-eyes-blue-mt0056387423 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref>\n{{Listen\n| filename = Crystal Gayle--Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue audio.ogg\n| title = \"Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue\"\n| description = Gayle's [[List of signature songs|signature song]] and her first to become a major [[country pop]] crossover hit (1977).\n}}\n\nGayle's fourth studio record, ''[[We Must Believe in Magic]]'', was also released in 1977. The album peaked at number 2 on the ''Billboard'' country albums chart and number 12 on the ''[[Billboard 200]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Crystal Gayle -- ''We Must Believe in Magic'' chart history (Country Albums) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |title=Crystal Gayle -- ''We Must Believe in Magic'' chart history (Billboard 200) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/tlp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> ''We Must Believe in Magic'' has received positive reviews since its initial release. [[AllMusic]] gave the record 3.5 out of 5 stars.<ref>{{cite web |title=''We Must Believe in Magic'' -- Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/we-must-believe-in-magic-mw0000198419 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> Paul Dennis of ''My Kind of Country'' gave the album a \"Grade A\" rating, calling it \"an eclectic mix of songs ranging from pop standards to rock 'n' roll hits to songs by contemporary country songsmiths.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dennis |first1=Paul |title=Album Review: Crystal Gayle \u2013 'We Must Believe In Magic' |url=https://mykindofcountry.wordpress.com/2017/01/12/album-review-crystal-gayle-we-must-believe-in-magic/ |website=My Kind of Country |date=12 January 2017 |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> ''We Must Believe in Magic'' became the first album by a female country artist to certify platinum in sales by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]].{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1354}}<ref>{{cite web |title=Gold and Platinum: ''We Must Believe in Magic'' |url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=we+must+believe+in+magic+crystal+gayle#search_section |website=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> In 1978, Gayle earned the [[Grammy Award for Best Female Country Vocal Performance]] for \"Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue\", while Leigh won a Grammy for [[Best Country Song]].{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1354}}\n\nIn 1978, her fifth studio album ''[[When I Dream]]'' was released, also reaching number 2 on the country albums chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Crystal Gayle -- ''When I Dream'' chart history (Country Albums) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> The album peaked at number 52 on the ''Billboard 200''<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Crystal Gayle -- ''When I Dream'' chart history (Billboard 200) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/tlp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> and certified by platinum by the RIAA.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gold & Platinum -- ''When I Dream'' |url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=when+i+dream+crystal+gayle#search_section |website=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> ''When I Dream'' also received positive reviews, garnering 3 out of 5 stars from [[AllMusic]]<ref>{{cite web |title=''When I Dream'' -- Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/when-i-dream-mw0000120202 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> and another \"Grade A\" rating from ''My Kind of Country''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Album Review: Crystal Gayle \u2013 'When I Dream' |url=https://mykindofcountry.wordpress.com/2017/01/13/album-review-crystal-gayle-when-i-dream/ |website=My Kind of Country |date=13 January 2017 |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> Its lead single was the [[Roger Cook (songwriter)|Roger Cook]]-penned \"[[Talking in Your Sleep (Crystal Gayle song)|Talking in Your Sleep]]\". It became a number 1 country single and crossed over to number 18 on the Hot 100. \"Talking in Your Sleep\" became Gayle's second international hit as well, peaking at number 11 in the United Kingdom. The album also included the hits \"[[Why Have You Left the One You Left Me For]]\" and the [[When I Dream (song)|title track]].{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1354}} By the end of 1978, Gayle had won \"Female Vocalist of the Year\" from both the [[Academy of Country Music]] and the [[Country Music Association]].<ref name=\"Lifetime\">{{cite web |last1=Rosenberg |first1=Sari |title=February 24, 1977: Crystal Gayle Won Best Female Vocalist at the 12th Annual ACM Awards |url=https://www.mylifetime.com/she-did-that/february-24-1977-crystal-gayle-won-best-female-vocalist-at-the-12th-annual-acm-awards |website=[[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> Before departing from the United Artists label, her sixth studio album ''[[We Should Be Together (album)|We Should Be Together]]'' (1979) was released. It featured the two top-ten hits: \"[[Your Kisses Will]]\" and \"[[Your Old Cold Shoulder]]\".{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1354}}\n\n===1979\u20131989: Continued crossover success===\nIn 1979, Gayle moved to [[Columbia Records]], bringing Reynolds with her.{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1355}} Under Columbia, Gayle began recording more cover versions of songs. This decision received praise from music critics, who credited her for being \"versatile\".{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=344}} Her seventh studio album, ''[[Miss the Mississippi]]'' was released in 1979 as well. It featured three major hits including \"[[Half the Way]]\", which became her third crossover pop hit.<ref name=\"Miss the Mississippi\">{{cite web |last1=Ankeny |first1=Jason |title=''Miss the Mississippi'' -- Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/miss-the-mississippi-mw0000272898 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> ''Miss the Mississippi'' peaked at number 3 on the ''Billboard'' Top Country Albums chart<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Miss the Mississippi'' -- Crystal Gayle chart history (Country Albums) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> number 36 on the ''[[Billboard 200]]''<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Miss the Mississippi'' -- Crystal Gayle chart history (Billboard 200) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/tlp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> and certified gold in sales from the RIAA.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gold & Platinum -- ''Miss the Mississippi'' |url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=miss+the+mississippi+#search_section |website=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> Gayle's eighth studio release ''[[These Days (Crystal Gayle album)|These Days]]'' (1980) spawned two more number 1 singles on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles chart: \"[[If You Ever Change Your Mind]]\" and \"[[Too Many Lovers]]\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ankeny |first1=Jason |title=''These Days'' -- Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/these-days-mw0000189982 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> In 1981, Gayle's ninth studio album ''[[Hollywood, Tennessee]]'' peaked at number 5 on the country albums chart<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Hollywood, Tennessee'' -- Crystal Gayle chart history (Country Albums) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> and number 99 on the ''Billboard 200''.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Hollywood, Tennessee'' -- Crystal Gayle chart history (Billboard 200) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/tlp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> Although commercially successful, it received mixed critical reviews. Mary A. Bufwack and Robert K. Oermann said that the album \"symbolized her uptown inspirations\"{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=344}} and Jason Ankeny of [[AllMusic]] gave the album only 2.5 out of 5 stars.<ref name=\"Hollywood\">{{cite web |last1=Ankeny |first1=Jason |title=''Hollywood, Tennessee'' -- Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/hollywood-tennessee-mw0000675174 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> ''Hollywood, Tennessee'' spawned three major hits on the ''Billboard'' country songs chart. This included the crossover hit, \"[[The Woman in Me (Crystal Gayle song)|The Woman in Me]]\", and the social awareness tune, \"[[Livin' in These Troubled Times]]\".{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=345}}<ref name=\"Hollywood\" />\n\nAs Gayle's music crossed multiple genres, she made more appearances outside of the Nashville establishment. Among these was hosting two [[prime time]] television specials: ''The Crystal Gayle Special'' (1979) and ''Crystal'' (1980).{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1355}} Both shows aired on [[CBS]] and were given critical acclaim. Gayle would also appear with [[Bob Hope]] on his 1979 television special called ''On the Road to China''.<ref name=\"Davis\">{{cite web |title=Crystal Gayle (2009) |url=https://www.davisarts.org/crystal-gayle/ |website=Davis Art Council |date=21 February 2009 |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> For the special, Gayle and Hope taped a performance on the [[Great Wall of China]].<ref name=\"TDN\">{{cite web |last1=Paulu |first1=Tom |title=Crystal Gayle blowin' into town on Friday |url=https://tdn.com/lifestyles/crystal-gayle-blowin-into-town-on-friday/article_1c54fec9-dfb8-5ec0-9c13-eb8e3f9081f2.html |website=TDN |date=February 2007 |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> The special made Gayle the first artist to film a performance on the Great Wall.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ross |first1=Doug |title=Crystal Gayle |url=https://www.nwitimes.com/news/history/famous-hoosiers/crystal-gayle/article_8b349ca1-988b-596e-bc68-667acc2d0d53.html |website=NWI |date=29 February 2016 |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref>\n\n[[File:Crystal Gayle--Billboard.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Gayle in ''Billboard'' magazine, 1977.]]\nIn 1982, Gayle collaborated with [[Tom Waits]] on the soundtrack of [[Francis Ford Coppola]]'s film ''[[One from the Heart]]''.{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=440}} Originally, [[Bette Midler]] was chosen for the project, however Midler could not fit it into her schedule. At first the soundtrack was delayed by Columbia Records due to a dispute with Coppola's Zoetrope Studios.<ref name=\"RS One from the Heart\">{{cite magazine |last1=Pond |first1=Steve |title=Tom Waits on 'One From the Heart' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/tom-waits-on-one-from-the-heart-63521/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=April 1982 |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> When it was released, the [[One from the Heart|soundtrack]] received positive reviews. Thom Jurek of [[AllMusic]] gave the release 4.5 out of 5 stars, who called it \"one of the most beautifully wrought soundtrack collaborations in history\".<ref name=\"One from the Heart\">{{cite web |last1=Jurek |first1=Thom |title=''One from the Heart'' -- Tom Waits, Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/one-from-the-heart-mw0000308412 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> Steve Pond of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' called it \"a dreamy series of duets with Crystal Gayle that drift in and out of the film, comment on the action and supply some crucial transitions.\"<ref name=\"RS One from the Heart\" />\n\nAlso in 1982, Gayle moved from Columbia to [[Elektra Records]], which would later merge with [[Warner Records|Warner Bros.]] Among the first recordings was a duet with [[Eddie Rabbitt]] titled \"[[You and I (Eddie Rabbitt and Crystal Gayle song)|You and I]]\".{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=440}} The song reached number 1 on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles chart and became her second top 10 hit on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100.<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" /> Gayle's first studio album with Elektra would also be issued in 1982, ''[[True Love (Crystal Gayle album)|True Love]]''. First produced by Allen Reynolds, when the album was presented to [[Jimmy Bowen]] (Elektra's division head), he commented that it \"rocked too much\". For these reasons, Bowen decided to produce three additional tracks for the album.<ref name=\"True Love\">{{cite web |last1=Roland |first1=Tom |title=''True Love'' -- Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/true-love-mw0001880860 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> The album would receive a mixed reception. In ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard Magazine]]''{{'}}s initial review, they praised Gayle's vocals despite the use of \"tougher arrangements\".<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Billboard's Top Album Picks |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=1982 |pages=64}}</ref> Tom Roland of AllMusic praised Gayle's performance, notably on the tracks \"[[Our Love Is on the Faultline]]\" and \"Deeper Than the Fire\". Roland also criticized the production arrangements Bowen arranged for.<ref name=\"True Love\" /> ''True Love'' spawned three singles that all reached the number 1 spot on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles]] chart: \"Our Love Is on the Faultine\", \"[[Baby, What About You]]\" and \"[['Til I Gain Control Again]]\".{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1355}}\n\nIn 1983, Gayle's released her next album called ''[[Cage the Songbird]]''. It was the first of Gayle's to be produced entirely by Jimmy Bowen.<ref>{{cite web |title=Crystal Gayle -- ''Cage the Songbird'' (1983, Vinyl) |url=https://www.discogs.com/Crystal-Gayle-Cage-The-Songbird/release/3012050 |website=[[Discogs]] |date=6 September 1983 |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> ''Cage the Songbird'' peaked at number 5 on the Top Country Albums chart<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Cage the Songbird'' -- Chart History (Country Albums) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> and number 171 on the ''Billboard 200''.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Cage the Songbird'' -- Chart History (Billboard 200) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/tlp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref> Among its singles were the crossover hits \"[[The Sound of Goodbye]]\" and \"[[Turning Away]]\". Gayle had further hits from her next studio releases in 1985 and 1986. Among these were the number one hits, \"[[Straight to the Heart (song)|Straight to the Heart]]\" (1986) and \"[[Cry (Churchill Kohlman song)|Cry]]\" (1986). The latter was a song originally popularized by [[Johnnie Ray]].<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Crystal Gayle -- \"Straight to the Heart\" -- chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2 January 2020}}</ref>{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1355}} In 1983, she would also record the theme song for the television series ''[[Masquerade (TV series)|Masquerade]]''.<ref name=\"Crystal Gayle\">{{cite web |title=About -- Crystal Gayle |url=http://www.crystalgayle.com/about.html |website=Crystal Gayle.com |access-date=3 January 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191231051132/http://www.crystalgayle.com/about.html |archive-date=31 December 2019 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In 1984, she sang a duet with Hong Kong singer [[Danny Chan]], titled \"Tell Me What Can I Do\",<ref>{{cite web |title=\"Tell Me What Can I Do\" EP (US/Australia Version) album database |url=https://musicbrainz.org/release/8cae6095-ddcb-43f5-8cb1-627af5c71637 |website=Musicbrainz.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=\"Tell Me What Can I Do\" 7\" Vinyl EP Photos |url=http://www.dannychan.cn/danny-library/?p=4672 |website=Dannychan.cn| date=28 June 2015 }}</ref> it was largely unknown due to lack of promotional budget.<ref>{{cite web |title=\"Tell Me What Can I Do\" (Danny Chan, Crystal Gayle) |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9tbhotSMaRA |website=Youtube | date=23 September 2019 |publisher=WEA Records}}</ref>\n\nBetween 1985 and 1987, Gayle collaborated with country artist [[Gary Morris]] on a series of duets.{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1355}} The first being the single \"[[Makin' Up for Lost Time (The Dallas Lovers' Song)|Makin' Up for Lost Time]]\". The song reached number 1 on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles chart in 1986.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=\"Makin' Up for Lost Time\" chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> \"Makin' Up for Lost Time\" was referred to as the \"Lovers' Theme\" on ''[[Dallas (1978 TV series)|Dallas]]''. It became an [[anthem]] for [[supercouple]] [[Bobby Ewing|Bobby]] ([[Patrick Duffy]]) and [[Pam Ewing]] ([[Victoria Principal]]) on the popular [[CBS]] [[prime time]] [[soap opera]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Crystal Gayle \u2013 February 13th \u2013 16th, 2020 |url=http://www.riversideresort.com/event/crystal-gayle-february-13th-16th-2020/ |website=Riverside Resort |access-date=3 January 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200103015019/http://www.riversideresort.com/event/crystal-gayle-february-13th-16th-2020/ |archive-date=3 January 2020 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The pair also recorded the theme for the [[NBC]] soap opera ''[[Another World (TV series)|Another World]]''. Also titled \"[[Another World (Crystal Gayle and Gary Morris song)|Another World]]\", it peaked on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles chart at number four in February 1986. Gayle would also guest star in the show as herself. The show would ultimately use Morris' and Gayle's recording as the show's opening theme for nine years.{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1355}} The duo would release their collaborative studio album in 1986 titled, ''[[What If We Fall in Love?]]''. The album peaked at number 25 on the ''Billboard'' country albums list in September 1987.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''What If We Fall in Love?'' chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/gary-morris/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> In 1988, Gayle released her final album of the decade entitled ''[[Nobody's Angel (Crystal Gayle album)|Nobody's Angel]]''. The album produced two singles; the [[Nobody's Angel (song)|title track]] and the single \"Tennessee Nights\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ankeny |first1=Jason |title=''Nobody's Angel'' -- Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/nobodys-angel-mw0000652259 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref>\n\nAlso in 1987, Gayle opened a [[gift shop]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] called \"Crystal's Fine Gifts and Jewelry\". The store contained various gifts, such as [[jewelry]] and stones made by various European artisans.{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=343}} The shop also included various types of [[crystal]]s. In a 1994 interview, Gayle commented on her business: \"The little shop turned into a much larger shop and it takes a lot of work, as anyone in retail well knows. But we have a lot of fun with it.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sweid |first1=Nancy |title=Crystal Gayle: Long-Haired Country Girl's Hobby a Fragile One |url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/1994/06/28/crystal-gayle-long-haired-country-girls-hobby-a-fragile-one/ |website=Nash Country Daily |access-date=4 January 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200104024417/http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/1994/06/28/crystal-gayle-long-haired-country-girls-hobby-a-fragile-one/ |archive-date=4 January 2020 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The shop officially closed in 2008.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Nelson |first1=Dick |title=Sunday Morning Classic Country Spotlight to Feature Crystal Gayle |url=https://minnesotasnewcountry.com/sunday-morning-country-classic-spotlight-to-feature-crystal-gayle/ |website=Minnesota's New Country |date=14 September 2012 |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref>\n\n===1990\u2013present: Later career and recent years===\nIn 1990, Gayle signed a new recording contract with [[Capitol Records]] and reunited with producer Allen Reynolds. The same year she released seventeenth studio album, ''[[Ain't Gonna Worry]]''.{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1355}} Bill Carpenter of AllMusic gave the release 4 out of 5 stars, calling it \"an excellent set of country pop\".<ref>{{cite web |title=''Ain't Gonna Worry'' -- Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/aint-gonna-worry-mw0000690301 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> The album spawned several singles, beginning with \"Just an Old Love\". In its initial review ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' gave it a positive response, praising the production style of Reynolds.<ref>{{cite web |title=Billboard Magazine: 1990 (November 24, 1990) |url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/90s/1990/BB-1990-11-24.pdf |website=American Radio History |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> Its third single, \"[[Never Ending Song of Love]]\", would become Gayle's last charting single to date, reaching number 72 on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Crystal Gayle Chart History: Country Airplay |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/csa/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> Her eighteenth studio album came in 1992 called ''[[Three Good Reasons]]''. The album was produced by Buzz Stone.{{sfn|Larkin|2007|p=1355}} The album's lead single of the same name spawned a [[music video]]. Bill Kohlhaase of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' gave the song and video a positive review, saying, \"The video, alternating between scenes of Gayle and her swirling tresses with sparsely staged visions of a single mother and her two children, is the kind of heartfelt, yet assertive statement that Gayle has parlayed into major success in the past.\"<ref name=\"Three Good Reasons\" /> AllMusic also gave the album 3 out of 5 stars.<ref>{{cite web |title=''Three Good Reasons'' -- Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/three-good-reasons-mw0000076640 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref>\n\n[[File:Sherry Lynn & Crystal Gayle at The Grand Ole Opry.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Crystal Gayle performing with Sherry Lynn at The Grand Ole Opry (2013)]]\nAs the 1990s progressed, Gayle recorded material for smaller labels and issuing specialty projects. Her first small label was the Branson Entertainment Group, where she released an album of re-recorded hits titled ''[[Best Always]]''.{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=440}} In 1995, she signed with [[Intersound Records]] and recorded a pair of [[gospel music|gospel]] studio albums. The first was 1995's ''[[Someday (Crystal Gayle album)|Someday]]'', which she co-produced with Bobby Wood.<ref name=\"Country Music\">{{cite book |last1=Stambler |first1=Irwin |title=Country Music: The Encyclopedia |date=2000 |publisher=MacMillan |location=New York, NY |isbn=0-312-15121-7 |pages=[https://archive.org/details/countrymusicency00stam/page/175 175] |url=https://archive.org/details/countrymusicency00stam/page/175 }}</ref> The album's first single included a music that was filmed in [[Greece]]. In a 1995 interview, she explained the message behind the title track, \"There are songs in there that definitely you've lived. The title track is a song that I think a lot of people, the way it's written, definitely relate to.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Stout |first1=Michael W. |title=Crystal Gayle Interview -- August 1995 |url=http://www.louisvillemusicnews.net/webmanager/index.php?WEB_CAT_ID=50&storyid=11688&headline=Crystal_Gayle_Interview&issueid=78 |website=Louisville Music News |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> In 1997, her second gospel collection was released titled ''[[Joy & Inspiration]]''.<ref name=\"Liner Notes\">{{cite book|last1=Gayle|first1=Crystal|title=''Joy & Inspiration'' (Cassette insert)|date=1997|publisher=Beautiful Music Company, Warner Special Products}}</ref>\n\nAt the dawn of the new millennium, Gayle expanded her musical interests. In 1999, she released an album of [[jazz music|jazz]] and [[traditional pop|American Standards]] called ''[[Crystal Gayle Sings the Heart and Soul of Hoagy Carmichael]]''.<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" /> It was as a tribute to [[Hoagy Carmichael]], whom Gayle worked with shortly before his death in the early 1980s. It album featured covers of songs he composed, including \"[[Stardust (1927 song)|Stardust]]\" and \"[[Georgia on My Mind]]\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gray |first1=Michael |title=''Heart & Soul'' |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1472939/heart-soul/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200103031507/http://www.cmt.com/news/1472939/heart-soul/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=3 January 2020 |website=[[CMT (American TV channel)|Country Music Television]] |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> AllMusic's Thom Jurek gave the release 4 out of 5 stars in his review of ''Heart and Soul''. Jurek called it, \"a gorgeous set, one that reaffirms Gayle's artistry to be sure, but also one that offers the first really new hearing of Carmichael in at least a decade.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Jurek |first1=Thom |title=''Heart and Soul'' -- Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/crystal-gayle-sings-the-heart-soul-of-hoagy-carmichael-mw0000670931 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> ''Billboard Magazine'' praised the lead single, \"[[Two Sleepy People]]\" (a duet with [[Willie Nelson]]), calling it \"sweet\" and \"playful\".<ref>{{cite magazine |title=American Radio History: Single Reviews and Previews |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iAgEAAAAMBAJ&q=crystal+gayle+heart+and+soul+album+review&pg=PA20 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=3 January 2020|date = 1999-12-11}}</ref> In 2000, she released a studio album of [[children's music]] titled ''[[In My Arms (album)|In My Arms]]''.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Demasters |first1=Karen |title=JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS; A Familiar Country Voice |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/10/nyregion/jersey-footlights-a-familiar-country-voice.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=10 December 2000 |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> In 2003, she released her second album of American standards called ''[[All My Tomorrows (Crystal Gayle album)|All My Tomorrows]]''.<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" /> Robert Daniels of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' commented positively, saying, \"Gayle's singing boasts directness and subtlety. There are no flashy or show-busy theatrics.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Daniels |first1=Robert L. |title=Crystal Gayle \u2014 All My Tomorrows |url=https://variety.com/2003/music/reviews/crystal-gayle-all-my-tomorrows-1200538363/ |website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=27 October 2003 |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> AllMusic gave the release 4 out of 5 stars, calling Gayle's singing \"stunning\" and \"capable.\"<ref name=\"All My Tomorrows\">{{cite web |last1=Jurek |first1=Thom |title=''All My Tomorrows'' -- Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/all-my-tomorrows-mw0000324401 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> In January 2007, fugitive [[Christopher Daniel Gay]] escaped from custody at an [[Interstate 95 in South Carolina|Interstate 95]] welcome center near [[Hardeeville, South Carolina]], and made his way to Tennessee where he stole Gayle's tour bus. Gay was arrested the following day and the bus was returned to Gayle.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Russell |first1=Steven |title=The Last Outlaw: The Ballad of Christopher Gay |journal=[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]] |date=August 2007 |pages=102\u201308}}</ref>\n\nFor several years, Gayle spent time recording her next studio release. She stated the album would consist of covers of country music classics and would be produced by her son, Chris Gatzimos. The project was originally titled ''Am I That Easy To Forget''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Christner|first1=Ryan|title=Career not slowing for indomitable Crystal Gayle|url=http://www.hutchnews.com/the_bee/career-not-slowing-for-indomitable-crystal-gayle/article_223ec0b7-533e-5004-a45a-3066df1172de.html|work=[[The Hutchinson News]]|date=December 7, 2016|access-date=March 13, 2017}}</ref> In 2019, Gayle announced it would be re-titled ''[[You Don't Know Me: Classic Country]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/TheCrystalGayle/status/1159833721157013504|title=My new cd YOU DON'T KNOW ME is available for Pre-Sale at my online store. Ships on or around 9/6/19 |first=Crystal|last=Gayle|website=[[Twitter]]|date=August 9, 2019}}</ref> It was officially released in September 2019 via Southpaw Productions and [[The Orchard (company)|The Orchard]].<ref name=\"Digital Journal\">{{cite web |last1=Papadatos |first1=Markos |title=Review: Crystal Gayle releases amazing country album 'You Don't Know Me' |url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/music/review-crystal-gayle-releases-amazing-country-album-you-don-t-know-me/article/557368 |website=Digital Journal |date=6 September 2019 |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> ''You Don't Know Me'' became Gayle's first studio album to chart since 1988, reaching number 40 on the ''Billboard'' [[Top Independent Albums|independent albums]] list.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Crystal Gayle chart history -- Independent Albums |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/crystal-gayle/chart-history/ind/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> The album received positive reviews from critics. AllMusic critic Stephen Thomas Erlewine gave the release 3 of 5 stars. Erlewine noted that her upper register is \"a little diminished\", but she still \"sounds amiable\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Erlewine |first1=Stephen Thomas |title=''You Don't Know Me'' -- Crystal Gayle -- Songs, Reviews, Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/you-dont-know-me-mw0003299344 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> Markos Papadatos of the ''Digital Journal'' gave it an \"A\" rating, commenting, \"Overall, Crystal Gayle is sensational on her new album, ''You Don't Know Me'', which is country as grits. Grab a bottle of wine and let this country queen lure you in with her timeless voice.\"<ref name=\"Digital Journal\" />\n\nAlso during the 1990s, Gayle famously wrote and recorded \u201cMidnight In The Desert\u201d for [[Art Bell]] [[Coast to Coast AM]] radio show.\n\n==Personal life==\n[[File:The Webb Family.jpg|left|thumb|Family photograph of the Webb family. Starting from the left - Herman, [[Peggy Sue (singer)|Peggy Sue]], Don, Crystal, Tommy Butcher, Clara, [[Jay Lee Webb|Jay Lee]], Betty, [[Loretta Lynn|Loretta]], Junior]]\nGayle and her siblings claim [[Cherokee]] ancestry on their maternal and paternal lines.<ref name=\"Associated Press\" /> In October 2001, she was inducted into the [[Native American Music Awards|Native American Music Awards Hall of Fame]] in honor of her self-identified Cherokee linkage.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gayle Honored at Native American Music Award |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1450240/gayle-honored-at-native-american-music-award/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200104023458/http://www.cmt.com/news/1450240/gayle-honored-at-native-american-music-award/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=4 January 2020 |website=[[CMT (American TV channel)|Country Music Television]] |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=HALL OF FAME |url=https://nativeamericanmusicawards.com/hall-of-fame |website=[[Native American Music Awards]] |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref>\n\nGayle has remained close to her seven siblings since childhood. Before signing a recording contract, she toured alongside her brother, [[Jay Lee Webb]], in his band.<ref name=\"Hutch\">{{cite web |last1=Christner |first1=Ryan |title=Career not slowing for indomitable Crystal Gayle |url=https://www.hutchnews.com/223ec0b7-533e-5004-a45a-3066df1172de.html |website=The Hutchinson News |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref> Included on her [[You Don't Know Me: Classic Country|2019 studio album]] is a cover of Webb's song \"You Never Were Mine\". In an interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', Gayle wished she had \"done it a long time ago\" because they spent a lot of time touring together.<ref name=\"You Don't Know Me\" /> Additionally, older sister [[Peggy Sue (singer)|Peggy Sue]], has been an active member of Gayle's road show for several years. Peggy Sue performs background vocals on Gayle's show and does her own solo material too.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lapann |first1=Paul |title=Crystal Gayle to perform at Peoples Bank Theatre in Marietta |url=https://www.newsandsentinel.com/news/community-news/2019/02/crystal-gayle-to-perform-at-peoples-bank%E2%80%88theatre-in-marietta/ |website=The Parkersburg News and Sentinel |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref>\n\nGayle also remained close to her oldest sister [[Loretta Lynn]]. Music writers and journalists have claimed the pair had \"sibling rivalry\". In an interview with ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', Lynn explained that such a rivalry did not exist: \"People try to make it like we compete, but that's all in their minds...We fight a little bit, but that's just sisters. And we never fight over the music business.\"<ref name=\"People 1978\" /> In a 2017 interview Gayle commented, \"Of course, we're sisters. We can bicker... but we really didn't have a problem. You know, I look up to my sister...We both have flaws in different ways, but we're not gonna tell what they are, you know? But, I mean, we love each other.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Liebig |first1=Lorie |title=Crystal Gayle Discusses Her 'Rivalry' with Sister Loretta Lynn |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/crystal-gayle-loretta-lynn/ |website=Wide Open Country |date=2 March 2017 |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref>\n\nGayle has been married to husband Bill Gatzimos since 1971.<ref name=\"Biography\">{{cite web |title=Crystal Gayle - Singer |url=https://www.biography.com/musician/crystal-gayle |website=[[Biography (TV program)]] |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref> The couple first dated in high school and while Gayle was signed to United Artists Records, Gatzimos attended [[law school]] at [[Vanderbilt University]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rockwell |first1=John |title=Crystal Gale's Singing Career Is a Lot More Than Luck |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/04/09/archives/crystal-gales-singing-career-is-a-lot-more-than-luck-winner-of.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=9 April 1978 |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref> Following law school, Gatzimos became Gayle's manager and has since been president of the couple's company, Gayle Enterprises.<ref name=\"Associated Press\" /> According to Gayle, their marriage has been successful because the couple pursues their \"own interests\" and lets each other \"breathe\".<ref name=\"Belfast\">{{cite news |last1=Wylie |first1=Lorraine |title=Country star Crystal Gayle on love of Northern Ireland, singing with Daniel O'Donnell and secret to long, happy marriage |url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/country-star-crystal-gayle-on-love-of-northern-ireland-singing-with-daniel-odonnell-and-secret-to-long-happy-marriage-38307721.html# |newspaper=[[Belfast Telegraph]] |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref> The couple have two children: a daughter, Catherine (born 1983) and a son, Christos (born 1986).{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=345}} Gayle's son is now a [[record producer]] and co-produced her 2019 album.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gayle announces new album, first in 16 years |url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=10697 |website=Country Standard Time |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref>\n\nWhen Gayle's first child was born, she continued working frequently. In 2003 she said, \"When I was onstage, I remember coming off stage and breast-feeding and then doing another show.\" When the couple had their second child, Gayle stayed home with the children.<ref name=\"Grand\">{{cite web |last1=Crosby |first1=Christine |title=A Glimmer of the Grammy-winning Artist, Crystal Gayle and Her Grandson |url=https://www.grandmagazine.com/2011/07/crystal-gayle/ |website=Grand Magazine |date=19 July 2011 |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref> She also has two grandchildren named Elijah and Bj\u00f6rn. Gayle spoke of her appreciation for grandchildren in a 2011 interview, \"Holidays are so amazing with Elijah. We make cookies, which is great because I never really got much of a chance to do this with my own children. There's a pull when I go on the road when I'm not around him, and I want to be. He's just a bright spot that you want to see all the time. He loves life.\"<ref name=\"Grand\" />\n\n==Musical styles==\nGayle's musical style is rooted in [[country music|country]], but is also in [[pop music|pop]] and [[folk music]].{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=343}} Unlike her siblings (who mostly were raised in rural Kentucky), Gayle's formative years were spent in an urban environment. In this diverse atmosphere, Gayle was exposed to various styles of music. In 2003, she commented, \"I've always enjoyed folk, pop, rock, gospel, country, everything...\" As a child, she especially liked music by [[Lesley Gore]], [[Brenda Lee]] and [[Patsy Cline]]. In her teen years, she developed a fondness for folk groups, most predominantly [[Peter, Paul and Mary]].{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=343}}\n\nYet, Gayle also was attracted to the traditional country sound of her oldest sister [[Loretta Lynn]]. However it was Lynn that encouraged Gayle to develop a unique style. In an interview with the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' Gayle remarked: \"But she (Lynn) said, `No, you gotta go the middle of the road and have a different sound.' And I'd never have made it if I had been straight-ahead country...\"<ref name=\"Chicago Tribune\">{{cite web |last1=Hurst |first1=Jack |title=CRYSTAL GAYLE SEES HER MUSIC AS A SOURCE |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1997-10-24-9710240366-story.html |website=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=24 October 1997 |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> This perspective encouraged her to record different styles. In 2007, she commented that she likes to be called a singer: \"I call myself a singer of songs. I love to sing, whether it's country, folk, pop or rock. I grew up singing all different styles, though definitely country is my roots.\"<ref name=\"TDN\" /> Gayle also said that her priority was to find quality material, \"I've had great producers. [[Allen Reynolds]] is one of them, and he is just fantastic. I would always find great songs that other people wrote, and I wanted to put out really really good songs.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Papadatos |first1=Markos |title=Crystal Gayle talks Adelphi University, Grand Ole Opry, longevity |url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/music/crystal-gayle-talks-adelphi-university-grand-ole-opry-longevity/article/493313 |website=Digital Journal |date=23 May 2017 |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref>\n \nMusic journalists and critics have also described Gayle as having a smooth vocal delivery, different from that of her sister's. [[AllMusic]]'s Thom Jurek noted \"her signature phrasing and sophisticated material\" to be a factor.<ref name=\"All My Tomorrows\" /> Stephen L. Betts of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' explained that Gayle had \"a polished persona and singing style tailor-made for country-pop crossover.\"<ref name=\"100 Greatest\">{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=100 Greatest Country Artists of All Time |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-lists/100-greatest-country-artists-of-all-time-195775/crystal-gayle-2-196058/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=15 June 2017 |access-date=3 January 2020}}</ref> Kurt Wolff of ''Country Music: The Rough Guide'' commented that she had a \"sweet radio-friendly voice\" that \"made a picture-perfect pop-country star.\"{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=439}}\n\n==Image==\nGayle's image has garnered her significant media attention. Notably, she is known for her floor-length hair.<ref name=\"Three Good Reasons\" /> As a child, Gayle's mother kept her hair short. She was inspired to grow her hair to her knees after seeing a woman with similar hair in Nashville.<ref name=\"Grand\" /> When her hair increased in length by the late 1970s, Gayle's fan club also significantly increased.<ref name=\"Biography\" /> By the early 1990s, her hair had reached floor's length. During that time, she considered significantly cutting her hair due to headaches and time spent maintaining it.<ref name=\"Three Good Reasons\" /> However, she ultimately decided not to cut it. Gayle credits her daughter for discouraging a haircut. Gayle's daughter told her, \"You can't cut your hair&nbsp;\u2014 you won't be Crystal Gayle.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kruh |first1=Nancy |title=Country Pop Queen Crystal Gayle Returns to Her Roots: Traditional Music 'Is in My Soul' |url=https://people.com/country/crystal-gayle-you-dont-know-me-album-release/ |website=[[People (magazine)|People]] |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref> Gayle also stated that it is easier to have long straight hair, \"I know some people think: 'Why does she keep it so long?' I'd probably love to try all the different styles, but I'm not a beautician. So, I keep it long. It's easy to wash and let it go.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Violanti |first1=Anthony |title=Crystal Gayle returns to Silver Springs |url=https://www.ocala.com/article/LK/20071213/news/604248176/OS |website=The Ocala Star Banner |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref> However, according to Gayle, she still continues seeing a hairstylist. Within a year, she cuts 9 to 12 inches of hair.<ref name=\"Belfast\" />\n\nGayle's physical appearance has also made her a [[sex symbol]]. Writers Robert K. Oermann and Mary A. Bufwack wrote in 2003, \"Crystal Gayle will be forever recalled by music fans for the sexy toss of her head that sent waves of motion through her [[Lady Godiva|Godiva]]-like brunette tresses.\"{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=345}} Author Kurt Wolff described Gayle as having \"knockout good looks\".{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=439}} In 1983, ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' named her among the \"50 Most Beautiful People in the World\".<ref name=\"Belfast\" />\n\n==Legacy==\nGayle has been credited as one of the most successful and important [[country pop]] [[crossover music|crossover]] artists.<ref name=\"Slick Country\" />{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=439}}{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=345}} Gayle's music and career helped open doors for future female country pop artists, including [[Faith Hill]], [[Shania Twain]] and [[Carrie Underwood]].<ref name=\"Lifetime\" /><ref name=\"Taste of Country\" /> Writer Kevin John Coyne described her successes and contributions: \"...&nbsp;she had accumulated an astonishing eighteen No.1 hits, two more than her older sister had under her belt, and fourth among all women in country music history, behind [[Dolly Parton]], [[Reba McEntire]] and [[Tammy Wynette]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Coyne |first1=Kevin John |title=100 Greatest Women -- Crystal Gayle (27) |url=http://www.countryuniverse.net/2018/08/09/100-greatest-women-27-crystal-gayle/ |website=Country Universe |date=9 August 2018 |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn recent years, Gayle has been given several awards and accolades for her accomplishments. In 2003, she was included by [[CMT (American TV channel)|Country Music Television]] on their list of the \"40 Greatest Women of Country Music\".<ref>{{cite web |title=40 Greatest Women Announced |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1457238/40-greatest-women-announced/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305012222/http://www.cmt.com/news/1457238/40-greatest-women-announced/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=5 March 2016 |website=[[CMT (American TV channel)|Country Music Television]] |access-date=7 September 2019}}</ref> In 2008, she was inducted into the Kentucky Music Hall of Fame and Museum.<ref>{{cite web |title=Crystal Gayle -- 2008 Inductions |url=http://www.kentuckymusichalloffame.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/2008_crystal_gayle.pdf |website=Kentucky Music Hall of Fame |access-date=4 January 2020 |archive-date=27 June 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190627130606/http://www.kentuckymusichalloffame.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/2008_crystal_gayle.pdf |url-status=dead }}</ref> In 2009, she received a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]. She was joined by artist [[Tanya Tucker]] and her family for the ceremony.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Appleford |first1=Steve |title=Crystal Gayle - Hollywood Star Walk |url=http://projects.latimes.com/hollywood/star-walk/crystal-gayle/ |website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref> In 2016, she was presented with the \"Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award\" from the [[Academy of Country Music]]. Gayle commented in 2016, \"It's nice to think maybe your music has influenced other artists who are out there.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Van Vleet |first1=Janet |title=Country pioneer Crystal Gayle brings her music to West Texas Fair & Rodeo |url=http://archive.reporternews.com/topstories/country-pioneer-crystal-gayle-brings-her-music-to-west-texas-fair--rodeo-3b4e8e09-af7d-10e4-e053-010-391966231.html |website=Abilene Reporter News |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn November 2016 almost 50 years after making her debut as a guest artist, Gayle was asked to become a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] by Carrie Underwood. The two performed \"Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue\" before Underwood announced the invitation. Gayle was officially inducted by [[Loretta Lynn]] in January 2017.<ref>{{cite news |last=Martin |first=Jeff |title=Country star Crystal Gayle inducted in Grand Ole Opry |url=http://www.wcvb.com/article/country-star-crystal-gayle-inducted-in-grand-ole-opry/8626605 |publisher=[[WCVB-TV]] |date=January 21, 2017 |access-date=January 22, 2017}}</ref> In 2017, Gayle was included in ''[[Townsquare Media#Web publications and services|Taste of Country]]''{{'}}s list of \"Country Music's Most Powerful Women\".<ref name=\"Taste of Country\" /> In 2019, she was among a dozen performers chosen to open the [[Country Music Association Awards]] as part of recognizing the women of country music. In the show's opening, Gayle performed \"Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Leimkuehler |first1=Matthew |last2=Watts |first2=Cindy |title=CMA Awards: Show opening with one dozen female country artists is 'epic celebration' |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/music/2019/11/13/cma-awards-opens-carrie-underwood-dolly-parton-epic-female-medley/4187027002/ |website=[[USA Today]] |access-date=4 January 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Crystal Gayle albums discography|Crystal Gayle singles discography}}\n\n'''Studio albums'''\n{{div col}}\n*''[[Crystal Gayle (album)|Crystal Gayle]]'' (1975)\n*''[[Somebody Loves You (Crystal Gayle album)|Somebody Loves You]]'' (1975)\n*''[[Crystal (Crystal Gayle album)|Crystal]]'' (1976)\n*''[[We Must Believe in Magic]]'' (1977)\n*''[[When I Dream]]'' (1978)\n*''[[We Should Be Together (album)|We Should Be Together]]'' (1979)\n*''[[Miss the Mississippi]]'' (1979)\n*''[[These Days (Crystal Gayle album)|These Days]]'' (1980)\n*''[[Hollywood, Tennessee]]'' (1981)\n*''[[True Love (Crystal Gayle album)|True Love]]'' (1982)\n*''[[Cage the Songbird]]'' (1983)\n*''[[Nobody Wants to Be Alone]]'' (1985)\n*''[[What If We Fall in Love?|What If We Fall in Love]]'' {{Small|(with [[Gary Morris]])}} (1986)\n*''[[Straight to the Heart (Crystal Gayle album)|Straight to the Heart]]'' (1986)\n*''[[A Crystal Christmas]]'' (1986)\n*''[[Nobody's Angel (Crystal Gayle album)|Nobody's Angel]]'' (1988)\n*''[[Ain't Gonna Worry]]'' (1990)\n*''[[Three Good Reasons]]'' (1992)\n*''[[Best Always]]'' (1993)\n*''[[Someday (Crystal Gayle album)|Someday]]'' (1995)\n*''[[Joy & Inspiration]]'' (1997)\n*''[[Crystal Gayle Sings the Heart and Soul of Hoagy Carmichael]]'' (1999)\n*''[[In My Arms (album)|In My Arms]]'' (2000)\n*''[[All My Tomorrows (Crystal Gayle album)|All My Tomorrows]]'' (2003)\n*''[[You Don't Know Me: Classic Country]]'' (2019)\n{{div col end}}\n\n==Filmography==\n{| Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jojo_Mason","to":"Jojo Mason"}],"pages":{"49486122":{"pageid":49486122,"ns":0,"title":"Jojo Mason","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Canadian country music singer-songwriter (born 1990)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Jojo Mason\n| image           = Jojo Mason.jpg\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1990|02|26|mf=yes}}\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_place     = [[Regina, Saskatchewan]], Canada<ref name=\"manicdown\">{{cite web|title=Jojo Mason|url=http://www.manicdown.com/jojo-mason.html|website=Manicdown Productions|accessdate=February 19, 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302044247/http://www.manicdown.com/jojo-mason.html|archivedate=March 2, 2015}}</ref>\n| origin          =\n| instrument      = Guitar, piano\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country pop]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 2015\u2013present\n| label           = Manicdown, [[604 Records|604]]\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = \n}}\n'''Jojo Mason''' (born February 26, 1990) is a Canadian [[country music]] singer-songwriter. Mason moved to [[Victoria, British Columbia]] in 2004 to play [[ice hockey|hockey]] at the junior (Saanich Jr Braves, VIJHL) ranks but suffered a [[spinal disc herniation|herniated disk]].<ref name=\"manicdown\" /> Later, he met songwriter/producer Dan Swinimer and worked on developing his vocals.<ref name=\"manicdown\" /> He signed to Manicdown Productions in 2014 and released his debut single, \"It's All Good\", in early 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Manicdown Productions|url=http://www.manicdown.com/|website=Manicdown Productions|accessdate=February 19, 2016}}</ref> It reached the top 10 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Canada Country]] chart.<ref name=\"Canada Country\" /> Mason's second single, \"Good Kinda Love\", was released in November 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fielder|first1=Courtney|title=JoJo Mason Debut's \"Good Kinda Love\"|url=http://www.discovermoosejaw.com/country-100/44231-jojo-mason-debut-s-good-kinda-love|accessdate=February 19, 2016|work=[[CILG-FM|Country 100]]|date=November 4, 2015|archive-date=March 2, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160302024145/http://www.discovermoosejaw.com/country-100/44231-jojo-mason-debut-s-good-kinda-love|url-status=dead}}</ref> He signed to [[604 Records]] for the release of his third single, \"Red Dress\", in May 2016.{{citation needed|date=August 2023}}\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n!
